means a person who is one (or more) of: (i) a retail client as defined in point (11) of Article 4(1) of EU MiFID II; or
(ii) a customer within the meaning of Directive (EU) 2016/97 (as amended, the “Insurance Distribution Directive”),
where that customer would not qualify as a professional client as defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of EU MiFID
II. Consequently no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 (as amended, the “EU
**PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering or selling the Senior Secured Notes or otherwise making them available to retail**
investors in the EEA has been prepared and therefore offering or selling the Senior Secured Notes or otherwise making
them available to any retail investor in the EEA may be unlawful under the EU PRIIPs Regulation.

**Certain Restatements and Reclassifications**

The Group has undertaken a detailed review of its application of IAS 36 – Impairment of Assets in relation
to testing for impairment of non-current assets. In particular, the Group has reassessed the application of the IAS 36
with respect to the following stages of the impairment review:

    - Identifying Cash Generating Units (“CGUs”) which exhibit impairment triggers;

    - Calculating the carrying value of CGUs which are tested for impairment; and

    - Calculating value-in-use (“VIU”) as part of determining the recoverable amount of CGUs.

As the reassessment of the Group’s application of IAS 36 has been applied in order to provide more reliable
information about the carrying value of the Group’s non-current assets at the balance sheet date, the Group has applied
judgement to conclude that the effect of the revised allocation of central costs to both the assessment of impairment
triggers and the forecast cashflows used in the value-in-use calculations and the allocation of central assets to CGUs
should be applied to the impairment review conducted at December 31, 2022.

This results in a pre-tax impairment charge for the year ended December 31, 2022 of £377.4 million (posttax £312.2 million) of which £357.5 million (pre-tax) was not previously recorded in the 2022 Financial Statements.
As this amount results from a change in application of the requirements of IAS 36, the Group has recorded a prior
year adjustment as per the requirements of IAS 8. The Group has also carried out the same impairment review at
December 31, 2021 and concluded that no changes in presentation are required as there were no significant changes
in the property values in the period since the LBO Acquisition in February 2021 to the end of 2021.

The net recoverable amount of the CGUs which was subject to impairment in the year ended December 31,
2022 increased in the year ended December 31, 2023 leading to a partial reversal of the impairment recorded in the
year ended December 31, 2022. This resulted in a net pre-tax impairment reversal of £225.7 million (post-tax £183.4
million) being recorded in the income statement in the 2023 Financial Statements.

The opening deferred tax liability includes the restatement for impairments, resulting in a reduction in the
opening deferred tax liability of £65.2 million.

In 2023 the Group identified that hardware assets with a net book value of £39.2 million were originally
classified as intangible assets. These have been reclassified to plant, equipment, fixtures and fittings during the year
ended December 31, 2023.

Financial Statements to separately show amounts classified as other income and to present an updated impairment
value Other income comprises concession and commission income and rental income. Rental income relates to income

**Non-IFRS Financial Measures**

In this Offering Memorandum the Group presents certain financial measures that are not required by or
presented in accordance with UK IFRS (the “Non-IFRS Measures”). The Non-IFRS Measures included in this
Offering Memorandum do not alone provide a sufficient basis to compare the Group’s performance with that of other
companies and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for an equivalent IFRS measure (if applicable)
or any other generally accepted measure as an indicator of operating performance or liquidity. Such non-IFRS financial
information has not been audited or reviewed by either KPMG LLP or Ernst & Young LLP.

We believe that the presentation of the Non-IFRS Measures provides investors with additional useful
information to understand our operating performance and our ability to service our debt. In addition, we believe that
EBITDA is a measure commonly used by investors. The Group’s Non-IFRS Measures may not be directly comparable
with similarly titled measures used by other companies. The EBITDA Measures (as defined below) and related
leverage and coverage ratios are not measurements of financial performance under UK IFRS and should not be

xv


-----

considered as alternatives to other indicators of our operating performance, cash flows or any other measure of
performance derived in accordance with UK IFRS. You are encouraged to evaluate each of the adjustments reflected
in the Group’s presentation of the Non-IFRS Measures and whether you consider each to be appropriate. In addition,
each of the Non-IFRS Measures may be defined differently from the definitions of corresponding or similar terms
under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture. The Group’s Non-IFRS Measures have important limitations as analytical
tools. Some limitations of the Non-IFRS Measures include:

    - they do not reflect the interest expense or cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal
payments on the Group’s debt;

    - they do not reflect any cash income and certain other taxes that the Group may be required to pay;

    - they are not adjusted for all cash income or expense items that are reflected in the Group’s statements of
cash flows;

    - they do not reflect the impact of earnings or charges resulting from certain matters the Group considers
not to be indicative of its ongoing operations; and

    - in respect of Adjusted EBITDA, Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA and the other Non-IFRS Measures that
reflect such measures, they reflect certain adjustments for anticipated cost savings, synergies and other
estimates that may not be realised, whether in part or at all.

Furthermore, you should carefully consider the risks and limitations of the Non-IFRS Measures, as they are
based in part on assumptions made by the Group’s management regarding the future impact of actions that have not
yet been, and which may not in fact be, implemented. For example, there is a risk that the synergies we seek to achieve
may not be realised in the anticipated time frame or at all and that the magnitude of cost savings may be significantly
less than expected.

Because of these limitations, our Non-IFRS Measures should not be considered as measures of discretionary
cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will be available to us to meet
our obligations, including in relation to the Senior Secured Notes offered hereby. You should compensate for these
limitations by relying primarily on the Group’s UK IFRS results and using these Non-IFRS Measures only in a
supplemental manner to evaluate the Group’s performance.

Our primary Non-IFRS Measures are defined as follows:

**_EBITDA_**

EBITDA, when used in this Offering Memorandum, is calculated by adding back to the Group’s profit for
the period income tax (credit)/expense, interest, amortisation and depreciation. See “Summary Historical Consolidated
_Financial Information and Other Financial Data—Other Financial Data—Other Financial Indicators.”_

**_EBITDA Margin_**

EBITDA Margin means the Group’s EBITDA as a percentage of total revenue (including fuel) for the
relevant period.

**_Adjusted EBITDA_**

Adjusted EBITDA, when used in this Offering Memorandum, means the Group’s EBITDA for a particular
period as adjusted for other income (such as (gain)/loss on disposal and gain/loss on sale and leaseback), certain
historical income and costs certain impairment charges, actual EBITDA attributable to Arthur Foodstores Limited
from closing of the transaction on October 30, 2022 through the CMA lifting the IEO on May 30, 2023 (as relevant
for the given period), asset-write offs, the elimination of IFRS 16 impact to reflect a rental charge for all leases in
Adjusted EBITDA, prior year ATM rates, tax saving pass throughs, pension buyout losses, asset retirement obligations
(“AROs”) provision release, rental income associated with the Starbucks freehold properties acquired from the EG
UK Acquisition, TSA prepayment unwind costs, the cost of servicing the Ground Rent Facility, the cost of settlement

xvi


-----

share-based payment liabilities, income from one-off legal settlements, one-off colleague incentive payments, one-off
incremental separation costs associated with the implementation of standalone IT infrastructure and integration
payments, restructuring adjustments comprise one off provisions relating to facilities management restructuring, instore bakery proposition restructuring, management and back office restructure and closure of Heston & Dartford
depots, one-off costs relating to the LBO Acquisition, the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition, other
advisor and integration fees, the impact of purchase accounting, restructuring costs from significant restructuring
programmes and an add-back related to the management incentive programme.

**_Adjusted EBITDA Margin_**

Adjusted EBITDA Margin means the Group’s Adjusted EBITDA as a percentage of total revenue (including
fuel) for the relevant period.

**_Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA_**

_Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA, when used in this Offering Memorandum, means the Group’s Adjusted_
EBITDA for a particular period as adjusted for the impact of the disposal Arthur Business sites following the CMA
decision; synergies from the Arthur Acquisition; annualisation adjustments (based on the actual results for the period
from January 1, 2023 to October 30, 2023 of the Acquired EG UK Target Group (as defined herein)) for the EG UK
Acquisition; synergies from the EG UK Acquisition, and the annualisation of rent costs and servicing costs associated
with the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions and the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction.

The Group believes that EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA and Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA (collectively, the
“EBITDA Measures”) provide useful information to investors about its results of operations for the following
reasons: (a) they are, or will be going forward, among the measures used by the Board of Directors and management
to evaluate the Group’s underlying operating performance, review business trends, identify strategies to improve
results and make day-to-day operating decisions, and (b) they allow a comparison of the Group’s results across periods
and results across companies in the industry in which the Group operates on a consistent basis, by removing the effects
on the Group’s operating performance of its capital structure (such as the varying levels of interest expense), asset
base and capital investment cycle (such as depreciation and amortisation) and items largely outside the control of
management (such as income taxes).

None of the EBITDA Measures should be considered in isolation or as a substitute for measures of the
Group’s operating performance reported in accordance with UK IFRS. The EBITDA Measures have limitations as
analytical tools, some of which are as follows:

    - the EBITDA Measures do not reflect the Group’s cash expenditures or future requirements for capital
investments or contractual commitments;

    - the EBITDA Measures do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, the Group’s working capital
needs;

    - none of the EBITDA Measures reflects the interest expense on the Group’s debt or the cash requirements
necessary to service interest or principal payments on the Group’s debt;

    - although depreciation and amortisation are non-cash charges, assets are depreciated or amortised over
differing estimated useful lives and the assets being depreciated and amortised will often have to be
replaced in the future, and the EBITDA Measures do not reflect any cash requirements for such
replacements;

    - the EBITDA Measures exclude certain tax payments that may represent a reduction in cash available to
the Group;

    - the EBITDA Measures are not adjusted for all non-cash income or expense items that are reflected in
the Group’s income statement;

xvii


-----

    - other companies in the industry in which the Group operates may calculate their own EBITDA measures
differently than the Group does, limiting their usefulness as comparative measures;

    - our calculation and presentation of the EBITDA Measures in this Offering Memorandum is similar to,
but different from, the calculation of Consolidated EBITDA under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture,
the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture or the Senior
Facilities Agreement. In particular, EBITDA reflects the adoption of IFRS 16 by the Group effective
January 1, 2019, while Consolidated EBITDA calculations under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture,
the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture and the Senior
Facilities Agreement may not. Accordingly, the EBITDA Measures do not provide precise indications
as to the level of our adherence to the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior
Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture and the Senior Facilities Agreement; and

    - certain adjustments made in calculating Adjusted EBITDA and Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA contain
estimates that management believes reflect the underlying results of operations and are therefore
subjective in nature and reflect certain adjustments for anticipated cost savings, synergies and other
estimates that may not be realised, whether in part or at all.

**_Like-for-like sales (excluding fuel)_**

Like-for-like sales (excluding fuel) is a measure of annual growth of sales calculated as current year
comparable sales excluding fuel (excluding VAT) versus prior year comparable sales. Current year comparable sales
includes all revenue except fuel sales, sales generated from stores in the first twelve complete calendar months
following grand opening, sales generated from stores that have permanently closed, sales generated from stores that
have been temporarily closed for more than two consecutive calendar months within the previous twelve full calendar
months, financial services commissions, ‘toyou’ sales and George international franchise sales. Sales are net of Asda
Rewards earned and other discounts. Like-for-like sales growth at category level (food, grocery and merchandise and
clothing) includes an allocation of Asda Rewards earned and discounts to sales, but excludes any allocation of financial
services sales, and breakage on gift cards.

**_Free Cash Flow_**

Free Cash Flow is calculated as Adjusted EBITDA less Capital Expenditure KPI (excluding capital
expenditure associated with the implementation of a standalone IT infrastructure as we separate from Walmart
(“Project Future”)). The Group uses Free Cash Flow as a liquidity measure to monitor cash flow generation.

The Group presents Free Cash Flow because, in the Group’s view, it provides investors with useful
information about the Group’s underlying ability to generate and extract cash flows from its various subsidiaries in
order to make interest and principal payments on the Group’s debt, including the Senior Secured Notes offered hereby.

Free Cash Flow is not a measure of liquidity under UK IFRS and has limitations as an analytical tool, some
of which are as follows:

    - it does not represent the residual cash flow available for discretionary expenditures by the Group,
particularly because, in the case of pre-tax free cash flow, the Group’s various tax payment obligations
are not deducted from such measure;

    - it does not deduct cash flows used by the Group in financing activities;

    - it is not a direct measurement of cash flows and attempts to derive and measure the Group’s ability to
service debt from income statement data of the Group. Accordingly, it does not directly correlate to the
actual collection of cash. In addition, Free Cash Flow does not take into account changes in working
capital of the Group that are otherwise factored in when calculating its net cash from operating activities;

    - it does not deduct certain other items settled in cash; and

xviii


-----

    - other companies in the industries in which the Group operates may calculate Free Cash Flow differently
than it does, limiting its usefulness as a comparative measure.

Underlying Cash Flow From Operations

Underlying Cash Flow From Operations is calculated as Free Cash Flow plus Movement in Net Working
Capital.

**_Movement in Net Working Capital_**

Movement in Net Working Capital for the year ended December 31, 2022 and year ended December 31,
2023 represents the sum of the movements in trade and other receivables, inventories, trade and other payables, and
provisions as disclosed in the Consolidated Statement of Cash Flows. Movement in Net Working Capital for the year
ended December 31, 2021 represents the sum of the movements in trade and other receivables, inventories, trade and
other payables, and provisions as disclosed in the Consolidated Statement of Cash Flows and which have been
annualised as if the Senior Notes Issuer had consolidated Asda Group Limited and its subsidiaries from January 1,
2021.The Movement in Net Working Capital for the year ended December 31, 2021 has been further adjusted to
remove the impact of business rates of £251 million accrued by Asda Group Limited at December 31, 2020 and paid
in the year ended December 31, 2021.

**_Cash Conversion_**

Cash conversion is defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA.

**_Capital expenditure_**

Capital expenditure is calculated as the purchase of property, plant and equipment plus purchase of intangible
assets.

**_Capital Expenditure KPI_**

Capital Expenditure KPI is defined as the total cost of assets classified as property, plant and equipment and
intangible assets that the Group takes ownership of within a financial period (as opposed to the UK IFRS measurement
of capital expenditure, which is based on cash flows). It excludes capital expenditure on Project Future, our investment
required to separate from Walmart’s IT systems, and timing differences.

**_Pro forma net debt_**

_Pro forma net debt consists of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s pro forma indebtedness in respect of the_
Senior Secured Notes, the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes (as defined below), the Senior Facilities
and the guarantees relating to the Existing Senior Notes, net of the Group’s cash and cash equivalents as at
December 31, 2023, as adjusted to give pro forma effect to the consummation of the Transactions on the Issue Date.
See “Capitalisation.” Pro forma net debt assumes that 100% of holders of targeted Existing Senior Secured Notes
tender in the Richmond Tender Offer. A total of £500 million in aggregate principal amount of the Existing 3.25%
Senior Secured Notes were not targeted in the Richmond Tender Offer (the “Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior
**Secured Notes”) and will remain outstanding following the Transactions. To the extent that fewer eligible holders**
participate in the Richmond Tender Offer (or such Existing Senior Secured Notes are not accepted by us), pro forma
net debt is not expected to change because we intend to hold the New Financing Proceeds (in cash or cash equivalents)
on balance sheet until applied to repay such Existing Senior Secured Notes (other than the Remaining Existing 3.25%
Senior Secured Notes) that were not subject to, or not tendered or accepted in, the Richmond Tender Offer, which is
currently anticipated to be at the stated maturity in relation to the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes and at, or soon
after, the First Optional Par Redemption Date in relation to the Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes. Our presentation
and calculation of the ratio of Pro forma net debt to Pro forma Adjusted EBITDA may be different from the calculation
of Consolidated Net Leverage Ratio under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes
Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture and the Senior Facilities Agreement and is not indicative of our level
of adherence to the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the

xix


-----

Existing Senior Notes Indenture or the Senior Facilities Agreement. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes”
and “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.”

**_Adjusted Net Cash Flow_**

Adjusted Net Cash Flow is defined as Adjusted EBITDA minus capex (excluding Project Future capex)
plus/minus change in net working capital minus Project Future costs (including Future capex) minus net financing
costs plus proceeds from disposals minus other and debt repayment plus cashflows Arthur Acquisition and EG UK
Acquisition.

**_Pro forma net senior secured debt_**

_Pro forma net senior secured debt consists of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s pro forma indebtedness in_
respect of the Senior Secured Notes, the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Facilities,
net of the Group’s cash and cash equivalents as at December 31, 2023, as adjusted to give pro forma effect to the
consummation of the Transactions on the Issue Date. See “Capitalisation.” Pro forma net senior secured debt assumes
that 100% of holders of targeted Existing Senior Secured Notes tender in the Richmond Tender Offer. The Remaining
Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes will remain outstanding following the Transactions. To the extent that fewer
eligible holders participate in the Richmond Tender Offer (or such Existing Senior Secured Notes are not accepted by
us), pro forma net senior secured debt is not expected to change because we intend to hold the New Financing Proceeds
(in cash or cash equivalents) on balance sheet until applied to repay such Existing Senior Secured Notes (other than
the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes) that were not subject to, or not tendered or accepted in, the
Richmond Tender Offer, which is currently anticipated to be at the stated maturity in relation to the Existing 3.25%
Senior Secured Notes and at, or soon after, the First Optional Par Redemption Date in relation to the Existing 4.50%
Senior Secured Notes. Our presentation and calculation of the ratio of Pro forma net senior secured debt to Pro forma
Adjusted EBITDA may be different from the calculation of Consolidated Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio under
the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes
Indenture and the Senior Facilities Agreement and is not indicative of our level of adherence to the terms of the Senior
Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture or the
Senior Facilities Agreement. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes” and “Description of Certain Financing
_Arrangements.”_

**_Pro forma interest expense_**

_Pro forma interest expense represents the interest expense on our pro forma net debt after giving pro forma_
effect to the consummation of the Transactions on the Issue Date. Pro forma interest expense (i) excludes charges
related to allocated debt issuance costs; (ii) excludes finance costs associated with leases (including, for the avoidance
of doubt, leases in connection with the 2021 Sale and Leaseback Transactions and the 2023 Sale and Leaseback
Transactions); (iii) excludes finance costs associated with liabilities relating to the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction;
and (iv) includes interest expense associated with the Senior Secured Notes offered hereby, the Remaining Existing
3.25% Senior Secured Notes, the Existing Senior Notes and the Senior Facilities. Pro forma interest expense has been
presented for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to describe what our interest expense would have actually
been had the above-mentioned transactions occurred at the beginning of the year ended December 31, 2023, nor does
it purport to project our interest expense for any future period or our financial condition at any future date.

**Reconciliation of Non-IFRS Measures**

We present a reconciliation of the EBITDA Measures, Free Cash Flow, Cash Conversion, Underlying Cash
Flow From Operations, capital expenditure and Capital Expenditure KPI to the most directly comparable measure
calculated and presented in accordance with UK IFRS and discuss their limitations. For a reconciliation of these
Non-IFRS Measures and such discussions, see “Summary Historical Consolidated Financial Information and Other
_Financial Data—Other Financial Data.”_

**Rounding Adjustments**

Certain numerical figures set out in this Offering Memorandum, including financial data presented
in millions or thousands, certain operating data, percentages describing market share and penetration rates, have been
subject to rounding adjustments and, as a result, the totals of the data included in this Offering Memorandum may
vary slightly from the actual arithmetic totals of such information. Percentages and amounts reflecting changes over
time periods relating to financial and other data set forth in the sections entitled “Management’s Discussion and
_Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations”_ are calculated using the numerical data in the consolidated
financial information of the Senior Notes Issuer or the tabular presentation of other data (subject to rounding)
contained in this Offering Memorandum, as applicable, and not using the numerical data in the narrative description
thereof. Figures shown as totals in some tables and elsewhere may not be exact arithmetic aggregations of the figures
that precede them.

**CBRE Report**

We instructed CBRE Limited (“CBRE”) to value our property portfolio (the “CBRE Report”) as of
December 31, 2023 (the “Valuation Date”). The CBRE Report was issued on April 12, 2024 and provides us with a
valuation of the Group’s freehold and long leasehold assets, including our supermarkets, PFS, Food to Go (also
referred to as Foodservice elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum) sites, industrial properties, office properties,
investment properties, development and landbank sites and Distribution Centre – Held for Sale. The CBRE Report
does not include de minimis non-operational parcels of lands or stores, short leaseholds, long leaseholds with no value
(in each case, as assessed by the Group), or a parcel of land at Oldbury which is pending a potential planning appeal
for refusal for residential development. The CBRE Report is intended to be a guide of the likely valuation of our
property portfolio based on a number of assumptions including Special Assumptions (as defined below):

    - _Supermarket Portfolio: Market Value on the Special Assumption that each Property is let to Asda Stores_
Limited at CBRE’s opinion of rental value on a full repairing and insuring basis (“FRI”) for a term of
25 years commencing at the Valuation Date, with annual upward only rent reviews linked to the
consumer price index (“CPI”) with a cap and collar of 1% to 4% per annum.

    - _Industrial Portfolio: Market Value on the Special Assumption of that each Property is let to Asda Stores_
Limited at CBRE’s opinion of rental value on a FRI basis for a term of 20 years, commencing at the
Valuation Date, with five yearly upward only rent reviews to the higher of open market rental value or
CPI subject to, a cap and collar of 2% to 4% per annum (compounded annually).

    - _Offices Portfolio: Market Value on the Special Assumption that each Property is let to Asda Stores_
Limited, at CBRE’s opinion of rental value, on an FRI basis for a term of 15 years, commencing at the
Valuation Date, with five yearly upward only rent reviews linked to CPI, with a cap and collar of 1% to
3% per annum (compounded annually).

    - _Food to Go Portfolio (the Food to Go Portfolio comprises drive through or drive to sites occupied and_
_operated by a Starbucks franchisee): Market Value on the Special Assumption that each Property is let_
to Egspresso Limited in accordance with the terms of the Template Lease provided to CBRE by the
Group, on an FRI basis, and at the current rent payable under licence for each of the sites as confirmed
to CBRE by the Group. The Template Lease is for a term of 20 years, assumed to commence at the
Valuation Date, with three yearly upward only rent reviews linked to the retail prices index with a cap
and collar of 1% to 3%, compounded annually.

For the Supermarket, Industrial, Office and Food to Go Portfolios, CBRE’s opinion of Market Value is
subject to the Special Assumptions outlined above and makes no allowance for tenant incentives such as rent-free
period or capital contributions. It is assumed that a purchaser has no liability with respect to capital expenditure or
repair costs and that Asda Stores Limited (Egspresso Limited for Food to Go Portfolio) is responsible for outgoings
including the payment of business rates and service charges but not the payment of head rents associated with long
leasehold interests (where applicable).

**Key Findings**

According to the CBRE Report, the aggregate of the individual property Market Values on the assumptions
and Special Assumptions set out above comprised of 402 supermarket properties, 3 industrial properties, 2 office
properties, 359 PFS properties 73 investment properties, 37 development land and landbank properties and 1

The Properties were valued individually, and no account has been taken of any discount or premium that may

The aggregate supermarket portfolio value is substantially higher than average annual investment transaction

to avoid saturating the investment market.

The valuation in the CBRE Report could be significantly higher than the proceeds achievable in an actual
sale of the properties in the portfolio.

**Overview of the Market**

The CBRE Report contains an overview of the relevant market prepared by CBRE.

_Supermarket Portfolio_

For the year ended December 31, 2023, CBRE Prime Benchmark Supermarket Yields were 175 bps higher
than in June 2022, representing the highest CBRE Benchmark Yield for the sector since 2009. The change in the
CBRE Prime Benchmark Yield occurred between June 2022 and December 2022, and there was no change in 2023.
Some categories of supermarket investment did however experience yield expansion in the second half of 2023,
primarily those assets subject to over-rent and/or with secondary property characteristics.

The CBRE Prime Benchmark Yield does not encompass all categories of supermarket investment but
provides a high-level indication of the impact of market change in this period. Investment yields for supermarket
investments may have changed by a greater or lesser degree than the CBRE Prime Benchmark Yield.

The drivers of yield expansion during this period were:

      - Geo-political risk;

      - Negative Economic Outlook, cautious investor outlook, “Mini-Budget”;

      - Persistent inflationary pressure;

      - Rising Interest Rates leading to higher cost of capital;

      - Selective investor demand with an increased focus on risk and store fundamentals; and

      - Increased sensitivity to over-rent and income risk.

Transaction volumes in 2023 were higher than £2.0 billion, above the five-year average, primarily driven by
three large portfolio transactions. This demonstrated liquidity in the sector but did not result in yield contraction due
to the ongoing price sensitivity outlined above.

**Terms and Assumptions**

The valuation of all properties was based on their current use. CBRE made various assumptions as to tenure,
letting, taxation, town planning, and the condition and repair of buildings and sites (including ground and groundwater
contamination). If any of the information or assumptions on which the valuations are based are subsequently found to
be incorrect, the valuation may also be incorrect and should be reconsidered. Where possible assumptions were
checked against the high-level information made available by the Group.

The valuation assumed that all properties included had the benefit of freehold or leasehold titles, free from
restrictions that would have impacted the value. The valuation assumes that the long leasehold interests contain no
restrictions that would prevent the sale of the relevant properties to a purchaser in the investment market.

xl


-----

The investment properties are generally situated adjacent to Asda supermarkets. The valuation assumes that
either a separate sale of the investment property could be achieved through the creation of a new title, separate from
the retail supermarket or that alternatively the investment property could be sold with the supermarket in the same
transaction.

In particular, in preparation of the CBRE Report, CBRE assumed each property to be the authorised use
under planning legislation and in accordance with the use registered with the relevant regulatory agency. During the
course of their engagement, CBRE did not perform site inspections, environmental audit, tests of services and
amenities, investigations or tests as to the condition of the properties. CBRE did not make planning or permitting
enquiries and did not examine deeds, leases or other documents relating to the title to our properties.

The CBRE Report was produced based on certain assumptions, including, but not limited to, the assumptions
that (i) our properties are not adversely affected by any existing or proposed environmental law and are free from,
environmental issues such as contamination, deleterious materials, flooding, ground conditions, invasive or protected
plants or species and the properties are not adversely affected by any existing or proposed environmental law, (ii)
there are no abnormalities as to repair and condition of the properties, all properties are free from defect, in good repair
and condition and well maintained and in marketable condition, compliant with all building, accessibility and fire
safety regulations and there are no abnormalities as to repair and condition of the properties, (iii) properties possess a
good and marketable freehold title free from any onerous restrictions or conditions, and all title, tenure, lettings,
planning, taxation, statutory and local authority requirements are complied with, (iv) all properties benefit from full
access and egress rights together with sufficient parking and loading facilities and are connected to all main services,
(v) the floor areas supplied by Asda comply with the RICS Code of Measuring Practice (vi) no capital expenditure is
required in respect of the properties and (vii) that the properties all have valid energy performance certificates
compliant with the relevant regulations in each jurisdiction of the United Kingdom.

**Bases of Value and Methodology**

All properties were valued in accordance with the Red Book and on the basis of Market Value, Market Value
subject to Special Assumptions (as outlined above) or “Investment Value (Worth)” as set out above. The RICS
Valuation—Global Standards contains mandatory rules, best practice guidance and related commentary for all
members undertaking asset valuations. These valuation standards define Market Value as “the estimated amount for
which an asset or liability should exchange on the valuation date between a willing buyer and a willing seller in an
arm’s length transaction after proper marketing and where the parties had each acted knowledgeably, prudently, and
without compulsion.” As required by the mandatory rules of the RICS, CBRE has confirmed to us that they do not
have a material conflict of interest when preparing the CBRE Report, and that they adhere to the rules of conduct, as
set out by the RICS.

CBRE determined the Market Value subject to the Special Assumptions outlined above for the Supermarket,
Industrial, Office and Food to Go Portfolios by applying a yield to their assumed rental income. The Market Value of
the Supermarket, Industrial, Office and Food to Go Portfolios, subject to the Special Assumptions referenced above,
will result in valuations which differ from the Market Value of the Properties as at the valuation date. Should a different
special assumption be adopted with respect to the lease, including details such as tenant covenant, rent, lease length,
rent review provisions, repairing provisions (amongst other lease terms) this will result in a difference in the valuation.

For the Supermarket, Industrial and Office Portfolio and Food to Go Portfolios, the Market Value at the
valuation date would be lower than the Market Value subject to the Special Assumptions referenced above. This is
because the Market Value would disregard the lease referenced by CBRE in their Special Assumptions.

CBRE determined the Market Value for the Petrol Filling Station Portfolio utilising the trading/profits
methodology.

Rental values were prepared on the basis of methods adopted by CBRE as appropriate in assessing the Market
Value (subject to Special Assumptions where relevant) and are not necessarily appropriate for other purposes, nor do
they necessarily accord with the definition of Market Rent in the Red Book, which is as follows: “The estimated
amount for which an interest in real property should be leased on the valuation date between a willing lessor and a
willing lessee on appropriate lease terms in an arm’s length transaction, after proper marketing and where the parties
had each acted knowledgeably, prudently and without compulsion.”

xli


-----

Investment Value (or Worth) is defined in International Valuation Standards as “The value of an asset to a
particular owner or prospective owner for individual investment or operational objectives.”

**Defined Terms**

As used in this “Valuation Report” section, “Market Value” means the estimated amount for which an asset
or liability should exchange on the valuation date between a willing buyer and a willing seller in an arm’s length
transaction, after proper marketing and where the parties had each acted knowledgeably, prudently and without
compulsion; “Properties” means properties owned by the Group; “Special Assumption” means an assumption that
either assumes facts that differ from the actual facts existing at the valuation date or that would not be made by a
typical market participant in a transaction on the valuation date; and “Investment Value (or Worth)” means the value
of an asset to a particular owner or prospective owner for individual investment or operational objectives.

**Overview**

We are the third-largest grocery retailer in the United Kingdom and the second-largest grocery retailer in the
North of England, Scotland and Wales (in each case in terms of Till Roll data on a 52-week basis as of January 21,
2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel). We operate a significant store estate of over 1,200 large stores and
convenience sites that are geographically diversified across the United Kingdom. We also have the second largest
online grocery platform in the United Kingdom (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of
January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel). We are also now a major player in the UK convenience market,
having added 472 convenience sites (including petrol filling stations) to our portfolio, as well as 124 stand-alone
foodservice sites (including 10 non-active sites), following the Arthur Acquisition and EG UK Acquisition. These
acquisitions have given us significant foothold in the fast-growing convenience market which, alongside our existing
fuel portfolio, makes us the second-largest independent fuel owner-operator in the United Kingdom. The graph below

We operate in the large and historically stable UK grocery retail market that is underpinned by favourable
macroeconomic factors including GDP, population, consumer confidence and household expenditure on food and
beverages and which has historically demonstrated resilient performance through economic fluctuations. Groceries
are a necessary and regular consumer expenditure, which we believe generally allows the grocery retail market to
weather economic downturns better than certain other retail markets. For example, the UK grocery retail market
demonstrated its two strongest periods of growth in recent history during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and

**Key Strengths**

We believe that we benefit from the following strengths, including being a business of significant scale with
a history of resilient performance, a differentiated operating model, a successful financial profile and a significant
asset backing, as further described below.

**_We are a business of significant scale with a history of resilient performance_**

_We operate in a large, historically stable, resilient and growing industry with favourable macroeconomic tailwinds_

We operate in the large and historically stable UK grocery retail market, which has demonstrated resilient
performance underpinned by favourable macroeconomic factors including GDP, population, consumer confidence
and household spend on food and beverages. For example, UK GDP growth has shown stable development over the
years. Although the United Kingdom’s GDP declined by 10.4% in 2020 due primarily to COVID-19, GDP rebounded
in 2021, returned to pre-COVID-19 levels in 2022 and amounted to approximately £2.0 trillion in 2023, according to
Fitch Solutions, with an average expected GDP growth of approximately 0.4% from 2023 to 2025.

5


-----

The UK grocery retail market is also characterised by favourable demographic characteristics, including a
growing population. According to ONS, the UK population is projected to grow from 67 million in 2021 to over 73
million by 2036, which is expected to result in an overall increase in the consumer base for groceries.

In addition to its historical stability, the UK grocery retail market is also resilient. In 2023, grocery retail was
the single largest category of retail spending in the United Kingdom – valued at £200.5 billion on a Retail Value RSP
(as defined herein) basis, according to Euromonitor. Groceries are a necessary and stable consumer expenditure, which
generally allows the grocery retail market to weather economic downturns better than certain other retail markets that
involve more discretionary spending. For example, the UK grocery retail market demonstrated its two strongest
periods of growth in recent history during and following the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and during the
COVID-19 pandemic: between 2009 and 2016, the UK grocery retail market grew at a CAGR of 2.2% and between
2016 and 2023, the UK grocery retail market grew at a CAGR of 3.1%, with a growth CAGR of 4.6% during the
COVID-19 pandemic from 2019 and 2020. Additionally, during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis, according to
ONS, the percentage of average weekly household spend on food and non-alcoholic drinks remained fairly consistent
at approximately 11.0%, demonstrating the market’s resilience during periods of macroeconomic difficulty, and this
percentage spiked to 14.4% in 2021 during the COVID-19 pandemic, reflecting an increase in at-home consumption
during the pandemic. This percentage has remained relatively flat in the intervening years, ranging between 10.5%
and 11.8% from 2007 to 2022. In recent years, as the COVID-19 global pandemic was waning, Russia’s invasion of
Ukraine sparked an energy crisis which further accelerated growing inflation and cost of living pressures. However,
according to Kantar Worldpanel, the UK grocery market, comprised of grocers (and excluding non-grocers), has
grown by 8.7% over the past three years (on a Till Roll basis for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, compared to
the 52 weeks ended January 24, 2021).

_We are the United Kingdom’s third-largest grocer, holding sizeable market share_

According to Kantar Worldpanel, we are the third-largest grocery retailer in the United Kingdom, with 13.7%
of market share and the second-largest grocery retailer in the North of England, Scotland and Wales (based on Till
Roll data over 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024). For the year ended December 31, 2023, our revenue was £21.9
billion (excluding fuel). We have a network of over 1,200 large stores and convenience sites throughout the United
Kingdom, with a particular focus on superstores, supermarkets, online formats and convenience. We are also the
second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom by value (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on
a 52-week basis as of January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel), and have grown our market share over
many years, maintaining this share in a much-enlarged market as customers turned to online shopping throughout the
COVID-19 pandemic. As a result, we believe that we are well-positioned as a large and established business with a
clear set of peers.

We also believe that our multi-format, omni-channel offer positions us well to compete effectively and to
continue growing our market share. Following the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition, which gave us a
significant foothold in the convenience and foodservice markets, our revenue and Adjusted EBITDA in the year ended
December 31, 2023 were £25,619.9 million and £1,078 million, respectively, compared to £24,477.8 million and £867
million, respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2022. We believe that we also hold a leading position in the
UK foodservice market.

We cater to a broad target demographic, which we believe provides us a long-term competitive advantage.
In contrast to discounters, we provide a broad range of branded and own-brand offers, while also having a more
developed and established online platform.

_We believe we have faced the greatest impacts of discounters on our market_

The adverse impact of discounters (primarily Aldi and Lidl) on the traditional grocers in recent years has
been significant but, while we believe that discounters will continue to put pressure on the market, we believe that we
and other traditional grocers have already faced the greatest impacts of this competition in the markets in which we
operate and, if anything, that the discounters pose a greater challenge to other traditional grocers, who we believe are
more geographically exposed to the areas where discounters are likely to focus in the near-term.

As compared to our traditional grocer peers, our geographical concentration is in the North of England,
Scotland and Wales, as evidenced by our number two market shares in those regions. The discounters have already

6


-----

penetrated these areas and we expect the discounters to continue to shift the focus of their expansion to the South of
England, the East of England and London, where we operate fewer sites as compared to the Midlands, the North of
England, Scotland and Wales. Furthermore, the catchment areas of 76.7% of our stores already contain both major
discounters, Aldi and Lidl, which is a higher percentage than any of our traditional grocer competitors (the boundary
used is a 10-minute drive-time radius around each point, which is consistent regardless of location type or size of
store, but excludes convenience stores, and stores are only included in the count where there is both Aldi and Lidl
stores present within the drive-time boundary). Therefore, we believe that our current performance already factors in
the adverse impact of discounters to a large extent.

Moreover, according to Kantar Worldpanel, we have stemmed the losses to the discounters in recent months,
and we have reduced switching losses to the discounters to a two-year record low for the 4 weeks ended February 18,
2024. Together, Lidl and Aldi account for 17.5% of the market, with Aldi’s share at 9.8% and Lidl at 7.6% in each
case on the basis of Till Roll data and according to Kantar Worldpanel for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024.
However, the growth experienced by the discounters has begun to fall sharply, with Aldi posting growth behind the
market for the four weeks ended January 21, 2024, and Lidl’s growth decreasing over 50% for the same period
compared to the four weeks ended January 22, 2023.

We also believe we can reduce losses to the discounters through our value proposition, including our opening
price point range, Just Essentials. In January 2024, we also launched a new price matching programme where we have
price matched Aldi and Lidl on 287 comparable grocery products, which reduced prices by an average of 17% to
match whichever discounter had the lowest price on these products.

_We have demonstrated resilience through downturns_

Just as our market has proven resilient in times of economic difficulty and uncertainty, our business has also
proven resilient during recent economic and market downturns, including during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis,
the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as through the rise of discounters in the UK grocery retail market in more recent
years, particularly during 2014 to 2016. During the 2007-2009 global financial crisis, we continued to perform well,
achieving an average like-for-like sales (excluding fuel) growth rate of 6.1% for the fiscal years ended December 31,
2008 and 2009. Our EBITDA margins have also remained stable, ranging from 4.7% to 4.9% between 2007 and 2023.

Despite the significant social and economic shifts driven by the COVID-19 pandemic, our business
experienced strong overall performance, particularly in our online and supermarket formats. Overall, our food business
performed consistently throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, despite an initial increase in sales due to panic buying
and customers stocking-up on key staples at the outset of each of the first three lockdown periods. Following an initial
decline at the beginning of the first lockdown, our general merchandise business also generally performed well
throughout these lockdown periods, due to increasing purchases of homeware products. While our clothing business
was initially negatively impacted during the early stage of the first UK lockdown period, we experienced improved
performance in this business in line with an overall improvement of the general economy and a rebound in consumer
confidence.

Recently, geopolitical tensions and ongoing inflation above historical norms and the Bank of England’s target
have led to uncertainty in the market and for our consumers. However, we have remained highly resilient in the face
of these challenges and have kept focused on supporting customers and colleagues with cost-of-living pressures, whilst
continuing to deliver strong financial results. During times of economic stress, we believe our value proposition is
particularly appealing to customers and can drive sales: we benefited from increased sales generating revenue
(excluding fuel) of £21.9 billion for the year ended December 31, 2023 compared to £20.4 billion for the year ended
December 31, 2021. As the current high inflationary environment persists, we are focused on initiatives to support our
customers in the cost-of-living crisis and protect market share by investing in price and quality, which we believe can
drive growth. For example, in 2022, we also launched our new grocery opening price point range, Just Essentials by
Asda that expands the range of its predecessor, Asda Smart Price, from approximately 160 to 272 products with new
branding and reformulations for taste and quality. In the same year, we also rolled out a “Dropped and Locked” price
campaign, where we locked in the prices of over 100 grocery items to give customers certainty around their shopping
costs during the year, as well as our loyalty rewards programme, Asda Rewards, as an indirect cost-saving scheme for
customers to earn cash back on their shopping.

**_We benefit from a differentiated operating model, including a diversified proposition with unique multi-format and_**
**_multi-channel offering_**

_We have well-developed own-brands_

We believe that our own-brand offers have been a key strength of our business and continue to offer growth
opportunities. We have an extensive own-brand product range in our food business, with approximately 7,800
own-brand SKUs. Our approach to range development and innovation enables us to identify and meet changing
customer needs and has resulted in the creation of many award-winning products; we launched approximately 950
lines in 2021, 1,547 new lines in 2022 and 1,597 new lines in 2023, and approximately 3,858 lines were reformulated
in 2023. As a result of the EG UK Acquisition, we also acquired Leon, our own proprietary foodservice brand. In
addition to our diverse and extensive product offer with our own-brand range, we have also been able to drive growth
through service and price positioning. We leverage our IPL sourcing model to deliver value, especially in our produce,
cooked meats and wine segments. In particular, the introduction and development of the opening price point range,
Just Essentials, has been key to helping customers with the cost-of-living pressures in 2023 after the “Dropped and
Locked” price campaigns in 2022, where we locked in the prices of over 100 grocery items to give customers certainty
around their shopping costs during that year. We also offer own-brands through George, see “—The George Clothing
_and George Home offers are generally profitable and well-established.”_

_We are driven by our commitment to delivering low prices to our customers_

We believe our commitment to delivering low prices to our customers is a competitive advantage as we aim
to lead on price while staying competitive on assortment and quality. We believe that we are the least expensive
full-selection traditional grocer in the United Kingdom: according to internal Asda data, our prices are approximately
2.5% to 6.1% less expensive than our traditional grocer competitors (on average for the first eight weeks in 2024,
based on total goods price gap percentage). Following the implementation of our Aldi and Lidl price matching
programme, which runs alongside our established customer value propositions, including Just Essentials, Asda Smart
Price, our price locking campaigns, Fab 5 and Asda Rewards, we believe our prices can compete with those of
discounters. Our low prices are supported by rigorous cost control and a commitment to affordability, which enables
us to control expenses so that we can pass cost savings on to our customers.

_Loyal customer base through our reward loyalty programme, Asda Rewards_

In 2022, we launched our new loyalty programme, Asda Rewards. The app-based scheme enables customers
to earn cash back on their shopping, building Asda Pounds in their cash pots to spend in store. The programme also
provides the opportunity to leverage data insights which enables us to better target investment in the customer
proposition. Asda Rewards total users and penetration among customers has grown quickly, with over 7.5 million new
users joining over the last 12 months and a total of 1.6 million members who have registered for Blue Light. The
number of total active customers reached 4.9 million as of December 31, 2023 over the prior 30-day period, and the
programme has earned around £300 million revenue in 2023.

_We operate the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom, which is profitable_

The United Kingdom has one of the most developed online grocery retail markets in the world, with one of
the highest rates of the population using the internet. There has been a significant shift in the grocery retail market
away from brick-and-mortar stores to online purchasing as demographic trends, greater mobile and device usage,
improved service proposition and technological advances in applications and customer interfaces have driven

-----

increasing penetration rates in the online grocery retail market. We believe we are poised to take advantage of these
favourable consumer trends, as we have already established ourselves in the rapidly growing UK online grocery retail
market and our store and warehouse footprint is strategically positioned across attractive geographic areas to service
the growing demand for groceries online.

According to Kantar Worldpanel, we are the second-largest online grocery retail platform in the United
Kingdom, holding 19.3% of market share (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales) for the 52-week period ended
January 21, 2024. Having responded quickly to the increase in demand for online shopping during the COVID-19
pandemic, we have continued to grow our online business, with an average of approximately 774,000 weekly orders
in 2022 and 2023 (based on the average weekly orders in 2022 and 2023). As a result of our strong performance in
the online market, combined sales for our online grocery business and George.com rapidly increased from previous
years to a total of £3.6 billion for the year ended December 31, 2023 (of which £3.2 billion were online grocery sales
and £0.4 billion were George.com sales) as compared to £3.3 billion for the year ended December 31, 2022 (of which
£2.9 billion were online grocery sales and £0.4 billion were George.com sales). According to Kantar Worldpanel, we
hold an 8.5% share of the UK online clothing, footwear and accessories market (in terms of volume of units sold on a
24-week basis as of January 7, 2024).

We believe there is greater scope for our online profitability to improve further. We expect that the demand
for online groceries will continue to be strong as customers increasingly adopt online shopping as a more permanent
and preferred way to purchase groceries.

_The George Clothing and George Home offers are generally profitable and well-established_

We launched our clothing offer, George, in 1990 and it is the third-largest clothing footwear and accessories
retailer in the United Kingdom by volume of units sold for the 52 weeks ended January 7, 2024 and is the leading UK
childrenswear retailer with 18.7% market share by volume of units sold for the 52 weeks ended January 7, 2024, in
each case according to Kantar Worldpanel. Despite challenges to this product category overall, our online clothing
sales have increased from £379.3 million for the year to December 31, 2021 to £423.4 million for the year ended
December 31, 2023, with 82% of all sales made via mobile devices in 2023. We believe this demonstrates our strength
in the online segment, which is a key part of our operating model. Additionally, we have expanded the George branded
offer to include general merchandise, including through collaborations with strategic partners. We have extended
product ranges with partners who specialise in certain categories, have a strong affinity fit with our existing customers
and bring complementary expertise and reputation, such as in homeware with Stacey Solomon and Claire’s in
jewellery and accessories. The George Home brand generated approximately £747.7 million in sales and contributed
approximately 50.0% of our total general merchandising sales for the year ended December 31, 2023. Sales by the
George Home brand grew at a CAGR of approximately 3% between the years ended December 31, 2021 and
December 31, 2023. Furthermore, the George Clothing and George Home product categories generally have higher
margins than our food product categories.

**_We benefit from a well invested and vertically integrated model and are supported by a significant asset base_**

_We benefit from vertically integrated procurement through IPL_

We believe that we have a competitive advantage in food sourcing via our captive sourcing arm, IPL, which
enables us to take a vertically integrated approach to procurement. We believe that IPL provides us with valuable
sourcing differentiation as compared to our competitors. IPL is one of the largest importers of produce in the United
Kingdom and, while IPL is a group company and exclusively serves Asda, it is also our largest supplier. The aim of
our vertically integrated procurement model is to consolidate import activity for key products and reduce our overall
costs. In 2023, we purchased £1,724 million of our products through IPL. The foundation of IPL’s cost-price advantage
is that it eliminates the “middleman” who typically serves as the intermediary in the supply chain, thereby giving us
greater control of costs, quality and supply of a diverse range of products. We have an extensive IPL footprint across
the United Kingdom, with nine processing facilities across the country and more than 3,793 colleagues as of the year
ended December 31, 2023. Our IPL product mix is diversified according to our needs, with a mix of 56% fruit and
vegetables, 28% protein, 7% plants and flowers, 6% beverages and 3% grocery in 2023. Additionally, we have been
able to build upon and benefit from our supplier relationships to deliver supply chain continuity and make progress in
our sustainability agenda. For example, through IPL we are supporting industry projects on water stewardship in our
produce supply chain.

10


-----

We also believe that IPL has provided greater stability and allowed us greater control over our supply chain
now that the United Kingdom has left the European Union’s single market and customs union. IPL’s EU supply chain
ensures IPL takes control of the transport direct from its suppliers’ sites. This allows IPL to appoint experts in haulage
and freight clearance, removing delays at the various border control points and ensuring the most efficient supply
chain. IPL’s logistics team are based in Spain, which is the top EU exporting country into the United Kingdom for
fresh produce. This has ensured IPL quickly understands any impacts to supply chains, such as localised disruption
by the farming fraternity, allowing IPL to take actions to protect the supply chains.

_We are supported by a significant asset portfolio_

We are supported by a well-invested and geographically diversified store estate and benefit from a total real
estate portfolio of £8.5 billion, which is comprised of freehold and long leasehold assets, and includes £756 million
of certain properties owned by the Group but pledged as collateral for the benefit of the creditors under the Ground
Rent Facility.

As of December 31, 2023, 77% of our asset portfolio was comprised of freehold or long leaseholds, based
upon attributable EBITDAR per property (less central allocations), with certain adjustments made to align the
calculation methodology across the Group’s properties following the EG UK Acquisition and the Arthur Acquisition.
Of this 77%, 12% is attributable to certain properties that are pledged as collateral for the benefit of the creditors under
the Ground Rent Facility.

Our valuable real estate portfolio also provides a potential source of liquidity and underpins our strong
ongoing cash flow generation. On August 10, 2023, we completed the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions with
Realty Income, which resulted in proceeds of £646 million that were used to finance a portion of the EG UK
Acquisition. On December 12, 2023, we also completed the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction with a number of investors,
which resulted in proceeds of £400 million that were used to repay a bridge loan that was used to finance a portion of
the EG UK Acquisition. In the future we may continue to selectively monetise portions of our real estate portfolio to
take advantage of favourable trading conditions and pursue our strategic priorities. See “Description of Certain
_Financing Arrangements—2023 Sale and Leaseback Facility” and “Description of Certain Financing_
_Arrangements—Ground Rent Transactions – Ground Rent Facility.”_

**_We have strong exposure to the resilient convenience and PFS channel with upside through synergies_**

In December 2022, we opened our first two convenience sites under the Asda Express banner. We also have
further organic Asda Express openings planned, with seven sites opened in early 2024 and a strong pipeline of
approximately 30 sites that have been identified for potential opening in 2024.

The Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition gave us a strong presence in the fast-growing
convenience market, having added 472 convenience sites and petrol filling stations to our portfolio. The Arthur
Acquisition comprised 116 convenience stores with PFSs attached and the EG UK Acquisition comprised 356 PFSs
(including two that have since been shut) with convenience stores and 124 standalone foodservice sites (including 10
non-active sites). These acquisitions accelerated our growth in the convenience sector and strategic ambition to bring
our value heritage as a consumer champion to even more customers. We completed the conversion of all the sites
acquired from the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition to Asda Express in March 2024. See also “—
_Business Strategy—Location.” We believe our recent acquisitions will drive our results by delivering additional net_
working capital and EBITDA synergies as we integrate buying for the wider convenience network into Asda and seek
to drive higher volumes and growth as a result of price investment in the fuel and grocery offering. We also expect
synergies to arise from range optimisation, monetisation of customer data, our increased scale, in-store marketing
income, improvement in fuel card terms and operational efficiencies. See “Summary Historical Consolidated
_Financial Information and Other Financial Data—Other Financial Indicators.”_

According to Euromonitor, in 2023, the UK convenience market was approximately £44 billion and the UK
foodservice market was approximately £67 billion, and the UK convenience market has grown at a faster rate than the
UK grocery retail market relative to 2015. Our exposure to these highly attractive and profitable convenience and
foodservice markets is underpinned by favourable structural factors including (i) the rise of shopping locally, (ii) the
evolution of shopper missions, (ii) the shift of our offering to a broader format of retail destinations, and (iv) our shift
into the foodservice and consumption market.
