**_We have achieved a successful financial profile_**

We have achieved a successful financial profile that is underpinned by strong profit margins, Adjusted
EBITDA margins, cash flows from operating activities, Free Cash Flow (defined as Adjusted EBITDA less Capital
Expenditure KPI) and Cash Conversion (defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA) in recent years.
Between the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2023, our average profit margin (defined as profit for the year
divided by revenue) was 4.3%, our average Adjusted EBITDA margin was 4.2% (including fuel), our cash flows from
operating activities totalled £3,340.6 million, cumulative free cash flow was approximately £2,097 million and our
average cash conversion was 68%. This strong financial performance is driven by our commitment to deliver low
prices to our clients, diverse product offer, strong own-brand grocery offer, expanded convenience and foodservice
offerings and well-established George-branded product categories. Our Adjusted EBITDA margins have benefitted
from our cost transformation programmes, which have generated SG&A cost savings without compromising the low
prices we offer our customers.

We are a structurally negative working capital business driven by growth in payables, and the beneficial
payment terms to suppliers versus payments received by consumers instantly on purchase. We delivered a strong net
working capital performance in the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023, with our active working capital
management, resulting in increased working capital inflows in those two years. Furthermore, we have pursued a
disciplined approach to our capital expenditure over time, with the aim of maintaining and improving our real estate
platform rather than opening new sites.

**_We have a highly experienced and execution focused management team_**

We are led by an experienced, entrepreneurial management team that is committed to continuing our strong
track record of growth, with a focus on product quality, delivering low prices to our customers and exceptional
customer service. Together with Michael Gleeson, the Group’s chief financial officer, our executive committee
provides strong, dynamic and deep, leadership. We also benefit from the long-standing experience, market expertise,
business relationships and industry know-how of our shareholder, Mohsin Issa, who is leading the management team
on an interim basis.

As we continue to expand our footprint and achieve our business goals, we plan to take advantage of
opportunities to further enhance and supplement our management talent, both from inside our organisation as well as
with external candidates. We have made key investments into our digital marketing team and expect to onboard a new
chief digital officer in the third quarter of 2024. Our search for a permanent chief executive officer is robust and
ongoing.

**Business Strategy**

Our primary strategy is designed to provide great value for money and to bring brighter living within
everyone’s reach. Our strategy is centred around four primary pillars which guide our business priorities and planning:
proposition, product, location and experience. These pillars are underpinned by our commitment to running an
efficient operating model, driving the business through improved data and systems and an ESG programme that builds
a sustainable business for the long term.

Through our strategy, we seek to maintain and extend our advantage in offering value for money by ensuring
that our prices are competitive and reassuring shoppers on quality. We aim to provide a consistent, trusted experience,
incentivising customers not to shop elsewhere through the creation of attractive store propositions and partnerships
that increase our appeal to customers. We serve our customers with our team of flexible and engaged colleagues, while
increasing the number of self-serve opportunities and transforming the in-store experience. We focus our growth
where customers care, expanding our addressable markets in online grocery, wholesale and community convenience.

We believe that our strategy provides a clear path to achieve our ambition of becoming the second-largest
grocer in the United Kingdom by market share.

12


-----

**_Proposition_**

Our proposition strategy is about creating more reasons to shop with us than anywhere else and providing an
offering that meets all of our customers’ needs under one roof. Demonstrating the strength in our offering across the
store, we recently won four awards at the 2023 annual Grocer Gold Awards, including the Grocer 33 Price award for
the 26th consecutive year, the ‘Own Label Range of the Year’ award for our Just Essentials product range, the
‘Consumer Initiative of the Year’ award for our Kids Eat for £1 Cafe Meals scheme and ‘Online Supermarket of the
Year.’

We believe we are well established as the lowest-price full-selection retailer in the United Kingdom, and we
lead the traditional grocers in terms of lowest price. Moving forward, we intend to reduce the complexity of the
customer shopping experience so that we can reflect that benefit to customers’ prices where it matters most in our
value proposition. We aim to simplify our value proposition to maintain price leadership, further improve quality
perception and continue to improve customer experience in-store and online. We also strive to create a more
hassle-free customer experience in-store with our digital transformation. For example, we have broadened our
Scan&Go services that allows customers to use a handset or the Scan&Go mobile app to scan and bag items as they
shop and utilise a dedicated checkout area for quick and easy payment.

We have also transformed our approach to rewarding customer loyalty through the launch of Asda Rewards
in 2022, our innovative, app-based loyalty scheme that gives customers Asda pounds, not points. Customers earn cash
back on their shopping, with regularly updated missions and star products enabling extra savings. Since 2022, more
than 5 million of our customers enrolled in Asda Rewards and as of December 31, 2023, Asda Rewards resulted in a
total of £383 million customer savings since it was first trialled. Following this initial success, we plan to look into
different ways to offer even further value to our customers, “gamefy” the application and to monetise and utilise the
data it provides. We believe that this approach will allow us to grow our customer analytics platform to bring better,
faster and deeper customer insights to our investment decisions and to improve the overall customer experience by
personalising our offer.

Through Asda Rewards, we are also able to roll out seasonal offerings such as our Christmas Saver Cashpot
that enabled customers save up their cash pot earnings in preparation for the festive period, with approximately 1.7
million members saving approximately £50 million into their 2023 Christmas Cashpots. We offered saving incentives
where customers who transferred savings earned from their Asda Rewards cash pot into their Christmas Saver Cashpot
received additional cash bonuses based upon the amount transferred. With improved availability and seasonal
offerings, we continue to earn our place in customers’ minds as the retailer for key celebrations throughout the year.
We believe that such rewards incentives will further drive customer loyalty and retention.

In non-food, we have begun trialling a number of initiatives across clothing and general merchandise in our
“lab stores.” We use the lab-store as a platform to test new technologies, concepts and ideas and assess what works
for customers and colleagues. For example, we tested a “shop within a shop” concept with our Big Asda Toyshop,
which had its own merchandising and look and feel, in eight stores in 2022. Following strong sales, we have rolled it
out in an additional 121 stores. For Halloween in 2023, we trialled a new approach to the store entrance, creating an
inviting and festive shopping environment. Through these and other concepts, we have overhauled the in-store
shopping experience, radically rethinking our use of space, lighting and merchandising and are looking at how to
replicate with new themes and categories on a regular basis across the portfolio.

We also aim to grow Asda as a platform by forming partnerships that enable us to provide a broader set of
relevant branded products and services, while also building upon our existing capabilities, such as logistics and our
customer-facing ‘toyou’ proposition. We believe adding partners to our platform will result in the creation of appealing
“one-stop-shop” store destinations for more customer missions. We believe these partnerships will not only provide
additional income through rent and revenue share models but will also create a positive effect on our overall business.

**_Product_**

Our goal under our product strategy is to make desirable products affordable. We aim to modernise our brand
and deliver the best value to our customers, helping them fulfil their money saving goals without needing to
compromise on quality.

13


-----

We began our product transformation in 2022 with the overhaul of our opening price point range, Just
Essentials by Asda. This line is a key part of our strategy to make desirable products that are affordable. In 2023, we
also locked in the price of over 500 popular products until the end of the summer to give customers certainty around
their budgets. We delivered three key price drops in 2023, lowering the prices on over 800 high volume lines, including
in October 2023 where we lowered prices by an average of 14% on many of our popular products. We will look to
continue dropping prices where possible and aim to pass price drops straight onto customers where we can. As inflation
is starting to ease in certain areas, we are working with our suppliers and IPL to ensure our customers feel the benefit
of those reductions.

As part of this brand reset, we are also focused on our mid-tier value and range offerings, investing throughout
our own brand offering to drive customers to reappraise us on quality. We launched our new scratch cooking and meal
solutions ranges and have introduced new own-label meal solutions brands, including Health Menu, Take-Out Club,
the Indian-inspired Bom Bahia and pan-Asian-inspired House of Yum ranges, and Bistro, a selection of hearty
pub-style favourites. These ranges are designed to compete directly with the likes of M&S Gastropub and takeaway
brands, a key opportunity as customers switch to at-home spending amidst cost-of-living pressures. We launched
ambitious quality and taste match campaigns during 2023 to demonstrate our confidence in the quality and value of
our products, including Harrod’s blind taste test products and M&S Taste Match campaign across a range of popular
household items. In the M&S Taste Match campaign, hundreds of our products were voted “as tasty” or “tastier than”
their M&S equivalents, but at a lower cost, in a blind taste testing conducted by Cambridge Market Research.

Foodservice and chilled categories also represent an avenue for growth and are important in moving the dial
on customers’ quality perception. A strong proposition in these categories is essential for fulfilling our ambition of
becoming a key market player in the convenience market.

In non-food, we launched ‘Exclusively at George’ in May 2023, which was dubbed the first-ever supermarket
elevated fashion collection. It put a spotlight on high-quality fabrics, with a focus on both quality and style. Following
the success of ‘Exclusively at George,’ we introduced the Studio Edit, which will be a permanent premium arm of the
George range, with a focus on wardrobe staples, premiere fabrics and finishing touches typically found in more
expensive pieces. Continuing in the elevated lifestyle space, we partnered with TV presenter and influencer Stacey
Solomon to create the homeware range, ‘At Home with Stacey Solomon Exclusively for George Home’ in
August 2023. We believe these lines showcase our ability to deliver high quality, highly desired products across a
broad range of categories to meet our customers’ every day needs.

**_Location_**

As part of our location strategy, we seek to be accessible however and whenever we are needed. We believe
that customers seeing Asda in new locations and new formats will help us broaden our customer base. In 2022, we
made significant progress in our location strategic priority area, increasing our expansion into the convenience sector.
Our core focus in our location strategy is on the successful integration of the recent Arthur Acquisition and EG UK
Acquisition, which together added 472 convenience sites and petrol filling stations and 124 standalone foodservice
sites to our portfolio.

In September 2023, we began the conversion of the Co-op sites from Co-op branding to our Asda Express
banner, implementing Asda pricing across fuel and grocery upon conversion. We completed the conversion of the
remaining convenience sites acquired from the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition to Asda Express in
March 2024. We believe we will be able to bring Asda’s great value to even more customers across the United
Kingdom by reaching new communities and shoppers with this smaller store format. In the converted Co-op sites, our
Asda Express prices were an average of 6.1% cheaper than their corresponding prices under Co-op ownership. We
also have further organic Asda Express openings planned to bolster our location strategy. Going forward, our focus
will be on the continued integration of the Co-op sites and EG UK Business into the Asda Group and delivering
synergies.

Beyond our expansion into the convenience market, we plan to continue to drive growth and market share
gains in the online channel through the expansion of our online grocery channel’s capacity to meet increased consumer
demand. We continue to seek to optimise our online grocery operating model and further develop our already
profitable economic model through the ongoing assessment of our online product range and promotions, further
monetisation of our e-commerce assets, as well as other initiatives. In addition to growing our core online grocery

business, we are targeting further growth by expanding the reach of our online platform and expanding our delivery
services. We expect to provide customers with greater and more convenient access to our product range by accelerating
our last-mile delivery capabilities via partnerships.

**_Experience_**

The goal of our experience strategy is to make shopping with us easy and enjoyable. We are focused on
operational excellence, testing scalable operational innovation for end-to-end service improvement. We are currently
looking at changes to further improve availability in store, improve stock flow and drive effective labour management.
For example, we are trialling artificial intelligence (“AI”) cameras to identify gaps in product availability and optimise
stock management in store. We believe this is an example of how AI could significantly help improve the customer
experience and optimise our colleagues’ time to focus on delivering high quality service.

We are also striving towards a best-in-class shopping experience that gives customers the range they desire
in an environment that’s easy to navigate. Our current store design had not been updated for many years, so our
near-term strategy includes modernising our stores to facilitate a better customer journey.

In order to ensure our colleagues are equipped to offer a best-in-class customer experience, we are also
investing in colleague hours in-store via a combination of additional temporary colleagues in stores and opportunities
for existing colleagues to work over-time if they wish to. Increasing the numbers of hours being worked in store means
that more colleagues are on hand to serve customers across the busy and peak periods (such as Christmas). Alongside
value and choice, we believe that service is a key quality signifier for customers and impacts where they choose to
shop. To help further this strategy, we also hired David Hills as our new Chief Customer Officer in September 2023,
who brings a wealth of retail and grocery-sector experience to our business and will play a pivotal role in providing
our shoppers a hassle-free and pleasurable experience when shopping at Asda.

**_Commitment to ESG targets and building a sustainable business for the long term_**

Part of our strategy is to ensure our Environmental, Social and Governance (“ESG”) commitments are fully
integrated into our wider business transformation plans. We believe the sales opportunity driven by eco-active
shoppers, or shoppers who are highly concerned about the environment and are actively taking actions to reduce their
waste, is expected to reach approximately £2 billion across the market by the year 2027. We believe ESG is a key
decision enabler for customers in deciding where to shop and that setting the right ESG plan is beneficial for our
customers, colleagues and investors.

Our ESG strategy is focused on four pillars: healthy and sustainable choices (providing our customers with
a product mix that is healthier and with a lower environmental impact), energy and climate change mitigation
(reducing our greenhouse gas emissions), nature positive (sourcing and farming which respects and restores) and waste
(reducing food, product and packaging waste). In August 2023, we published our third ESG report (based on 2022
data), which provided an annual update on the progress we had made towards supporting these pillars and meeting
our environmental targets and in October 2023, we received our first external assessment of our ESG strategy, with
an entity score of 54 points and an overall rating of 3 (on a scale of 1 to 5, where 1 is the strongest) by the financial
services ratings’ agency Sustainable Fitch. Sustainable Fitch positively assessed our human and labour rights policies,
gender balanced workforce and well-defined management systems, as well as our actions to increase the share of
non-high fat, salt and sugar own-brand products and improve food nutrition labelling. Obtaining this rating is part of
our ongoing commitment to transparently reporting on our efforts to achieve our ESG targets. For example, we have
continued to reduce our operational carbon footprint, with emissions down 8% from 2021 to 2022 and 40% from 2015
to 2022, and we believe we are well on the way to achieving our commitment to reduce emissions 50% by 2025 and
reaching net zero emissions by 2040. We have committed to setting a near-term science-based carbon reduction target,
including a specific Forests, Land and Agriculture (“FLAG”) target. These targets have been submitted to the
Science-Based Targets Initiative (“SBTi”) for validation. The proposed targets were submitted before the Arthur
Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition so reflect our footprint prior to these acquisitions.

In terms of waste reduction, over 90% of our own brand packaging was recyclable in 2022, and we donated
over 2,000 tonnes of surplus food through our charity partnerships, both reducing waste and supporting those in need
during challenging times. We increased the proportion of our own-label packaging that can be recycled at the kerbside
to 88% (with a further 4.7% recyclable in store) and introduced the Refill Price Guarantee on our in-store refill zones,

15


-----

guaranteeing that unpackaged products are cheaper than their packaged equivalents. We reused or repurposed 86% of
our operational waste and sent zero operational waste to landfill in 2022.

We believe we have made significant progress towards our ESG goals but that there is still much to do, and
we will continue working to build a sustainable business for the long term.

**History**

Headquartered in Leeds, we are an omni-channel retailer across England, Scotland, Wales and Northern
Ireland. We have built our business on listening to our diverse range of customers, offering what they need at the best
value and bringing innovation to the UK market.

We were founded in 1965 through the merger of the Asquith family grocery business with the Associated
Dairies company in Yorkshire. Our name is derived from this historic merger, combining “Asquith” and “Dairies” to
form “Asda.”

Founded in the North of England, we have a rich history, heritage and culture. The Asquith family has deep
ties to the grocery business, W.R. Asquith having run a butcher’s shop in Knottingley, West Yorkshire, which
eventually expanded to seven shops. W.R. Asquith’s sons, Peter and Fred, went on to create the United Kingdom’s
first self-service supermarket in Castleford, introducing food discounting to the UK grocery market, and eventually
co-founded Asda. In parallel to the growth of the Asquith family business, a group of West Riding dairy farmers joined
forces, eventually becoming Associated Dairies & Farm Stores Limited led by Arthur Stockdale. Arthur’s son, Sir
Noel Stockdale, went on to co-found Asda with Peter and Fred Asquith.

In 1965, we acquired GEM, a major U.S. discount retailer operating in the United Kingdom. With the
addition of general merchandise to the former GEM stores, we introduced the superstore to the UK market, a landmark
event in the development of UK retailing. To complement this offer, Peter Asquith also introduced the first discounted
petrol filling station.

By 1970, we operated over 30 stores and were poised to expand beyond our original home in the North of
England. Throughout the 1970s, we grew our presence in the South of England, opening stores in Newport, Plymouth
and Gosport. In 1977, we launched our “Asda Price” TV adverts, featuring the “pocket tap” which came to be the
official sign language for Asda. By the end of the 1970s, we were operating over 80 stores and opened our 100[th] store
in 1981.

Throughout the 1980s, we focused on expanding our distribution capabilities, opening seven new distribution
centres strategically located throughout the United Kingdom by 1985. In 1987, our flagship Watford store opened,
another landmark in UK retailing, and featured the longest-ever checkout bank at the time, with 45 checkouts. In 1988,
we opened our headquarters in Leeds, with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher overseeing the opening ceremonies. In
1989, George Davies was asked to produce a line of clothing for us that was high-quality, high-value and had its own
identity: the pioneering George brand was born.

In the 1990s, we developed the Asda Way of Working, an innovative framework for a new organisational
structure that focuses on our stores and promotes colleague involvement, which set the stage for the Asda culture of
today. In 1996, we opened our first Asda Pharmacy location in Harrogate, North Yorkshire and launched our “Tickled
Pink” campaign to raise money for the fight against breast cancer, a partnership that continues to this day. In 1998,
we began our online retail operations with a dedicated depot in Croydon.

In 1999, we joined the Walmart family, becoming part of the world’s largest retailer. Throughout the early
2000s, we continued to grow and innovate, expanding our online and Click & Collect offers, opening our first Asda
Living store and our first Eco Store, winning awards for the value we offer customers as well as for the positive
environment we create for colleagues, launching our Free From and Extra Special offers, launching stand-alone PFSs
as well as Asda Opticians. In 2015, we celebrated our 50[th] birthday and George’s 25[th] birthday. Asda has continued to
innovate, including the United Kingdom’s first parcel tower, which allows customers to collect online orders in less
than 60 seconds, and voice-activated shopping through Google Home.

16


-----

In October 2020, the Issa Brothers and TDR Capital reached an agreement with Walmart to acquire a majority
stake in Asda, with Walmart retaining an equity interest in the business. Following regulatory approval, the deal closed
in February 2021 and our new owners were able to take operational control in June 2021.

In October 2022, we took our first significant step into the convenience market and acquired 116 convenience
sites from the Co-operative Group (“Co-op”) as part of the Arthur Acquisition, expanding our community-focused
reach of retail destinations and petrol filling station driving footfall in strategic locations at the heart of residential
areas.

On October 31, 2023, we greatly expanded our footprint in the convenience market and completed the
purchase of the majority of the EG UK business for total cash consideration of £2.1 billion (including transaction
fees), adding a total of 480 sites to our portfolio (consisting of 356 petrol filling stations, two of which have since
closed, and 124 foodservice sites) through the EG UK Acquisition. In March 2024, we completed the conversion of
the acquired Co-op sites and EG UK Business sites to Asda Express. We look forward to exciting prospects in this
new market, including the expansion of the Asda Express convenience format to new locations.

Our values are rooted in service to our customers, respect for the individual, striving for excellence and acting
with integrity. We pursue our values with the support of our colleagues, culture and technology.

**The Transactions**

The Senior Facilities Agreement originally provided for (i) the Original Facility A, (ii) the Original Facility
B, (iii) the Original Revolving Facility and (iv) a further revolving credit facility in principal amount of £190,000,000
which was voluntarily cancelled by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer in full on September 16, 2021.

In connection with the EG UK Acquisition, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer entered into an additional
revolving facility 1 in principal amount of £117,272,727 (the “Additional Revolving Facility 1”) and an additional
revolving facility 2 in principal amount of £50,000,000 (the “Additional Revolving Facility 2”, and together with
Additional Revolving Facility 1, the “Additional Revolving Facilities”), which increased the Original Revolving
Facility by a principal amount of £167,272,727. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer further entered into the Private
Placement Facility.

It is contemplated that on or around the Issue Date, (i) the Senior Secured Notes Issuer will issue the Senior
Secured Notes offered hereby and (ii) the Senior Facilities Agreement will be amended and restated via an amendment
and restatement agreement to amend the terms thereof and constitute the Senior Facilities as at the Issue Date.

On or around the Issue Date, we will use the gross proceeds from the New Financing and cash on hand to
(i) partially repurchase the Existing Senior Secured Notes, (ii) prepay and cancel Original Facility B in full (the
“Facility B Refinancing”) and (iii) pay fees and expenses incurred in connection with the Transactions. In addition,
New Facility A will also be utilised on or around the Issue Date and the proceeds of such utilisation will be applied
(directly or indirectly) in or towards financing part of the outstanding amounts under the Original Facility A, thereby
effecting a maturity extension of the commitments of consenting lenders (the “Facility A Maturity Extension”).
Likewise, the New Revolving Facility will also be established on or around the Issue Date and it is expected that the
commitments under the Original Revolving Facility will be cancelled, thereby effecting a maturity extension of the
commitments of consenting lenders (the “Revolving Facility Maturity Extension”).

In this Offering Memorandum, we refer to the following as the “Transactions”: (i) the New Financing and
the use of proceeds therefrom, including the making and consummation of the Richmond Tender Offer, (ii) the
establishment of New Facility A and New Revolving Facility and use of proceeds therefrom, (iii) the Facility A
Maturity Extension, the Revolving Facility Maturity Extension and the Facility B Refinancing, (iv) the payment of
fees and expenses related to the Transactions, and (v) to the extent not used to repurchase and cancel Existing Senior
Secured Notes in connection with the Richmond Tender Offer, prepay and cancel the Original Facility B in full and
pay the aggregate fees and expenses in respect of the Transactions, the holding of the New Financing Proceeds on
balance sheet (in cash or cash equivalents) and the application thereof to repay any Existing Senior Secured Notes
(other than the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes) that were not subject to, or not tendered or accepted
in, the Richmond Tender Offer, as applicable, which is currently anticipated to be at the stated maturity in relation to
the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes and at, or soon after, the First Optional Par Redemption Date in relation to

**Richmond Tender Offer**

Concurrently with the Offering, we have launched an offer to purchase for cash our outstanding Existing
Senior Secured Notes held pursuant to Regulation S under the Securities Act (the “Richmond Tender Offer”) up to
a certain maximum acceptance amount, expected to be set not to exceed (x) the sum of (i) the aggregate net proceeds
from the New Financing and (ii) £415 million less (y) the sum of (i) the aggregate amount required for the prepayment
and cancellation of the Original Facility B in full and (ii) the aggregate fees and expenses in respect of the Transactions.
Pursuant to the terms of the Richmond Tender Offer, we will not accept any tenders with respect to Existing Senior
Secured Notes held pursuant to Rule 144A under the Securities Act. The Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior Secured
Notes, representing £500 million in aggregate principal amount of the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes, which
were not targeted in the Richmond Tender Offer, will remain outstanding following the Transactions.

The Richmond Tender Offer is being made upon terms and subject to the conditions set out in the separate
tender offer memorandum dated April 26, 2024 (the “Tender Offer Memorandum”). The Richmond Tender Offer
is conditioned upon the satisfaction or waiver of certain conditions, including, but not limited to, the consummation
of the New Financing, on terms satisfactory to the Issuer in its sole discretion.

We cannot assure you that the Richmond Tender Offer will be consummated in accordance with its terms, or
at all, or that any of the Existing Senior Secured Notes will be tendered and purchased in the Richmond Tender Offer.
The Offering is not conditioned upon the consummation of the Richmond Tender Offer. The maximum amount of
Existing Senior Secured Notes and the maximum amount of each series of Existing Senior Secured Notes accepted in
the Richmond Tender Offer will be determined by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer in its sole and absolute discretion,
subject to the terms of the Richmond Tender Offer. This Offering Memorandum does not relate to the Richmond
Tender Offer, which is only made upon the terms and subject to the conditions set out in the Tender Offer
Memorandum, and is only made to certain eligible holders of Existing Senior Secured Notes holding book-entry
interests in the Regulation S global note.

**The Senior Secured Notes Issuer**

The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a public limited company incorporated and existing under the laws of
England and Wales. The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is resident in the United Kingdom for tax purposes. Since the
date of its incorporation, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s activities have related only to acting as an investment and

plc and it was incorporated on September 3, 2020 under registration number 12855280 and re-registered as a public

**The Shareholders**

Mohsin Issa CBE and Zuber Vali Issa CBE have been active in the forecourt and convenience retail sector
since the acquisition of a single petrol station in Bury, United Kingdom in 2001. Following a merger of their UK-based
Euro Garages business with TDR Capital LLP’s EFR Group in 2016, EG Group was established, which the Issa
Brothers now lead as co-CEOs. The business, globally headquartered in Blackburn, United Kingdom, has an
established pedigree of delivering a world class fuel, grocery & merchandise and foodservice offer. The Issa Brothers
were honoured as Commanders of the Order of the British Empire by Her Late Majesty Queen Elizabeth II in her
Birthday Honours List 2020 for their contribution to business and charity. They were also jointly named the 2018 EY
Entrepreneur of the Year in the United Kingdom. In July 2023, Zuber Issa received an Honorary Fellowship from the
University of Central Lancashire.

TDR Capital LLP is a leading European private equity firm based in the United Kingdom, managing over
€15.0 billion of committed capital across four European buyout funds. Founded in 2002, TDR Capital LLP has been

has a proven value-based and operationally focused investment strategy, which is delivered by a dedicated team of

engaged in global operations of retail, wholesale and other units, as well as eCommerce, located throughout the U.S.,
Africa, Canada, Central America, Chile, China, India and Mexico.

**Recent Developments**

**_EG UK Acquisition_**

On October 31, 2023, Project America Bidco Ltd, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Senior Notes Issuer,
completed its acquisition of Euro Garages (Jersey) Limited, comprising the majority of EG Group’s UK business (the
“EG UK Business”). The EG UK Business is a fuel, grocery and foodservice retailer operating throughout the United
Kingdom and was acquired for an enterprise value £2.07 billion on a cash-free, debt-free basis. The final proceeds at
the point of acquisition were £2.1 billion (including transaction fees) and comprised:

    - £401 million of equity from the Group’s shareholders in the form of a subordinated shareholder loan;

    - the Private Placement Facility;

    - £646 million of proceeds from a sale and leaseback transaction of 24 stores completed in August 2023,
with a further store that completed in November 2023 (the “2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions”);

    - a bridge loan of £290 million (the “America Bridge Loan”); and

    - £88 million of cash on balance sheet.

The America Bridge Loan was refinanced and the cash on balance sheet was replenished via a ground rent
property transaction on 55 of Asda’s freehold and long leasehold property sites, which completed in December 2023
with proceeds of £400 million (the “2023 **Ground Rent Transaction”). The remaining proceeds from the 2023**
Ground Rent Transaction were retained as cash on balance sheet, in part repaying cash utilised to fund the EG UK
Acquisition and to settle transaction fees. For more detail on the Private Placement Facility, the 2023 Sale and
Leaseback Facility and the Ground Rent Transaction, see “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.”

**_Strategic Discussions Regarding Shareholder Changes_**

The shareholders are involved in active discussions regarding Zuber Issa ceasing to continue as a shareholder
of the Group in which he holds his participation through his 50% ownership in Able Holdings Limited and consequent
withdrawal from his directorships in the Asda business. Upon the completion of a transaction whereby Zuber Issa
would no longer be a shareholder of the Group, it is expected that he would resign from his directorships in all Bellis
and Asda entities. The discussions remain ongoing and there can be no assurance that a definitive agreement will
ultimately be entered into or that any such transaction will take place.

Based on preliminary management accounts, we estimate that our revenue (excluding fuel) for the threemonth period ended March 31, 2024 was £5,305 million (of which we estimate £5,109 million was attributable to the
standalone Asda business (excluding acquisitions), £65 million was attributable to sales from the Arthur Business and
£131 million was attributable to sales from the EG UK Business), an increase of £210 million, or 4%, compared to
£5,095 million for the three-month period ended March 31, 2023 (of which £5,012 million was attributable to the
standalone Asda business (excluding acquisitions) and £83 million was attributable to sales from the Arthur Business,
which were not consolidated into the Group results until May 30, 2023 when the CMA lifted its Initial Enforcement
Order in connection with the Arthur Acquisition). Asda standalone sales excluding fuel have increased by 1.9% yearover-year, with like-for-like growth of 0.5%. This overall increase was driven in part by investments made into our
proposition, including as a result of the Aldi and Lidl Price Match programme, Fab 5 and mega deals driving
improvements in price perception. We also benefited from non-food sales, which grew faster than the Asda group as
a whole and faster than the market. The grocery market continues to be very competitive and overall our sales growth,
excluding fuel, was slower than the market in the three-month period ended March 31, 2024, partly reflecting slower
than market growth in our inflation.

For the three-month period ended March 31, 2024, we estimate that our Adjusted EBITDA was £254 million,
an increase of £48 million, or 23%, from £206 million for the three-month period ended March 31, 2023. For the three
month-period ended March 31, 2024, we estimate that £7 million of Adjusted EBITDA was attributable to the Arthur
Business, £35 million of Adjusted EBITDA was attributable to the EG UK Business and £ (17) million was attributable
to the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions and 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. For the three-month period ended
March 31, 2023, £16 million of Adjusted EBITDA was attributable to the Arthur Business. This overall increase was
supported by improved year-over-year trading margins and disciplined cost control, with Adjusted EBITDA margins
(excluding fuel) increasing by 0.70 percentage points year-over-year to 4.8% in the three-month period ended March
31, 2024, from 4.1% in the three-month period ended March 31, 2023. Fuel margins were slightly lower in the period
in the standalone Asda business, as well as in the EG UK Business and the Arthur Business, as cost prices rose
significantly while retail prices did not increase as quickly.

We believe this overall growth in the Group’s Adjusted EBITDA is mainly driven by recovering gross
margin, including a strong performance in our clothing line and our ability to control costs, which highlights the
resilience of our business model. We believe in continued investment in price, particularly as inflation softens, which
could boost consumers discretionary spending. We expect utility costs to begin to decline year-on-year from April
2024. We continue to integrate the EG UK Business and the Arthur Business and expect to crystallise synergies.

We closed the three-month period ended March 31, 2024, with cash balance of approximately £1 billion with
a strong underlying Cash Conversion. Our Adjusted Net Cash Flow (defined as Adjusted EBITDA minus capex
(excluding Project Future capex) plus/minus change in net working capital minus Project Future costs (including
Future capex) minus net financing costs plus proceeds from disposals minus other and debt repayment plus cashflows
Arthur Acquisition and EG UK Acquisition) was negative £32 million in the three-month period ended March 31,
2024 as compared to negative £157 million in the three-month period ended March 31, 2023. Ongoing positive
momentum on the net working capital with improving payment terms, particularly on fuel and on inventory
management further helped improve our cash generation.

Secured Notes Issuer and (e) a floating charge over all or

Security Principles, the Senior Secured Notes will be further
secured by first-priority interests over each Guarantor’s (a)

Guarantors, (c) material intercompany receivables owned to
such Guarantors by other member of the Group, (d) a floating
charge over all or substantially all of the assets (other than
customarily excluded assets) of each of the Guarantors and
also secured by interests over (a) the shares held in Euro
Garages (Jersey) Limited by Project America Bidco Limited
and (b) any material receivables owed to it by Euro Garages
(Jersey) Limited or its Subsidiaries from time to time, in each
case on a third party limited recourse basis. Within 180 days
of the Issue Date, subject to Agreed Security Principles, the
Senior Secured Notes will be further secured by first-priority
interests over the Material Real Property (by way of
mortgage, fixed charge or, as applicable, standard security).

**Other Financial Data**

In assessing the performance of our business, we consider a variety of alternative performance measures and
financial measures. Such indicators are either purely operational in nature, include financial information not derived
from our accounting system and may include VAT which is collected by us at the cash registers or online checkout
but turned over to the competent tax authorities. For certain 2021 financial information, we present an annualised
figure. The actual financial results of the Group do not include a full year of trading in the year ended December 31,
2021, as the Senior Notes Issuer acquired the trading group Asda Group Limited part way through the year on February
16, 2021. As a result, actual results for the year ended December 31, 2021 for the Senior Notes Issuer consolidated
group do not constitute a full comparative period. Therefore, to provide a more meaningful comparison, the results
for the year ended December 31, 2021 are presented on an annualised basis as if Asda Group Limited had been
acquired by the Senior Notes Issuer on January 1, 2021.

_the Senior Secured Notes. The risks and uncertainties described below are not the only ones the Group faces._

_also adversely affect the Group’s business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects. If any of the_

_prospects could be materially and adversely affected. If that happens, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer may not be_

**Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry**

**_Risks Relating to Our General Operations_**

**_We operate in a highly competitive industry and our business, financial condition and results operations, as well_**
**_as the strength of our brand, may be materially adversely affected by actions of our competitors and our failure to_**
**_respond to competitive pressures._**

In the highly competitive grocery retail industry, success depends on satisfying changing customer needs
more effectively than the competition. Failure to meet consumer demands is a competitive disadvantage and we may
therefore be exposed to a loss of market share. There can be no assurance that we can continue to successfully compete
with existing competitors or new market entrants. Our competition generally includes international and domestic
brick-and-mortar retailers (including, generalist grocers, supermarket chains, discount retailers, grocery specialists
and convenience stores), some of which also operate omni-channel businesses such as Amazon, as well as online pure
players, such as Ocado. In recent years, the historically stable grocery retail market in the United Kingdom has
undergone a structural shift towards discounters, such as Aldi and Lidl, convenience formats and online retailers, to
the detriment of traditional supermarkets and hypermarkets. We generally compete for, among other things, customers,
market share, employees, digital prominence, products and services and in other important aspects of the business
with many other local, regional, national and global omni-channel retailers, wholesale operators and retail
intermediaries. Our competitors generally compete with us on the basis of, among other things, price, quality,
selection, availability, services offered to customers, location, store hours, in-store amenities, shopping convenience,
brand reputation, overall shopping experience, attractiveness and ease of use of our online platforms, cost and delivery
speed of merchandise purchased through our digital platforms or through our omni-channel integration of our physical
and digital operations.

In executing our strategy, we may face a variety of competitive challenges, including, among others:

    - potential emergence of new competitors, including foreign and domestic retailers entering our markets,
or consolidation, strengthening or expanded offerings of existing operators, as has been the case in recent
years with the emergence of discounters (for more information, see “Industry” and “Business—Key
_Strengths”);_

    - potential creation by competitors of new store formats, additional convenience grocery retail store
offerings, in-store or online services, delivery and pick-up options, loyalty and reward schemes or online
platforms that customers may prefer;

    - the risk of our competitors successfully adopting our business model in their own stores;

    - competitive pressure on product pricing from core competitors, as well as increasing competition from
discounters and online retailers;

41


-----

    - the risk of our competitors providing better service, quality, value or availability of products; and

    - the risk of our competitors better utilising customer data to provide personalised and efficient services,
including better loyalty and reward schemes and preferred pricing for loyalty and reward schemes’
members.

The performance of our competitors and changes in their pricing, promotions, product mix or other business
strategies, and our response (or failure to respond) to such competitive pressures, may lead to lower sales revenue,
higher operating expenses and/or lower profit margins and may require a significant amount of management attention
and resources, which may disrupt or otherwise have a material adverse effect on our ongoing business operations.
There can be no assurance that, with evolving customer preferences, our customers will not shift towards competitors
with a different business model.

Even in geographies, channels and formats where we have a strong retail presence, we face the risk that new
retail market entrants may attempt to gain market share through pricing pressure. For example, the UK grocery retail
market has seen the rapid growth of discounters (mainly represented by Aldi and Lidl) that compete through
differentiation on price coupled with a more limited selection of own-brand products. We experience downward
pricing pressure, and if we are unable to maintain our competitive position, we could experience additional downward
pressure on prices, lower demand for our products, reduced retail margins, the inability to take advantage of new
business opportunities and the loss of market share, which could materially adversely affect our business, results of
operations and financial condition.

In recent years, and in particular during the COVID-19 pandemic, the demand for online shopping services
has increased substantially and many of our competitors have expanded their online offerings. If our competitors are
able to offer faster or cheaper deliveries, and/or more convenient delivery options, we could lose current or potential
customers, our brand and reputation could suffer, all of which could have a material adverse effect on our results of
operations. To remain competitive, we must continue to develop and enhance our online offering and the information
systems that support our online activities, as well as continue to optimise our logistics and distribution capabilities.
This may require the acquisition of equipment and software and the development, either internally or through
third-parties of new proprietary software and logistics and distribution solutions. In addition, any impairment of or
disruption to our supply chain or delivery fleet could result in a disruption in the delivery of our products to our online
customers, which could harm our brand and could generate additional costs. Furthermore, the online grocery industry
in the United Kingdom may not sustain or improve upon current levels of demand, and we may fail to develop our
online retail proposition to successfully appeal to a broader customer base and sustain current growth rates. If we are
unable to effectively compete with our online competitors or if we fail to retain and attract online customers, this may
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Additionally, we may fail
to successfully compete with the growing convenience retail market, despite our growing presence is such market. If
we are unable to successfully expand our operations into the convenience retail market and the convenience retail
market continues to grow, this may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of
operations.

**_We may be unable to manage risks relating to health and safety, sourcing, food safety and customer expectations_**
**_for both food and non-food products and in our stores and premises, which increases the risk of injury or loss of_**
**_life, reputational damage, and decreased customer confidence._**

Food and product safety and food hygiene and traceability (including in respect of product origins, freshness
and conditions of preservation through the supply chain) are top priorities for us: the actual safety of the food and
other products and services we offer, as well as the public’s perception of that safety, are essential to our business,
brand and reputation. Any event, such as a significant product recall or negative press reaction to statements made or
actions taken could damage our brand or reputation or cause customers to lose confidence in the safety and quality of
the products we sell. We are also subject to a number of food safety and hygiene regulations. See “Business—
_Regulation—Food Safety, Hygiene, Labelling and Nutrition and Consumer Protection.” Failures to comply with these_
regulations could result in a number of adverse consequences, including fines, loss of licences, costs of compliance or
certification requirements.

We may not be able to ensure that our customers always enjoy safe, quality products. We sell food for human
consumption, which subjects us to safety risks such as contamination (including the presence of an undeclared

42


-----

allergen, a foreign object, substance, unintentional microbe or chemical, other agent or residue or the introduction of
a genetically modified organism, and other types of contamination caused by the presence of pests that are inherent to
the product in question or present where such product may be stored), spoilage, mislabelling, expired products and
product tampering, all of which could lead to product withdrawals or recalls or destruction of inventory and could
result in bad publicity, temporary store or warehouse closures and substantial costs in connection with compliance or
remediation. There is also a risk that products may not be sourced in a responsible or sustainable way. We may also
be impacted by any assertion that our products have caused illness or injury, whether true or false, proven or unproven.
We could also be subject to claims or lawsuits relating to an actual or alleged illness or injury stemming from product
contamination, spoilage, mislabelling, expired products, product tampering or any other incidents that compromise
the safety and quality of our products. From time to time we also recall products.

Risks to the health of our customers can also arise from our branded and own label suppliers, some of whom
are third parties who operate outside of our direct control, in relation to the ingredients, foods and products we sell in
our stores. For example, we rely on suppliers, some of whom are third parties who operate outside of our control, for
ingredients, foods and products we sell in our stores. Our use of third-party suppliers increases the risk that any of the
aforementioned types of incidents could be caused by factors outside of our control and that multiple locations could
be affected. In addition, food or product safety-related risks may also occur under any one of our own-brand labels
and we may be impacted by negative publicity regarding any assertion that our food or other products have resulted
in illness or injury. Our customers expect that we will provide them with a large selection of safe, high-quality
products. Our colleagues are critical to maintaining our customer and supplier relationships and ultimately protecting
our reputation as a business. If we are unable to control and guarantee the quality of the products we sell, especially
our own-brand products and in-store services, our brand and reputation may be negatively impacted.

We rely upon electrical power to operate all our facilities across our distribution network. To attain maximum
performance, these types of facilities must often operate on a continuous basis and at the appropriate pre-set
temperatures. As a result, any shortage or interruption in power supply may result in food spoilage and any extended
power supply shortages or interruptions could result in perishable food losses, each of which could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. Actual recent increases and potential
future increases in wholesale energy prices may result in an increase in our costs incurred to maintain adequate and
constant power supply at our facilities. Cold chain requirements, setting out the temperatures at which our ingredients
and products must be stored and transported, are established both by law and by us to help guarantee the safety of our
food products. Our cold chain must be maintained from the moment the ingredients arrive at, or are frozen by, our
suppliers, through transportation and ultimately to the time of sale in our stores or delivery to our customers. In the
past, the United Kingdom has experienced shortages of CO2 due to the temporary shutdown of fertilizer manufacturing
facilities of which CO2 is a by-product and is an important component of our cold chain. CO2 is also used in the
preparation of some of the foods and beverages we produce or we otherwise buy from suppliers, for sale in our stores
and in the refrigeration technologies of some of the sites we acquired. A failure in our cold chain could lead to food
spoilage, risks to the health of our customers, fines and other penalties and damage to our brand and reputation, each
of which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

Consumers are increasingly focused on the traceability of food products to assist them in deciding what to
purchase. In January 2013, incidents of horse meat in parts of the European food supply chain mislabelled as beef
were identified, negatively impacting retailers and producers throughout Europe, including Asda, and led to additional
standards, such as BRC standards on traceability, food fraud and food defence. While we conduct quality practices
and procedures, it may be difficult to detect contamination, spoilage, mislabelling, product tampering or any other
incidents that compromise the safety and quality of our products, particularly fraudulent or malicious activity. Adverse
publicity about these types of problems, whether valid or not, may discourage customers from buying our products or
may affect our brand and reputation. Our actual or perceived sale of unsafe food products could result in product
liability claims, a loss of customer confidence, product recalls and legal claims, which could have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

A significant lawsuit, widespread product recall or other events leading to the loss of customer confidence in
the safety and quality of our products could damage our brand and reputation and negatively impact our sales,
profitability and prospects for growth. Further, if a product recall is required in circumstances where the financial
consequences are not covered by the relevant supplier or our insurance, it may have a material adverse effect on our
financial performance. Although we maintain product liability insurance, we cannot be certain that our coverage will

markdowns of inventory, or otherwise materially adversely affect our operations and results of operations and could

**_Sales of our products are subject to changing customer preferences and trends and we may be unable to_**
**_successfully or timely respond to these changing customer preferences._**

The success of our business depends on the continued appeal of the range of products and services we offer,
as well as our ability to provide an appealing omni-channel offering that draws new and returning customers. Given
the varied backgrounds and tastes of our customer base, we must offer a sufficient range of products to satisfy a broad
spectrum of preferences.

Demand for our food products is affected by customer tastes and preferences, which are impacted by, among
other things, social trends, health concerns, ethical considerations and culinary trends. Further to a review on customer
and product trends, customers are increasingly focused on health and wellness, including avoiding foods with certain
ingredients such as trans fats, gluten, sugar, sodium, processed wheat, animal products or other product attributes and
prefer foods which fit in to their image of a healthy lifestyle. Customers have also shown increasing preference for
vegan and organic products, ethically sourced products, environmentally-friendly product packaging and products that
support local business. The review suggests that other food trends include foods that can be cooked with just an oven,
on-the-go eating, comfort food with global influences, gourmet fast food and indulgent hybrid snack combinations.
We must adapt and develop products to address these trends and preferences in a timely manner in order to remain
competitive. Further, our customers increasingly expect a seamless omni-channel experience and when making a
decision to purchase products from us, want to be able to have access to greater amounts of information than ever
before, including on traceability, environmental sustainability and nutritional value. Likewise, our clothing, home
product lines and general merchandise offer are subject to changing customer tastes in apparel and decor which are
also impacted by sustainability considerations. Customers also increasingly expect to be able to interact with us in a
variety of ways, such as through mobile application purchases, which require investments in technology and human
resources. Customers also increasingly desire convenience and accessibility, requiring further investments to expand
our footprint in the convenience market, including under our Asda Express banner. In addition, in this current
economic environment, customers continue to experience cost pressures on their household budgets as they face a real
wage decline, increasing the importance of value or lower margin food and non-food offerings. However, consumer
patterns, which have increasingly been tending towards eating and working at home due to inflationary pressures and
the increase in working from home in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic in the last three years, may reverse
and an increasing number of employees may return to working from the office or an increase in dining out once

47


-----

inflationary pressures subside, which in turn may have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition
and results of operations.

If we do not identify or effectively respond to customer trends and preferences in a timely manner, or if we
fail to meet our customers’ expectations, it could negatively affect our relationship with our customers, our reputation,
the perception of our value proposition, demand for our products and services, our market share and the growth of our
business, which could in turn have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of
operations. It is difficult to quickly, consistently and successfully predict the products and services our customers will
be interested in and respond to changes in their shopping patterns. Responding to shifts in customer preferences and
expectations also can entail significant costs.

The success of our business depends on how accurately and quickly we predict customer demand, availability
of merchandise, the related impact on the demand for existing products and the competitive environment. Price
transparency, assortment of products, customer experience, convenience and the speed, ease and cost of delivery or
collection options are of primary and increasing importance to customers, particularly as a result of the growth of
digital tools and social media that inform customers. Further, if we misjudge demand for certain products, particularly
for our non-food products, we may build up excess inventory for those products, which could result in a decrease in
their sales price and inefficient working capital management which, if material, could have a material adverse effect
on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Conservation measures, technological advances and negative shift in market perception towards the oil and gas_**
**_industry could reduce demand for fuel._**

As a retailer of petroleum-based fuel that increased its market presence following the EG UK Acquisition,
we may be unable to adapt to fast-paced developments regarding climate change and the impact of petroleum-based
fuel on the environment, which may alter consumer sentiments and lead to the increased use of alternative fuels.
Increasing attention to climate change, fuel conservation measures, alternative fuel requirements, incentives to
conserve energy or use alternative energy sources (such as electric vehicles and biofuels), increasing consumer
demand for alternatives to oil and natural gas, and technological advances in fuel economy and energy generation
devices may result in increased costs, reduced demand for our fuel and reduced revenues.

Global efforts to respond to the challenges of climate change may also have an impact on the demand for the
price of oil and gas moving forward, as countries increasingly shift toward alternative energy sources, which may in
turn impact our revenues in the long term if we are unable to achieve or maintain a sufficiently low break-even price.
In particular, the automobile industry has focused heavily on reduced fuel consumption, a trend that will likely
continue with improvements to alternative fuels such as electricity, hydrogen or compressed natural gas. If customers
and the automobile industry continue to embrace electric and hybrid vehicles and alternative fuels, this could have an
adverse impact on our growing fuel business, our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.
For example, in October 2022, the European Union adopted legislation requiring a 55% CO2 emission reduction for
new cars and 50% for new vans by 2030 compared to 2021 levels and for a 100% CO2 emission cut by 2035, effectively
prohibiting the sale of new combustion engine cars. Should similar legislation be enacted in the United Kingdom, this
could accelerate the transition of the economy away from the use of fossil fuels towards lower-or-zero-carbon
emissions alternatives, which could decrease demand for, and in turn the prices of, the fuel we sell, which could have
an adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operation.

In addition, institutional lenders may, of their own accord, elect not to provide or place additional restrictions
on funding for fuel-linked companies based on climate change related concerns, which could affect our access to
capital for potential growth projects and other financing requirements.

**_Our business and the markets in which we operate may be adversely impacted by climate change, adverse weather_**
**_conditions, the carbon transition and climate change regulation._**

Climate change, including the impact of global warming, subjects our businesses to a broad range of risks at
several different levels. Our operations are subject to physical risks across all regions of operation, which include an
increase in sea level and changes in weather conditions, such as rapid changes in precipitation and extreme weather
events. For example, global shipping may be disrupted as a result of extreme weather patterns.

48


-----

Food production systems require a diverse range of plants, animals, bacteria and fungi, both for the direct
supply of food and to sustain the underlying ecosystem processes that make agriculture possible – from water supply
to soil fertility enhancement, pollination and natural pest control. Changing global weather patterns in the geographies
of food production systems may negatively impact or destroy the ecosystems where products grow, in turn affecting
such products’ availability and/or quality. In addition, water resources are vital to food production systems and the
scarcity of such resources may have an adverse impact on agricultural production and yields. See “Business—Our
_Quality Control System, Health and Safety and Environmental Policies—Our Environmental, Social and Governance_
_Goals—Our ESG Priority Areas—Energy and Climate Mitigation.” Other climate-related issues such as adverse_
weather conditions may have a significant impact on our operations, property, supply chain (particularly in our fresh
food offering) and our ability to maintain availability on our shelves.

We also face transitional risks related to climate change. Developments related to climate change may
expedite a transition away from the use of carbon-intensive sources for energy generation and products derived from
certain fossil fuels, which could have a material and adverse effect on us if we are not able to demonstrate that our
products align with a low-carbon transition or we are not able to meet our carbon transition targets. As a retailer, we
recognise that we have a responsibility to minimise the adverse impact that our business activities have on the
environment. Failure to do this may result not only in adverse environmental impacts, but also financial penalties and
long-term damage to our reputation. As the global climate crisis becomes more critical, there is a risk that we will fail
to address climate-related impacts on our business in reputational, operational and financial terms and may not meet
stakeholder expectations.

In addition, we are subject to legislation and regulation regarding climate change and the emission of
greenhouse gases including with respect to our supply chain, and compliance with related rules could be difficult and
costly. We could incur increased energy, environmental and other costs and capital expenditures to comply with
existing or new greenhouse gas emission laws and regulations. Failure to comply with any such laws and regulations
could result in penalties as well as adverse consequences to our reputation and image among our customers and
stakeholders. The realisation of any of the foregoing risks could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition and results of operations.

**_commodities and packing material, as well as to fluctuations in the price of electricity and fuel and labour,_**

Our results of operations are influenced by market prices for certain essential food ingredients and products,
commodities, packing materials, gas, electricity and fuel, as well as other raw materials and energy-related costs and
labour, transportation and manufacturing costs. Increases in prices or scarcity of any of these ingredients, commodities,
products or materials required for our business could materially increase our costs and disrupt our operations. Food
cost inflation, particularly during periods of rapid inflation, could reduce our operating margins as it may reduce the

which we are able to increase the price of our products and pass them on to our customers. Volatility in the price and
availability of raw materials can result from a wide variety of factors beyond our control, including poor harvests,
shortages or interruptions, weather conditions, disease, political instability and changes in climate, among many other
factors. Events such as Brexit, COVID-19 lockdowns, the war in Ukraine or the threat of political or social unrest (or
the perceived threat thereof) have had or may have a material adverse impact on commodity, product or material
prices, the availability of food ingredients and products, and labour, transportation and manufacturing costs. See “—
_Our business is dependent on the economic situation in the United Kingdom and we are exposed to local, regional,_
_national and global economic, political, social and other trends that could materially adversely impact our business,_
_financial condition and results of operations.”_

Notwithstanding our hedging policies, we cannot fully eliminate the risks of price movements or risks
associated with the availability of food products and ingredients. For example, we are currently experiencing
industry-wide retail price inflation arising from labour shortages, the war in Ukraine, increases in the cost of key

which may cause our suppliers to raise their prices, which could materially increase our costs and negatively impact
our business. Whilst it is not possible to predict the long-term impact of the war in Ukraine, it has resulted in significant
volatility in the price of energy and price and availability of agricultural and other commodities in the short-term (such
as wheat, for example), as well as volatility in the market price of commodities. Our ability to pass along increased
costs through price increases to our customers depends upon competitive conditions in our industry and pricing
regulations and may not be compatible with our business ethos and strategy. If we are unable to pass such cost
increases on to our customers or if the higher cost of the products offered results in decreased demand for our products,
our business, results of operations and financial condition, as well as our brand, may be materially adversely affected.

Food purchases account for a significant portion of our cost of goods sold. The prices of ingredients that we
and our suppliers purchase are subject to volatility. Such fluctuations are attributable to, among other things, global
commodity prices (which may be because of such commodity’s availability), currency exchange rates, and fiscal

policy support for agriculture. The invasion of Ukraine by Russia in 2022, for example, led to significant rises in the

Increases in prices or scarcity of ingredients or packaging materials required for our products could increase

In addition, fuel prices have remained high with the potential to increase the operating costs of our sites,

Fluctuations in the price of fuel products may also negatively affect the business of our petrol stations. Any

our inventory and the related costs of goods sold, thus reducing our profit margins. In particular, when fuel cost prices
increase, whether as a result of governmental intervention or global oil market conditions, we may not always be able
to pass such increases onto our customers, which may reduce our fuel margins. Fluctuations in fuel cost prices may
be exacerbated in the future, for example, as a result of environmental legislation or regulation or we may face pressure
from consumers and governments to not increase our fuel retail prices. As such, there can be no assurance that the
price of fuel will remain stable or that we will be able to pass any price increases onto our consumers, in a timely
manner or at all, resulting in higher expenses, lower margins and other material adverse effects on our business,

The retail business continues to rapidly evolve, and consumers increasingly embrace online shopping,
convenience and accessibility. As a result, the portion of total customer expenditures with retailers occurring through

Our strategy, which includes investments in online channels, technology, store remodels and other

Given the various risks to which we are exposed and the uncertainties inherent in our business, we cannot

**_Competitive pressures in the apparel, footwear and homeware retail industries are high, which may impact our_**
**_ability to compete successfully against existing or future competitors._**

The apparel, footwear and homeware retail industries are each highly competitive and the marketplace is
highly fragmented as many different retailers compete for market share by utilising a variety of store and on-line
formats and merchandising strategies. The George Clothing and George Home brands compete on the basis of, among
other things, the location of our stores; website, mobile applications and their respective design; the breadth, quality,
style price and availability of our merchandise; and the level of customer service offered. In particular, the George
Clothing brand faces competition from other low-cost and fast fashion retailers that have recently made significant
price investments in their merchandise offerings and target some of the same categories of customers as the George
Clothing brand. We expect competition to increase in the future. There are no significant economic barriers for others
to enter our apparel, footwear and homeware retail sectors and our existing competitors are constantly adjusting their
pricing, business strategies and promotional activity (particularly during holiday periods) in response to changing
market conditions or their own financial condition.

Additionally, the substantial sales growth in online apparel, footwear and homeware retail within the last
decade has encouraged the entry of many new competitors, new business models and an increase in competition from
established companies looking for ways to create successful online shopping alternatives. The internet and other
technologies also facilitate comparison shopping in our apparel, footwear and homeware retail segments. Our digital
channel competes against numerous websites, mobile applications and catalogues, which may have a greater volume
of circulation and web traffic or more effective marketing through online media and social networking sites. We offer
an omni-channel shopping experience for our customers and use social media and mobile applications as a way to
interact with them to enhance their shopping experiences. Omni-channel retailing is constantly evolving, and we must
keep pace with changing customer expectations and new developments by our competitors. There is no assurance that
we will be able to continue to successfully maintain or expand our digital sales channels and respond to shifting
consumer traffic patterns and digital buying trends. Our inability to adequately respond to these risks and uncertainties
or successfully maintain and expand our digital business could have an adverse impact on our results of operations.

We may not be able to continue to compete successfully against existing or future competitors. Intense
pressures from our competitors, our inability to adapt effectively and quickly to a changing competitive landscape or
a failure to effectively execute our model to retain and win customers in our targeted customer categories, could reduce
demand for our merchandise, decrease our inventory turnover, cause us to take greater markdowns and negatively
affect our sales and margins.

_risks if our insurance coverage proves to be inadequate.” Any increases in the cost of transportation, including as a_
result of increased fuel prices or environmental regulations or initiatives that mandate more costly methods of

without disruptions or delays is essential, especially for our fresh food products.

Changes in our logistics structures, including as a result of impacts to our facilities, labour disruptions, fleet

**_Increased transportation costs or disruption to transportation services could materially adversely impact our_**
**_business, results of operations and financial condition._**

Cost-effective transportation of our products is an important element of our cost structure. We depend on the
use of refrigerated trailers for the shipping of certain of our products from our suppliers’ facilities to our distribution
centres, from our distribution centres to our stores and from our stores and distribution centres to our customers. Asda
drivers deliver goods to stores and customers using a fleet of leased tractors, trailers and vans, as well as occasional
spot-hire or third-party hauliers. See “Business—Our Suppliers and Logistics.” Transportation costs have historically
fluctuated significantly over time, in particular in connection with oil prices, and increases in transportation costs
could result in reduced profits. For example, more recently we have experienced increases in global shipping rates
resulting from increased demand for container-based shipping and increases in the cost of fuel for our HGV fleet
resulting from increases in the global price of oil, which, especially if protracted, could materially increase our costs
and adversely impact our business, results of operations and financial condition. Additionally, climate change related
taxes and levies are a large portion of the energy related costs required to maintain the cold chain. These climate
change related taxes have been increasing in recent years and are expected to increase in the future.

We are subject to regulations governing the number of hours and days that drivers can work consecutively,
and as a result, we may not have enough drivers available to work during periods of very high demand or adverse
weather conditions. Additionally, we face competition from other retailers and businesses in hiring and retaining
drivers and couriers for our delivery services and distribution network. Moreover, delivery service is also a field with
inherent high attrition rate and job mobility. We have been facing sustained freight inflation, plus a shortage of heavy
goods vehicle drivers across the United Kingdom. In addition, the reduction in the number of EU nationals working
in the United Kingdom following Brexit has led to shortages of staff at national food suppliers and in the food supply
chain, as well as a shortage of drivers in the logistics sector. As a result, we may not be able to hire a sufficient number
of drivers to meet our demand, which may result in us paying increased labour costs in order to attract new drivers or
retain existing ones. Continued labour shortages or increased labour costs could materially adversely impact our
business, results of operations and financial condition. Additionally, climate change related taxes and levies are a large
portion of the energy related costs required to maintain the cold chain. These climate change related taxes have been
increasing in recent years and are expected to increase in the future. Any increases in the cost of labour or

Consumer expectations regarding the use of digital tools and omni-channel shopping are rapidly evolving, with
