further develop the omni-channel retail experience we offer our customers. We rely in part on third parties for
development of and access to such new technologies and tools. We expect that new services and technologies will
continue to emerge. These new services and technologies may be superior to, or render obsolete, the technologies that
we currently use. Incorporating new technologies into our products and services may require substantial expenditures
and take considerable time, and ultimately may not be successful. In addition, our ability to adopt new services and
develop new technologies may be inhibited by industry-wide standards, new laws and regulations, or third parties’
intellectual property rights. Our success will depend on our ability to develop new technologies and adapt to new
technological changes and evolving industry standards.

systems are compromised as a result of data corruption or loss, a cyberattack or a network security incident, or if our
colleagues or certain third-parties fail to comply with data protection laws and regulations (and, as a result, information
about our customers or colleagues is obtained by unauthorised persons and/or used inappropriately), we could be
subject to liabilities and penalties, damage to our reputation, litigation or government enforcement actions, substantial
costs and a loss of customer confidence, all of which may significantly adversely affect our business, results of
operations and financial condition.

Our performance depends on accurate, timely information and numerical data from key software applications

**_Our use of open-source software may restrict our ability to exploit our proprietary software and IT systems and_**
**_exposes us to certain risks._**

Our key proprietary software and critical IT systems incorporate significant elements of “open source”
software, our use of which is subject to the terms of applicable licences. Open-source software is typically licensed
for use at no initial charge on terms which allow modification and distribution of the software by the licensee.
However, licence terms may impose on the user compliance requirements and obligations to disclose modifications
we have made to the software to third parties. Our ability to realise fully the commercial benefits of any such software
may be restricted because:

    - Open-source licences may be drafted in legally ambiguous language and may result in unanticipated
consequences or obligations regarding our software;

    - due to the requirements to licence modified software, our competitors or licensees may have access to
information which may help them to develop competitive products;

    - open-source software is available to the public for anyone to access and utilise, including our
competitors; and

    - it may be difficult for us to identify accurately the developers of the open-source code (who may be
licensors of the software) and whether the licensed software infringes third party intellectual property
rights.

Furthermore, to the extent we use open-source software we face certain more general risks which apply to
any organisation making use of such software. Our use of GNU General Public Licence (“GPL”) software could
subject certain portions of our proprietary software to GPL requirements, including an obligation on us to disclose
that software to third parties and to permit them to use the software free of charge. Finally, open-source licences
typically present onerous compliance requirements and failure to observe these may result in litigation or the loss of
the right to use the software which may have an adverse effect on our financial condition and future prospects.
Although we are not aware that we have breached any of these compliance requirements, and to our knowledge no
third party has claimed that software owned by us should be made available on an open-source basis, any of the risks
or restrictions relating to open-source software mentioned above could have an adverse impact on our financial
condition and future prospects.

**_If the technology-based systems that give our customers the ability to shop with us in stores and online do not_**
**_function effectively, our results of operations, as well as our ability to grow our omni-channel business, could be_**
**_materially adversely affected._**

Increasingly, customers are using computers, tablets, and smart phones to shop with us and with our
competitors and to do comparison shopping. We use our websites, social media, online advertising, and email
campaigns to interact with our customers and as a means to enhance their shopping experience. As a part of our
omni-channel strategy, we offer home delivery and pickup options under which many products available for purchase
online can be picked up in-store by the customer via our Click & Collect offer and our Scan&Go service that allows
customers to use a handset or the Scan&Go mobile app to scan and bag items as they shop and utilise a dedicated
checkout area for quick and easy payment, in each case providing additional customer traffic at such stores. In 2022,
we also implemented a new loyalty programme, Asda Rewards, which is an app-based system whereby customers
earn cash back on their shopping, building Asda Pounds in their cash pots to spend in store and online, and earn
additional discounts on certain products.

Omni-channel retailing is a rapidly evolving part of the UK retail grocery industry. We must anticipate and
meet our customers’ changing expectations while adjusting for technology investments and developments in our
competitors’ operations through focusing on the building and delivery of a seamless shopping experience across all
channels. Any failure on our part to provide attractive, user-friendly secure digital platforms that offer a wide
assortment of merchandise at competitive prices and with low-cost and rapid delivery options and that continually
meet the changing expectations of online shoppers and developments in online and digital platform merchandising
and related technology could place us at a competitive disadvantage, result in the loss of online and other sales, harm

our reputation with customers, have a material adverse impact on the growth of our online business and have a material

**_Use of social media may adversely impact our reputation or subject us to fines or other penalties._**

There has been a marked increase in the use of social media platforms and similar devices, including blogs,
social media websites and other forms of internet-based communications which allow individual access to a broad
audience of customers and other interested persons. Consumers value readily available information concerning
retailers, manufacturers and their goods and services and often act on such information without further investigation,
authentication and without regard to its accuracy. The availability of information on social media platforms and
devices is virtually immediate as is its impact. Social media platforms and devices immediately publish the content
their subscribers and participants post, often without filters or checks on accuracy of the content posted. The
opportunity for dissemination of information, including inaccurate information, is virtually limitless. Information
concerning or affecting us may be posted on such platforms and devices at any time. Information posted may be
inaccurate and adverse to us, and it may harm our business. The harm may be immediate without affording us an
opportunity for redress or correction. Such platforms also could be used for the dissemination of trade secret
information or compromise of other valuable company assets, any of which could harm our business.

We also use social media platforms as marketing tools. For example, we maintain TikTok, Instagram,
Facebook and Twitter accounts. In addition, we may from time-to-time partner with celebrities, influencers and other
third parties across various social media platforms, but there can be no assurance that these campaigns will be
successful or that their values align with Asda’s values and therefore our association with such parties may negatively
affect or harm our reputation. Furthermore, other social media users with whom we do not have partnerships or control
over may use their accounts and following based on these social media platforms to criticise Asda with subjective or
false, or without basis, which may in turn adversely impact our reputation. See also “—Any events that negatively
_impact the reputation of, or value associated with, our brands could materially adversely affect our business, financial_
_condition and results of operations.”_

As laws and regulations rapidly evolve to govern the use of these platforms and devices, the failure by us,
our colleagues or third parties acting at our direction to abide by applicable laws and regulations in the use of these
platforms and devices could adversely impact our business or subject us to fines or other penalties.

Certain of our stores and warehouses are leased pursuant to commercial leases for fixed terms consistent with

line with certain indices or in line with the open market rent. Our ability to maintain our existing rental rates during

renewals or to renew any expired lease on favourable terms will depend on many factors which are not within our

prospective landlords. If rent reviews were to increase at higher rates than currently anticipated or if we were unable

Further, we may be unable to extend expiring lease agreements at all or may have no or limited ability to
close certain store locations that do not meet our financial targets or are no longer consistent with our brands’
positioning. These changes in the size of our store network can have a significant impact on our revenues and expenses

we can. The above risks are also applicable to (i) the leases of the Warehouse Assets pursuant to the 2021 Sale and
Leaseback Transactions, (ii) the leases of the SLB Properties pursuant to the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions
and (iii) the leases of the CGR Properties pursuant to the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction.

Any breach that we commit under our lease agreements and do not remedy in line with the relevant forfeiture
provisions may lead to forfeiture of the relevant lease by the landlord, subject to our ability to seek relief from
forfeiture (except in respect of lease agreements for stores located in Scotland where no such relief process applies)
from the courts (any such relief being at the discretion of the courts). Forfeiture of the leases would result in the loss
of our right to occupy the property and may entail material interruption to the business and operations of the Group.
In addition, a breach of any Ground Lease may entitle the lender under the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction to accelerate
the Ground Rent Transaction Facility Agreement and enforce security over all properties secured under the 2023
Ground Rent Transaction resulting in the loss of ownership of the freehold and long leases properties comprising the

If we are unable to renew our lease agreements as they expire or if any of our existing lease agreements are

The Group’s leases of the Warehouse Assets and SLB Properties and the Ground Leases are leases for terms

or underlet the lease and must meet the criteria set out in the relevant leases to effect a disposition. In a depressed
market or if there is no demand for a property, the Group may not be able to exit that property in a cost-efficient
manner, or at all. In terms of the Ground Leases, the tenant is not permitted to assign so in order to exit the property

**_Our failure to attract and retain qualified colleagues, increases in labour costs and social charges and other_**
**_changes to wage regulations could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial_**
**_condition._**

We are reliant on our staff for the management, operation, creation, maintenance, repair and upgrading of
our business, operations and systems. Our ability to recruit or adequately replace, retain and motivate suitably qualified
and experienced staff is important for our ongoing success. It may in the future become more difficult for us to recruit
or retain such members of staff with the relevant skillset, retain key colleagues, or adapt colleague skillsets to align
with transformation activities, which could lead to a negative impact on operational performance, a delay in separation
transformation and ultimately impact our external reputation. Moreover, the UK labour market may become more
competitive. An inability to recruit and retain sufficient personnel of the right calibre or the incurring of significant
costs in order to do so may have an adverse effect on our financial condition and future prospects. Furthermore, our
automated warehouses and delivery trucks still require intensive labour. Colleague benefits (which include wages,
National Insurance contributions and other payments) currently represent one of our most significant cost items,
accounting for a substantial portion of our total expenses. Consequently, our commercial success depends in part on
our ability to manage our labour costs and control their impact on our margins. We may in the future be forced to raise
our wages due to changes in market conditions, new labour laws and regulations, collective bargaining with our
recognised trade unions or general wage increases across the industry or in any particular region in which we operate.
For example, in April 2023, we voluntarily increased our rate for hourly-paid store colleagues to £11.00 an hour and
further increased this in July 2023 to £11.11 an hour. For stores inside the M25 and around Greater London, our rate
for hourly-paid store colleagues increased to £12.28 an hour. The national minimum wage is due to increase to £11.44
an hour in April 2024, and we plan to give our colleagues an interim increase, with those inside the M25 and around
Greater London receiving £12.61 an hour. In July 2024, we are proposing a further increase in pay to 120,000 of our
colleagues which will increase the basic pay for retail workers to £12.04 an hour, with those at stores inside the M25
and around Greater London receiving £13.21 an hour. Overall, this is an 8.4% increase in pay from £11.11 in July
2023 to the proposed £12.04 in July 2024.

Additionally, we compete with other producers for dependable employees. The supply of such employees is
limited and competition to hire and retain them may result in higher labour costs, for example as a result of higher
wages implemented in response to inflationary pressure and cost of living increases. Furthermore, a number of our

63


-----

employees are subject to national minimum wage requirements. Given the high proportion of our colleagues who are
paid hourly, future increases or changes to the National Minimum Wage legislation, the National Living Wage or
other hourly wage legislation or regulations could have an impact on our future financial success. As of April 2023,
the National Living Wage increased from £9.50 per hour as of April 2022 to £10.42 per hour. The National Living
Wage will increase in increments with a target to be set by the UK government of reaching £11.44 by April 2024. We
must comply with such legislation. Any failure to comply could result in criminal prosecution with any party found
to be guilty of deliberate non-compliance being subject to disqualification as a company director for up to 15 years.
From time to time, we are subject to legal proceedings in connection with the wages we pay. See “Business—Legal
_Proceedings—Equal Value Litigation.” If legislation is enacted that has the effect of raising national minimum wage_
requirements, requires additional mandatory employee benefits or affects our ability to hire or dismiss employees, we
could face substantially higher labour costs. Increases in labour costs could adversely affect our profitability if we are
not able to pass them on to our customers.

As national minimum hourly wage rates increase, we may be required to increase not only the wage rates of
our hourly paid colleagues but also the wages of our salaried managers as an increase in hourly rates inevitably erodes
the pay gap between hourly paid and first line managers. This makes it more challenging to incentivise our most
talented colleagues to progress into management positions. It also makes it difficult to retain our talented managers.
Although difficult to predict with certainty, these higher salaried costs could have a material adverse effect on our
profitability. While we cannot be certain how this will affect our business, an increase in the minimum wage rate paid
to certain workers will increase our labour costs which may adversely affect our results of operations and financial
condition.

Our ability to meet our management labour needs, while controlling wage and labour-related costs, is subject
to numerous external factors, including the availability of and competition for qualified persons in the local markets
in which we are located, unemployment levels within those markets, prevailing pay rates, changing demographics,
and changes in employment and labour laws. Such laws related to hours, wages, job classification and benefits could
significantly increase operating costs.

If we fail to maintain our competitive position on pay and benefits, the quality of our workforce could decline,
causing our customer service to suffer, while increasing wages for our colleagues could cause our profit margins to
decrease. If we are unable to hire, retain, and train colleagues capable of meeting our business needs and expectations,
our business and brand image may be impaired. Any failure to meet our staffing needs or any material increase in

Furthermore, we are required to pay social security, National Insurance contributions, pension contributions
and other similar charges for our colleagues. These may increase over time or the laws and regulations setting forth
any exonerations or other exemptions from payment of such charges from which we currently benefit may change,
increasing our liabilities.

We maintain a defined contribution pension plan that covers current and former colleagues pursuant to which
the employer, employee or both make contributions on a regular basis to such plans. See “Management’s Discussion
_and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—_
_Asda Group Pension Scheme Buy-In.” Any of the foregoing may affect our profitability and may have a material_
adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. If we are not able to pass on such higher
costs to our customers, these higher labour costs could materially adversely affect our profitability.

Third parties that licence our proprietary rights may also take actions that diminish the value of our proprietary rights

resources. Moreover, the steps we take to protect our intellectual property may not adequately protect our rights or

services and continue to develop our online channel. We may also face claims from our suppliers if they consider that

prevent us from selling some of our products and/or services. In addition, the resolution of claims may require us to
abandon the sale or provision of the litigious product or service, redesign our own private-label products or acquire
licence rights from third parties, which could have a material adverse impact on our business, results of operations
and financial condition.

**_Robbery, shop crime and fraud in our stores may adversely affect us._**

We, like other grocers, have increasingly become the target of robberies, burglaries and theft across our
stores. We have witnessed the rate of such crimes increase (in volume and frequency) recently, which may be linked
to the continuing cost of living crisis in the United Kingdom. We and are our personnel are exposed to safety threats
such as theft, assault or destruction of property. Higher crime rates throughout the United Kingdom could negatively
our sales and operations. Despite our efforts to reduce our exposure to such crimes, for instance through security
guards or security cameras on our sites, we expect to continue to be exposed to such crimes and new forms of crime.
There can be no assurance that our current or future efforts to counteract crimes will be effective or that the cost of
such efforts will not increase. In addition, we have been the target of other forms of crime such as, fraud and
embezzlement by our colleagues. Any crime we become victim of may give rise to litigation and related costs,
including reputational costs and the costs linked to the diversion of the attention from our management team from
day-to-day operations of our business. A single significant incident of fraud, or increases in the overall level of fraud,
may be sufficient to result in significant reputational damage to us or could lead to the imposition of regulatory
sanctions. Our inability to control and reduce robberies, whether intentional or not, burglaries, fraud, embezzlement
or other forms of crime in a cost-effective manner could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial
condition, liquidity, results of operations and prospects.

**_Certain activities of our business are seasonal or cyclical in nature, and our revenue, working capital requirements_**
**_and results of operations may vary from quarter to quarter as a result._**

Our sales, profits, working capital requirements and cash flows within any given year have historically been
affected by seasonal fluctuations. For example, sales volumes have historically been higher in the run-up to the
Christmas and Easter holidays and historically lower in February. In addition, sales of certain of our products have
historically been higher during the summer tourist season. These seasonal influences have a direct impact on our
earnings, and fluctuations in our inventory or store closings during these peak periods could affect our working capital
requirements. If seasonal fluctuations are greater than anticipated, there could be a material adverse effect on our
business, financial condition and results of operations. Our quarterly results of operations may also fluctuate
significantly as a result of other factors, including the timing of new store openings, temporary or definitive closings

65


-----

or disposals, and the revenue contributed by new stores or the loss of revenue from closed or sold stores. For these
reasons, sequential quarterly comparisons may not be a good indication of our performance or how we may perform
in the future. For a further discussion of the impact of seasonality on our business, see “Management’s Discussion
_and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—_
_Seasonality of Our Results of Operations.”_

**_We are exposed to payments risks, including processing risks, increases in transaction fees, actions taken by third_**
**_parties that could disrupt our operations, failure by us or third parties on whom we rely to fully comply with rules_**
**_and standards governing payment processing, and system failures and security breaches._**

We are reliant on electronic payment methods. We accept payments using credit and debit cards, gift cards,
contactless, PayPal, Android Pay and Apple Pay. As we offer new payment options to customers, we and our
customers may be increasingly exposed to fraud (although fraud is not currently a significant concern). For existing
and future payment options we offer our customers, we may become subject to additional regulations and compliance
requirements (including obligations to implement enhanced authentication processes that could result in significant
costs and reduce the ease of use of our payments products). We pay interchange and other fees for these card payments,
which may increase over time and raise operating costs and lower margins. Interchange fees on Visa and MasterCard
are regulated and are therefore currently subject to an effective minimum amount, which is beyond our control.
Interchange fees on American Express payments are negotiated with American Express on an arm’s-length basis. We
rely on third parties to provide payment processing services, and it could disrupt our operations if these companies
become unwilling or unable to provide these services. We are also subject to payment card association operating rules,
certification requirements, PCI-DSS and rules governing electronic funds transfers, which could change or be
reinterpreted, making them difficult or impossible to comply with. If we fail to comply with these rules or
requirements, we may be subject to fines and/or higher transaction fees and, in extreme cases, may lose our ability to
accept payments from customers, process electronic funds transfers or facilitate other types of online payments. See
also “—We rely extensively on information systems to process transactions, summarise results and manage our
_business. These systems are interdependent and disruptions in the IT infrastructure that we use could materially_
_adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.”_

Any failure of our payment processing systems, whether caused by a systems failure or otherwise, will
adversely affect our income in the short-term and may result in us losing customers which may have a material adverse
effect on our financial condition and prospects. In addition, there can be no assurance that advances in computer
capabilities, new discoveries in the field of cryptography, or other events or developments will not result in a
compromise or breach of the processes we use to protect customer transaction data. If any such compromise or breach
were to occur, it could have a material adverse effect on our reputation, business, prospects, financial condition and
results of operations.

In certain circumstances, our contract with our payment card acquirer and American Express generally
require us to adhere to payment card network rules which could make us liable to payment card issuers and others if
information in connection with payment cards and payment card transactions that we process is compromised. In such
cases, resulting liabilities could be substantial.

**_We may from time to time pursue acquisitions, which may prove more costly than anticipated and may not generate_**
**_anticipated synergies and which may have an adverse impact on our business, as could our failure to successfully_**
**_integrate such businesses following acquisition. Our business could also be negatively impacted by merger control_**
**_rules and antitrust limitations imposed by supranational and national laws and regulations._**

We have in the past acquired and may in the future from time to time acquire other companies or businesses.
Pursuing future acquisitions depends on, among other things, identifying suitable acquisition or investment
opportunities and successfully completing those transactions. Acquisitions involve numerous risks, any of which could
harm our business, including difficulties in integrating the technologies, operations, existing contracts and personnel
of an acquired company; difficulties in supporting and transitioning vendors, if any, of an acquired company; diversion
of financial and management resources from existing operations or alternative acquisition opportunities; failure to
realise the anticipated benefits or synergies of a transaction; failure to identify all of the problems, liabilities or other
shortcomings or challenges of an acquired company or technology, including issues related to intellectual property,
regulatory compliance practices, revenue recognition or other accounting practices or colleague or customer issues;
risks of entering new markets in which we have limited or no experience; potential loss of key colleagues, customers

66


-----

and suppliers from either our current business or an acquired company’s business; inability to generate sufficient
revenue to offset acquisition costs; additional costs associated with funding the acquisition; and possible write-offs or
impairment charges relating to acquired businesses. Furthermore, acquisitions of businesses outside of our markets
may present additional challenges due to cultural and linguistic differences and the difficulties presented by integrating
and managing a business that is geographically more remote. Our ability to integrate and manage acquired businesses
effectively and to handle any future growth will depend upon a number of factors, and failure to manage growth
effectively could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. See also “—
_Risks Relating to Our Acquisitions—We may not be able to successfully integrate the businesses we have recently_
_acquired into our business.”_

In addition, the growth of our business to date, and our future growth, has placed and is expected to continue
to place significant demands on our management and operational and financial infrastructure. Managing growth has
in the past and will in the future continue to require significant expenditure and allocation of management resources,
as well as an expansion in headcount. If we fail to achieve the necessary level of efficiency as we continue to grow,
there could be a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. See also “—We
_depend on the services of our senior management team, and our business and growth strategy could be materially_
_adversely impacted if we were to lose a significant number of members of our senior management and were unable to_
_replace them with executives of equal experience and capabilities.”_

Acquisitions may also increase our indebtedness, both through debt incurred to finance the acquisition and
existing indebtedness of the acquired company, which could make it more difficult to incur additional indebtedness.
Any increase in indebtedness in connection with an acquisition may have a material adverse effect on us. See “—
_Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes—We may incur additional debt in the future,_
_which may make it difficult for us to service our debt, including the Senior Secured Notes, and impact our ability to_
_operate our businesses.”_

Moreover, merger control rules and antitrust limitations imposed by national laws and regulations could
negatively impact our business if such laws and regulations prevent us from expanding our growth through the
consummation of mergers or acquisitions in certain categories or oblige us to divest certain stores or activities that
may have an impact on our market shares in some geographical areas. For example, in order to address competitive
concerns raised by the Competition and Markets Authority (“CMA”), we agreed to divest 13 sites in connection with
the Arthur Acquisition. At the same time, if smaller players in our markets are able to consolidate, this could increase
the competitive pressure on our business due to an increase in such competitors’ economies of scale and a reduction
in their operating costs. Moreover, our competitors might acquire smaller players in our markets, further strengthening
their position in the market. These events could cause our business, financial condition and results of operations to be
materially and adversely affected. See “—We are susceptible to claims of anti-competitive practices.”

**_We are susceptible to claims of anti-competitive practices._**

Part of our overall strategy is to be a leader in our business sectors. We may be accused of anti-competitive
practices based on our conduct and taking into account our market position. Any such claims could materially
adversely affect our reputation, potentially result in legal proceedings that could have an impact on our business,
financial condition and results of operations and require us to divest assets. Such claims could also impair our ability
to conduct acquisitions accretive to our business. For example, in 2023, we were part of a CMA fuel pricing market
study which resulted in a fine to Asda related to the delayed provision of information. Before certain potential future
acquisitions can be consummated, we may also be required to seek approvals and consents from regulatory agencies
or there may be applicable waiting periods that will need to expire. We may be unable to obtain such regulatory
approvals or consents, or, in order to obtain them, we may be required to dispose of assets or take other actions that
could have the effect of reducing our return on potential future acquisitions. For example, in order to address
competitive concerns raised by the CMA, we agreed to divest 13 sites in connection with the Arthur Acquisition. Even
if regulatory authorities do not require disposals or other actions, the regulatory approval process may have the effect
of delaying our ability to implement potential future acquisitions. See also “—We are subject to extensive, increasingly
_stringent and frequently changing laws and regulations and increased scrutiny from regulators and enforcement_
_authorities, including in relation to advertising, food and product safety, health and safety matters and the_
_environment, and both compliance and non-compliance therewith could impose substantial liabilities and costs and_
_have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.”_

**_A loss of key personnel or of our ability to attract and retain experienced members of management, qualified_**

We rely on our senior management as one of our major competitive strengths. Our success depends, in part,
upon the continued services of our senior management team to operate our business and execute our strategies. Our
senior management’s knowledge of the market, our businesses and our company represent a key strength of our
business model. The success of our business strategy and our future growth also depend on our ability to attract, train,
retain and motivate skilled colleagues, managerial, sales, administration, development and operating personnel. There

**_Increased criminal sophistication to facilitate human trafficking and modern slavery may lead to our business_**
**_operations being infiltrated and abused more often for the illegal purpose of exploiting vulnerable individuals._**

Because of our dependency on cross-continental goods transport and the type of operations such as food
packaging manufacturing that are well-documented targets for exploitation schemes by criminals, there is a risk that
criminals will continue to attempt to conduct their exploitative schemes undetected within our supply chain or business
operations. We have dealt with occasional incidents of modern slavery and human trafficking in recent years, and we
believe that these criminal acts in general across any business sector in the United Kingdom will continue to exist and
may increase. If we are unable to identify, act and remediate third party criminal acts quickly then, despite not having
acted illegally ourselves, there is a significant risk of negative publicity.

**Risks Relating to Asda Pharmacy and Asda Opticians**

**_Certain risks are inherent in providing pharmacy services, our insurance may not be adequate to cover any claims_**
**_against us and may cause us reputational harm._**

As of December 31, 2023, we operate 247 pharmacies and, as a result, we are exposed to risks inherent in
the packaging, dispensing, distribution and disposal of pharmaceuticals and other healthcare products, such as risks
of liability for products which cause harm to customers, as well as increased regulatory risks and related costs and
reputational risks. We cannot guarantee that the coverage limits under our insurance programmes will be adequate to
protect us against future claims, or that we will be able to maintain this insurance on acceptable terms in the future, or
at all. Our results of operations, financial condition or cash flows may be materially adversely affected if in the future
our insurance coverage proves to be inadequate or unavailable, or there is an increase in the liability for which we
self-insure, or we suffer harm to our reputation as a result of an error or omission.

We are subject to numerous government regulations. Each of our in-store pharmacies must be registered with
the General Pharmaceutical Council (or the Pharmaceutical Society of Northern Ireland in Northern Ireland).
Additionally, before a registered pharmacy can dispense prescriptions under the National Health Service, it must be
included in the pharmaceutical list relating to a Health and Wellbeing Board Area, maintained by NHS England, NHS
Scotland or NHS Wales and maintained by the Family Practitioner Services in Northern Ireland. In addition,
pharmacies dispensing controlled substances are required to maintain records of sale and supply and report incidents
to the NHS. If we fail to comply with existing or future laws and regulations, we could be in breach of professional
standards and/or NHS terms of service, which could lead to a hierarchy of penalties up to and including the loss of
such pharmacy’s registration. Each pharmacy therefore has a responsible pharmacist to ensure it operates in a safe and
legal manner and corporate-wide this responsibility is shared by the Superintendent Pharmacist.

Application of laws and regulations could subject our current practices to allegations of impropriety or
illegality or could require us to make changes to our operations. In addition, we cannot predict the impact of future

68


-----

legislation and regulatory changes on our pharmacy business or assure that we will be able to obtain or maintain the
regulatory approvals required to operate our business.

**_Changes in results of our pharmacy business could materially adversely affect overall results._**

A majority of our retail pharmacy revenue is generated by filling prescriptions for which we receive payment
from the NHS. We also generate revenue through providing NHS services, private services and the sale of
over-the-counter medicines that can only be sold from a registered pharmacy by a pharmacist or a person acting under
the supervision of a pharmacist.

Our retail pharmacy operations are subject to numerous risks, including: changes in availability, pricing, and
safety profiles of prescription drugs that we purchase and sell, changes in NHS reimbursement for prescription drugs;
a reduction in the pharmacy global sum leading to reduced retained purchase margins available for pharmacy in
England; a reduction in dispensing activity payments; the introduction of new NHS services; and a move away from
reimbursement for dispensing prescription drugs; increased competition from other retail pharmacy operations,
including online; overall economic conditions; and changes in the regulatory environment for the retail pharmacy
industry and the pharmaceutical industry, and other changes in laws, rules and regulations that affect our retail
pharmacy business.

If the supply of certain pharmaceuticals provided by one or more of our vendors were to be disrupted for any
reason, we would in turn have to seek a new supplier for such pharmaceuticals, with related risks of shortages or
delays in our own pharmacy operations. Any such disruption could cause reputational damage and result in a number
of our pharmacy customers transferring their prescriptions to other pharmacies. One or a combination of such factors
may adversely affect the volumes of prescriptions we dispense, our cost of sales associated with our retail pharmacy
operations, and the revenue and gross margin of those operations or result in the loss of cross-store selling
opportunities and, in turn, affect our overall revenue, other results of operations, cash flows and liquidity.

**_Certain risks are inherent in providing optometry services, and our insurance may not be adequate to cover any_**
**_claims against us._**

As of December 31, 2023, we operate Opticians in 157 stores and in all four nations of the United Kingdom.
We also have an online site supplying powered contact lenses under the “general direction” of a registered optometrist,
suitably qualified dispensing optician or medical practitioner. The majority of our revenue is from the sale of
spectacles and eye examinations.

We are regulated by the General Optical Council (“GOC”). To operate in the United Kingdom and use the
title “Opticians” we have to be registered as a Body Corporate with the GOC and therefore are subject to the GOC
Business Standards as well as the Opticians Act 1989. It is a requirement of the GOC that any Body Corporates which
do not have GOC registrants as the majority of their Board, must have a Responsible Officer (Superintendent
Optometrist) in position. All Optometrists and Opticians also have to be registered with the GOC to be able to practice
and they are subject to the GOC Professional Standards as well as the Opticians Act 1989. Breaches to the GOC
standards could lead to warnings, fines, sanctions on practice up to being removed from the GOC register either as a
business or individual and unable to practice.

All of our optical departments also hold a contract with the NHS Integrated Care Boards or Health Board to
be able to provide NHS services. Breaches of the terms within such contracts can lead to penalties, including up to
revoking such contract and stopping us providing NHS services. These penalties can occur at the store level, regional
level or national level. Since 78% of our eye examinations were funded by the NHS in 2023, any penalties or stoppage
in NHS services would have a material adverse impact on our business.

Our Optometrists in all four nations also have to be registered on an NHS performer’s listing to be able to
provide NHS eye examinations. In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland, some of our stores also conduct additional
NHS services which are commissioned at a local level, which requires such stores to abide by additional NHS standard
contracts with local service level agreements. In Wales, Optometrists also need to have Wales Eye Care Services
(WECS) accreditation and completed Wales General Ophthalmic Services (WGOS) training to be registered as a
performer on the NHS performers list.

Changes in the regulatory environment for the optical industry and other changes in laws, rules, NHS contract
terms and regulations may also have an effect on our operating and commercial model.

The provision of professional eye care services entails an inherent risk of professional malpractice and other
similar claims. We may become subject to professional malpractice regulatory or NHS actions or claims under various
theories relating to the professional services provided by our departments. This could also lead to a public relations
and/or reputational risk both at the local and national level. We may not be able to continue to obtain adequate liability
insurance at reasonable rates, in which event, the cost could require us to exit this offering, as insurance is a regulatory
requirement for both a Body Corporate and individual registrants. Furthermore, our insurance may not be adequate to
cover claims asserted against us, thus, potentially decreasing our future cash position.

If the glazing supply provided by our main Optical vendor was to be disrupted for any reason, our Optical
operations could be severely affected until at least such time as we could transfer to a new glazing manufacturer. Any
such disruption could cause reputational damage and result in a number of our Optical customers transferring their
purchases to other Opticians. This may adversely affect the volumes of glasses we dispense, our cost of sales
associated with our Optical operations, and the revenue and gross margin of those operations.

**Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters**

**_From time to time we and/or our management are subject to claims that can result in litigation, arbitration, tax or_**
**_regulatory proceedings which could distract management from our business activities and result in significant_**
**_liability._**

We may be subject to legal and regulatory enquiries or investigations, both civil and criminal, that could
divert management time and resources and result in fines, taxes, sanctions, variation or revocation of permissions and
authorisations, as well as reputational damage. For example, from time to time, we and/or our management are
involved in litigation, tax audits, claims and other proceedings related to the conduct of our business, including, but
not limited to, claims from our current and former employees, claims of intellectual property infringement, claims
from customers (such as for injuries at our premises), claims asserting unfair competition and unfair business practices
by third parties and environmental, health and safety claims (including, for example, related to the presence of asbestos
in any of our properties). We could face a wide variety of employee claims, including general discrimination, privacy,
labour and employment and disability claims.

For example, Asda Stores Limited has been served with approximately 52,923 employment tribunal claims
(the “Equal Value Claims”) that began in 2008 and are proceeding before an Employment Tribunal in Manchester
(the “Employment Tribunal”) in the United Kingdom on behalf of current and former Asda store employees, and
further claims may be asserted in the future. There are also 8,147 claims filed in the High Court which are stayed
pending the outcome of the Equal Value Claims. The claimants allege that the work performed by employees in Asda’s
retail stores is of equal value in terms of, among other things, the demands of their jobs compared to that of employees
working in Asda’s warehouse and distribution facilities, and that the difference in pay between these job positions
disparately impacts women because more women work in retail stores while more men work in warehouses and
distribution facilities, and that the pay difference is not objectively justified. The claimants are requesting differential
back pay based on higher wage rates in the warehouse and distribution facilities and higher wage rates on a prospective
basis.

In October 2016, following a preliminary hearing, the Employment Tribunal ruled that claimants could
compare their positions in Asda’s retail stores with those of employees in Asda’s warehouse and distribution facilities.
On March 26, 2021, the Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal’s decision, that the work of hourly-paid workers
in distribution centres and the work of hourly-paid workers in stores can be compared.

The litigation is currently in the equal value stage when the Employment Tribunal Claimants are proceeding
in the next phase of their claims. That phase will determine whether the work performed by the claimants is of equal
value to the work performed by employees in Asda’s warehouse and distribution facilities. The equal value hearing is
scheduled to take place from September 9, 2024 to December 13, 2024 at the Manchester Employment Tribunal.

At present, we cannot predict the number of such claims that may be filed and cannot reasonably estimate
any loss or range of loss that may arise from these proceedings. Accordingly, we can provide no assurance as to the

70


-----

scope and outcomes of these matters and any losses that may arise from these proceedings could have a material
adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations or cash flows. See “Business—Legal
_Proceedings—Equal Value Litigation.”_

Any claims could result in litigation against us and could also result in regulatory proceedings being brought
against us by various governmental agencies. Often these cases raise complex factual, accounting and legal issues,
which are subject to risks and uncertainties and which could require significant management time and legal expenses.
Litigation and claims and regulatory proceedings against us or our management could result in unexpected expenses
and liability and could also materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. Even
if we were successful in defending such proceedings, we could still suffer from the distraction of management
resources to such proceedings, incur certain expenses and possibly face harm to our reputation from case-related
publicity. The involvement in litigation and arbitration proceedings could have a material adverse effect on our
business, results of operations and financial condition. See “Business—Legal Proceedings.”

**_We are subject to extensive, increasingly stringent and frequently changing laws and regulations and increased_**
**_scrutiny from regulators and enforcement authorities, including in relation to advertising, food and product safety,_**
**_health and safety matters and the environment, and both compliance and non-compliance therewith could impose_**
**_substantial liabilities and costs and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results_**
**_of operations._**

In the ordinary course of our business, our operations and properties are subject to increasingly stringent laws
and regulations relating to, among other things, labour, competition, imports and exports, advertising, customer
protection, alcohol and tobacco licencing, supplier relations, planning approvals for the opening of new stores,
business operations, product safety, intermediation in customer credit and insurance, information technology, store
safety and accessibility and health, safety and environment. Moreover, some of our businesses are subject to specific
regulations, compliance with each of which can be complex and costly or can result in significant cash outflows. These
include compliance with marketing laws and regulations, compliance with pharmaceutical laws and regulations,
compliance with optometry laws and regulations, compliance with e-commerce laws and regulations and compliance
with real estate laws and regulations. Additionally, we are subject to, among other things: telecommunications
regulation, both directly and indirectly; regulations that govern our relationships with our suppliers, limiting our
operational flexibility; and labour and employment laws that regulate the human resources implications of any
proposals to restructure our business, our colleagues’ working conditions, maximum working hours and, in certain
jurisdictions, the ability to have stores open 24 hours a day or work on Sundays. We may be subject to audits and/or
inquiries into our labour law practices by competent authorities and enforcement costs and penalties can be significant.
Any claims could result in litigation against the Group and could also result in regulatory or legal proceedings and
fines being brought against the Group. For example, in 2023, the CMA fined Asda £60,000 in connection with a
market-wide fuel pricing market study. Often these cases raise complex factual, accounting and legal issues, which
are subject to risks and uncertainties and which could require significant management time, legal expenses and
exposure to financial penalty. In addition, the CMA introduced the Green Claims Code, and in 2022, launched
investigations into George and other non-Asda apparel brands for eco-friendly and sustainability claims made about
their fashion products, including clothing, footwear, and accessories. For more information see “Business—
_Regulation—Competition and Markets Authority—Green Claims Code,” and “Business—Legal Proceedings—_
_Environmental Claims Matter.”_

We are also subject to the Groceries Supply Code of Practice (“GSCOP”), a statute governing the largest
UK food retailers which requires these retailers to treat their suppliers fairly, lawfully and in good faith. The proposed
fines for breaching the legislation may be up to 1% of the breaching retailer’s turnover. Even if no fines are assessed,
a finding of breach by the Groceries Code Adjudicator responsible for enforcing the GSCOP may cause negative
publicity and damage our image, reputation or brand, which could have a material adverse effect on our business,
financial condition and results of operations. Additionally, we are subject to the Groceries Market Investigation
(Controlled Land) Order 2010 (the “Controlled Land Order”), which is legislation administered by the CMA and
designed to limit the ability of large grocery retailers to prevent land being used by their competitors for grocery
retailing in the future.

Prior to the LBO Acquisition, we purchased our electricity on a wholesale basis via a dedicated subsidiary,
which sold the electricity back into Asda. These electricity purchases are regulated by the Office of Gas and Electricity
Markets (“OFGEM”), which is the government regulator for gas and electricity markets in Great Britain. Since

71


-----

March 2021, we have purchased our electricity on a retail basis facilitated through a third-party agent. Therefore, since
the regulations relating to wholesale electricity purchases do not apply to the retail purchases made since March 2021,
we have navigated the process of revoking the electricity supply license with the help of a consultancy firm. This
process has confirmed that we have met of our obligations and we have no liabilities outstanding. In addition, we are
subject to regulation by the Office of Communications (“OFCOM”), an independent regulator and competition
authority for the UK communications industries, which regulates selling practices for mobile telecommunication
services and changes to mobile termination rates, among other things.

The FCA is responsible for the regulation of insurance and customer credit-related activities in the United
Kingdom. Firms carrying on such activities in the United Kingdom must generally be authorised by the FCA with
appropriate permissions, and FCA authorised firms are subject to ongoing regulation and supervision by the FCA. In
connection with distributing the Asda Money suite of white-labelled financial services products, Asda Stores Limited
is authorised by the FCA with limited permission to carry out credit broking, and both Asda Stores Limited and Asda
Financial Services Limited are registered with the FCA as introducer appointed representatives of a number of
third-party insurance and credit product providers. Any failures in or inadequate controls around the customer
introduction process for those regulated financial services products, or any technical deficiencies in the arrangements
with such third-party insurance and credit product providers, could in principle result in regulatory investigations and
related costs and penalties, as well as reputational damage.

Additionally, as a retailer and manufacturer of food products for human consumption, we are subject to
stringent production, packing, health, quality, labelling and distribution standards. Each of our stores and our
suppliers’ facilities may be subject to licencing, reporting requirements and official quality controls by numerous
governmental authorities. Difficulties in obtaining or failure to obtain the necessary licences or approvals could delay
or prevent the development or operation of a given retail location or distribution centre. Our stores and our distribution
centres are subject to regular inspection by authorities for compliance with hygiene regulations applicable to the sale,
storage and manufacturing of foodstuffs and the traceability of genetically modified organisms, meats and other raw
materials. Should any non-compliance with such regulations be discovered during an inspection, authorities may
temporarily shut down the store, distribution centre or facility concerned and/or result in prosecution and the
imposition of a fine for such non-compliance which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition and results of operations.

Further, we are subject to various environmental and health and safety requirements, including those
governing discharges to water and air, waste disposal, the clean-up of contaminated sites, product content and labelling
and worker health and safety. We could incur substantial costs, including clean-up obligations, fines, penalties and
other criminal and civil sanctions, and third-party claims for personal injury or property damage, as a result of
violations of our liabilities under these requirements. For example, we own and operate service stations, which include
significant storage of petrol, liquified natural gas or other hazardous materials, and many of our sites store fuel for use
in backup generators and, as a result, we are subject to a variety of legislation governing the use, management, storage
and disposal of hazardous substances, wastes and other regulated materials, such as petroleum and petroleum products,
and any environmental impacts from current or historical operations at such locations. Our operations and facilities
also require permits and authorisations under environmental, health and safety requirements, which are subject to
renewal, modification and rescission by issuing authorities. We also may be required to incur substantial capital or
other costs to comply with such requirements or those that are promulgated in the future.

In addition, we could be sued for health problems caused by the use of tobacco products. In fact, various
health related legal actions, proceedings and claims arising out of the sale, distribution, manufacturing, development,
advertising and marketing of cigarettes have been brought against vendors of tobacco products in the United States.
If this trend progressed to the United Kingdom, any unfavourable verdict against us in a health-related suit could
adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.

From time to time, we may be notified of or otherwise become aware of additional laws and regulations that
governmental organisations or others may claim should be applicable to our business. Compliance with future
requirements could result in substantial costs to us. Failure to comply with any such laws or regulations could subject
us to sanctions which could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition or results of operations. Future
changes in such laws and regulations could also have a material adverse effect on our financial condition or results of
operations. The laws and regulations to which we are subject frequently change, which may materially impact our
business operations, and our failure to comply with such laws can result in significant fines and other penalties. See

**_We are subject to regulations relating to the implementation of the exit of the United Kingdom from the European_**
**_Union._**

Since January 1, 2021, the United Kingdom has been trading as an independent country outside of the
European Union following the UK electorate voting in favour of leaving the European Union (commonly referred to
as “Brexit”) in June 2016 and the conclusion of a new trading agreement between the European Union and the United
Kingdom which was entered into in December 2020. This means that new regulations are in place governing the
import and export of goods between the United Kingdom and the European Union from this date which places a
greater cost and administrative burden on us. For example, from April 30, 2024, physical, documentary and identity
checks at the border are scheduled to be required for medium-risk animal products, plants and plant products, such as
chilled and frozen meat, fish, cheese, eggs, dairy products and certain cut flowers and seeds, imported to United
Kingdom from the European Union. There are also additional regulations in place governing tariffs for products of
non-EU origin when they are exported across the border from the United Kingdom to the European Union which also
can place a greater cost and administrative burden on us. The UK government may implement additional regulations
governing trade movement into and out of the United Kingdom which could have a negative impact on our business,
financial condition and results of operations.

We are a UK business. The Brexit administration requirements could mean that the United Kingdom will
suffer as a result of losing commercially favourable access to the EU single market, or specific countries in the
European Union, further resulting in a negative impact on the general and economic conditions in the United Kingdom
and the European Union which could in turn have a negative impact on our business, financial condition and results
of operations. Additionally, since we operate 18 stores in Northern Ireland, Brexit has had an additional impact on our
business, results of operation and prospects due to new bureaucratic hurdles and the implementation of the Northern
Ireland Retail Movement Scheme on October 1, 2023, which established a new framework for the movement of retail
goods from Great Britain to Northern Ireland. Future changes may occur in regulations that we are required to comply
with as well as amendments to treaties governing but not limited to tax, duties and tariffs, which could adversely
impact our operations and require us to modify our financial and supply arrangements.

**_We collect and process personal data in our daily business, and the leakage of such data may violate law and could_**
**_materially adversely affect our business._**

We are subject to regulations regarding the use of personal data. In the ordinary course of our business, we
collect, process and in some cases store certain personal financial and other information about our customers and
colleagues (some of which may be sensitive, such as information about customers’ dietary preferences or restrictions),
marketing initiatives and the large number of credit and debit transactions we process. For example, we use our Asda
Rewards loyalty programme to leverage data insights about our customers for targeted investment in our business. We
also process sensitive information about our colleagues, including their bank details, union membership and health
status. We must therefore comply with strict data protection, privacy and security laws and regulatory guidance. In
order for our business to function successfully, we must process personal data, including credit and debit card
information in an adequately secure manner. In addition, our online operations depend heavily upon the secure
transmission of confidential information over public networks, including the use of cashless payments. We rely on

third-party service providers to process customer payments made using debit cards and credit cards. See also “Risks

_operations, failure by us or third parties on whom we rely to fully comply with rules and standards governing payment_
_processing, and system failures and security breaches.”_

The use and handling of this personal information is regulated by evolving and increasingly demanding laws
and regulations at the national and international levels, as well as by certain third-party contracts. The legal and
regulatory frameworks governing the use and handling of personal information are relatively new in our markets and
are still evolving. Any failure or perceived failure by us or any of our third-party service providers to comply with our
policies or with any other privacy related laws, regulations, industry self-regulatory principles, industry standards or
codes of conduct, regulatory guidance, orders to which we may be subject or other legal obligations could materially
adversely affect our reputation and brands and may result in claims, fines (including by card merchants), civil or
criminal proceedings or actions against us by governmental entities or others. For example, we are subject to the UK
GDPR which became applicable on January 31, 2020. The UK GDPR is almost identical to the EU GDPR, which
strengthens existing rights, provides for new rights and gives customers and colleagues increased control over their
personal data, including the requirement for data collectors to process and use personal information solely for the
reasons for which they were collected. Laws, such as the UK GDPR, restrict our ability to collect and use personal
information relating to individuals including the use of that information for marketing purposes. We rely on our own
colleagues to maintain our databases and seek to ensure that procedures are in place to ensure compliance (including
that we maintain proper privacy notices). Non-compliance with the UK GDPR could result in a possible fine of up to
either £17.5 million or 4% of total worldwide annual turnover for the preceding financial year, whichever is higher,

_inadequate designed processes, failure of IT or other systems, improper conduct by colleagues and third parties,_

Moreover, even if we are compliant with such laws and requirements, we may not be able to prevent security

Laws and regulations relating to privacy, data protection, customer protection and the digital advertising

**_We are exposed to the risk of violations of anti-corruption laws, sanctions or other similar regulations._**

We must comply with certain anti-corruption laws or other similar regulations. We operate in certain parts

Violations of such laws can result in civil penalties, including fines, denial of export privileges, injunctions,

consequences that we may suffer due to the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition and results of operations.

**_Changes in tax rates or laws, tax liabilities or tax accounting rules could affect future results._**

We are subject to complex tax laws in the United Kingdom and have historically been subject to international
tax laws in connection with international sales of the George Clothing and George Home products. Changes in (or
changes in interpretations of) tax treaties, tax laws or regulations or tax authority guidance could materially adversely
affect our tax position, including our effective tax rate or tax payments, possibly with a retroactive effect. Our effective
tax rate and tax liability will be affected by a number of factors in addition to our results of operations, accounting
standards and changes in accounting standards, and future changes in the law. If our tax positions are challenged by
relevant tax authorities, the imposition of additional taxes could require us to pay taxes that we currently do not collect
or pay or increase the costs of our services to track and collect such taxes, which could increase our costs of operations
or our effective tax rate and have a negative effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations. For
example, in the United Kingdom, if the tax authority concluded that VAT was chargeable on a particular supply on
which we did not charge VAT to customers, we would be liable to account for such VAT. The occurrence of any of

76


-----

the foregoing tax risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of
operations.

In the jurisdictions in which we operate, governments might centrally adjust the value of business rates in
the property market. For instance, in the United Kingdom, the government adjusts the value of business rates to reflect
changes in the property market approximately every five years. The most recent revaluation came into effect in
England, Scotland and Wales on April 1, 2023 (based on rateable values from April 1, 2021). At revaluation, all
properties are given a new rateable value which, depending on the underlying movement in the value of the property,
can have an adverse impact on the tax liability due on the property. Adjustments to business rates could result in
increased costs and consequently could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results
of operations.

Further, legislation has been enacted or is currently under consideration in a number of jurisdictions to adopt
and implement Pillar Two of the base erosion and profit shifting (“BEPS”) project initiated by the Organization for
Economic Cooperation and Development (“OECD”), which is designed to introduce a global minimum tax rate of
15% for certain multinational groups. In December 2021 and March 2022, the OECD published model rules and
related commentary to support member jurisdictions of the G20/OECD Inclusive Framework on BEPS (including the
United Kingdom) to implement the Pillar Two framework. For example, the United Kingdom government has
legislated to implement the Pillar Two income inclusion rule by introducing a “domestic top-up tax” and a
“multinational top-up tax” for certain large multinational and UK groups for accounting periods beginning on or after
December 31, 2023. The legislation applies to certain multinational and UK groups with annual group revenue
exceeding €750 million. Broadly, the “domestic top-up tax” may be assessed inter alia on UK located qualifying
entities of a qualifying group where the effective tax rate (“ETR”) of all UK members of the relevant group is less
than 15%. Further, the “multinational top-up tax” may be assessed inter alia on a UK responsible member (typically,
the ultimate parent, or where the ultimate parent is not in a territory which has implemented Pillar 2, the most senior
group member in such a territory) of a qualifying multinational group where members have an ETR of less than 15%
(as determined under the applicable rules) to the extent that a qualifying domestic top-up tax has not otherwise been
collected. Based on initial analysis undertaken by the Group, the Pillar Two transitional safe harbour is expected to
apply for each relevant territory and an election will be made such that no top-up tax charge is expected to arise in
respect of the accounting period ended December 31, 2024. If this were not to be the case, and the ETR of the Pillar
Two group members were to be at any point less than 15%, it is possible that Pillar Two top-up taxes could be assessed
on the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and/or other members of the Group. Further changes related to Pillar Two are
expected to be implemented in the United Kingdom and in other jurisdictions in which we do business. The timing
and ultimate impact of any such changes on our tax obligations remains uncertain and will continue to be monitored
by the Group.

on which tax authorities have taken different views or from which disputes have arisen or may arise, which if
unfavourably determined may require us to pay settlement amounts, assessment amounts, interest, fees or penalties,
which may adversely impact our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_Limitation of Valuations – Property valuations are inherently subjective and uncertain and are based on_**
**_assumptions which may prove to be inaccurate. We cannot assure you that the projections or assumptions used,_**
**_estimates made or procedures followed in the third-party valuation report of our portfolio of real estate assets are_**
**_correct, accurate or complete._**

Property valuations are inherently subjective and uncertain and are based on assumptions which may prove
to be inaccurate. We cannot assure you that the projections or assumptions used, estimates made or procedures
followed in the third-party valuation report of our portfolio of real estate assets are correct, accurate or complete. As
a result, the valuation report presents the external valuer’s best estimate of the value of the Group’s properties subject
to the assumptions and Special Assumptions set out above.

This Offering Memorandum refers to the CBRE Report with respect to certain of the real estate portfolio
owned by Asda. Valuation of property and property-related assets is inherently subjective and uncertain, in part
because all property valuations are made on the basis of information and assumptions which may not prove to be
accurate, and in part because of the individual nature of each property. Property valuations are complex, involve the
use of data which is not publicly available and involve a degree of subjective professional judgement by the valuers.
In valuing properties, the valuers are required to make certain key assumptions in respect of matters including, but not
limited to, the existence of willing buyers, title to the property, condition of structure and services, deleterious
materials, environmental matters, legal matters, statutory and regulatory requirements and planning, estimated market
rental values, market-based yields, expected future rental revenues from the property, where relevant potential future
trading performance, and other factors. In respect of properties which may require development, redevelopment or
refurbishment, the development considered achievable, assumed timescale, the assumed future development cost and
an appropriate finance rate and profit rate and/or discount rate are also used to determine the property value together
with market evidence and recent comparable properties where appropriate.

The adoption of different assumptions would be likely to produce different valuation results. The assumptions
made may prove to be inaccurate or not borne out by future events and could negatively affect the valuation of the
properties.

The CBRE Report was furthermore produced on a desktop basis and without visual inspection of Asda’s
properties. Where properties have not been inspected, the valuer will not carry out the usual range of enquiries
performed during a full inspection of properties and will make the appropriate assumptions based on the information
provided or available that, without a full inspection, cannot be verified. The instructing parties have acknowledged
and accepted the heightened and inherent uncertainty and risks relying upon a valuation prepared on a desktop basis.
The CBRE Report is thus based on information provided by management and certain assumptions, including, but not
limited to, the assumptions that (i) our properties are not adversely affected by any existing or proposed environmental
law and are free from, environmental issues such as contamination, deleterious materials, flooding, ground conditions,
invasive or protected plants or species and the properties are not adversely affected by any existing or proposed

We have included data for the three months ended March 31, 2024 in order to provide information about our
recent performance but this information should be treated with a higher level of caution for reasons including but not
limited to the fact that management accounts are not prepared with the same level of rigor and are not subject to the
same level of management review and scrutiny as interim or year-end financial information. In addition, we provide
information about for the three months ended March 31, 2024, in accordance with the Group’s accounting policies,
which may differ materially from U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles and/or UK IFRS, in accordance
with which we have prepared the Financial Statements and certain other financial information included in this Offering
Memorandum. Furthermore, management accounts may not provide for closing procedures that are as detailed as
those conducted at period or year end. Additionally, management accounts may be subject to cut-off errors and
misallocation of items between months.

**_We may not have the ability to meet our additional financial and other reporting requirements or implement_**
**_effective systems of internal control and other standards, which may adversely affect our business._**

Our internal controls over financial reporting are intended to ensure we maintain accurate records, promote
the accurate and timely reporting of our financial information, maintain adequate control over our assets, ensure the
independence of our auditors and detect unauthorised acquisition, use or disposition of our assets. Effective internal
and disclosure controls are necessary for us to provide reliable financial reports and to operate successfully as a
business. Our management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal controls.

Any system of controls, however well designed and operated, can provide only reasonable, and not absolute,
assurance that the objectives of the system are met. In addition, the design of any control system is based in part upon
certain assumptions about the likelihood of future events. Because of these and other inherent limitations of control
systems, there can be no assurance that any design will succeed in achieving its stated goals under all potential future
conditions, regardless of how remote. If our internal controls do not keep pace with the size and sophistication of our
businesses and the applicable financial reporting framework, or we fail to successfully integrate the businesses we
acquired as part of the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition, we may not be able to implement and maintain
adequate internal controls. If we fail to implement and maintain effective internal controls, it could result in material
misstatements in our financial statements or failure to meet our reporting obligations in a timely manner, which may
cause a loss of confidence in our reported financial information which could increase our operating costs and
materially impair our ability to operate our business. See also “—Risks Relating to Our Acquisitions—We may not be
_able to successfully integrate the businesses we have recently acquired or will in the future acquire into our business.”_
