Moreover, we may acquire companies or assets which we determine to be complementary to our current
business. Such acquired companies or assets may have insufficient systems of internal control, or otherwise have
defects which we do not discover until we begin to integrate these systems of internal control with ours. We cannot
assure you that we will be successful in integrating these systems of internal control with ours, or that such a task will
be within our initial expectations in terms of costs, resources and time expended.

**_Our non-current assets, primarily goodwill and store-level assets, may not be fully realisable and are subject to_**
**_periodic testing for impairment, and we may incur significant impairment charges as a result._**

Our non-current assets, primarily goodwill and store-level assets, are subject to periodic testing for
impairment. We have recorded a significant amount of goodwill. Total goodwill, which represents the difference
between the consideration paid plus any non-controlling interest and the acquisition date fair value of identifiable net
assets, was £1,182.2 million as of December 31, 2023, or 6% of our consolidated total assets. Within total goodwill,
the Arthur Acquisition resulted in goodwill of £290.5 million, of which £30.4 million has since been allocated to assets
held for sale, and the EG UK Acquisition resulted in goodwill of £922.1 million. The value of any goodwill recorded
on our financial statements may not be fully realisable upon sale of all or part of the business or any other liquidity
event.

Goodwill is recorded on the date of acquisition and, in accordance with UK IFRS, is tested for impairment
annually and whenever there is any indication of impairment. Impairment may result from, among other things,
deterioration in our performance, a decline in expected future cash flows, adverse market conditions, adverse changes
in applicable laws and regulations, any changes in the key assumptions used for internal calculations of values in use
and a variety of other factors. The amount of any impairment must be expensed immediately as a charge to our income
statement. We can give no assurance that we will not record any goodwill impairments in the future. Any future
impairment of goodwill may result in material reductions of our income and equity under UK IFRS.

**Risks Relating to Our Acquisitions**

**_Delays in our ability to separate from Walmart could result in significant cost and any issues with the separation_**
**_process, particularly related to our transition to a new IT system, could significantly disrupt business operations_**
**_and impact our ability to meet our strategic objectives._**

The separation from Walmart is a complex transaction that requires significant management attention and
poses a number of risks including, but not limited to, system cutovers and those related to the implementation of our
new IT infrastructure independent from Walmart.

Prior to the LBO Acquisition, the Asda Group was historically part of the operations of Walmart, which
provided us with operational, financial, and other support, and certain of our accounting and information technology
systems were incorporated in Walmart’s larger operations. As a result of the LBO Acquisition, we became a standalone
company and, accordingly, we have had to develop and implement the systems and infrastructure necessary to support
our current and future business.

On the LBO Acquisition Completion Date, Asda Stores Limited and Walmart entered into the TSA, under which
Walmart undertakes to provide certain information technology services to Asda on a transitional basis (the
“Transitional Services”). The Transitional Services include continuity of IT and communication services and provide
support and facilitate our ability to operate on a standalone basis. Under the TSA, each relevant Transitional Service
is to be supplied by Walmart until the earlier of (i) the migration of the relevant service as part of the separation of
Asda from Walmart, and (ii) the termination of the TSA by Walmart or Asda Stores Limited under certain
circumstances as described under “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional Agreements
_with Walmart—Transitional Services Agreement.” If Walmart terminates the TSA in accordance with its terms or is_
unable or unwilling to provide the Transitional Services as agreed, we may not be able to replace these services at an
acceptable price and in a timely manner, or at all. The Transitional Services include certain IT services which are
provided pursuant to third-party vendor contracts. These services will require the vendor consent to extend the term
of the underlying agreement past the LBO Acquisition Completion Date, and thereafter will have to be renegotiated
with the IT vendor.

81


-----

The complexity of our new IT system and of its implementation means that we may not be able to successfully
transition the systems to our standalone operations under Project Future. See “Risks Relating to Our Business and
_Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—We rely extensively on information systems to process_
_transactions, summarise results and manage our business. These systems are interdependent and disruptions in the_
_IT infrastructure that we use could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial_
_condition.” Any failure to transition successfully within the terms of the applicable Transitional Agreement(s) may_
cause us to incur substantial expenses in addition to the anticipated separation costs and would have a material adverse
effect on our business, financial condition, and results of operations.

At the LBO Completion Date, Walmart and the LBO Seller also entered into several other transitional
agreements with various entities within the Asda Group alongside the TSA. The Transitional Agreements include a
TMA which includes licences of the George, Scan & Go, Smart Price and Rollback trademarks, certain domain names,
including George.com, as well as certain other Walmart-owned trade mark rights used by a member of the Asda Group
between October 2019 and the LBO Acquisition Completion Date. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party
_Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart” for a description of the Transitional Agreements that are still_
in place. In the event any of our service relationships and agreements with Walmart are terminated, we may find it
difficult to find a suitable alternative supplier of such services in a timely fashion or at all. Any of the foregoing could
have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.

**_We may not be able to successfully integrate the businesses we have recently acquired into our business._**

We may not be able to successfully integrate our recent acquisitions, namely the Arthur Acquisition and the
EG UK Acquisition, There is the risk that the integration of these acquisitions could result in significant added
complexity and management distraction, as well as difficulty related to, among other things, the integration of certain
operating and IT systems, including point of sale systems and inventory processing systems, the loss of customers or
key employees, the disruption of our respective ongoing businesses or possible inconsistencies in standards,
procedures and policies. Delays or issues could lead to additional cost which impacts profitability. Furthermore,
certain acquired contracts may have terms and conditions that are weaker than our standard contracts, and we may not
be able to integrate or update them as quickly as we would like or without incurring significant fees. In addition, we
may not have, or be able to retain or hire, employees with the appropriate skill sets for the tasks associated with our
integration plans, particularly in the expected time frame in which we require them, and could experience employee
departures and early retirement due to relevant business changes, all of which could adversely affect the success of
the integration plans. In particular, the loss of key managers or other experienced and knowledgeable local employees,
may result in the loss of knowledge and continuity for the relevant business. The integration process for our
acquisitions, if implemented ineffectively, would restrict the realisation of the full expected benefits, including cost
savings and synergies. Failure to meet the challenges involved in integrating these businesses into our existing business
and to realise the anticipated benefits therefrom could cause an interruption of, or a loss of momentum in, our activities
and could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operation.

In order to fully integrate the financial accounting systems of our acquired businesses, we will also have to
complete the implementation of our own standalone IT system. Prior to the completion of Project Future, the
businesses acquired from the Arthur Acquisition are being migrated onto the IT systems of EG Group. Both the Arthur
Business and the EG UK Business will remain on the IT systems of EG Group for a transitional period, after which,
they will have to be transitioned onto our new system. This has required, and will continue to require, additional
capital investments by us, and may require incremental resources and system configurations that could increase our
operating costs in future periods, as we continue in our ongoing efforts to adjust our control environment to the
standards of a business of our size and scale. See also “—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating
_to Our General Operations—We may from time to time pursue acquisitions, which may prove more costly than_
_anticipated and may not generate anticipated synergies and which may have an adverse impact on our business, as_
_could our failure to successfully integrate such businesses following acquisition. Our business could also be negatively_
_impacted by merger control rules and antitrust limitations imposed by supranational and national laws and_
_regulations.”_

In connection with these acquisitions, we may also face risks related to unforeseen legal or regulatory issues
as we expand our fuel and convenience operations, difficulty in consolidating facilities and infrastructure, and a
diversion of management’s attention from our day-to-day business as a result of the need to deal with the foregoing
disruptions and integration matters.

**_We may be unable to achieve some or all of the returns, synergies, cost savings or other benefits that we expect to_**
**_realise from our recent acquisitions or group initiatives._**

We cannot assure you that we will be able to successfully realise the expected benefits from the EG UK
Acquisition or the Arthur Acquisition or the group initiatives that we have taken, or expect to take, aimed at realizing
synergies, operational efficiencies or cost savings, or that the costs to realise these benefits will not be higher than
anticipated. A variety of risks could cause us not to realise some or all of the expected benefits. These risks include,
among others, unexpected costs associated with operating our business, inability to eliminate duplicative back-office
overhead or redundant selling and general and administrative functions and an inability to avoid labour disruptions in
connection with any integration of the foregoing. Our ability to successfully manage organisational changes is
important for our future business success. In particular, our reputation and results of operations could be harmed if
colleague morale, engagement, or productivity decline as a result of organisational or other changes.

Moreover, our implementation of these initiatives may disrupt our operations and performance, and our
estimated cost savings from these initiatives are based on several assumptions that may prove to be inaccurate and, as

than our estimates, or our improvement initiatives adversely affect our operations or cost more or take longer to
implement than we project, or if our assumptions prove inaccurate, our business, financial condition and results of
operations may be materially adversely affected. These actions may not provide the expected benefits, or could take
longer to achieve than expected, and could lead to disruption of our operations, loss of or inability to recruit key
personnel, decline in colleague productivity, weakening of internal standards, controls or procedures, and impairment
of key customer and supplier relationships. In addition, cost saving and operational efficiencies may not be able to be
sustained due to changes in customer needs, changes in regulations, availability and cost of materials or other cost
variables.

Our anticipated cost saving and benefits from the EG UK Acquisition and Arthur Acquisition are based upon
assumptions about our ability to implement cost saving measures in a timely fashion within certain cost parameters
and implement net cost savings which are in excess of inflationary cost increases. Our ability to achieve planned cost
saving and benefits of these acquisitions is dependent upon a significant number of assumptions, some of which may
be beyond our control, including the development of the markets for our products and services, political, legal, fiscal,
market and economic conditions including but not limited to cost price inflation through our supply chain, regulatory
developments, and tariff and wage increases. If one or more of our underlying assumptions regarding these measures
proves to have been incorrect, these efforts could lead to substantially higher costs than planned and we may not be
able to realise fully or at all, or realise in the anticipated timeframe, the expected benefits from our cost saving and
operational measures.

We also undertake a number of group initiatives aimed at realizing synergies, operational efficiencies or cost
savings. There can be no assurance that our acquisitions or any of these initiatives will be as successful or accretive
as initially expected or meet our strategic goals. For example, we may fail to realise expected operational efficiencies
or cost savings. There is also a risk that the synergies that we seek to achieve may not be realised within the time
frame we currently anticipate, or at all, and that the magnitude of cost savings or operational efficiencies may be less
than expected or the costs of achieving these synergies may be higher than expected. Our anticipated synergies are
based on a number of assumptions, which are subject to uncertainties and contingencies that are outside of our control.

**Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes**

**_Our leverage and debt service obligations could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition,_**
**_liquidity, results of operation or prospects._**

As of December 31, 2023, after giving effect to the Transactions, we would have had total third-party debt
of £4,500 million (equivalent) comprising Original Facility A, New Facility A, Facility B (EUR), the Private
Placement Facility, the Senior Secured Notes, the Existing Senior Notes and the Remaining Existing 3.25% Senior
Secured Notes. See “Capitalisation.” We are highly leveraged and that leverage could be sustained at this level or
higher for the foreseeable future. The level of indebtedness that we hold, and will continue to hold, could, among other
things:

    - limit our ability to obtain additional financing to fund future working capital, capital expenditures,
business opportunities and other corporate requirements;

    - reduce our flexibility to respond to, and pose additional risks for us in the face of, general adverse
economic and industry conditions;

    - reduce the portion of our Underlying Cash Flow From Operations that will be available for uses other
than servicing our debt, such as funding working capital, capital expenditures, acquisitions, joint
ventures or other general corporate purposes;

    - restrict us from pursuing strategic acquisitions or exploiting certain business opportunities;

    - limit our flexibility in planning for, or reacting to, changes in our business and the competitive
environment and the industry in which we operate;

    - place us at a disadvantage compared to our competitors that are not as highly leveraged;

    - negatively impact credit terms with our creditors; and

    - limit our ability to borrow additional funds and increasing the cost of any such borrowing.

Any of these, or other, consequences or events could have a material adverse effect on our ability to satisfy
our debt obligations, including our obligations under the Senior Secured Notes.

**_We may incur additional debt in the future, which may make it difficult for us to service our debt, including the_**
**_Senior Secured Notes, and impact our ability to operate our businesses._**

The agreements governing our debt limit our ability to incur additional indebtedness, but do not prohibit us
from doing so. The terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures and
the Existing Senior Notes Indenture permit us (and, in the case of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will permit us)
to incur additional debt, including in respect of committed borrowings of at least £747,722,727 million under the New
Revolving Facility. Some of this debt could rank pari passu with the Senior Secured Notes, be structurally senior to
the Senior Secured Notes or be secured on assets which do not form part of the Collateral for the Senior Secured
Notes. Additional debt could also mature prior to the Senior Secured Notes. In addition, under the terms of the Existing
Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement, we are
permitted, and under the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, we will be permitted, subject to certain
conditions (including the refinancing of the term loan indebtedness outstanding as of the Issue Date under the Senior
Facilities Agreement in full), to incur new debt that has super senior priority status over the Senior Secured Notes in
respect of the proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral and certain distressed disposals. If new debt is added
to the Group’s existing debt levels, the related risks that we currently face would increase. Furthermore, if we are able
to designate some of our Restricted Subsidiaries under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture as Unrestricted
Subsidiaries, those Unrestricted Subsidiaries would be permitted to borrow beyond the limitations specified in the
Senior Secured Notes Indenture and engage in other activities in which Restricted Subsidiaries may not engage. See
“Description of the Senior Secured Notes.” In addition, the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Existing Senior Secured
Notes Indentures and the Existing Senior Notes Indenture do not, and the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will not,

**_The Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a holding company dependent upon cash flow from subsidiaries to meet its_**
**_obligations on the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees._**

As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer is a holding company with no
revenue-generating activities of its own and no business operations, and its primary assets relate to its shares in
Acquisition 2 and its primary liabilities relate to inter-group balances with the Senior Notes Issuer, commitments
under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the issuance of the Existing Senior Secured Notes, the guarantees of the
Existing Senior Notes and the Transactions.

We expect our operating subsidiaries to provide us with funds to meet our obligations in respect of the Senior
Secured Notes through a combination of dividends and payments in respect of intercompany loans. Our subsidiaries’
obligations under intercompany loans will be junior obligations and will be subordinated in right of payment to all of
the Group’s existing and future senior and senior subordinated indebtedness, including obligations under, or
guarantees of obligations under, the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Senior Secured Notes.

If our subsidiaries do not distribute cash sufficient to make scheduled payments on the Senior Secured Notes,
we will not have any other source of funds that will allow us to make payments to the holders of the Senior Secured
Notes. In addition, various agreements governing the Group’s debt may restrict and, in some cases may actually
prohibit, the ability of these subsidiaries to move cash within their restricted group. Applicable tax laws may also
subject such payments to further taxation and applicable corporate law may limit the amounts that some of our
subsidiaries will be permitted to pay as dividends or distributions on their equity interests, or even prohibit such
payments. In particular, our subsidiaries’ ability to pay dividends to us may be limited to the amount of distributable
reserves available to them. Finally, our subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Senior Secured Notes have no obligation
to make payments with respect to any of the Senior Secured Notes.

The inability to transfer cash among entities within their respective consolidated groups may mean that, even
though the entities, in aggregate, may have sufficient resources to meet their obligations, they may not be permitted
to make the necessary transfers from one entity in their consolidated group to another entity in their consolidated
group in order to make payments to the entity owing the obligations.

**_The Senior Secured Notes will be structurally subordinated to the liabilities and preference shares (if any) of the_**
**_Group’s non-guarantor subsidiaries._**

Generally, claims of creditors of a non-guarantor subsidiary, including trade creditors, and claims of
preference shareholders (if any) of the subsidiary, will have priority with respect to the assets and earnings of the
subsidiary over the claims of creditors of its parent entity, including claims by holders of the Senior Secured Notes
under the Notes Guarantees. For example, the lender under the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction (the “CGR Lender”)
is a priority creditor in respect of Asda Propco Limited (being the borrower under the Group Rent Transaction, which
a non-Guarantor subsidiary). In the event of any foreclosure, dissolution, winding-up, liquidation, reorganisation,
administration or other bankruptcy or insolvency proceeding of any of the Group’s non-guarantor subsidiaries, holders
of their indebtedness and their trade creditors will generally be entitled to payment of their claims from the assets of
those subsidiaries before any assets are made available for distribution to the parent entities of such non-guarantor
subsidiaries. As such, the Senior Secured Notes and each Notes Guarantee will each be structurally subordinated to
the creditors (including trade creditors) and preference shareholders (if any) of the Group’s non-guarantor subsidiaries.
In addition, the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will not require subsidiaries that become a member of the Regulated
Group to guarantee the Senior Secured Notes under any circumstances and any Notes Guarantee will be automatically
released upon the relevant Guarantor becoming a member of the Regulated Group.

As of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, the Guarantors collectively accounted for 98% of the Asda
Group’s consolidated revenues and, as of December 31, 2023, based on Asda’s allocation of properties for accounting
purposes (which has not been verified by an assessment of the registered proprietor of each of the properties) and
subject to matters disclosed in the section of this Offering Memorandum entitled “Valuation Report”, the Guarantors
hold sites representing over 99% of the value of the Market Value SA Properties (consisting of Asda supermarkets
(excluding supermarkets pledged in connection with the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction), Food to Go sites, industrial
properties and office properties), 90% of the value of the Market Value Properties (consisting of PFSs, investment
properties, development and landbank sites and a Distribution Centre – Held for Sale site) and 0% of the properties
leased in connection with the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. As of and for the year ended December 31, 2023,
subsidiaries that are not Guarantors had no third-party debt outstanding. In addition, our audited consolidated financial
statements include both Guarantor and non-guarantor subsidiaries and, as such, may be of limited use in assessing the
financial position of the Guarantors.

**_Currency exchange rates may have an impact on our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations_**
**_and prospects._**

We are subject to foreign currency translation and transaction effects because the Group’s business is based
in the United Kingdom and the Group prepares its consolidated financial statements in pounds sterling; however, we
have a significant amount of euro-denominated debt, including Facility B (EUR), and may incur further
euro-denominated debt in the future. Our results of operations may be affected by both the transaction effects and the
translation effects of foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations. We are and will continue to be required to pay
principal and interest payments in a currency outside of our functional currency, exposing us to unrealised and realised
gains and losses due to foreign exchange depending on fluctuations in exchange rates. In addition, fluctuations in the
euro-sterling currency exchange rate could have a substantial effect on our financial statements due to related gains or
losses resulting from the conversion into sterling of euro-denominated liabilities. Although we may use currency
swaps to hedge against the effect of changes in the euro-sterling rate and some purchases in US Dollars are managed
using forward contracts, there can be no assurance that hedging or such forward contracts will be available on
commercially reasonable terms and, even if such arrangements are available, they may not completely insulate us
from currency exchange risks. In addition, hedging itself carries certain risks, including that we may need to pay a
significant amount (including costs) to terminate any hedging arrangements.

The Group is currently contemplating additional cross-currency swaps as well as interest rate swaps in respect
of the unhedged portion of our ongoing EUR exposure and floating rate exposure respectively under the Senior
Facilities Agreement. From time to time we also enter into additional currency swap transactions in order to manage
any operational currency exposures. We may, but are under no obligation to, enter into additional foreign exchange
interest rate swaps or cross currency swaps as well as interest rate swaps in order to hedge our ongoing EUR exposure
and floating rate exposure respectively under the Senior Facilities Agreement. However, there can be no assurance
that such hedging will eliminate the potentially material adverse effect of such fluctuations.

See also “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—
_Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Financial Risk Overview—Foreign Currency Risk.”_

**_Our variable interest rate debt may be impacted by applicable regulation and may bear interest that could rise_**
**_significantly, thereby increasing our costs and reducing our cash flow._**

The debt the Group has incurred, and may incur in the future, under the Senior Facilities Agreement bears
interest at variable rates, and we are exposed to the risk of fluctuations in interest rates. In addition, the Senior Secured
Notes Indenture will permit us to incur substantial additional indebtedness, which may bear a floating rate of interest.

These interest rates could rise significantly in the future, increasing our interest expense associated with these
obligations, reducing cash flow available to fund working capital, capital expenditures or other general corporate
purposes and hindering our ability to make payments on the Senior Secured Notes. Although we may enter into and
maintain certain hedging arrangements designed to fix a portion of these rates, there can be no assurance that hedging
will be available on commercially reasonable terms or that it will continue to be available on such terms in the future.
Hedging itself carries certain risks, including that we may need to pay a significant amount (including costs) to
terminate any hedging arrangements.

In addition, any elimination of any applicable benchmark, or changes in the manner of administration of such
benchmark, could require an adjustment to the terms and conditions of our floating rate debt. Any such consequence
could have a material adverse effect on the value of and return on any such floating rate debt. If any applicable
benchmark was discontinued or otherwise unavailable, the rate of interest on our floating rate debt will be determined
for the relevant period by the fallback provisions applicable to such debt. Any such change, as well as manipulative
practices or the cessation thereof, may result in a sudden or prolonged increase in a reported benchmark rate, which
could have an adverse impact on the Group’s ability to service debt that bears interest at floating rates of interest.

**_Investors may face foreign exchange risks by investing in the Senior Secured Notes._**

The Senior Secured Notes will be denominated and payable in pound sterling. If investors in the Senior
Secured Notes measure their investment returns by reference to a currency other than sterling, such investment in the
Senior Secured Notes will entail foreign exchange-related risks due to, among other factors, possible significant
changes in the values of the pound sterling relative to the currency by reference to which investors measure the return
on their investments because of economic, political and other factors over which the Group has no control.
Depreciation of the pound sterling against the currency by reference to which investors measure the return on their
investments could cause a decrease in the effective yield of the Senior Secured Notes below their stated coupon rates
and could result in a loss to investors when the return on such Senior Secured Notes is translated into the currency by
reference to which the investors measure the return on their investments. Investments in the Senior Secured Notes
denominated in a currency other than U.S. dollars by U.S. investors may also have important tax consequences as a
result of foreign exchange gains or losses, if any. See “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain United States Federal
_Income Tax Considerations.”_

**_The Senior Secured Notes may be issued with original issue discount for U.S. federal income tax purposes._**

The Senior Secured Notes may be issued with original issue discount (“OID”) for U.S. federal income tax
purposes. The Senior Secured Notes will be considered to be issued with OID if the stated principal amount of the
Senior Secured Notes exceeds their issue price (as determined for U.S. federal income tax purposes) by an amount
equal to or more than a statutorily defined de minimis amount. In such event, investors in the Senior Secured Notes
subject to U.S. federal income taxation generally will be required to include such OID in their gross income (as
ordinary income) on an annual basis under a constant yield accrual method regardless of their regular method of
accounting for U.S. federal income tax purposes. As a result, such investors generally will include any OID in income
in advance of the receipt of cash attributable to such income. See “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain United States
_Federal Income Tax Considerations—Original Issue Discount.”_

the loan and enforce their mortgages over the properties subject to the transaction, or over the shares in Asda Propco
Limited (which owns the freehold or long leasehold interest in all of the relevant properties). Events of default are
included for the insolvency of the tenant under the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction (i.e., Asda Stores Limited), and for
persistent non-payment under or material breach of the CGR Ground Leases. In the case of the latter, such an event
of default will not arise unless either (i) in respect of a CGR Ground Lease in England & Wales, a notice of intended
forfeiture under s.146 Law of Property Act 1925 has been served on the tenant and the tenant has not complied with
such notice, or (ii) in respect of a CGR Ground Lease in Scotland, an irritancy warning notice has been served on the
tenant, and Asda Propco Limited has not substituted the affected property. It is proposed that the Ground Rent
Transaction Facility Agreement will be amended to reflect the distinction between forfeiture and irritancy in English
and Scottish leases, respectively.

**_We have certain liabilities under the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction where the lenders’ recourse is not limited to_**
**_the value of the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction properties._**

Asda Group Limited has entered into a tax deed of covenant with Asda Propco Limited and the lender under
the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction for the purposes of managing certain group level tax compliance obligations in
respect of the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. The tax deed of covenant also contains a tax indemnity given by Asda
Group Limited to Asda Propco Limited to cover the imposition of unexpected tax liabilities arising in connection with
the Asda Group. For example, the tax deed of covenant contains an indemnity covering the imposition of any
secondary liability taxes or the imposition of any de-grouping charge.

Asda Group Limited has provided an indemnity in favour of the lender under the 2023 Ground Rent
Transaction for any increased costs it incurs itself, and for any liability for increased costs incurred by noteholders in
each case in the event the transaction is characterised as a securitisation under UK Securitisation Regulation Rules or
EU Securitisation Regulation Rules. In addition, Asda Group Limited undertakes to take such actions as are within its
control to comply with UK Securitisation Regulation Rules and EU Securitisation Regulation Rules, and to procure
that Asda Propco Limited and any relevant affiliate does likewise.

**_The transfer of the Senior Secured Notes is restricted, which may adversely affect their liquidity and the price at_**
**_which they may be sold._**

The Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees have not been registered under, and the Group is not
obliged to register the Senior Secured Notes or the Notes Guarantees under, the Securities Act or the securities laws
of any other jurisdiction and, unless so registered, may not be offered or sold except pursuant to an exemption from,
or a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the Securities Act and any other applicable laws. See
“Notice to Investors.” The Group has not agreed to or otherwise undertaken to register any of the Senior Secured
Notes or the Notes Guarantees, and do not have any intention to do so.

**_The Senior Secured Notes will initially be held in book-entry form, and therefore you must rely on the procedures_**
**_of the relevant clearing systems to exercise any rights and remedies._**

Unless and until the Senior Secured Notes are in definitive registered form, or definitive registered notes are
issued in exchange for book-entry interests (which may occur only in very limited circumstances), owners of
book-entry interests will not be considered owners or holders of the Senior Secured Notes. The common depositary
(or its nominee) for Euroclear and Clearstream will be the sole registered holder of the global notes. Payments of
principal, interest and other amounts owing on or in respect of the global notes representing the Senior Secured Notes
will be made to the Paying Agent, which will make payments to Euroclear and Clearstream. Thereafter, these

95


-----

payments will be credited to participants’ accounts that hold book-entry interests in the global notes representing the
Senior Secured Notes and credited by such participants to indirect participants. After payment to the common
depositary for Euroclear and Clearstream, we will have no responsibility or liability for the payment of interest,
principal or other amounts to the owners of book-entry interests. Accordingly, owners of book-entry interests in the
Senior Secured Notes must rely on the procedures of Euroclear and Clearstream and if such owners are not a
participant in Euroclear and/or Clearstream, on the procedures of the participant through which their interest is owned,
to exercise any rights and obligations of a holder of the Senior Secured Notes under the Senior Secured Notes
Indenture.

Unlike the holders of the Senior Secured Notes themselves, owners of book-entry interests will not have any
direct rights to act upon any solicitations for consents, requests for waivers or other actions from holders of the Senior
Secured Notes. Instead, owners of book-entry interests will be permitted to act only to the extent they have received
appropriate proxies to do so from Euroclear and Clearstream or, if applicable, from a participant. There can be no
assurance that procedures implemented for the granting of such proxies will be sufficient to enable an owner of a book
entry interest to vote on any matters or on a timely basis.

Similarly, upon the occurrence of an event of default under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, unless and
until the definitive registered Senior Secured Notes are issued in respect of all book-entry interests, owners of
book-entry interests will be restricted to acting through Euroclear and Clearstream. We can make no assurances that
the procedures to be implemented through Euroclear and Clearstream will be adequate to ensure the timely exercise
of rights under the Senior Secured Notes.

**_The interests of the group’s principal shareholders may conflict with your interests._**

The interests of the Group’s principal shareholders, in certain circumstances, may conflict with your interests
as holders of the Senior Secured Notes. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, all of the outstanding shares of
the Senior Secured Notes Issuer are held by the Senior Notes Issuer, which is 50% indirectly owned by Mohsin and
Zuber Issa and 50% indirectly owned by funds managed by TDR Capital LLP. See “Principal Shareholders.” As a
result, the principal shareholders have, and will continue to have, directly or indirectly, the power to, among other
things, affect the Group’s legal and capital structure and its day-to-day operations, as well as the ability to elect and
change its management and to approve any other changes to its operations. Our shareholders may make strategic
decisions with regards to their ownership of the Group that may not be aligned with the interests of holders of the
Senior Secured Notes. For instance, they may seek to acquire further ownership interests or dispose their existing
ownership interests in the Group. Our principal shareholders may also have an interest in pursuing acquisitions,
divestitures, financings or other transactions that, in their judgment, will enhance their equity investments, although
such transactions might involve risks to you as a holder of Senior Secured Notes. For example, these shareholders
could vote to cause us to incur additional indebtedness, sell certain material assets or pay dividends, in each case, so
long as the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes
Indenture, the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Intercreditor Agreement so permit. The incurrence of additional
indebtedness could increase the Group’s debt service obligations, the payment of dividends would reduce the Group’s
ability to meet its debt service obligations or fund working capital, capital expenditures or general corporate purposes
and the sale of certain assets would reduce the Group’s ability to generate revenue, each of which could adversely
affect holders of the Senior Secured Notes. Such transactions may not be in the best interests of the Group or the
holders or the Senior Secured Notes.

In addition, TDR Capital is in the business of making investments in companies and may, from time to time,
acquire and hold interests in businesses that compete directly or indirectly with us. TDR Capital may also pursue
acquisitions that may be complementary with our business and, as a result, those acquisition opportunities may not be
available to us. So long as our shareholders continue to indirectly own a significant amount of the outstanding shares
of our common stock, even if such amount is less than 50%, our shareholders will continue to be able to strongly
influence or effectively control our decisions.

In addition, our principal shareholders own EG Group, which operates in the fuel and convenience retail
industry in jurisdictions including the United Kingdom, and may, in the future, own businesses that directly compete
with ours or do business with us. This may give rise to a conflict of interest for such directors in circumstances where
the interests of EG Group are not aligned with the Group’s interests. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party
_Transactions.”_

**_We will be subject to significant restrictive debt covenants, which limit our operating and financial flexibility._**

The Senior Secured Notes Indenture will contain covenants which impose significant operating and financial
restrictions on us. These agreements limit our ability to, among other things:

    - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness or issue certain preferred stock;

    - make certain restricted payments and investments;

    - transfer or sell assets or enter into sale and leaseback transactions;

    - enter into transactions with affiliates;

    - create or incur certain liens;

    - make certain loans, investments or acquisitions of minority interests;

    - create or incur restrictions on the ability of our subsidiaries to pay dividends or to make other payments
to us;

    - take certain actions that would impair the Security Interests granted for the benefit of the holders of the
Senior Secured Notes;

    - incur or enter into certain sale and leaseback transactions, ground rent transactions and qualified
securitizations involving real property; and

    - merge, consolidate or transfer all or substantially all of our assets.

These covenants could limit our ability to finance our future operations and capital needs and our ability to
pursue acquisitions and other business activities that may be in our interest.

In addition, we are subject to the affirmative and negative covenants contained in the Senior Facilities
Agreement, the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures and the Existing Senior Notes Indenture, which, in the case
of the negative covenants, are substantially in line with those applicable to the Senior Secured Notes (other than certain
additional covenants applicable to the Senior Facilities Agreement customary for facilities of that nature and certain
covenants applicable to the Private Placement Facility that are more restrictive than included in the Senior Secured
Notes Indenture). See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement—Covenants.”
Asda Propco Limited is also subject to certain affirmative and negative covenants in connection with the 2023 Ground
Rent Transaction (which are transaction-specific and broadly based on the Loan Market Association Single Currency
Term Facility Agreement for Real Estate Finance Multiproperty Investment Transactions). A breach of any of those
covenants could result in an event of default under those debt documents, which could lead to an event of default and
acceleration under our other debt instruments that contain cross-default or cross-acceleration provisions, including the
Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures and the Existing Senior Notes Indenture. If our creditors accelerate the
payment of amounts owing to them under such other debt instruments, we cannot assure you that our assets and the
assets of our subsidiaries would be sufficient to repay in full those amounts, to satisfy all our other liabilities and the
liabilities of our subsidiaries which would be due and payable and to make payments to enable us to repay the Senior
Secured Notes, in full or in part. In addition, if we are unable to repay those amounts, our creditors could proceed
against any security interests granted to them to secure repayment of those amounts.

**_We may be unable to access the short-term and long-term funding required to meet business needs._**

The availability and ability to access appropriate levels of funding and liquidity on financial terms acceptable
to us is critical for continued business operations. Our Treasury function seeks to ensure that we continue to have
access to sufficient funding by, amongst other things, monitoring rolling forecasts of our cash flows, which includes
our ability to service our debt obligations. We have sought to manage our liquidity through entry into short-term
financing arrangements with a number of third-party financial institutions, including arrangements to allow a number
of our suppliers to participate in supply chain finance (“SCF”) arrangements with such financial institutions. Such

97


-----

arrangements reduce pressure on supplier payment terms, allowing payments in respect of supplier invoices on longer
payment terms and correspondingly increasing short-term liquidity. However, as these SCF facilities are uncommitted
and the level of funding financial institutions provide pursuant to them is discretionary, there is a risk that these
facilities will not be sufficient to meet our liquidity needs. A decision by one or more of these third-party financial
institutions to reduce the amount of funding available pursuant to such SCF facilities or fully withdraw the access to
such SCF facilities, or a disruption to one or more of the financial institutions providing such facilities, could adversely
affect our cash flows and liquidity. The withdrawal of such facilities could lead to a review of payment terms by
suppliers, with a significant reduction in payment terms to suppliers risking a working capital outflow.

If these programmes or underlying supplier terms do not continue and we are unable to secure alternative
programmes, our cash and working capital may be negatively affected and we may have to increase our long-term
borrowings for short- and long-term liquidity requirements.

For a description of our supply chain finance arrangements, see “Description of Certain Financing
_Arrangements—Supply Chain Facilities.”_

We are also subject to the risk that our capital structure may not be sufficient to support the growth of our
business and maintain our existing credit rating. Our capital structure consists of debt obligations (including the Senior
Facilities, the Senior Secured Notes, the Existing Senior Secured Notes and the Existing Senior Notes) and equity
(issued share capital, share premium and reserves). Part of our capital risk management strategy is to monitor a broad
range of financial metrics and manage compliance with financial covenants relating to our debt obligations. There is
a risk that we are unable to access to financial markets to obtain appropriate sources and levels of funding at economic
rates or debt funding is removed due to noncompliance with lending agreements and related covenants.

**_We will require a significant amount of cash to service our debt, fund working capital, rental and lease payments_**
**_and sustain our operations. Our ability to generate or raise sufficient cash depends on many factors beyond our_**
**_control._**

On the Issue Date, we expect to issue a significant amount of debt and will have significant debt service
obligations, including under the Senior Secured Notes, the Existing Senior Secured Notes, the Existing Senior Notes
and the Senior Facilities. Our ability to make principal or interest payments when due on and to refinance our debt,
and to fund working capital, rental and lease payments and capital expenditures, will depend on our future operating
performance and ability to generate sufficient cash. This depends, to some extent, on the success of our business
strategy and on general economic, financial, competitive, market, legislative, regulatory and other factors discussed
in these “Risk Factors” and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, as well as other factors, many of which are
beyond our control. This also depends on our cash flow cycle, which experiences seasonal fluctuations. Levels of
customer traffic at our stores are affected by the weather and travel patterns, among other factors, which could also
have a negative impact on our cash position and impact our ability to make payments on and to refinance our debt and
to fund working capital and capital expenditures. If our interest or lease payment dates coincide with periods of
significant cash outflow, we may have insufficient cash to pay our obligations as they come due.

We cannot assure you that the currently anticipated cost savings, revenue growth and operating improvements
will be realised, that cash flows from operations will be sufficient, or that future debt and equity financing will be
available to us on satisfactory terms or in an amount sufficient to enable us to refinance all or a portion of our debt,
pay our debts when due, or to fund our other liquidity needs.

If our future cash flows from operations and other capital resources are insufficient to pay our obligations as
they mature or to fund our liquidity needs, we may be forced to:

    - reduce or delay our business activities and capital expenditures;

    - sell assets;

    - obtain additional debt or equity capital; or

    - restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, on or before maturity.

98


-----

We cannot assure you that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or on
satisfactory terms, if at all. In particular, our ability to restructure or refinance our debt will depend in part on our
financial condition at such time as well as on many factors outside of our control, including then-prevailing conditions
in the international credit and capital markets. In such event, we may not to be able to meet our debt repayment
obligations. In addition, the terms of our debt limit, and any future debt may limit, our ability to pursue any of these
alternatives. See _“—We will be subject to significant restrictive debt covenants, which limit our operating and_
_financial flexibility.” Any refinancing of our debt could be at higher interest rates and could require us to comply with_
more onerous covenants, which could further restrict our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations
and prospects. There can be no assurance that any assets which we could be required to dispose of could be sold or
that, if sold, the timing of such sale and the amount of proceeds realised from such sale would be acceptable.

Furthermore, our inability to meet payment obligations under our existing debt could trigger various default
provisions, accelerate a substantial portion (if not all) of our debt, and would materially adversely affect our business,
financial condition, liquidity, results of operations and prospects.

**_Holders of the Senior Secured Notes will not control decisions regarding the Collateral in certain circumstances._**

Subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Secured Notes and the Guarantees will be secured on a
first-priority basis by the same Collateral securing the obligations under the Senior Facilities. In addition, under the
terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes
Indentures, the Existing Senior Notes Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement, the Group is (or, in the case of the
Senior Secured Notes Indenture, will be) permitted to incur significant additional indebtedness and other obligations
that may be secured by the same Collateral on a pari passu basis, including other credit facilities and certain hedging
liabilities.

The Intercreditor Agreement provides that a common Security Agent, who is also the security agent for the
lenders under the Senior Facilities Agreement and any additional debt secured by the Collateral permitted to be
incurred by the Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the Senior Facilities Agreement, will act only as provided for in
the Intercreditor Agreement. The Intercreditor Agreement regulates the ability of the Senior Secured Notes Trustee or
the holders of the Senior Secured Notes to instruct the Security Agent to take enforcement action. Initially, the Security
Agent will not be required to take enforcement action unless instructed to do so by an Instructing Group (as defined
under “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement”) that comprises creditors holding
more than 50% of the indebtedness under the Senior Secured Notes, the Senior Facilities Agreement, and indebtedness
ranking pari passu with such indebtedness (the “Majority Senior Secured Creditors”) (in each case acting through
their respective creditor representative). Additionally, the Senior Facilities Agreement allows (or, in the case of the
Senior Secured Notes Indenture, will allow) the Group to incur additional indebtedness secured on a pari passu basis
with the Senior Secured Notes, which would further dilute the voting interest of holders of the Senior Secured Notes
issued on the Issue Date.

The lenders under the Senior Facilities Agreement and creditors in respect of any indebtedness secured on a
_pari passu basis with the Senior Secured Notes that we may incur in the future may have interests that are different_
from the interests of holders of the Senior Secured Notes and they may, subject to the terms of the Intercreditor
Agreement, elect to pursue their remedies under the Security Documents at a time when it would be disadvantageous
for the holders of the Senior Secured Notes to do so.

In addition, if the Security Agent sells Collateral comprising the shares of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer
or any of its holding companies or subsidiaries as a result of an enforcement action or other distressed disposal in
accordance with the Intercreditor Agreement, claims under the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees
against, and the liens over any other assets of, such entities and any subsidiaries of such entity securing the Senior
Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees may be released. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—
_Intercreditor Agreement” and “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Release_ _of Liens.”_

**_The Collateral may not be sufficient to secure the obligations under the Senior Secured Notes._**

On the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be secured by security interests
in the Initial Collateral, within 30 days of the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be
secured by security interests in the Post-Closing Non-Real Estate Collateral and, within 180 days of the Issue Date,

99


-----

the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees will be secured by security interests in the Post-Closing Real
Estate Collateral, in each case as described in this Offering Memorandum. The Collateral securing the Senior Secured
Notes will also secure the obligations under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Existing Senior Secured Notes
Indentures and, with respect to the Shared Security, the Existing Senior Notes (on a second-priority basis). Such
Collateral may also secure additional debt ranking pari passu with the Senior Secured Notes to the extent permitted
to be incurred by the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Intercreditor
Agreement. The holders of Senior Secured Notes’ rights to the Collateral may therefore be diluted by any increase in
the debt secured by such Collateral on a pari passu or senior basis or a reduction in the value of the Collateral securing
the Senior Secured Notes.

The value that holders of the Senior Secured Notes may receive upon enforcement of the Collateral will
depend upon many factors, including, among others, the ability to sell this Collateral in an orderly sale, the condition
of the economies in which our operations are located and the availability of buyers. The book value of the Collateral
should not be relied on as a measure of realisable value for such assets. All or a portion of the Collateral may be
illiquid and may have no readily ascertainable market value. Likewise, we cannot assure you that there will be a market
for the sale of the Collateral, or, if such a market exists, that there will not be a substantial delay in its liquidation. In
addition, the share pledges over the shares of an entity may be of no value if that entity is subject to an insolvency or
bankruptcy proceeding. The Collateral is located in England and Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland, and the
multi-jurisdictional nature of any foreclosure on the Collateral may limit its realisable value. For example, the
bankruptcy, insolvency, administrative and other laws of the various jurisdictions may be materially different from,
or conflict with, each other, including in the areas of rights of creditors, priority of government and other creditors,
ability to obtain post-petition interest and duration of the proceedings. In addition, third parties may have rights over
Material Real Property (including rights to acquire and pre-emption rights) exercisable in the event of transfer of such
Material Real Property (including as a result of enforcement of security interests in such Collateral). In such cases,
the enforcement of the security interests over, or transfer of, such Material Real Property may be significantly delayed,
prevented in part or prevented entirely.

**_The granting of the security interests in connection with the issuance of the Senior Secured Notes or the incurrence_**
**_of permitted debt in the future, may create or restart hardening periods, i.e., the periods of time following the_**
**_granting of security interests during which such security interests may be challenged in accordance with the laws_**
**_applicable in certain jurisdictions._**

The granting of security interests to secure the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Guarantees following the
Issue Date may create hardening periods for such security interests in certain jurisdictions. The granting of shared
security interests to secure future indebtedness permitted to be secured on the Collateral may restart or reopen such
hardening periods in particular, as the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will permit the release and retaking of security
granted in favour of the Senior Secured Notes in certain circumstances, including in connection with the incurrence
of future indebtedness and a Permitted Reorganisation. Please see “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—
_Security.”_

The applicable hardening period for these new security interests can run from the moment each new security
interest has been granted or perfected. At each time, if the security interest granted or recreated were to be enforced
before the end of the respective hardening period applicable in such jurisdiction, it may be declared void or ineffective
and/or it may not be possible to enforce it. Please see “Certain Insolvency Considerations and _Limitations on Validity_
_and Enforceability of the Notes Guarantees and the Security Interests.”_

**_If the New Revolving Facility is designated as super senior liabilities in accordance with the terms of the_**
**_Intercreditor Agreement and the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, creditors under the New Revolving Facility and_**
**_counterparties to certain hedging obligations and future indebtedness permitted to be incurred on a super senior_**
**_basis under the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement are entitled to be_**
**_repaid with proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral in priority to the Senior Secured Notes._**

The Intercreditor Agreement includes provisions governing the sharing of proceeds from enforcement of the
Collateral. Such enforcement proceeds are required to be turned over to the Security Agent after certain events,
including the acceleration of the Senior Secured Notes. The Security Agent is required to apply turned-over amounts
and other recoveries by the Security Agent from enforcement actions toward discharging the super senior obligations
(including, among others, (following the designation of the New Revolving Facility as super senior liabilities in

100


-----

accordance with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement and the Senior Secured Notes Indenture) those under the
New Revolving Facility, certain hedging obligations and supply chain financings that may, pursuant to the terms of
the Indentures, be secured on a super senior basis (the “Super Senior Liabilities”) under certain circumstances,
including the refinancing in full of the Term Loan Facilities) in priority to applying any such amounts toward
discharging the Senior Secured Notes. As such, in the event of a foreclosure of the Collateral, holders of the Senior
Secured Notes may not benefit from such recoveries if the then-outstanding claims under such Super Senior Liabilities
are greater than the proceeds recovered. Any proceeds remaining from an enforcement sale of Collateral will, after all
obligations under such Super Senior Liabilities have been discharged, be applied pro rata in repayment of the Senior
Secured Notes, the Senior Facilities (other than the New Revolving Facility where a designation of the New Revolving
Facility as super senior liabilities in accordance with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement has occurred) and any
other obligations secured by the Collateral which are permitted to rank pari passu with the Senior Secured Notes.
Furthermore, claims of other secured creditors that are secured by assets that do not also secure the Senior Secured
Notes will have priority with respect to such assets over the claims of holders of the Senior Secured Notes. As such,
the claims of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes will be effectively subordinated to the rights of such secured
creditors to the extent of the value of the assets securing such indebtedness.

**FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS**

_and for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023, as derived from the Financial Statements. All references_

_The discussion and analysis below provides information that we believe is relevant to an assessment and_

_Financial and Other Information—Non-IFRS Financial Measures.”_

**Overview**

We are the third-largest grocery retailer in the United Kingdom and the second-largest grocery retailer in the
North of England, Scotland and Wales (in each case in terms of Till Roll data on a 52-week basis as of January 21,
2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel). We operate a significant store estate of over 1,200 large stores and
convenience sites that are geographically diversified across the United Kingdom. We also have the second largest
online grocery platform in the United Kingdom (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of
January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel). We are also now a major player in the UK convenience market,
having added 472 convenience sites (including petrol filling stations) to our portfolio, as well as 124 stand-alone
foodservice sites (including 10 non-active sites), following the Arthur Acquisition and EG UK Acquisition. These
acquisitions have given us significant foothold in the fast-growing convenience market which, alongside our existing
fuel portfolio, makes us the second-largest independent fuel owner-operator in the United Kingdom.

108


-----

The graph below compares our total grocery market share with that of other major UK grocery retailers based
on Till Roll data for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel.

_(Source: Kantar Worldpanel, Take Home Panel, Grocery, 52 w/e January 21[st] 2024, Till Roll.)_

We operate in the large and historically stable UK grocery retail market that is underpinned by favourable
macroeconomic factors including GDP, population, consumer confidence and household expenditure on food and
beverages and which has historically demonstrated resilient performance through economic fluctuations. Groceries
are a necessary and regular consumer expenditure, which we believe generally allows the grocery retail market to
weather economic downturns better than certain other retail markets. For example, the UK grocery retail market
demonstrated its two strongest periods of growth in recent history during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and
during the COVID-19 pandemic, followed only by a slight contraction as the pandemic eased. Since, the UK grocery
retail market has experienced consistent growth, achieving a record-high size of £144.0 billion in sales for the 52week period ended December 24, 2023, according to Kantar Worldpanel, despite facing high inflation and global
geopolitical tensions in 2022 and 2023. See also “Industry.”

One of the key capabilities that drives our performance is our differentiated operating model, which is in turn
centred around our omni-channel offer (with multiple fulfilment options), our commitment to offering high quality
products with low prices to our customers and our wholly-owned supplier, International Procurement and Logistics
Ltd (“IPL”), which enables us to take a vertically-integrated approach to procurement and which we believe gives us
a competitive advantage in food sourcing. Other key capabilities that drive our performance include our profitable and
well-established George Clothing and George Home offers, our well-developed own-brand grocery offers, our
growing presence in the convenience and foodservice market, our popular customer loyalty programme Asda
Rewards, and our team of flexible and engaged colleagues.

We are a highly cash-generative business of scale with strong asset backing. In the year ended December 31,
2023, our revenue was £25.6 billion (including fuel), with 16.5% of sales made online, our net cash flow from
operating activities was £1,245.8 million, our profit for the year was £194.5 million, and our Pro Forma Adjusted
EBITDA was £1,264 million.

109


-----

Excluding the results of the EG UK Business, which was acquired on October 31, 2023, and the results of
the Arthur Business, which was consolidated from May 31, 2023, the chart below presents the breakdown of our 2023
revenue by product category (food, general merchandise, clothing and petrol), and channel (stores and online
(including George.com)).

_(Source: Asda information. Year ended December 31, 2023. Note: excluding approximately £588 million from the Arthur Acquisition, £411_
_million from the EG UK Acquisition and £199 million of other revenue from Asda Mobile sales, financial services sales, shipping and wrapping_
_revenue, pharmacy revenue and, until the EG UK Acquisition, Asda On The Move.)_

Our differentiated operating model has resulted in strong financial performance: our successful financial
profile is underpinned by strong Adjusted EBITDA margins, free cash flow (defined as Adjusted EBITDA less Capital
Expenditure KPI) and cash conversion (defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA) in recent years. For
more information on our differentiated operating model, see “—Key Strengths—We benefit from a differentiated
_operating model.”_ Between 2021 and 2023, our average profit margin (defined as profit for the year divided by
revenue) was 4.3%, our average Adjusted EBITDA margin was 4.2% (including fuel), our cumulative cash flows from
operating activities totalled £3,340.6 million, cumulative free cash flow was approximately £2,097 million and our
average cash conversion was 68%. See “Summary Historical Consolidated Financial Information and Other Financial
_Data—Other Financial Data—Other Financial Indicators.”_

We believe that our business, operating model and financial performance also benefit from our significant
freehold real estate asset portfolio, which also can provide a potential source of liquidity. See “Valuation Report.” In
2023, through the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions and 2023 Ground Rent Transaction, we have been able to,
and in the future may continue to, selectively monetise portions of our real estate portfolio to take advantage of
favourable trading conditions and pursue our strategic priorities. See “—Lease Agreements.”

We believe that our omni-channel food offer delivers low prices across the full basket and that we maintain
a meaningful price gap as compared to other traditional grocers in the United Kingdom. We have made more than
£300 million annualized price investment since 2022 across over 1,200 lines. Within the UK value market, we have
strong market shares across core grocery products (13.1%), beers, wines and spirits (12.8%), impulse grocery (12.1%),
household and pet (12.1%), frozen (11.4%) and total grocery (11.4%) (in each case in terms of Total Grocery Absolute
Sales as of the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel). Our offer is strong across the full
food basket: our category market shares range from 9.6% to 13.1% (except health and beauty)(in each case in terms
of Total Grocery Absolute Sales as of the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel). We
believe that we are the least expensive full-selection traditional grocer in the United Kingdom: according to internal

110


-----

Asda data, our prices are approximately 2.5% to 6.1% less expensive than our traditional grocer competitors (on the
average of the first eight weeks in 2024, based on total goods price gap percentage). We believe our prices continue
to compete with those of discounters such as Lidl and Aldi. In January 2024, we launched a new price matching
programme where we have price matched Aldi and Lidl on approximately 300 comparable grocery products, which
reduced prices by an average of 17% to match whichever discounter had the lowest price on these products.

Our food business is already of significant scale, is supported by a strong online offer and is supplemented
by a large clothing and general merchandise business. We offer our entire range of food and non-food products to
customers as an accessible “one-stop shop” experience that is supported and enhanced by our strong online offer and
expansion into the convenience market under the Asda Express banner. We believe our omni-channel offer, through
which we reach customers at our brick-and-mortar stores and through our significant online offering and on our app,
appeals to our customers. The COVID-19 pandemic increased use of and engagement with our online platforms. In
the first half of 2021, there were approximately 8.6 million weekly visits to groceries.asda.com, with order growth
from approximately 488,000 weekly orders pre-COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the seven days ended
February 28, 2020) to an average of more than 773,000 weekly orders in 2021 (based on the average weekly orders
for the first 26 weeks of 2021) and a peak of more than 850,000 orders during the third lockdown (based on the seven
days to January 15, 2021). Online engagement has fallen from the peaks experienced during the COVID-19 pandemic,
but we have continued to grow our online business, with an average of approximately 774,000 weekly orders in 2022
and 2023 (based on the average weekly orders in 2022 and 2023). We also offer at-home delivery and customers are
able to collect their purchases at one of approximately 460 Asda Click & Collect sites. Our business model integrates
our store-based and online offer by leveraging our stores to fulfil online orders.

Our online grocery business is profitable within one of the world’s most developed online grocery markets.
According to Kantar Worldpanel, as of January 21, 2024, we operate the second-largest online grocery platform in
the United Kingdom, holding 19.3% of market share (on a 52-week basis, in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales),
growing our market share in a market that is 5.5% larger on a one-year basis (comparing Total Grocery Absolute
Online Sales from the 52 weeks ended January 22, 2023 to the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024). Our online business
is already of significant scale; the chart below shows the growth of our online sales, including a breakdown of online
grocery versus George.com sales, for the periods presented.

_(Source: Asda information.)_

According to Kantar Worldpanel, we are the third-largest online clothing, footwear and accessories retailer
in the United Kingdom by volume of units sold for the 52 weeks ended January 7, 2024 and we held 8.5% of the total
UK online clothing, footwear and accessories market by volume for the 24 weeks ended January 7, 2024. Combined
sales for our online grocery business and George.com have rapidly increased in recent years, growing from £1.7 billion
(of which £1.5 billion were online grocery sales and £0.2 billion were George.com sales) in 2018 to £3.6 billion in
2023 (of which £3.2 billion were online grocery sales and £0.4 billion were George.com sales), representing a CAGR
of 16.2% between 2018 and 2023. Additionally, our ‘toyou’ service allows customers to conveniently collect and

111


-----

return orders from George.com and other partner retailers at our stores. We have partnered with 112 brands and
processed more than 4.4 million parcels in the year ended December 31, 2023.

We also have a strong presence in the convenience market with significant opportunity for additional
expansion in this fast-growing sector. In October 2022, we took our first notable step into the convenience market
after acquiring 132 sites including 129 convenience sites attached to forecourts from the Co-op (the “Co-op sites,”
and such business, the “Arthur Business”) and three development sites as part of the Arthur Acquisition. We agreed
to divest 13 of the Co-op sites following the recommendation of the CMA after an Initial Enforcement Order stemming
from its review of the acquisition. The disposals of these sites completed across December 2023 to January 2024 for
proceeds of £25.2 million. Each Co-op site included a grocery retail store between 1,500 and 3,000 square feet of
space and an attached petrol filling station driving footfall. In October 2023, we acquired the majority of EG Group’s
business in the United Kingdom for total cash consideration of £2.1 billion (including transaction fees). The deal
represented a major step in our convenience proposition, adding 356 well-invested PFSs to our convenience portfolio,
161 of which are stand-alone and 195 of which are co-located with foodservice concessions, as well as 124 stand-alone
foodservice sites (including 10 non-active sites). In foodservice, we acquired franchises for some of the United
Kingdom’s best loved outlets, including Greggs, Subway, Burger King and Sbarro, as well as our own proprietary
brand, Leon. Certain of our acquired sites also continue to benefit from an additional KFC and Starbucks non-Group
branded offerings operated by third parties. Through this acquisition, we accessed another high-growth sector,
foodservice, tapping into a new market which is highly complementary to Asda’s current offering. Each of the acquired
sites are community-focused and strategically located at the heart of residential areas with a diversified footprint across
the United Kingdom, and represent broader retail destinations with ancillary services such as parcel delivery, car wash
and last mile food delivery, with opportunity to expand further. The acquired sites also present a significant

through operational leverage.

In September 2023, we began the conversion of the Co-op sites from Co-op branding to our Asda Express
banner, implementing Asda pricing across fuel and grocery upon conversion. We completed the conversion of the

the Co-op sites and EG UK Business into the Asda Group and delivering synergies.

Currently, with our team of approximately 150,000 flexible and engaged colleagues, with around 98,000 fulltime employees, serving approximately 16.8 million customer trips each week (based on the average of weeks 37 to

Our business model is supported by diversification. First, we are a mass market retailer that serves the entire

**Segment Reporting**

We are engaged in a single reportable operating segment of business: the retailing of food (including grocery
and foodservice outlets), clothing, general merchandise, fuel and services in a single geographical segment, the United
Kingdom and online. The majority of our revenue is generated by the sale of goods through retail outlets in the United
Kingdom and through the Group’s online channels. The operations of all product areas of the business are subject to
similar economic characteristics and are sold in a similar retail environment. The Group is not reliant on any individual
major customers.
