**Key Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations**

Our results of operations are affected by a combination of factors. This section discusses key factors that we
believe have had a material effect on our results of operations and financial condition during the periods under review,
as well as those that are reasonably likely to have a material effect on our results of operations and financial condition
in the future. While we believe that our results of operations and financial condition, and particularly the results of
operations and financial condition during the periods under review, have been primarily affected by the following key
factors, these factors are not exhaustive, and the entirety of this Offering Memorandum should be reviewed,
particularly the “Risk Factors” section. Additionally, although we believe that the underlying operating trends that
have benefitted our business in recent years, as described further below, are relatively stable and will generally
continue to drive relatively steady patterns of revenue and EBITDA metrics, it is difficult to predict future performance
with any degree of certainty.

**_Competitive Environment_**

We operate in the highly competitive UK grocery retail market, which we believe is undergoing a period of
significant structural change, characterised by factors such as strong growth and aggressive pricing on the part of
discounters (such as Lidl and Aldi) as well as the other traditional grocers, and a shift away from large
brick-and-mortar stores to online purchasing and convenience retail, all against the backdrop of the general political
and economic uncertainty, including high inflation and the ongoing war in Ukraine, and any lingering impacts of the
COVID-19 pandemic, the latter of which has accelerated many of these trends. In a highly competitive environment
during a time of economic uncertainty, there is a risk we are unable to navigate changes in market structure or
consumer shopping trends leading to failure to enhance brand value, an inability to execute our strategic plan and we
could be exposed to loss of market share.

Across all of our market channels, we compete with grocery retailers and other operators for customers,
employees, locations, products and other important aspects of our business. Our success depends on our ability to
satisfy customer needs more effectively than the competition. In order to do so, we have adopted a strategy to
differentiate ourselves from our competitors and compete effectively against them on range, quality, price,
convenience of location and the overall shopping experience, among other things. We believe our market proposition
is that we offer the greatest value in terms of the price and quality of our products. For example, through our M&S
Taste Match campaign, hundreds of our products were voted “as tasty” or “tastier than” their M&S equivalents, while
our recent Aldi and Lidl Price Match programme delivers a broad range of popular everyday products at discounter
rates. Our market differentiation strategy focuses on optimising our product offerings, monitoring our mix of formats
and store concepts, expanding into convenience formats, strengthening our brand identity and seeking out

113


-----

opportunities to increase omni-channel sales. Further, our strategy is based on what we believe to be a well-established
own-brand grocery offering, our large and diverse store estate that caters to our customers’ different preferences and
our deployment of digital tools and online platforms and innovation and a well-known and successful clothing and
general merchandise brand, George.

Competition may also affect the prices we charge for our products, which in turn impacts our revenue and
margins, although this is usually experienced on a product-specific basis. For example, a competitor may cut its prices
to attract footfall to its stores, which in turn may require us to respond with a similar price reduction. In January 2024,
we announced a new price matching programme where we have price matched Aldi and Lidl on 287 comparable
grocery products, which reduced prices by an average of 17% to match whichever discounter had the lowest price on
these products. This Aldi and Lidl Price Match programme runs alongside our established customer value
propositions, including Price Drop and Asda Rewards. We have also implemented various other strategic initiatives
and investments in new product development, particularly low cost/high-quality options. For example, in May 2022,
we launched a new grocery opening price point range, Just Essentials By Asda. The range replaced the existing budget
offering, Asda Smart Price, expanding the range from approximately 160 to 272 products, with items reformulated
and refreshed to offer optimum price and quality.

Prices for most of our products are set on a national basis and, as a result of significant structural changes to
the UK grocery market, there has been substantial pressure on profit and EBITDA margins across the industry, which
has led market participants to engage in intense short-term promotional activity, particularly through multibuy offers,
member pricing and selective price cuts. At the same time, we have also experienced an overall market trend of food
and other input price inflation. For example, increases in the UK National Minimum Wage and National Living Wage,
alongside voluntary wage increases to support workers in this high inflationary environment, have led to grocery
market wage inflation. Moreover, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine led to significant pressures on the energy market,
which further accelerated rising inflation. As a result, we and other grocers experienced input inflationary pressures
relating to food prices, energy and fuel. Following the easing of COVID-19 lockdown measures across the United
Kingdom in the first half of 2021, the increase in economic activity led to increased pressure across global supply
chains, including in relation to labour shortages within the food manufacturing supply chain (including shortages of
HGV drivers ), a lack of container capacity within global shipping, increases in wholesale energy prices, shortages of
certain raw materials (including CO2); and increases in commodity prices which have resulted in input price inflation
within the supply chain, and there is no assurance that such pressures will not further increase in the future. Sourcing
and supply chain challenges could also be exacerbated through climate change and adverse weather conditions.

We manage this input cost inflation in several ways, such as by using our bargaining power with suppliers,
increasing or decreasing the prices of certain products to offset each other, through product re-engineering, for
example by maintaining the same price point and altering the weight or recipe, but without compromising on quality
and, in certain circumstances, passing through cost increases to consumers. In addition, we have also worked with
suppliers to help alleviate the challenges arising from recent supply chain pressures. This has included using our own
logistics network to support suppliers in the transportation of products from their manufacturing sites to our
distribution centres, and amending ordering profiles to enable suppliers to better manage the efficiency of their
production lines. These changes, however, have put pressure on our profit and EBITDA margins during the periods
under review. Whilst the level input inflation as of the date of this Offering Memorandum has been reduced compared
to 2022 and 2023, we expect input cost inflation to continue during the remainder of 2024.

We also operate in the highly competitive UK clothing and footwear retail market through the George
Clothing brand, which offers a wide variety of low cost, high-quality clothing and apparel for babies, children, men
and women, including jewellery, footwear and hosiery selections. The George Clothing brand was the number three
clothing, footwear and accessories retailer by volume of units sold in the United Kingdom for the 52 weeks ended
January 7, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel, with strong margins as compared to food categories and strong
online growth in the past three years. However, we face competitive challenges in the clothing and footwear retail
market, including from competitors that continue to invest in their online and in-store presence. Such competitors
target some of George Clothing’s key customer categories. We will continue to face steep competition on the basis
of, among other things, the location of our stores; our website and mobile applications, and their respective design;
the breadth, quality, style, price and availability of our merchandise; and the level of customer service offered. See
“Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—
_Competitive pressures in the apparel, footwear and homeware retail industries are high.” For a further discussion of_

our competitive landscape, market share and consumer trends in the UK grocery retail business, see “Industry—UK
_Grocery Retail Market Competitive Landscape.”_

**_General Economic Conditions in Our Geographic Markets_**

Our core grocery retail business generated 84.2% of our total sales (excluding fuel) for the year ended
December 31, 2023. The grocery retail business is generally relatively insulated from swings in demand related to
general economic conditions because consumer purchases of grocery and non-grocery staples tend to be less
discretionary than purchases in other retail categories. Certain of our other non-grocery offerings, on the other hand,
are more correlated to discretionary spending, and therefore, are more susceptible to changes in general economic
conditions. Such offerings, including George Clothing and general merchandise, generated 15.8% of our total sales
(excluding fuel) for the year ended December 31, 2023.

Notwithstanding the overall resilient nature of our core grocery retail business, consumer tastes and shopping
practices are affected by specific economic conditions in the local markets in which we operate, as well as, to a lesser
extent, global economic conditions. Such conditions include employment levels, inflation, GDP growth, average and
minimum wage levels, real disposable income, currency exchange rates, consumer confidence and consumer
willingness to spend. In addition, the outbreak and spread of COVID-19 resulted in national and local authorities
mandating or recommending various restrictions and other measures throughout most of 2020 and the first half of
2021, including mandatory business restrictions and closures and social distancing, quarantine and lockdown
measures. However, our grocery operations were classified as an essential business in all locations in which we operate
and remained open to serve the needs of our customers. As a result, with many other stores closed and consumers
often preferring to do as much shopping as they could in one place to minimise potential exposure to the virus, we
experienced exceptionally strong sales during this time. These results were partially offset by other challenges during
the COVID-19 pandemic, such as increased cleaning costs, supply chain delays, increased freight costs and wholesale
energy prices and shortages of certain raw materials. While our operations have largely recovered from the impacts
of COVID-19 and the worst of the outbreak is largely considered to be in the past, there could be additional outbreaks
and there is a risk of continued disruption as a result of such outbreaks at locations within our supply chain, or other
related disruption at suppliers.

As the COVID-19 pandemic waned and related governmental measures were eased, the economy reopened
and our results in 2022 and 2023 decreased from the highs experienced during the COVID-19 pandemic. However,
as the world emerged from the global pandemic, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine sparked an energy crisis which further
accelerated growing inflation and cost-of-living pressures have continued to create uncertainty for customers and
businesses alike. When consumers are confident about current and future economic conditions, we believe our
premium grocery offerings, some of which carry higher margins than core products, are more likely to attract shoppers
and that customers with rising disposable incomes are more likely to make impulse purchases, which can be margin
accretive and lift average basket sizes. Conversely, during an economic downturn, basket sizes may tend to decrease
while frequency of trips increases as customers disposable income reduces and they carefully manage their spend
within a more constrained household budget. Consumers may increasingly opt for cheaper alternatives, such as
“discount” retailers, and we may record more purchases of our affordably-priced and attractive mid-tier and opening
price point own-brand products relative to local and international third party branded goods.

The high inflationary environment, however, can also drive revenue as a result of the price inflation of
products, rather than solely relying on an increase in the volume of products sold. During times of economic stress,
however, we believe our value proposition is also particularly appealing to customers and can further drive sales and
volumes. As the current high inflationary environment persists, we are focused on initiatives to support our customers
in the cost-of-living crisis and protect market share by investing in price and quality. For example, in April 2022, we
launched our Dropped and Locked price campaign, which locked in the prices of a variety of products. As a result,
prices on these products dropped by an average of 12% and locked until the end of 2022 to give customers certainty
around their shopping in light of these cost-of-living pressures. While we expect the UK grocery market to remain
resilient into 2024, we also expect customers to continue feeling the impact of cost pressures on their household
budgets as they face a real wage decline, making it more important than ever that we continue to focus on providing
our strong value offering in food and non-food to enable us to serve customers on any type of budget. Additionally,
our expansion into the convenience market provides further opportunity as customers increasingly desire convenience
and accessibility and represents progress towards our strategic objective to be accessible to customers.

**_Convenience and Integration Strategies_**

The Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition have had a key role in shaping our commercial strategy,
and the implementation of these strategies and integration of these businesses will have an impact on our results of
operations.

We now have an active strategy to penetrate the convenience market, which will accelerate following the
acquisition of 356 PFSs and 124 standalone foodservice sites through the EG UK Acquisition and 116 convenience
sites as part of the Arthur Acquisition. Following the trial of Asda On the Move, where we offered Asda-branded
products at sites owned by EG Group, we recently launched the Asda Express brand for our standalone Asda owned
and operated convenience sites. These Asda Express convenience stores stock up to 3,000 branded and own-label
products to suit a broad range of customer needs. In December 2022, we opened our first two organic Asda Express
stores. We also have further organic Asda Express openings planned, with seven sites opened in 2023 (including five
opened in the fourth quarter of 2023) and a strong pipeline of approximately 40 sites that have been identified for
potential opening in 2024. The sites acquired from the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition have all been
converted to the Asda Express branding. We believe that these store concepts will allow us to access the convenience
market and are responsive to changes in our customers’ lifestyles. However, there can be no assurance that this venture
into the convenience sector will be successful or profitable. The development of this convenience proposition will
also require additional capital expenditures and may have a significant impact on our results of operations.

We also anticipate £86 million of synergies stemming from incremental uplift to Asda’s margin from the EG
UK Acquisition and the Arthur Acquisition. We expect to achieve these synergies from price investment in the fuel
and grocery offering, which we believe will lead to in an increase in volumes and will in turn enable buying benefits
across the Asda product portfolio. In addition, we expect synergies to arise from range optimisation, monetisation of
customer data, our increased scale, in-store marketing income, improvement in fuel card terms and operational
efficiencies. However, we cannot assure you that we will be able to successfully realise the expected synergies and
benefits from the EG UK Acquisition and the Arthur Acquisition, or that the costs to realise these synergies and
benefits will not be higher than anticipated.

The integration of the EG UK Business and Arthur Business into the Group could also result in various
challenges, including related to the integration of certain operating and IT systems, including point of sale systems
and inventory processing systems, the loss of customers or key employees, diversion of management’s attention, the
disruption of our respective ongoing businesses or possible inconsistencies in standards, procedures and policies.
Furthermore, certain contracts may have terms and conditions that are weaker than our standard contracts, and we
may not be able to integrate or update them as quickly as we would like or without incurring significant fees. In order
to fully integrate the financial accounting systems of our acquired businesses, we will have to complete the
implementation of our own standalone IT system. Prior to the completion of Project Future, the business acquired
from the Arthur Acquisition is being migrated onto the IT systems of EG Group. Both the Arthur Business and the
EG UK Business will remain on the IT systems of EG Group for a transitional period, after which, they will have to
be transitioned onto our new system. If the TSA expires before we complete the implementation of Project Future or
we are not able to successfully transfer onto our new IT platform, this could result in increased costs or a material
disruption to the business. Project Future and the integration of the Arthur Business and EG UK Business have
required, and will continue to require, additional capital investments by us, and may require incremental resources
and system configurations that could increase our operating costs in future periods, as we continue in our ongoing
efforts to maintain our control environment to the standards of a business of our size and scale.

**_Sensitivity of Our Cost Structure_**

Excluding purchases of goods sold, we have a largely fixed cost base in the short- to medium-term, which
does not fluctuate with sales volumes. Instead, our costs generally increase from period to period based on the
sensitivity of certain costs to inflation. We are able to control some costs to a certain degree, such as those related to
marketing and labour (via short-term contracts as well as adjustments to the number of hours our colleagues work),
but must maintain sufficient sales levels to absorb the increase in our expenses in order to maintain or improve our
retail margins. We have also been able to reduce overall costs by leveraging our vertically integrated procurement

116


-----

arm, IPL, which is a wholly-owned supplier that serves us exclusively and provides us with a cost price advantage by
eliminating the “middle man” in our supply chain and sources goods such as fresh fruit and vegetables, flowers, cooked
meats and wines. However, even after taking such actions, certain expenses such as rent, the price of food ingredients,
energy costs, energy taxes and other direct and indirect taxation are outside of our control. See “Risk Factors—Risks
_Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General Operations—We are vulnerable to cost_
_inflation and fluctuations in the availability and price of food ingredients and products, commodities and packing_
_material, as well as to fluctuations in the price of electricity and fuel and labour, transportation and manufacturing_
_costs.”_

Labour costs represent a significant part of our cost structure. Whilst we can adjust the size of our workforce,
where we have proposals to reduce our headcount, we have legal obligations to consult with colleague representatives
(including trade unions) and engage other labour force actors before proposals can be implemented. The obligation to
consult with colleague representatives may result in amendments to proposed reductions in headcount and therefore
take time before we can implement such changes should they proceed. Additionally, we are subject to laws setting
minimum wages. During the periods presented, the UK government increased the National Minimum Wage and
National Living Wage and we agreed to further wage increases to support our colleagues and ease inflationary
pressures, which had an impact on our cost structure and generally increased our costs, although this has been in part
offset by cost saving and efficiency initiatives. For example, in April 2023, we voluntarily increased our rate for hourly
paid store colleagues to £11.00 an hour and further increased this in July 2023 to £11.11 an hour. For stores inside the
M25 and around Greater London, our rate for hourly paid store colleagues increased to £12.28 an hour. The national
minimum wage is due to increase to £11.44 an hour in April 2024, and we plan to give our colleagues an interim
increase, with those inside the M25 and around Greater London receiving £12.61 an hour. In July 2024, we are
proposing a further increase in pay to 120,000 of our colleagues which will increase the basic pay for retail workers
to £12.04 an hour, with those at stores inside the M25 and around Greater London receiving £13.21 an hour. Overall,
this is an 8.4% increase in pay from £11.11 in July 2023 to the proposed £12.04 in July, 2024. Any further increase in
wages, energy, maintenance or any other input in our cost structure which is not mitigated, can also affect our results
of operations. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Business and Industry—Risks Relating to Our General
_Operations—Our failure to attract and retain qualified colleagues, increases in labour costs and social charges and_
_other changes to wage regulations could materially adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial_
_condition.”_

**_Investment in New Store Concepts and Channel and Product Innovation_**

One of the drivers of our results of operations is our ability to maintain our traditional customer base and
attract new customers through our ongoing investments in fulfilment capacity and development of our operations,
including the evolution of our network of brick-and-mortar retail stores. Our retail store network is largely mature;
however, we regularly evaluate the performance of our stores and have repositioned and remodelled stores under new
store concepts to improve our customers’ experience and respond to their changing preferences. For example, we have
refocused capital expenditure on remodelling our existing stores, in particular to realign store space and offerings to
enhance our customer proposition and better respond to customers’ shopping behaviour. In October 2020, we opened
our first “sustainability store” at our Middleton superstore location, which is a concept designed to encourage
customers to reuse and refill their products, allowing customers to bring and fill their own containers with products
such as coffee, rice, pasta and other goods, as well as offering second-hand clothing and increased recycling options.
We have since opened three further refill sections in our stores in Toryglen, York and Milton Keynes. We are also
further responding to shifting customer preferences, who increasingly desire fast and accessible products, through our
roll-out of our Asda Express convenience stores. See “—Convenience and Integration Strategies.” In addition to new,
standalone store concepts, we have also invested in new “shop within a shop” concepts with our Big Asda Toyshop,
which has its own merchandising and look and feel. We first trialled this concept in eight stores in 2022 and following
strong sales, we are aiming to roll it out in an additional 121 stores over the next year. We generally incur initial and
ongoing capital expenditure and pre-opening costs with each new grocery retail store and store concept.

We have also dedicated significant investment into the expansion of our online grocery channel, Asda
Groceries, our Click & Collect and ‘toyou’ parcel collection and return services, and rapid delivery services through
Uber Eats, Deliveroo and Just Eat to access new and existing customers who are increasingly shopping online, a trend
that accelerated during the COVID-19 pandemic. We intend to continue to target operating model improvements to
our online channel supported by developments in our IT infrastructure and use data to help us better understand our

117


-----

customers. In August 2022, we rolled out our new loyalty programme, Asda Rewards nationwide, following trials in
a number of stores earlier in the year. Asda Rewards provides customers with Asda pounds instead of points for their
loyalty through an app-based scheme. Customers earn cash back on their shopping, with regularly updated missions
and star products enabling extra savings. Asda Rewards grew to almost five million active users by the end of 2023
(over the prior 30-day period) and continues to deliver strong incremental sales for the Group, while also providing
valuable insight into the shopping patterns of our customers.

**_The Online Grocery Market in the United Kingdom_**

The United Kingdom has one of the most developed online grocery retail markets in the world, with one of
the highest rates of the population using the internet. We believe it will continue to grow in the mid-term, fuelled by
consumers shifting to online channels and at-home consumption, which accelerated following the COVID-19
pandemic. We believe our growth has been, and we expect our growth to continue to be in the medium term. According
to Kantar Worldpanel, we are the second-largest online grocery retail platform in the United Kingdom, holding 19.3%
of market share (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales) for the 52-week period ended January 21, 2024.

The UK online grocery market is intensely competitive. We compete with traditional grocery retailers that
are active in the online grocery retail market, including Tesco.com, Sainsburys.co.uk, Waitrose.com and
Morrisons.com, as well as with new competitors in the online grocery market, including broad-reaching e-commerce
companies such as Amazon, as well as pure online players like Ocado. In order to retain our competitiveness in the
evolving UK online grocery market, we continue to develop innovative customer solutions, such as our Express
Collection service which enables customers to place an order for collection within four hours while other grocers also
explore rapid delivery offerings (e.g., Ocado Zoom, Sainsbury’s Chop Chop). Furthermore, we continue to invest in
strategic partnerships that lead to innovation and that we believe will drive further increases in our market share, such
as our partnerships with Uber Eats, Just Eat and Deliveroo which provide express and last-mile delivery options for
convenience groceries. See “Business—Our Online Platform” and “Business—Our Tenants and Strategic Partners”
for further detail. We believe these broad-ranging online options, and in particular our in-store picking model, has
bolstered, and will continue to bolster, the performance of our online channel and our ability to adapt to shifting
consumer demands.

**_Monetisation and Accounting Treatment of Real Estate Asset Portfolio_**

We are supported by a significant freehold real estate backing from properties across the United Kingdom in
England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland. As part of the financing for the EG UK Acquisition, we utilised a
portion of our real estate portfolio and entered into the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions and 2023 Ground Rent
Transaction. In the future, we may continue to selectively monetise portions of our real estate portfolio to take
advantage of favourable trading conditions and pursue our strategic priorities on attractive terms. Such transaction
would have the effect of raising our interest expenses, which would depress net income.

In accordance with IAS 16 (Property, Plant and Equipment), land and buildings are stated at cost less
accumulated depreciation and impairment losses. Property, Plant and Equipment was recognised at fair value on
February 16, 2021 at the time of the original LBO Acquisition in accordance with the requirements of IFRS 3
(Business Combinations) which for the purposes of IAS 16 represents cost. These assets have subsequently been stated
at deemed cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses. Items under construction are valued at cost and
not depreciated. Depreciation is charged from the date that the assets are available for use on a straight-line basis over
the estimated useful lives of each part of an item of property, plant and equipment. Land is not depreciated. When an
item is disposed of or when no future economic benefits are expected to arise from its continued use, any gain or loss
arising on the derecognition of the asset is included in the income statement.

channels, where we believe there are significant opportunities to serve our customers in new and appealing ways. For
example, in 2023, we launched our first Deliveroo HOP site at the new ‘Asda Express’ convenience store in Tottenham

Certain partnerships have also allowed us to focus on our omni-channel proposition or expand our non-core

**_Key Factors Affecting the Comparability of Our Financial Information_**

The comparability of the Group’s historical financial information is impacted by a number of factors. This
section discusses key factors that the Group believes have had a material effect on the comparability of its results of
operations and financial condition during the periods under review, as well as those that are reasonably likely to have
a material effect on its results of operations and financial condition in the future.

**_Seasonality of Our Results of Operations_**

Our sales and cash flows are affected to a relatively limited extent by seasonal variations due to consumers’
shopping habits and, to a lesser extent, weather conditions. Family groups represent a significant proportion of our
customer base. As a result, our revenue has historically been comparatively higher during the Christmas and Easter
periods. In general, revenue shifts due to weather tend to be relatively short-term, with impacts occurring within a
given month, rather than across a quarter or a longer period. From time to time, we may also experience reduced sales
revenue if inclement or severe weather reduces in-store footfall and impulse purchases, without concomitant offset by
online sales. At the same time, adverse weather conditions, such as snow or flooding, can increase customer demand
for our online offerings, although they can also adversely affect our ability to deliver products to customers. In this
case, however, increased demand for online offerings would not likely offset reduced sales revenue in stores resulting
from inclement weather. In general, our fixed costs, including labour expenses (other than related to seasonal workers),
real estate leases and SG&A expenses, are more evenly distributed over the year. Additionally, our procurement and
sourcing activities are also generally more evenly spread throughout the year, except for a build-up in preparation for
the Christmas season and to a lesser extent a build-up in preparation for Easter in April. While our financial calendar
generally aligns with our operational profile, we experience calendar effects when, for example, the number of trading
days or payroll periods in a given period varies from period to period or year to year or certain holidays fall in different
periods from year to year. As a result of the foregoing, comparisons of consecutive interim periods may not be a good
indication of our performance, and the calendar effects we experience may have an impact on year-on-year
comparisons of interim periods.

**_Asda Group Pension Scheme Buy-In_**

During the year ended December 31, 2019, the trustees of the Asda Group Pension Scheme entered into an
agreement for a bulk annuity insurance buy-in of the Asda Group Pension Scheme with Rothesay Life. The agreement
was entered into with Rothesay Life, and insures the long-term benefits of approximately 12,300 members of the Asda
Group Pension Scheme. The buy-in transaction, which was enabled by a one-off final contribution by Asda of £0.7
billion and a loan facility made available by the Asda Group Pension Scheme’s sponsor, Asda Stores Limited (see

119


-----

below), has taken place ahead of a full scheme-buy-out that was completed in July 2021. The transaction removed
future Asda Group Pension Scheme liabilities from the Asda balance sheet, simplifying the business. The buy-out
means Asda Group Pension Scheme members have received an individual annuity policy, issued by Rothesay Life,
which will pay members’ pension benefits in full.

At the time of the buy-in, it was agreed that certain of the assets of the Asda Group Pension Scheme did not
meet the criteria for transfer to Rothesay Life pursuant to the buy-in transaction and were retained by the Asda Group
Pension Scheme (the “Illiquid Assets”). The sponsor of the scheme, Asda Stores Limited, agreed to make a loan
facility available to the trustees in an aggregate principal amount of £467.0 million in 2019 with the principal purpose
of providing liquidity to the Asda Group Pension Scheme to allow the trustees to pay the premium in full under the
buy-in policy with Rothesay Life, and also to provide prudent reserves that are available to fund the operation of the
Asda Group Pension Scheme up to completion of the buy-out and eventual winding-up (the “Pension Scheme
**Expenses”). The loan facility was set up on arm’s-length terms, including in relation to interest. Since completion of**
the buy-in transaction any proceeds realised in respect of the Illiquid Assets have been required to be applied by the
trustees to fund interest and principal payments under the loan facility, to the extent such proceeds are not required to
be retained to maintain prudent reserves with respect to the Pension Scheme Expenses. Pursuant to arrangements
agreed in connection with the LBO Acquisition Agreement, payments received by Asda Stores Limited under the loan
facility that are attributable to the Illiquid Assets are required to be paid to Walmart. Accordingly, the risk and reward
of the performance of the Illiquid Assets was effectively transferred to Walmart. To the extent that realisations from
the Illiquid Assets are insufficient to cover interest and principal payments owing to Asda Stores Limited under the
loan facility, Asda Stores Limited is obliged under a separate agreement to provide sufficient funding to the Asda
Group Pension Scheme to enable the trustees to fund such shortfall. As the amount of such funding provided by Asda
Stores Limited to the Asda Group Pension Scheme would be applied to repay the loan facility owing to Asda Stores
Limited, the combined effect of such transactions would have no net impact on Asda Stores Limited. Asda Stores
Limited reached an agreement with the trustees of the Asda Group Pension Scheme to make a cash contribution of
£214.6 million to the Asda Group Pension Scheme on December 30, 2020. Such amount was applied to repay amounts
due to Asda Stores Limited under the loan facility on the same day.

On July 9, 2021, the trustees of the Asda Group Pension Scheme completed the full buy-out of the Asda
Group Pension Scheme with Rothesay Life. Following this transaction, from the date of the buy-out, Rothesay Life
has become directly responsible for the Asda Group Pension Scheme liabilities and as such, the Asda Group Pension
Scheme assets and Scheme liabilities (except for a pension liability of £0.5 million, which has continued to be
accounted for as pension liabilities in line with the requirements of IAS 19 (Employee Benefits)) were derecognised
in the Group balance sheet from July 9, 2021. From the date of the buy-out, the outstanding balance on the buy-in
loan referred to above has been accounted for as a financial asset in line with the requirements of IFRS 9 (Financial
_Instruments). Any differences between the fair value of the buy-in loan and the pension asset at the date of the buy-in_
has been accounted for as a loss or gain within the other comprehensive income statement or the income statement
depending on their nature. We do not anticipate material amounts to be recognised in respect of these differences
individually or in aggregate.

The remaining liabilities with respect to the Asda Group Pension Scheme were settled in the year to
December 31, 2023. The carrying value of liabilities associated the Asda Group Pension Scheme at December 31,
2023 is £nil, compared to £0.5 million in at December 31, 2022.

**_The Acquisition Transactions_**

We consolidate the results of operations of any acquired business in our financial statements from the
acquisition date. The acquisition date is the date when the Group obtains control of the acquired business as defined
by IFRS 10 Consolidated Financial Statements. Therefore, our historical financial periods are not directly comparable
to one another. For example, following the closing date of the EG UK Acquisition on October 31, 2023, the results of
EG UK were consolidated into our results. Following the closing of the Arthur Acquisition in October 2022, the CMA
implemented an IEO and consequently, management concluded that the restrictions imposed by the IEO meant that
the Group did not obtain control of the Arthur Business at the closing date. On May 30, 2023, after accepting our
proposed remedies of disposing of 13 of the acquired sites, the CMA lifted the IEO and the results of the Arthur
Business were consolidated into our results from that date. Our results in 2023 have been impacted by the revenues
and expenses of the acquired business starting from the relevant date when we started consolidated the results of the
applicable acquired business, whereas prior comparative periods do not include the results of the acquired business.

120


-----

Moreover, if we incur additional debt or enter into new financing arrangements in connection with any acquisition,
our financial condition and results of operations will be impacted such instruments and may differ from the historical
financial condition and results of operations presented in this discussion. For example, on October 31, 2023, we
completed the EG UK Acquisition, which was also funded, among others, with the proceeds of external indebtedness,
including the Private Placement Facility and the America Bridge Loan, the latter of which was subsequently refinanced
with the proceeds from the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction. Accordingly, our financial condition and results of
operations following the EG UK Acquisition were, and will be, impacted by debt interest costs and rental expenses
and may differ from the historical financial condition and results of operations presented in this discussion.

In addition, all historical financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum is that of the Senior
Notes Issuer and its consolidated subsidiaries. However, the financial results of the Senior Notes Issuer do not include
a full year of trading in the year ended December 31, 2021, as it acquired the trading group Asda Group Limited part
way through the year on February 16, 2021. As a result, results for the year ended December 31, 2021 for the Senior
Notes Issuer consolidated group do not constitute a full comparative period.

In certain instances, to provide a more meaningful comparison, the results for the year ended December 31,
2021 down to the level of operating profit are presented on an annualised basis as if Asda Group Limited had been
acquired by the Senior Notes Issuer on January 1, 2021. Such annualised results are derived from the financial
statements of Bellis Finco plc for the period ended December 31, 2021 and the actual results of Asda Group Limited
from January 1, 2021 to the date of acquisition of Asda Group by Bellis Finco plc on February, 14 2021.

**_Other Income_**

Other income consists of income from concessions and commissions and rental income earned by the Group
as a lessor that comes from sources other than sale of goods and fuel.

**_Reimbursement Income_**

Reimbursement relates to a reimbursed settlement relating to historical tax reliefs, the gain on bargain
purchase of Asda Group Limited by the Senior Notes Issuer and the gain on 2021 Sale and Leaseback Transactions.

**_Operating costs_**

Operating costs include costs, other than finance costs and tax. The largest components of operating costs are
cost of goods sold (net of supplier rebates), employment costs, depreciation and amortisation, property costs including
business rates, utilities, marketing costs, distribution costs, maintenance expenses, consumables, store suppliers,
interchange fees and IT costs (including the costs of Project Future and charges under the TSA payable to Walmart).
For the year ended December 31, 2021, operating costs also included income (of which the most significant is income
from recycling of certain categories of waste) other than revenue, other income and finance income.

**_Finance income and finance costs_**

Finance income consists of bank interest receivable and interest receivable on amounts owed from fellow
subsidiary undertakings of the ultimate parent of the Group. Finance costs consist of external interest payable, interest
on lease liabilities, interest payable on amounts owed to fellow subsidiary undertakings of the ultimate parent of the
Group, asset retirement obligations discount unwind and net interest cost on the Asda Group’s defined benefit pension
schemes. External interest payable includes interest on external debt issued by the Group during the current year and
prior period, amortisation of fees incurred in relation to external debt and commitment fees and interest relating to the
Original Revolving Facility.

**_Income tax expense_**

Income tax expense comprises current taxation, including UK corporation tax and a UK corporation tax
adjustment to prior periods, as well as deferred taxation, including deferred taxation arising from the origination and

reversal of temporary differences, from changes in tax rates and laws, and from previously unrecognised tax losses,
tax credits or any temporary differences in prior periods.

_Revenue_

Revenue (including fuel) for the year ended December 31, 2023 was £25,616.9 million, an increase of
£1,139.1 million, or 4.7%, compared to £24,477.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was
due to growth in non-fuel sales, partly offset by an overall decline in fuel sales revenue, a result of the comparatively
lower average selling price in 2023 compared to high and volatile prices in 2022.

Revenue (excluding fuel) for the year ended December 31, 2023 was £21,898.4 million, an increase of
£1,446.1 million, or 7.1%, compared to £20,452.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was
primarily a result of growing revenue across both food and non-food in the existing Asda business, whilst also
reflecting the additional sales from the Arthur Business and the EG UK Business. The Group recorded particularly
strong year on year growth in the first half of 2023, by comparison to the first half of 2022, as a result of the impact
of weaker performance in the first half of 2022, following emergence from COVID-19 lockdowns and supply chain
challenges. Sales in the second half of 2023 showed more modest growth, partly due to unseasonable weather in the
summer and autumn, which impacted customer behaviour and created unpredictability, particularly in seasonal
categories, which was partially offset by positive impacts following the launch of Asda Rewards in August 2022.

Further commentary below provides detail on the performance of our key categories.

_Food_

Food sales increased in the year ended December 31, 2023 as compared to year ended December 31, 2022,
including impact of sales from the acquired businesses.

The Group has continued to invest in its food proposition in 2023, building on the success of the launch of
the Just Essentials opening price point range in 2022. Value remains a key priority, including the aim to pass along
the benefits of commodity price deflation where it has occurred and reflecting significant investment in our key
supplier relationships. Nevertheless, sales performance in 2023 continues to reflect the pass through of the significant
commodity price inflation which has occurred over the past two years.

The Group has continued to invest in driving quality improvement across our own-brand mid-tier offering.
Following refreshes to the Group’s produce, meat fish and poultry, and bakery in 2021 and 2022, the Group has
overhauled its core chilled, meal solutions, and cooking ingredients ranges in 2023. These categories are key signifiers
of quality and are central to the Group’s strategic priority to make desirable products affordable, giving customers a
reason to reappraise Asda’s offering. The Group has also launched a selection of premium sub-brands, including two
vegan-friendly ranges, Plant Based, a healthy, balanced selection of meat-free lines, and OMV!, an indulgent vegan
range, as well as ranges to rival takeaway offerings and key competitor prepared food ranges. These include, our
popular Bistro, Take Out and House of Yum ranges. The Group also launched some ambitious quality and taste match
campaigns during the year, including an M&S quality match across a range of popular items.

127


-----

_Non-food_

Non-food sales grew slightly in the year ended December 31, 2023 as compared to year ended December 31,
2022 on a like-for-like basis and were particularly strong in the first half of 2023, in both clothing and general
merchandise. Across both clothing and general merchandise, the third quarter was particularly impacted by the
unseasonal weather, but rebounded to like for like growth in the fourth quarter of 2023.

_Online_

Online sales comprise Asda.com grocery sales and non-food sales through George.com. Online grocery is a
key strength of the Group, where it held the number two grocery market share position throughout 2023, and online
is a key element of Asda’s omnichannel retail offering, fostering strong customer loyalty and typically larger spend
per basket. The proportion of sales made through online delivery and click and collect was slightly higher in 2023.

_Fuel_

Fuel sales were £3,719 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, a decrease of 7.6% as compared to
£4,026 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. A decrease in the Asda legacy business’ fuel sales was
predominantly due to the lower average selling price of fuel in 2023 compared to 2022, which saw record and volatile
commodity prices following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. This was partly offset by the additional fuel sales from the
acquired businesses.

_Foodservice_

The Group acquired 419 food service outlets in the EG UK Business, comprising franchises of brands
including Greggs, Subway and Burger King, as well as one proprietary brand Leon. Food service sales of £40 million
were recorded in 2023 following the completion of the EG UK Acquisition. We believe that the addition of foodservice
to Asda’s portfolio is a strong strategic fit and complements our omni-channel retail offering, with further opportunity
for growth and synergies within the store estate.

_Other income_

Other income for the year ended December 31, 2023 was £70.9 million, an increase of £1.1 million, or 1.6%,
compared to £69.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily a result of slightly
increased rental income for the year ended December 31, 2022.

_Operating costs_

Operating costs post-underlying items for the year ended December 31, 2023 were £25,119.2 million, an
increase of £430.9 million, or 1.7%, compared to £24,688.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase
was primarily a result of increases in the cost of goods sold as a result of higher sales, year-on-year increases in
inventory losses, investments in colleague pay and a year-on-year increase in Project Future costs, as well as additional
transaction costs relating to the EG UK Acquisition in the year ended December 31, 2023.

_Finance income_

Finance income post-underlying items for the year ended December 31, 2023 was £52.5 million, a decrease
of £2.9 million, or 5.2%, compared to £55.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2022. This decrease was primarily
due to a £23.0 million decrease in interest receivable from a fellow subsidiary of the ultimate parent, after an exercise
to settle intercompany loan receivables and payables was carried out in September 2022. This decrease was partially
offset by a £20.6 million increase in bank interest receivable, driven by an increase in interest rates on short-term
deposits, and higher average cash balances. This included the impact of £646 million of net proceeds in respect of the
Sale and Leaseback Transaction, the majority of which was received approximately 11 weeks in advance of the
completion of the EG UK Acquisition.

_Revenue_

Revenue (including fuel) for the year ended December 31, 2022 was £24,477.8 million, an increase of £989
million, or 4.2%, compared to £23,489 million on an annualised basis for the year ended December 31, 2021. Actual
revenue (including fuel) for the year ended December 31, 2021 was £20,710.4 million. This increase was primarily
due to higher fuel prices in the year driven by inflation in oil prices, and higher fuel volume sales following lockdowns
in the year ended December 31, 2021 impacting travel.

Revenue (excluding fuel) for the year ended December 31, 2022 was £20,452 million, an increase of £28
million, or 0.1%, compared to £20,424 million on an annualised basis for the year ended December 31, 2021. Actual
revenue (excluding fuel) for the year ended December 31, 2021 was £17,900 million. Revenue for the year ended
December 31, 2022 was broadly in line with the prior year. Performance in the first half of 2022 was challenging. In
the context of growing inflation and cost of living pressures and exceptional sales in 2021 during COVID-19
lockdowns, we experienced a decline in like-for-like sales and some loss of market share. Performance recovered in
the second half of the year and showed strong growth, driven by new initiatives to drive strategic objectives, including
launching Dropped and Locked prices, Just Essentials and Asda Rewards. Market share recovered in the second half
of the year and the total number of customer transactions increased.

Further commentary below provides detail on the performance of our key categories.

_Food_

In the first six months of the year ended December 31, 2022 we experienced like-for-like decline in sales due
to the tailwind from COVID-19 related lockdowns in 2021 which led to an increase in at-home grocery consumption.
The lockdown was in place for the majority of the first quarter of 2021, with some restrictions continuing into the

130


-----

second quarter of 2021 and beyond. We also experienced loss of market share over the first six months of the year
ended December 31, 2022 which further contributed to like-for-like sales declines.

From the second quarter of 2022 onwards, we experienced an improvement in sales momentum and recorded
positive like-for-like results for the second half of the year. Food sales were boosted following the launch of Asda’s
Dropped and Locked price campaign, which locked prices for customers in light of cost-of-living pressures. The
campaign saw prices of a wide selection of family favourite products dropped and locked until the end of the year to
give customers certainty around their shopping. In May 2022, Asda launched its new opening price point own brand
range, Just Essentials by Asda. The range replaced Asda Smart Price, with new branding and products reformulated
for taste and quality, doubling the number of items in the range and providing all the products customers need to keep
the household running on a budget.

Throughout the year ended December 31, 2022, we also continued our investment in mid-tier own-brand
ranges. Following on from refreshing the produce range in the year ended December 31, 2021, we overhauled our
bakery and meat, fish and poultry categories including expanding the range of products, improving the quality and
refreshing the packaging. These categories are key signifiers of quality and are central to our strategic priority to make
desirable products affordable, giving customers a reason to reappraise our offering and contributing to strong
like-for-like sales growth in food in the last six months of year ended December 31, 2022.

In August 2022, we rolled out our new loyalty programme Asda Rewards nationwide, following successful
trials in a number of stores since the start of the year. Asda Rewards provides customers with Asda pounds, not points,
for their loyalty through an app-based scheme. Customers earn cash back on their shopping, with regularly updated
missions and star products enabling extra savings.

_Non-food_

In non-food sales, performance in the second quarter of 2022 was similarly lower than the comparative period
in 2021 when we benefited from non-essential retail stores being closed during COVID-19 lockdowns. Sales in both
clothing and general merchandise were also impacted by supply chain challenges from the fourth quarter of 2021
which led to the wrong stock being in place in the early part of the year. Direction provided by new leadership
contributed to significant improvement in sales momentum in the second quarter of 2022, in particular following the
Queen Elizabeth’s Jubilee Weekend, when our proposition appealed strongly to customers and we delivered new
relevant product. In the third quarter of 2022, clothing grew ahead of the market, with particular strengths in women’s
wear and back to school sales, supported by improvements in merchandising and in-store shopping experience
following reopening fitting rooms after COVID-19-related closures. In the fourth quarter of 2022, clothing sales were
impacted by availability challenges resulting which arose during a major system upgrade. Some issues with the transfer
to the new system led to challenges in visibility and allocating stock, preventing product from being distributed around
the store network appropriately; however, sales recovered in December 2022 following resolution of these issues and
have since continued in positive growth in line with expectations.

In General Merchandise, the George Home range delivered strong performance in the second half of the year
ended December 31, 2022, offering an affordable and stylish proposition to customers. Highlights included summer
outdoor and seasonal ranges, with particular growth in energy-saving and winter products to support customers
through the cost of living and energy crisis in the fourth quarter of 2022.

_Online_

We have a strong market position in grocery home shopping, with around 16% of our food sales coming
through online channels in the year ended December 31, 2022 (including home delivery and click and collect services).
Online continues to be a key part of our omni-channel strategy to enable customers to shop wherever and however
they choose. Online sales stabilised in the year ended December 31, 2022 following considerable growth in the channel
during the COVID-19 pandemic; total online sales for the full year were slightly lower than the prior year and lower
as a proportion of total sales, as more customers returned to shopping instore. We continue to invest in ways to optimise
the online experience for customers, focusing on availability, range and service.

_Other income_

Other income for the year ended December 31, 2022 was £69.8 million, a decrease of £2,863.6 million,
compared to £2,933.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This decrease was primarily due to the gain on
bargain purchase of the Asda Group Limited by the Senior Notes Issuer of £2,654 million, and the gain on sale and
leaseback of the warehouse assets of £279 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, which was not repeated in
the year ended December 31, 2022. In the year ended December 31, 2022 other income was primarily related to rental
income and concession and commission income.

_Operating costs_

Operating costs post-underlying items for the year ended December 31, 2022 were £24,688.3 million, an
increase of £4,425.8 million, or 21.8%, compared to £20,262.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This
increase was primarily due to significant increase in inflation across our cost base, partially offset to a certain extent
by cost saving initiatives such as bringing cleaning in-house from a third-party supplier, delivering operating
efficiencies in our stores and depots and reduction in COVID-19-related costs.

There has been a significant increase in supply side inflation in the year ended December 31, 2022, in
particular following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Labour shortages, investment in colleague wages, increases in
energy and fuel cost inflation have driven higher cost prices in our supply base and in our own cost base. In our
non-food business, margins were also impacted by significant increases in freight, detention and demurrage costs as
the global economy emerged from the pandemic, exacerbated by further lockdowns in China, and adverse movements
in foreign exchange rates following the UK mini-budget in September 2022. In the selling, general and administrative
cost base, we also saw notable cost increases which impacted profitability. These cost increases included energy costs
for operating our stores, depots and offices and fuel costs in running our logistics and online operations. We also
incurred additional exceptional costs in the year ended December 31, 2022 relating to our investment in Project Future,
and transaction costs incurred in connection with the LBO Acquisition.

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

Our principal source of liquidity on an ongoing basis is expected to be our operating cash flows and
borrowings under our New Revolving Facility. Our cash-generative business, due to the nature of the grocery industry,
together with our relatively low capital expenditure, has driven cash flow generation, including comparatively high
unlevered free cash flow.

Our ability to generate cash depends on our future operating performance, which, in turn, depends to some
extent on general economic, financial, industry and other factors, many of which are beyond our control. See “Risk
_Factors.” We are a structurally negative working capital business driven by growth in payables, and the beneficial_
payment terms to suppliers versus payments received by consumers instantly on purchase. In 2023, we increased our
focus on cash management, particularly related to working capital. We delivered a very strong net working capital
performance in 2022 and 2023, with our active working capital management resulting in increased working capital
inflows in those two years. These improvements in net working capital were driven partly through key supplier partner
negotiations related to the deferral of cash payables. Stock was also more tightly managed and we began to see a more
favourable trajectory for fuel price and volume.

Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operations, together with available borrowings under
our New Revolving Facility, will be adequate to meet our anticipated working capital and general corporate needs for
the next 12 months, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operating activities

133


-----

or that future debt financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due,
including the Senior Secured Notes offered hereby, or to fund our other liquidity needs. The availability of our New
Revolving Facility is dependent upon certain conditions, including compliance with a springing maintenance covenant
as described further under “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement.”

The Senior Facilities Agreement shall, with effect on and from the Issue Date, provide for the multi-currency
senior secured New Revolving Facility in an aggregate amount at least £747,722,727 (with a possible incremental
commitment of £45,000,000 under the New Revolving Facility, which could be made available on or shortly after the
Issue Date). The New Revolving Facility may be utilised by any Original Revolving Facility Borrower or Additional
Revolving Facility Borrower (subject to certain exceptions) under the Senior Facilities Agreement. Pursuant to the
terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement, a Lender may also provide Letters of Credit, Fronted Ancillary Facilities or
Ancillary Facilities (in each case as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) on a bilateral basis in place of all or
part of its Revolving Facility Commitment (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement).

Pursuant to the terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement, loans made under the New Revolving Facility may
be borrowed, repaid and re-borrowed at any time. Such loans will be available to be used for, amongst other purposes,
general corporate and working capital purposes of the Group (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) and,
without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing, to fund certain permitted acquisitions and capital expenditure and
to backstop existing ancillary facilities, letters of credit and/or hedging arrangements of the Group.

The Group is subject to certain customary affirmative, negative and incurrence covenants under the Senior
Facilities Agreement, which impose restrictions on, among other things, incurrence of other debt, making restricted
payments, disposal of assets and granting of security, subject to certain agreed exceptions and permissions,
qualifications and thresholds. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements.”

The New Revolving Facility is expected to be undrawn at the Issue Date and the Original Revolving Facility
has been undrawn since the first quarter of 2022.

**_Capital Expenditure_**

The Group typically has relatively low capital expenditure requirements. Capital expenditure has on average

plant and equipment and purchase of intangible assets. We also use Capital Expenditure KPI as a key performance
indicator, which is defined as the total costs of property, plant and equipment and intangible assets of which the Group
takes ownership within a financial period (as opposed to the UK IFRS measurement of capital expenditure which is
based on cash flows). It excludes capital expenditure on Project Future, our investment to separate from Walmart’s IT

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Financial Risk Overview**

**_Overview_**

In the ordinary course of the Group’s business, it is exposed to a variety of market risks arising in relation to
its financial assets and liabilities, including credit risk, interest rate risk, liquidity risk, foreign currency risk and capital
risk. The Group has a risk management programme in place through which it seeks to mitigate the adverse effects of
these market risks. In addition, the Group hedges interest and exchange rate exposure on foreign currency debt
obligations. We do not enter into financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes.

**_Credit risk_**

We believe there is no significant credit risk within the Group. The maximum credit risk exposure relating
to financial assets is included in their carrying value as at the balance sheet date. See note 18 (“Trade, other receivables
_and derivative assets”) of the 2023 Financial Statements for further information on trade receivables, intercompany_
receivables and details of recoverability.

The Group has established procedures to minimise the risk of default in relation to trade receivables including
detailed credit checks undertaken before a customer is accepted. Surplus cash is placed in both short-term deposits
and money market funds with various global financial institutions. This is managed by the Group’s treasury function
which actively monitors the market in order to identify the best terms of deposit in keeping with internal objectives.
This includes monitoring the credit rating of counterparties and investing in accordance with our internal policy.
Counterparty credit limits are reviewed on a monthly basis, and may be updated throughout the financial year. The
limits are set to minimise the concentration of risk and are set taking into account the type of financial asset and the
credit rating of the financial institution.

Intercompany receivables have been considered in relation to the expected credit losses model under IFRS 9
and the impact is not material. As such, the provision for expected credit losses is less than £0.1 million (as compared
to less than £0.1 million in the year ended December 31, 2022).

**_Interest rate risk_**

The Group is exposed to interest rate risk on its floating rate liabilities (based on SONIA and EURIBOR)
primarily composed of the Senior Facilities. During 2023, the Group was exposed to interest rate risk on a bridge
facility entered into to partially fund the Arthur Acquisition (the “Arthur Additional Bridge Facility”), this was
settled in full on October 23, 2023. The EURIBOR interest rate risk on Original Facility B is hedged through entering
into cross-currency interest rate swaps to fix the interest payments in pound sterling at rates between 3.70% and 3.76%
which expired on February 16, 2024. The SONIA interest rate risk on the Private Placement Facility entered into
during 2023 is hedged through entering into interest rate swaps to fix a proportion of the interest payments at a fixed
interest rate between 4.75% and 4.78% which expires on November 16, 2025. Interest on the Senior Secured Notes
and the Senior Unsecured Notes is charged at fixed rates between 3.25% and 4.50%.

The Existing Senior Secured Notes are set at fixed rates of 3.25% and 4.50%. The Existing Senior Notes are
set at a fixed rate of 4.00%. The Senior Secured Notes will also be a fixed rate instrument.

138


-----

The Group, after the impact of hedge accounting, is exposed to possible changes in SONIA on its outstanding
floating rate loans. In the year ended December 31, 2023, it is anticipated that a 0.5% increase in the SONIA rate
would give rise to a decrease in profit before tax of £1.8 million (as compared to £1.2 million in the year ended
December 31, 2022 and £0.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2021).

The Group’s Original Facility A, and Original Revolving Facility have been impacted by the interest rate
benchmark reform in 2022. The Group transitioned these agreements to the new UK risk-free rate benchmark, SONIA,
which was applied to the Group’s interest period starting April 1, 2022 and which will also apply to New Facility A
and the New Revolving Facility. See note 21 (“Financial Instruments”) of the 2023 Financial Statements for further
information on interest rate risk.

_Interest rate swaps_

The Group has entered into the Private Placement Facility with interest rates calculated based on SONIA.
The variable interest rate exposes the Group to interest rate fluctuations that impact the profit or loss on a consolidated
basis.

At December 31, 2023, the Group holds interest rate swaps (“IRS”) with a total nominal value of £540.0
million, designated as cash flow hedges. The hedge ratio is on a 79% current notional basis. These IRS result in a
fixed GBP interest rate ranging from 11.50% to 11.53%.

The IRS were assessed to be highly effective and as at December 31, 2023, a net unrealised loss of £4.8
million was included in the hedge reserve in respect of these swaps. The net loss recognised in other comprehensive
income during the year in respect of these swaps was £4.8 million. This consists of a £0.4 million gain reclassified to
the income statement during the year and a £6.0 million loss on the fair value of the swaps at year end and a taxation
credit of £1.6 million.

The value of the IRS is sensitive to movements in SONIA. A 0.5% change in SONIA results in a £10.9
million change in value of the IRS.

Following the Transactions, we plan to re-evaluate the implementation of foreign exchange and interest rate
hedging contracts in line with our historical approach.

**_Foreign currency risk_**

_Forward currency hedging contracts_

The Group purchases goods and services denominated in currencies other than pounds sterling. Cash flows
can be affected by movements in exchange rates, primarily US dollars and euro. Some purchases in US dollars are
managed using forward contracts.

The Group implements hedge accounting and has forward currency hedging contracts outstanding at
December 31, 2023, designated as hedges of expected future purchases from suppliers in US dollars. The forward
currency contracts are being used to hedge the foreign currency risk of future purchases. The terms of the forward
currency hedging contracts have been negotiated to match the terms of the commitments and none exceed a period of
more than 18 months after December 31, 2023. Amounts recognised in other comprehensive income are transferred
to the income statement when the hedged transaction affects profit or loss.

The cash flow hedges of the expected future purchases were assessed to be highly effective and at
December 31, 2023, a net unrealised loss of £12.2 million (as compared to a net unrealised gain of £36.2 million at
December 31, 2022 and a net unrealised gain of £43.7 million at December 31, 2021) was included in the hedge
reserve in respect of hedging contracts. The net loss recognised in other comprehensive income during the year ended
December 31, 2023 in respect of these hedging contracts was £15.8 million (as compared to a net loss of £7.5 million
at December 31, 2022 and a net gain of £43.7 million at December 31, 2021) and a gain of £32.6 million was
reclassified to retained earnings during the year ended December 31, 2023. This consists of a £36.3 million loss on
not-yet-matured contracts during the year (as compared to a gain of £14.4 million at December 31, 2022 and a net
gain of £11.6 million at December 31, 2021), £15.3 million of losses reclassified to the income statement during the
year (as compared to £23.4 million of gains at December 31, 2022 and £42.3 million of losses at December 31, 2021)
and a £5.2 million taxation credit (as compared to a £1.5 million taxation credit as at December 31, 2022 and a £10.2
million charge as at December 31, 2021).

Under the Group’s hedging policy, forward currency contracts can be used for both goods for resale and
goods not for resale. The only items for which forward currency contracts are in place as at December 31, 2023 are
forecast purchases of goods for resale. The Group hedges up to 100% of forecast cash flows. Gains and losses
attributable to forward contracts are transferred to cost of inventories recognised as an expense within the income
statement at the point of sale. Forward contracts entered into which are not in line with forecast cash flows would be
the principal source of hedge ineffectiveness. No instances of this have occurred during the year ended December 31,
2023 (which was also the case during the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022), therefore amounts recognised
in the income statement in relation to ineffective forward contract hedges were £nil (which was also the case during
the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2022).

At December 31, 2023, the Group held £1,234.4 million of outstanding forward foreign currency contracts,
designated as cash flow hedges (as compared to £749.5 million as at December 31, 2022 and £699.9 million as at
December 31, 2021). These forward contracts are largely in relation to purchases of US dollars (notional $1,470.0
million) and euros (notional €71.4 million) with varying maturities up to June 2025. For the above currencies the rates
ranged from USD/GBP from 1.210 to 1.302 (as compared to 1.098 to 1.369 in the year ended December 31, 2022 and
1.315 to 1.420 in the year ended December 31, 2021) and euro/GBP 1.142 to 1.164 (as compared to 1.132 to 1.157 in
the year ended December 31, 2022 and 1.165 to 1.189 in the year ended December 31, 2021).

As the Group manages much of its foreign currency exposure using forward currency contracts, changes in
exchange rates are not expected to have a significant impact on short-term profitability or cash flow. It is anticipated
that a 5% movement in the US Dollar/pounds sterling exchange rate, which represents management’s assessment of
a reasonably possible change, would give rise to a movement in the cash flow hedge reserve of £47.2 million at
December 31, 2023 (as compared to a movement of £34.6 million in December 31, 2022 and a movement of
£33.5 million during the year ended December 31, 2021).

140


-----

See note 21 (“Financial Instruments”) of the 2023 Financial Statements for further information on foreign
currency risk.

_Cross-currency swap_

The Group has entered into Facility B (EUR) which is a floating rate euro denominated term loan facility.
The non-pounds sterling interest and principal repayment cash flows from the euro debt agreement expose the Group
to fluctuations in foreign exchange rates that impact the consolidated basis.

Under the Group’s hedging policy, the Group hedges both the foreign exchange and interest rate risk
associated with a portion of the Group’s existing euro foreign-currency denominated debt using EUR-GBP cross
currency interest rate swap contracts to effectively eliminate variability in the Group’s functional currency equivalent
cash flows due to variability in the EUR-GBP exchange rate and the variable interest rate. The hedge ratio is 100%
on a current notional basis. The Group has excluded from the cross-currency interest rate swap both the time value
and currency basis elements of the cross-currency interest rate swap. Ineffectiveness could arise from movements in
counterparty credit spread, the non-zero fair value at the hedge designation date due to market changes that have
occurred since the instrument’s inception and changes to critical terms (such as reset dates, index mismatches or
payment dates). To test the hedge effectiveness, the Group uses the hypothetical derivative method and compares the
changes in the fair value of the hedging instruments against the change in fair value of the hedged items attributable
to the hedged risks. The amounts recognised in the income statement for the year ended December 31, 2023 relating
to ineffectiveness and excluded items was less than £0.3 million (as compared to less than £0.1 million in the year
ended December 31, 2022).

At December 31, 2023, the Group holds cross-currency interest rate swaps (“CCIRS”) with a total nominal value of
€844.5 million, designated as cash flow hedges. These swaps result in a fixed pounds sterling interest rate ranging
from 3.70% to 3.76% and EUR/GBP rate of 1.1412. On February 16, 2024, following the expiration of the CCIRSs
in place as at December 31, 2023, the Group entered into new CCIRSs with an expiration date of February 16, 2025
with the same counterparty banks. This eliminates variability in the Group’s functional currency equivalent cash flows
in relation to Original Facility B (EUR) for the Group for the 12-month period to February 16, 2025 and fixes the
interest rate on Original Facility B (EUR) at fixed GBP interest rates of between 8.03% and 8.06%. The Group is also
currently contemplating additional cross-currency swaps as well as interest rate swaps in respect of the unhedged
portion of its ongoing EUR exposure and floating rate exposure respectively under the Senior Facilities Agreement.
See “Risk Factors— Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure and the Senior Secured Notes—Currency exchange rates
_may have an impact on our business, financial condition, liquidity, results of operations and prospects.”_

The CCIRSs were assessed to be highly effective and as at December 31, 2023, a net unrealised gain of £3.1
million (as compared to £21.2 million at December 31, 2022 and £6.6 million at December 31, 2021) was included in
the hedge reserve in respect of these swaps. The net loss recognised in the cash flow hedge reserve during 2023 in
respect of these swaps was £18.1 million (as compared to a gain £14.5 million at December 31, 2022 and a gain of
£7.3 million at December 31, 2021). This consists of a £2.5 million gain reclassified to the income statement during
2023 (as compared to £35.5 million gain at December 31, 2022 and £34.6 million loss at December 31, 2021), by a
£21.8 million loss (as compared to a £54.9 million gain at December 31, 2022 and £25.5 million loss at December 31,
2021) on the fair value of the swaps at period end and a taxation credit of £6.3 million (as compared to £4.8 million
at December 31, 2022 and £2.4 million at December 31, 2021).

The value of the CCIRSs is sensitive to movements in EURIBOR and EUR/GBP exchange rates. A 0.5%
change in EURIBOR would result in a £2.8 million change in value of the CCIRSs (as compared to £2.9 million at
December 31, 2022 and £6.5 million at December 31, 2021) and a 5% change in the EUR/GBP exchange rates would
result in a £47.2 million change in the value of the CCIRSs (as compared to £38.9 million at December 31, 2022 and
£38.1 million at December 31, 2021). The amounts charged to the income statement are not sensitive to a change in
interest rates but a 5% increase in the FX rate would increase the amount of ineffectiveness by £nil (as compared to
£nil at December 31, 2022 and £0.4 million at December 31, 2021).

Following the Transactions, we plan to re-evaluate the implementation of foreign exchange and interest rate
hedging contracts in line with our historical approach.

**_Capital risk_**

The Group is subject to the risk that its capital structure may not be sufficient to support the growth of its
business and maintain its existing credit rating. The capital structure of the Group consists of debt obligations

Notes) and equity (issued share capital, share premium and reserves).

Part of the Group’s capital risk management strategy is to monitor a broad range of financial metrics and
manage compliance with financial covenants relating to the Group’s debt obligations. As at December 31, 2023, there
have been no breaches of financial covenants.
