**Overview**

The retail sector in the United Kingdom, across all sales channels, was estimated by Euromonitor in the Retail
2024 edition to have had sales of approximately £460.4 billion in 2023, compared to £439.3 billion in 2022 (based on
a retail value retail sales price basis excluding sales tax (“Retail Value **RSP”) in current value terms), and to have**
grown at a CAGR of 3.0% between 2009 and 2023. According to Euromonitor, grocery retail – referring to the sum
of hypermarkets and supermarkets, convenience stores, discounters, forecourt retail, warehouse clubs, small local
grocers and food/drink/tobacco specialists – is the single largest category of retail spending in the United Kingdom.
It represented £200.6 billion of Retail Value RSP (comprising approximately 44% of total retail sales) in 2023,
compared to £190.7 billion of Retail Value RSP (comprising approximately 43% of total retail sales) in 2022. In the
past fourteen years, grocery retail in the United Kingdom only experienced negative year-on-year growth in 2015
(negative 0.2%) and 2016 (negative 4.6%), in spite of macroeconomic, uncertainties and periods of food deflation
measured by the consumer price index (“CPI”), according to the OECD.

We operate in the retail market, offering a wide range of both food and non-food products and services from
our supercentres, superstores, supermarkets, convenience and Asda Living stores, as well as through various online

**_UK Grocery Retail Market Competitive Landscape_**

The following chart illustrates the UK grocery market breakdown by channel on a Retail Value RSP basis
and its development between 2009 and 2023, as well as the CAGRs between the years 2009 and 2016, 2016 and 2023,
and 2009 and 2023.

_(Source: Euromonitor: Retail 2024 Edition; Retail Value RSP excl. Sales Tax, GBP, Current terms. Note: The UK grocery retail market refers to_
_the sum of channels, including hypermarkets and supermarkets, convenience stores, discounters, forecourt retail, warehouse clubs, small local_
_grocers as well as food/drink/tobacco specialists.)_

Grocery retail sales in the United Kingdom are made via multiple channels, including hypermarkets,
supermarkets, convenience stores, discounters, forecourt retailers and online. We currently operate in the hypermarket,
supermarket, convenience, forecourt and online channels.

Hypermarkets are larger-format retail stores, frequently located on out-of-town sites or as anchor stores in a
shopping centre, with a primary focus on selling food, beverages, tobacco and other groceries while offering a wide
variety of non-grocery products, such as general merchandise and clothing. Supermarkets are smaller-scale retail
stores that offer a wide variety of food, beverages and household products. Hypermarket formats are offered by the
traditional grocers, while supermarket stores are offered by stores such as the Co-op, Waitrose and M&S, in addition
to the traditional grocers. Based on Euromonitor data, the sum of hypermarket and supermarket channels constitute
the largest share by Retail Value RSP of the UK grocery retail market, representing 54.1% of grocery Retail Value
RSP in 2023. However, in the last five calendar years, growth for the sum of these two channels has slowed, with a
combined CAGR of 2.3% between 2018 and 2023, according to Euromonitor.

In contrast, over the past 15 years convenience stores such as Tesco Express, Sainsbury’s Local, Co-op On
the Go, Little Waitrose and M&S Simply Food, have gained popularity. In 2023, they represented 19.0% of Retail
Value RSP and are the second-largest channel in the grocery retail market, according to Euromonitor.

The forecourt channel represented 3.0% of the total grocery retail market on a Retail Value RSP basis in
2023 and grew at a CAGR of 2.3% between 2016 and 2023, according to Euromonitor. This was driven by recent
initiatives from forecourt operators to improve the food product quality and the foodservice offering. Forecourts also
usually have longer opening hours compared to hypermarkets and supermarkets and are often in close proximity to
end consumers. Based on Euromonitor, convenience retailers grew at a CAGR of 3.4% between 2015 and 2023.
Excluding convenience retailers, the UK grocery retail market grew at a 2.5% CAGR between 2015 and 2023.

The 2007-2009 global financial crisis and the resulting weakened customer sentiment thereafter helped
discounters (mainly represented by Aldi and Lidl) to gain a strong foothold in the UK grocery retail market. Between

147


-----

2007 and 2015, discounters gained considerable scale and market share due to new store openings and increased
footfall resulting primarily from product offerings targeted at increasingly price-conscious customers. According to
Euromonitor, the discounters channel represented 14.0% of the total grocery retail market on a Retail Value RSP basis
in 2023. For more information, see “—UK Grocery Retail _Key Trends.”_

Since the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, the UK grocery retail market has seen an increasing shift away
from physical stores to online purchasing, with online grocery sales having grown significantly faster than those of
physical stores in recent years. According to Euromonitor, in 2023, the online channel (food & drink e-commerce)
comprised 13.8% of the UK grocery retail market. The online channel, which has also reported strong Retail Value
RSP growth historically, with a CAGR of 20.3% between 2018 and 2023, is driven by shoppers’ growing appetite for
convenience and digital connectivity, as well as by service enhancements in online operations. Following the outbreak
of the COVID-19 pandemic, this growth has been bolstered as customers increasingly turn to online groceries in order
to maintain social distance, a trend which may result in a sustained change in preferences going forward.

On the basis of Till Roll data for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, we are the third-largest player in the
UK grocery retail market (with a 13.7% market share), according to Kantar Worldpanel. Other key players are Tesco
(with a 27.3% market share), Sainsbury’s (with a 15.1% market share) and Aldi (with a 9.8% market share), in each
case on the basis of Till Roll data for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel. Together,
the traditional grocers of Tesco, Asda, Sainsbury’s and Morrisons comprise 64.9% of the total market on the basis of
Till Roll data for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel. Other grocery retailers
include Aldi, Co-op, Lidl and Waitrose. Waitrose operates at the premium end of the market and commands a lower
share of the market at 4.5%, while the discounters Aldi and Lidl hold market shares of 9.8% and 7.6%, respectively,
in each case according to Kantar Worldpanel and on the basis of Till Roll data for the 52 weeks ended January 21,
2024.

The UK clothing and footwear retail market experienced a significant downturn in 2020 due to COVID-19

with a 17.3% and 20.6% decrease respectively in the value of retail sales of clothing and footwear at current prices
(seasonally adjusted) compared to the same period a year earlier, according to ONS. As a result of COVID-19 related
lockdowns, the UK clothing and footwear retail market also experienced a significant shift from in-store purchasing
to online channels, which saw a 22.3% year-on-year growth according to Euromonitor.

In the years following the COVID-19 pandemic, the UK clothing and footwear retail market recovered
beyond pre-pandemic levels by 2022, with a market value of £43.6 billion, according to Euromonitor. The return of
office working and in-person social events increased the need to purchase more formal clothing and footwear, while
the easing of COVID-19 restrictions has fuelled footfall recovery. This was further supported by pent-up demand and
local consumers missing the in-person shopping experience. Altogether, the in-store channel has benefitted from a
6.9% year-on-year growth and is valued at £28.8 billion in 2023, according to Euromonitor. While a smaller segment
of customers have either remained in a remote work environment or visited stores less often, as online shopping
consumer behaviour became the norm in a post-pandemic environment, sales for retail e-commerce fell in 2022.
Although habit persistence among some consumers ensured that overall sales levels for the latter remained
significantly higher than pre-pandemic levels. For a further discussion of Asda’s position in the clothing market,

**UK Grocery Retail Key Trends**

The UK grocery retail market has been undergoing a fundamental shift in recent years, driven by changing
customer lifestyles, technological changes, evolving competitive dynamics and socio-economic factors. These trends
have led to a shift towards discounters, convenience stores and online channels, amongst other changes.

We believe there are five key trends that may shape the future of the UK grocery retail market: the increased
focus on value-based propositions and the growth of the discounters, the growth of the online channel, the shift to
convenience, the redefinition of service expectations and the increased demands for social responsibility.

**_Increased focus on Value-Based Propositions and Growth of the Discounters_**

Since the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and as bolstered by recent inflationary conditions and the current
cost of living pressures, customers have become increasingly price sensitive. Such customers, however, still desire
high-quality offerings. In response, discounters developed a range of value-based propositions focused on delivering
high quality at low prices, which appeal to this growing number of UK shoppers who seek a good ‘value.’ These

153


-----

propositions have helped discounters to achieve a strong presence in the UK grocery retail market. For example,
discounters Aldi and Lidl have increased their combined market share (on a Till Roll basis) from 4.4% in the calendar
year 2010 to 17.5% in the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel and as reflected in the
following chart.

_(Source: Kantar Worldpanel Take Home Panel, Grocery, 52 w/e January 21[st] 2024, Till Roll.)_

From 2013 to 2023, discounters gained considerable scale and market share as a result of new store openings
and continued price consciousness from customers, notably in the post COVID-19 environment, which has been
underpinned by higher inflation and a more cash-strapped consumer. According to Euromonitor and relevant public
reporting, discounters’ store count grew from 1,118 in 2013 to 1,980 in 2023, as set forth in the following chart.

_(Source: Euromonitor: Retail 2024 edition, stores in units.)_

As discounters have increased their store counts, they have won market share from other market players.
According to Kantar Worldpanel, for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, we had significant market share in the
same geographic areas where discounters already commanded a relatively high market share - the North of England
(15.8%), Scotland (13.5%) and Wales (14.1%) - on a Total Grocery Absolute Sales basis, where the discounters also
see strong performance. We believe that, as discounters seek to increase their market share through expansion in new
areas, they are likely to consider expanding into new regional markets - particularly in London, South of England and
East of England - where we have a lower market share, a trend that we believe is supported by the information about

discounters in their catchment area.

_(Source: Kantar Worldpanel, Take Home Panel, Grocery, Online, 52 w/e January 21[st] 2024, Spend.)_

discounters already commanded a relatively high market share - the North of England (19.4%), Scotland (16.6%) and

**_Growth of Online Channel_**

Asda, along with Tesco, Sainsbury’s, Morrisons and Waitrose, offer groceries and non-food items for
purchase and delivery online alongside “Click & Collect” services for purchases made through our websites. Pure
online players, such as Ocado and Amazon Fresh, also compete in the UK online grocery market.

The strong growth of online grocery sales in the United Kingdom is supported by multiple drivers, including:

    - Increasing population of tech-aware customers with a higher propensity to buy online;

    - Higher internet penetration (driven by increased usage of mobile and faster connections) combined with
an increasing propensity to use the internet to buy online;

    - Technological advances significantly improving the online proposition for customers (such as better
interfaces, mobile apps, convenient digital wallets and payment systems);

    - Improving product offerings as technology improves and competition increases (for example, greater
availability of products online compared to in-store); and

    - Improving delivery options as density of deliveries improves (resulting in cheaper, faster deliveries and
improved availability of more predictable, flexible and diverse delivery timeslots).

Growth in online grocery has been accelerated by the onset of COVID-19 as customers have increasingly
prioritised factors such as social distancing and convenience and government restrictions have encouraged customers
to find ways to remain at home.

**_Shift to Convenience_**

Another significant customer trend shaping the UK grocery retail market is customers’ increasing
prioritisation of convenience.

During 2020, the value of convenience store sales experienced a large growth spike of 9.2% as consumers
sought and bought their groceries closer to home, driving increased footfall into local convenience and forecourt retail
stores. Following the pandemic, convenience sales continued to remain elevated due to inflationary pressures related
to growing supply chain costs and rising energy bills, driving prices higher. In addition, convenience store sales in
2022 were boosted by the Jubilee weekend and its festivities, a warmer than usual summer with record temperatures
and the FIFA World Cup, boosting sales of products ranging from snacks to cold beverages. Finally, convenience
stores also benefitted from the return of pre-pandemic behaviour with footfall levels in city and town centres at higher
levels.

Growth is expected to normalise in the coming years as a result of the continued cost of living crisis, driving
local consumers to become more conscious of their spending, in particular with the rising cost of food products and
the growing value proposition of discount retailers. In spite of growth expectations settling down, however, there
remains notable tailwinds including the arrival of “frictionless” store formats, which enable the customer to shop for
groceries and walk out without passing by the point of sale, and growing partnership with third-party delivery services,
which will help drive visibility revenue and reach. Moreover, growth in the convenience retail segment will be
supported by an increasing preference amongst customers for more frequent but smaller shopping trips, with numerous
top-ups through the course of the week at smaller, more conveniently located stores. This trend can be partly explained
by a preference for reduced food waste in light of growing environmental concerns, smaller households, less
pre-planned lifestyles and a growing preference in general for convenience.

**_Redefined Service Expectations_**

Increasing digitalisation and evolving customer dynamics have shaped an increasingly fast-paced market.
Customers are now seeking a transparent and frictionless experience to improve and expedite their grocery retail
experience. This is reflected in the increased usage of self-checkout, “Scan & Go,” “Click & Collect” and online
services as customers opt to use these facilities to tailor and improve their shopping experiences. In line with the

156


-----

growing desire for convenience and efficient shopping experiences, there is increasing demand for combined and
differentiated service offerings in the grocery retail market, which allow customers to fulfil multiple needs in one
convenient location such as parcel collection and drop-off, pharmacy services and selections of household items, all
in addition to traditional grocery retail offerings. Grocery retailers, like ourselves, have responded with increased
service offerings such as ‘toyou,’ which takes advantage of customers’ growing online shopping habits to create a
service that allows customers to return or collect online purchases while on a regular trip to a brick-and-mortar grocery
retailer.

**_Increased Demand for Social Responsibility_**

Dedication to social responsibility is increasingly relevant to customers, particularly for Gen Z and Millennial
customers, and a commitment to social responsibility has become a necessary factor if retailers want to meet
customers’ expectations. There is a growing share of customers who have concerns about animal welfare,
environmental sustainability and ethical sourcing, and who view their purchasing decision as a lifestyle statement. In
line with these concerns, customers are increasingly demanding traceability and information about production
methods, driving the popularity of fair trade and organic products that can meet these needs. In response, retailers are
adapting their business models in order to meet customers’ demand.

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We are the third-largest grocery retailer in the United Kingdom and the second-largest grocery retailer in the
North of England, Scotland and Wales (in each case in terms of Till Roll data on a 52-week basis as of January 21,
2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel). We operate a significant store estate of over 1,200 large stores and
convenience sites that are geographically diversified across the United Kingdom. We also have the second largest
online grocery platform in the United Kingdom (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on a 52-week basis as of
January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel). We are also now a major player in the UK convenience market,
having added 472 convenience sites (including petrol filling stations) to our portfolio, as well as 124 stand-alone
foodservice sites (including 10 non-active sites), following the Arthur Acquisition and EG UK Acquisition. These
acquisitions have given us significant foothold in the fast-growing convenience market which, alongside our existing
fuel portfolio, makes us the second-largest independent fuel owner-operator in the United Kingdom. The graph below
compares our total grocery market share with that of other major UK grocery retailers based on Till Roll data for the
52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel.

_(Source: Kantar Worldpanel, Take Home Panel, Grocery, 52 w/e January 21[st] 2024, Till Roll.)_

We operate in the large and historically stable UK grocery retail market that is underpinned by favourable
macroeconomic factors including GDP, population, consumer confidence and household expenditure on food and
beverages and which has historically demonstrated resilient performance through economic fluctuations. Groceries
are a necessary and regular consumer expenditure, which we believe generally allows the grocery retail market to
weather economic downturns better than certain other retail markets. For example, the UK grocery retail market
demonstrated its two strongest periods of growth in recent history during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and
during the COVID-19 pandemic, followed only by a slight contraction as the pandemic eased. Since, the UK grocery
retail market has experienced consistent growth, achieving a record-high size of £144.0 billion in sales for the 52week period ended December 24, 2023, according to Kantar Worldpanel, despite facing high inflation and global

**History**

Headquartered in Leeds, we are an omni-channel retailer across England, Scotland, Wales and Northern
Ireland. We have built our business on listening to our diverse range of customers, offering what they need at the best
value and bringing innovation to the UK market.

We were founded in 1965 through the merger of the Asquith family grocery business with the Associated
Dairies company in Yorkshire. Our name is derived from this historic merger, combining “Asquith” and “Dairies” to
form “Asda.”

Founded in the North of England, we have a rich history, heritage and culture. The Asquith family has deep
ties to the grocery business, W.R. Asquith having run a butcher’s shop in Knottingley, West Yorkshire, which
eventually expanded to seven shops. W.R. Asquith’s sons, Peter and Fred, went on to create the United Kingdom’s
first self-service supermarket in Castleford, introducing food discounting to the UK grocery market, and eventually
co-founded Asda. In parallel to the growth of the Asquith family business, a group of West Riding dairy farmers joined
forces, eventually becoming Associated Dairies & Farm Stores Limited led by Arthur Stockdale. Arthur’s son, Sir
Noel Stockdale, went on to co-found Asda with Peter and Fred Asquith.

In 1965, we acquired GEM, a major U.S. discount retailer operating in the United Kingdom. With the
addition of general merchandise to the former GEM stores, we introduced the superstore to the UK market, a landmark
event in the development of UK retailing. To complement this offer, Peter Asquith also introduced the first discounted
petrol filling station.

By 1970, we operated over 30 stores and were poised to expand beyond our original home in the North of
England. Throughout the 1970s, we grew our presence in the South of England, opening stores in Newport, Plymouth
and Gosport. In 1977, we launched our “Asda Price” TV adverts, featuring the “pocket tap” which came to be the
official sign language for Asda. By the end of the 1970s, we were operating over 80 stores and opened our 100[th] store
in 1981.

Throughout the 1980s, we focused on expanding our distribution capabilities, opening seven new distribution
centres strategically located throughout the United Kingdom by 1985. In 1987, our flagship Watford store opened,
another landmark in UK retailing, and featured the longest-ever checkout bank at the time, with 45 checkouts. In 1988,
we opened our headquarters in Leeds, with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher overseeing the opening ceremonies. In
1989, George Davies was asked to produce a line of clothing for us that was high-quality, high-value and had its own
identity: the pioneering George brand was born.

In the 1990s, we developed the Asda Way of Working, an innovative framework for a new organisational
structure that focuses on our stores and promotes colleague involvement, which set the stage for the Asda culture of
today. In 1996, we opened our first Asda Pharmacy location in Harrogate, North Yorkshire and launched our “Tickled
Pink” campaign to raise money for the fight against breast cancer, a partnership that continues to this day. In 1998,
we began our online retail operations with a dedicated depot in Croydon.

162


-----

In 1999, we joined the Walmart family, becoming part of the world’s largest retailer. Throughout the early
2000s, we continued to grow and innovate, expanding our online and Click & Collect offers, opening our first Asda
Living store and our first Eco Store, winning awards for the value we offer customers as well as for the positive
environment we create for colleagues, launching our Free From and Extra Special offers, launching stand-alone PFSs
as well as Asda Opticians. In 2015, we celebrated our 50[th] birthday and George’s 25[th] birthday. Asda has continued to
innovate, including the United Kingdom’s first parcel tower, which allows customers to collect online orders in less
than 60 seconds, and voice-activated shopping through Google Home.

In October 2020, the Issa Brothers and TDR Capital reached an agreement with Walmart to acquire a majority
stake in Asda, with Walmart retaining an equity interest in the business. Following regulatory approval, the deal closed
in February 2021 and our new owners were able to take operational control in June 2021.

In October 2022, we took our first significant step into the convenience market and acquired 116 convenience
sites from the Co-operative Group (“Co-op”) as part of the Arthur Acquisition, expanding our community-focused
reach of retail destinations and petrol filling station driving footfall in strategic locations at the heart of residential
areas.

On October 31, 2023, we greatly expanded our footprint in the convenience market and completed the
purchase of the majority of the EG UK business for total cash consideration of £2.1 billion (including transaction
fees), adding a total of 480 sites to our portfolio (consisting of 356 petrol filling stations, two of which have since
closed, and 124 foodservice sites) through the EG UK Acquisition. In March 2024, we completed the conversion of
the acquired Co-op sites and EG UK Business sites to Asda Express. We look forward to exciting prospects in this
new market, including the expansion of the Asda Express convenience format to new locations.

Our values are rooted in service to our customers, respect for the individual, striving for excellence and acting
with integrity. We pursue our values with the support of our colleagues, culture and technology.

**Key Strengths**

We believe that we benefit from the following strengths, including being a business of significant scale with
a history of resilient performance, a differentiated operating model, a successful financial profile and a significant
asset backing, as further described below.

**_We are a business of significant scale with a history of resilient performance_**

_We operate in a large, historically stable, resilient and growing industry with favourable macroeconomic tailwinds_

We operate in the large and historically stable UK grocery retail market, which has demonstrated resilient
performance underpinned by favourable macroeconomic factors including GDP, population, consumer confidence
and household spend on food and beverages. For example, UK GDP growth has shown stable development over the
years. Although the United Kingdom’s GDP declined by 10.4% in 2020 due primarily to COVID-19, GDP rebounded
in 2021, returned to pre-COVID-19 levels in 2022 and amounted to approximately £2.0 trillion in 2023, according to
Fitch Solutions, with an average expected GDP growth of approximately 0.4% from 2023 to 2025.

The UK grocery retail market is also characterised by favourable demographic characteristics, including a
growing population. According to ONS, the UK population is projected to grow from 67 million in 2021 to over 73
million by 2036, which is expected to result in an overall increase in the consumer base for groceries.

In addition to its historical stability, the UK grocery retail market is also resilient. In 2023, grocery retail was
the single largest category of retail spending in the United Kingdom – valued at £200.5 billion on a Retail Value RSP
(as defined herein) basis, according to Euromonitor. Groceries are a necessary and stable consumer expenditure, which
generally allows the grocery retail market to weather economic downturns better than certain other retail markets that
involve more discretionary spending. For example, the UK grocery retail market demonstrated its two strongest
periods of growth in recent history during and following the 2007-2009 global financial crisis and during the
COVID-19 pandemic: between 2009 and 2016, the UK grocery retail market grew at a CAGR of 2.2% and between
2016 and 2023, the UK grocery retail market grew at a CAGR of 3.1%, with a growth CAGR of 4.6% during the
COVID-19 pandemic from 2019 and 2020. Additionally, during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis, according to

163


-----

ONS, the percentage of average weekly household spend on food and non-alcoholic drinks remained fairly consistent
at approximately 11.0%, demonstrating the market’s resilience during periods of macroeconomic difficulty, and this
percentage spiked to 14.4% in 2021 during the COVID-19 pandemic, reflecting an increase in at-home consumption
during the pandemic. This percentage has remained relatively flat in the intervening years, ranging between 10.5%
and 11.8% from 2007 to 2022. In recent years, as the COVID-19 global pandemic was waning, Russia’s invasion of
Ukraine sparked an energy crisis which further accelerated growing inflation and cost of living pressures. However,
according to Kantar Worldpanel, the UK grocery market, comprised of grocers (and excluding non-grocers), has
grown by 8.7% over the past three years (on a Till Roll basis for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024, compared to
the 52 weeks ended January 24, 2021).

_We are the United Kingdom’s third-largest grocer, holding sizeable market share_

According to Kantar Worldpanel, we are the third-largest grocery retailer in the United Kingdom, with 13.7%
of market share and the second-largest grocery retailer in the North of England, Scotland and Wales (based on Till
Roll data over 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024). For the year ended December 31, 2023, our revenue was £21.9
billion (excluding fuel). We have a network of over 1,200 large stores and convenience sites throughout the United
Kingdom, with a particular focus on superstores, supermarkets, online formats and convenience. We are also the
second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom by value (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales on
a 52-week basis as of January 21, 2024, according to Kantar Worldpanel), and have grown our market share over
many years, maintaining this share in a much-enlarged market as customers turned to online shopping throughout the
COVID-19 pandemic. As a result, we believe that we are well-positioned as a large and established business with a
clear set of peers.

We also believe that our multi-format, omni-channel offer positions us well to compete effectively and to
continue growing our market share. Following the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition, which gave us a
significant foothold in the convenience and foodservice markets, our revenue and Adjusted EBITDA in the year ended
December 31, 2023 were £25,619.9 million and £1,078 million, respectively, compared to £24,477.8 million and £867
million, respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2022. We believe that we also hold a leading position in the
UK foodservice market.

We cater to a broad target demographic, which we believe provides us a long-term competitive advantage.
In contrast to discounters, we provide a broad range of branded and own-brand offers, while also having a more
developed and established online platform.

_We believe we have faced the greatest impacts of discounters on our market_

The adverse impact of discounters (primarily Aldi and Lidl) on the traditional grocers in recent years has
been significant but, while we believe that discounters will continue to put pressure on the market, we believe that we
and other traditional grocers have already faced the greatest impacts of this competition in the markets in which we
operate and, if anything, that the discounters pose a greater challenge to other traditional grocers, who we believe are
more geographically exposed to the areas where discounters are likely to focus in the near-term.

As compared to our traditional grocer peers, our geographical concentration is in the North of England,
Scotland and Wales, as evidenced by our number two market shares in those regions. The discounters have already
penetrated these areas and we expect the discounters to continue to shift the focus of their expansion to the South of
England, the East of England and London, where we operate fewer sites as compared to the Midlands, the North of
England, Scotland and Wales. Furthermore, the catchment areas of 76.7% of our stores already contain both major
discounters, Aldi and Lidl, which is a higher percentage than any of our traditional grocer competitors (the boundary
used is a 10-minute drive-time radius around each point, which is consistent regardless of location type or size of
store, but excludes convenience stores, and stores are only included in the count where there is both Aldi and Lidl
stores present within the drive-time boundary). Therefore, we believe that our current performance already factors in
the adverse impact of discounters to a large extent.

Moreover, according to Kantar Worldpanel, we have stemmed the losses to the discounters in recent months,
and we have reduced switching losses to the discounters to a two-year record low for the 4 weeks ended February 18,
2024. Together, Lidl and Aldi account for 17.5% of the market, with Aldi’s share at 9.8% and Lidl at 7.6% in each
case on the basis of Till Roll data and according to Kantar Worldpanel for the 52 weeks ended January 21, 2024.

164


-----

However, the growth experienced by the discounters has begun to fall sharply, with Aldi posting growth behind the
market for the four weeks ended January 21, 2024, and Lidl’s growth decreasing over 50% for the same period
compared to the four weeks ended January 22, 2023.

We also believe we can reduce losses to the discounters through our value proposition, including our opening
price point range, Just Essentials. In January 2024, we also launched a new price matching programme where we have
price matched Aldi and Lidl on 287 comparable grocery products, which reduced prices by an average of 17% to
match whichever discounter had the lowest price on these products.

_We have demonstrated resilience through downturns_

Just as our market has proven resilient in times of economic difficulty and uncertainty, our business has also
proven resilient during recent economic and market downturns, including during the 2007-2009 global financial crisis,
the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as through the rise of discounters in the UK grocery retail market in more recent
years, particularly during 2014 to 2016. During the 2007-2009 global financial crisis, we continued to perform well,
achieving an average like-for-like sales (excluding fuel) growth rate of 6.1% for the fiscal years ended December 31,
2008 and 2009. Our EBITDA margins have also remained stable, ranging from 4.7% to 4.9% between 2007 and 2023.

Despite the significant social and economic shifts driven by the COVID-19 pandemic, our business
experienced strong overall performance, particularly in our online and supermarket formats. Overall, our food business
performed consistently throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, despite an initial increase in sales due to panic buying
and customers stocking-up on key staples at the outset of each of the first three lockdown periods. Following an initial
decline at the beginning of the first lockdown, our general merchandise business also generally performed well
throughout these lockdown periods, due to increasing purchases of homeware products. While our clothing business
was initially negatively impacted during the early stage of the first UK lockdown period, we experienced improved
performance in this business in line with an overall improvement of the general economy and a rebound in consumer
confidence.

Recently, geopolitical tensions and ongoing inflation above historical norms and the Bank of England’s target
have led to uncertainty in the market and for our consumers. However, we have remained highly resilient in the face
of these challenges and have kept focused on supporting customers and colleagues with cost-of-living pressures, whilst
continuing to deliver strong financial results. During times of economic stress, we believe our value proposition is
particularly appealing to customers and can drive sales: we benefited from increased sales generating revenue
(excluding fuel) of £21.9 billion for the year ended December 31, 2023 compared to £20.4 billion for the year ended
December 31, 2021. As the current high inflationary environment persists, we are focused on initiatives to support our
customers in the cost-of-living crisis and protect market share by investing in price and quality, which we believe can
drive growth. For example, in 2022, we also launched our new grocery opening price point range, Just Essentials by
Asda that expands the range of its predecessor, Asda Smart Price, from approximately 160 to 272 products with new
branding and reformulations for taste and quality. In the same year, we also rolled out a “Dropped and Locked” price
campaign, where we locked in the prices of over 100 grocery items to give customers certainty around their shopping
costs during the year, as well as our loyalty rewards programme, Asda Rewards, as an indirect cost-saving scheme for
customers to earn cash back on their shopping.

**_We benefit from a differentiated operating model, including a diversified proposition with unique multi-format and_**
**_multi-channel offering_**

_We have well-developed own-brands_

We believe that our own-brand offers have been a key strength of our business and continue to offer growth
opportunities. We have an extensive own-brand product range in our food business, with approximately 7,800
own-brand SKUs. Our approach to range development and innovation enables us to identify and meet changing
customer needs and has resulted in the creation of many award-winning products; we launched approximately 950
lines in 2021, 1,547 new lines in 2022 and 1,597 new lines in 2023, and approximately 3,858 lines were reformulated
in 2023. As a result of the EG UK Acquisition, we also acquired Leon, our own proprietary foodservice brand. In
addition to our diverse and extensive product offer with our own-brand range, we have also been able to drive growth
through service and price positioning. We leverage our IPL sourcing model to deliver value, especially in our produce,
cooked meats and wine segments. In particular, the introduction and development of the opening price point range,

-----

Just Essentials, has been key to helping customers with the cost-of-living pressures in 2023 after the “Dropped and
Locked” price campaigns in 2022, where we locked in the prices of over 100 grocery items to give customers certainty
around their shopping costs during that year. We also offer own-brands through George, see “—The George Clothing
_and George Home offers are generally profitable and well-established.”_

_We are driven by our commitment to delivering low prices to our customers_

We believe our commitment to delivering low prices to our customers is a competitive advantage as we aim
to lead on price while staying competitive on assortment and quality. We believe that we are the least expensive
full-selection traditional grocer in the United Kingdom: according to internal Asda data, our prices are approximately
2.5% to 6.1% less expensive than our traditional grocer competitors (on average for the first eight weeks in 2024,
based on total goods price gap percentage). Following the implementation of our Aldi and Lidl price matching
programme, which runs alongside our established customer value propositions, including Just Essentials, Asda Smart
Price, our price locking campaigns, Fab 5 and Asda Rewards, we believe our prices can compete with those of
discounters. Our low prices are supported by rigorous cost control and a commitment to affordability, which enables
us to control expenses so that we can pass cost savings on to our customers.

_Loyal customer base through our reward loyalty programme, Asda Rewards_

In 2022, we launched our new loyalty programme, Asda Rewards. The app-based scheme enables customers
to earn cash back on their shopping, building Asda Pounds in their cash pots to spend in store. The programme also
provides the opportunity to leverage data insights which enables us to better target investment in the customer
proposition. Asda Rewards total users and penetration among customers has grown quickly, with over 7.5 million new
users joining over the last 12 months and a total of 1.6 million members who have registered for Blue Light. The
number of total active customers reached 4.9 million as of December 31, 2023 over the prior 30-day period, and the
programme has earned around £300 million revenue in 2023. The following graph shows the increasing sales
penetration, or the number of sales linked to customers using Asda Rewards since its inception, which reached 50.6%
in the week of Christmas in 2023:

By the end of 2023, we saw approximately 47% of sales linked to Asda Rewards. We have found that after
joining Asda Rewards, members spend more than non-members within every segment and are more likely to become
repeat customers. In particular, we believe that members spend more than 10% after joining the programme (measured

_We operate the second-largest online grocery platform in the United Kingdom, which is profitable_

The United Kingdom has one of the most developed online grocery retail markets in the world, with one of
the highest rates of the population using the internet. There has been a significant shift in the grocery retail market
away from brick-and-mortar stores to online purchasing as demographic trends, greater mobile and device usage,
improved service proposition and technological advances in applications and customer interfaces have driven
increasing penetration rates in the online grocery retail market. We believe we are poised to take advantage of these
favourable consumer trends, as we have already established ourselves in the rapidly growing UK online grocery retail
market and our store and warehouse footprint is strategically positioned across attractive geographic areas to service
the growing demand for groceries online.

According to Kantar Worldpanel, we are the second-largest online grocery retail platform in the United
Kingdom, holding 19.3% of market share (in terms of Total Grocery Absolute Sales) for the 52-week period ended
January 21, 2024. Having responded quickly to the increase in demand for online shopping during the COVID-19
pandemic, we have continued to grow our online business, with an average of approximately 774,000 weekly orders
in 2022 and 2023 (based on the average weekly orders in 2022 and 2023). As a result of our strong performance in
the online market, combined sales for our online grocery business and George.com rapidly increased from previous
years to a total of £3.6 billion for the year ended December 31, 2023 (of which £3.2 billion were online grocery sales
and £0.4 billion were George.com sales) as compared to £3.3 billion for the year ended December 31, 2022 (of which
£2.9 billion were online grocery sales and £0.4 billion were George.com sales). According to Kantar Worldpanel, we
hold an 8.5% share of the UK online clothing, footwear and accessories market (in terms of volume of units sold on a
24-week basis as of January 7, 2024).

We believe there is greater scope for our online profitability to improve further. We expect that the demand
for online groceries will continue to be strong as customers increasingly adopt online shopping as a more permanent
and preferred way to purchase groceries.

_The George Clothing and George Home offers are generally profitable and well-established_

We launched our clothing offer, George, in 1990 and it is the third-largest clothing footwear and accessories
retailer in the United Kingdom by volume of units sold for the 52 weeks ended January 7, 2024 and is the leading UK
childrenswear retailer with 18.7% market share by volume of units sold for the 52 weeks ended January 7, 2024, in
each case according to Kantar Worldpanel. Despite challenges to this product category overall, our online clothing
sales have increased from £379.3 million for the year to December 31, 2021 to £423.4 million for the year ended
December 31, 2023, with 82% of all sales made via mobile devices in 2023. We believe this demonstrates our strength
in the online segment, which is a key part of our operating model. Additionally, we have expanded the George branded
offer to include general merchandise, including through collaborations with strategic partners. We have extended

product ranges with partners who specialise in certain categories, have a strong affinity fit with our existing customers
and bring complementary expertise and reputation, such as in homeware with Stacey Solomon and Claire’s in
jewellery and accessories. The George Home brand generated approximately £747.7 million in sales and contributed
approximately 50.0% of our total general merchandising sales for the year ended December 31, 2023. Sales by the
George Home brand grew at a CAGR of approximately 3% between the years ended December 31, 2021 and
December 31, 2023. Furthermore, the George Clothing and George Home product categories generally have higher

**_We benefit from a well invested and vertically integrated model and are supported by a significant asset base_**

_We benefit from vertically integrated procurement through IPL_

We believe that we have a competitive advantage in food sourcing via our captive sourcing arm, IPL, which
enables us to take a vertically integrated approach to procurement. We believe that IPL provides us with valuable
sourcing differentiation as compared to our competitors. IPL is one of the largest importers of produce in the United
Kingdom and, while IPL is a group company and exclusively serves Asda, it is also our largest supplier. The aim of
our vertically integrated procurement model is to consolidate import activity for key products and reduce our overall
costs. In 2023, we purchased £1,724 million of our products through IPL. The foundation of IPL’s cost-price advantage
is that it eliminates the “middleman” who typically serves as the intermediary in the supply chain, thereby giving us
greater control of costs, quality and supply of a diverse range of products. We have an extensive IPL footprint across
the United Kingdom, with nine processing facilities across the country and more than 3,793 colleagues as of the year
ended December 31, 2023. Our IPL product mix is diversified according to our needs, with a mix of 56% fruit and
vegetables, 28% protein, 7% plants and flowers, 6% beverages and 3% grocery in 2023. Additionally, we have been
able to build upon and benefit from our supplier relationships to deliver supply chain continuity and make progress in
our sustainability agenda. For example, through IPL we are supporting industry projects on water stewardship in our
produce supply chain.

We also believe that IPL has provided greater stability and allowed us greater control over our supply chain
now that the United Kingdom has left the European Union’s single market and customs union. IPL’s EU supply chain
ensures IPL takes control of the transport direct from its suppliers’ sites. This allows IPL to appoint experts in haulage
and freight clearance, removing delays at the various border control points and ensuring the most efficient supply
chain. IPL’s logistics team are based in Spain, which is the top EU exporting country into the United Kingdom for
fresh produce. This has ensured IPL quickly understands any impacts to supply chains, such as localised disruption
by the farming fraternity, allowing IPL to take actions to protect the supply chains.

_We are supported by a significant asset portfolio_

We are supported by a well-invested and geographically diversified store estate and benefit from a total real
estate portfolio of £8.5 billion, which is comprised of freehold and long leasehold assets, and includes £756 million
of certain properties owned by the Group but pledged as collateral for the benefit of the creditors under the Ground
Rent Facility.

As of December 31, 2023, 77% of our asset portfolio was comprised of freehold or long leaseholds, based
upon attributable EBITDAR per property (less central allocations), with certain adjustments made to align the
calculation methodology across the Group’s properties following the EG UK Acquisition and the Arthur Acquisition.
Of this 77%, 12% is attributable to certain properties that are pledged as collateral for the benefit of the creditors under
the Ground Rent Facility.

Our valuable real estate portfolio also provides a potential source of liquidity and underpins our strong
ongoing cash flow generation. On August 10, 2023, we completed the 2023 Sale and Leaseback Transactions with
Realty Income, which resulted in proceeds of £646 million that were used to finance a portion of the EG UK
Acquisition. On December 12, 2023, we also completed the 2023 Ground Rent Transaction with a number of investors,
which resulted in proceeds of £400 million that were used to repay a bridge loan that was used to finance a portion of
the EG UK Acquisition. In the future we may continue to selectively monetise portions of our real estate portfolio to
take advantage of favourable trading conditions and pursue our strategic priorities. See “Description of Certain
_Financing Arrangements—2023 Sale and Leaseback Facility” and “Description of Certain Financing_
_Arrangements—Ground Rent Transactions – Ground Rent Facility.”_

**_We have strong exposure to the resilient convenience and PFS channel with upside through synergies_**

In December 2022, we opened our first two convenience sites under the Asda Express banner. We also have
further organic Asda Express openings planned, with seven sites opened in early 2024 and a strong pipeline of
approximately 30 sites that have been identified for potential opening in 2024.

The Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition gave us a strong presence in the fast-growing
convenience market, having added 472 convenience sites and petrol filling stations to our portfolio. The Arthur
Acquisition comprised 116 convenience stores with PFSs attached and the EG UK Acquisition comprised 356 PFSs
(including two that have since been shut) with convenience stores and 124 standalone foodservice sites (including 10
non-active sites). These acquisitions accelerated our growth in the convenience sector and strategic ambition to bring
our value heritage as a consumer champion to even more customers. We completed the conversion of all the sites
acquired from the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition to Asda Express in March 2024. See also “—
_Business Strategy—Location.” We believe our recent acquisitions will drive our results by delivering additional net_
working capital and EBITDA synergies as we integrate buying for the wider convenience network into Asda and seek
to drive higher volumes and growth as a result of price investment in the fuel and grocery offering. We also expect
synergies to arise from range optimisation, monetisation of customer data, our increased scale, in-store marketing
income, improvement in fuel card terms and operational efficiencies. See “Summary Historical Consolidated
_Financial Information and Other Financial Data—Other Financial Indicators.”_

According to Euromonitor, in 2023, the UK convenience market was approximately £44 billion and the UK
foodservice market was approximately £67 billion, and the UK convenience market has grown at a faster rate than the
UK grocery retail market relative to 2015. Our exposure to these highly attractive and profitable convenience and
foodservice markets is underpinned by favourable structural factors including (i) the rise of shopping locally, (ii) the
evolution of shopper missions, (ii) the shift of our offering to a broader format of retail destinations, and (iv) our shift
into the foodservice and consumption market.

**_We have achieved a successful financial profile_**

We have achieved a successful financial profile that is underpinned by strong profit margins, Adjusted
EBITDA margins, cash flows from operating activities, Free Cash Flow (defined as Adjusted EBITDA less Capital
Expenditure KPI) and Cash Conversion (defined as Free Cash Flow divided by Adjusted EBITDA) in recent years.
Between the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2023, our average profit margin (defined as profit for the year
divided by revenue) was 4.3%, our average Adjusted EBITDA margin was 4.2% (including fuel), our cash flows from
operating activities totalled £3,340.6 million, cumulative free cash flow was approximately £2,097 million and our
average cash conversion was 68%. This strong financial performance is driven by our commitment to deliver low
prices to our clients, diverse product offer, strong own-brand grocery offer, expanded convenience and foodservice
offerings and well-established George-branded product categories. Our Adjusted EBITDA margins have benefitted
from our cost transformation programmes, which have generated SG&A cost savings without compromising the low
prices we offer our customers.

We are a structurally negative working capital business driven by growth in payables, and the beneficial
payment terms to suppliers versus payments received by consumers instantly on purchase. We delivered a strong net
working capital performance in the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023, with our active working capital
management, resulting in increased working capital inflows in those two years. Furthermore, we have pursued a
disciplined approach to our capital expenditure over time, with the aim of maintaining and improving our real estate
platform rather than opening new sites.

**_We have a highly experienced and execution focused management team_**

We are led by an experienced, entrepreneurial management team that is committed to continuing our strong
track record of growth, with a focus on product quality, delivering low prices to our customers and exceptional
customer service. Together with Michael Gleeson, the Group’s chief financial officer, our executive committee
provides strong, dynamic and deep, leadership. We also benefit from the long-standing experience, market expertise,
business relationships and industry know-how of our shareholder, Mohsin Issa, who is leading the management team
on an interim basis.

As we continue to expand our footprint and achieve our business goals, we plan to take advantage of
opportunities to further enhance and supplement our management talent, both from inside our organisation as well as
with external candidates. We have made key investments into our digital marketing team and expect to onboard a new
chief digital officer in the third quarter of 2024. Our search for a permanent chief executive officer is robust and
ongoing.

**Business Strategy**

Our primary strategy is designed to provide great value for money and to bring brighter living within
everyone’s reach. Our strategy is centred around four primary pillars which guide our business priorities and planning:
proposition, product, location and experience. These pillars are underpinned by our commitment to running an
efficient operating model, driving the business through improved data and systems and an ESG programme that builds
a sustainable business for the long term.

Through our strategy, we seek to maintain and extend our advantage in offering value for money by ensuring
that our prices are competitive and reassuring shoppers on quality. We aim to provide a consistent, trusted experience,
incentivising customers not to shop elsewhere through the creation of attractive store propositions and partnerships
that increase our appeal to customers. We serve our customers with our team of flexible and engaged colleagues, while
increasing the number of self-serve opportunities and transforming the in-store experience. We focus our growth
where customers care, expanding our addressable markets in online grocery, wholesale and community convenience.

We believe that our strategy provides a clear path to achieve our ambition of becoming the second-largest
grocer in the United Kingdom by market share.

**_Proposition_**

Our proposition strategy is about creating more reasons to shop with us than anywhere else and providing an
offering that meets all of our customers’ needs under one roof. Demonstrating the strength in our offering across the
store, we recently won four awards at the 2023 annual Grocer Gold Awards, including the Grocer 33 Price award for
the 26th consecutive year, the ‘Own Label Range of the Year’ award for our Just Essentials product range, the
‘Consumer Initiative of the Year’ award for our Kids Eat for £1 Cafe Meals scheme and ‘Online Supermarket of the
Year.’

We believe we are well established as the lowest-price full-selection retailer in the United Kingdom, and we
lead the traditional grocers in terms of lowest price. Moving forward, we intend to reduce the complexity of the
customer shopping experience so that we can reflect that benefit to customers’ prices where it matters most in our
value proposition. We aim to simplify our value proposition to maintain price leadership, further improve quality
perception and continue to improve customer experience in-store and online. We also strive to create a more
hassle-free customer experience in-store with our digital transformation. For example, we have broadened our
Scan&Go services that allows customers to use a handset or the Scan&Go mobile app to scan and bag items as they
shop and utilise a dedicated checkout area for quick and easy payment.

We have also transformed our approach to rewarding customer loyalty through the launch of Asda Rewards
in 2022, our innovative, app-based loyalty scheme that gives customers Asda pounds, not points. Customers earn cash
back on their shopping, with regularly updated missions and star products enabling extra savings. Since 2022, more
than 5 million of our customers enrolled in Asda Rewards and as of December 31, 2023, Asda Rewards resulted in a
total of £383 million customer savings since it was first trialled. Following this initial success, we plan to look into
different ways to offer even further value to our customers, “gamefy” the application and to monetise and utilise the
data it provides. We believe that this approach will allow us to grow our customer analytics platform to bring better,
faster and deeper customer insights to our investment decisions and to improve the overall customer experience by
personalising our offer.

Through Asda Rewards, we are also able to roll out seasonal offerings such as our Christmas Saver Cashpot
that enabled customers save up their cash pot earnings in preparation for the festive period, with approximately 1.7
million members saving approximately £50 million into their 2023 Christmas Cashpots. We offered saving incentives
where customers who transferred savings earned from their Asda Rewards cash pot into their Christmas Saver Cashpot
received additional cash bonuses based upon the amount transferred. With improved availability and seasonal

170


-----

offerings, we continue to earn our place in customers’ minds as the retailer for key celebrations throughout the year.
We believe that such rewards incentives will further drive customer loyalty and retention.

In non-food, we have begun trialling a number of initiatives across clothing and general merchandise in our
“lab stores.” We use the lab-store as a platform to test new technologies, concepts and ideas and assess what works
for customers and colleagues. For example, we tested a “shop within a shop” concept with our Big Asda Toyshop,
which had its own merchandising and look and feel, in eight stores in 2022. Following strong sales, we have rolled it
out in an additional 121 stores. For Halloween in 2023, we trialled a new approach to the store entrance, creating an
inviting and festive shopping environment. Through these and other concepts, we have overhauled the in-store
shopping experience, radically rethinking our use of space, lighting and merchandising and are looking at how to
replicate with new themes and categories on a regular basis across the portfolio.

We also aim to grow Asda as a platform by forming partnerships that enable us to provide a broader set of
relevant branded products and services, while also building upon our existing capabilities, such as logistics and our
customer-facing ‘toyou’ proposition. We believe adding partners to our platform will result in the creation of appealing
“one-stop-shop” store destinations for more customer missions. We believe these partnerships will not only provide
additional income through rent and revenue share models but will also create a positive effect on our overall business.

**_Product_**

Our goal under our product strategy is to make desirable products affordable. We aim to modernise our brand
and deliver the best value to our customers, helping them fulfil their money saving goals without needing to
compromise on quality.

We began our product transformation in 2022 with the overhaul of our opening price point range, Just
Essentials by Asda. This line is a key part of our strategy to make desirable products that are affordable. In 2023, we
also locked in the price of over 500 popular products until the end of the summer to give customers certainty around
their budgets. We delivered three key price drops in 2023, lowering the prices on over 800 high volume lines, including
in October 2023 where we lowered prices by an average of 14% on many of our popular products. We will look to
continue dropping prices where possible and aim to pass price drops straight onto customers where we can. As inflation
is starting to ease in certain areas, we are working with our suppliers and IPL to ensure our customers feel the benefit
of those reductions.

As part of this brand reset, we are also focused on our mid-tier value and range offerings, investing throughout
our own brand offering to drive customers to reappraise us on quality. We launched our new scratch cooking and meal
solutions ranges and have introduced new own-label meal solutions brands, including Health Menu, Take-Out Club,
the Indian-inspired Bom Bahia and pan-Asian-inspired House of Yum ranges, and Bistro, a selection of hearty
pub-style favourites. These ranges are designed to compete directly with the likes of M&S Gastropub and takeaway
brands, a key opportunity as customers switch to at-home spending amidst cost-of-living pressures. We launched
ambitious quality and taste match campaigns during 2023 to demonstrate our confidence in the quality and value of
our products, including Harrod’s blind taste test products and M&S Taste Match campaign across a range of popular
household items. In the M&S Taste Match campaign, hundreds of our products were voted “as tasty” or “tastier than”
their M&S equivalents, but at a lower cost, in a blind taste testing conducted by Cambridge Market Research.

Foodservice and chilled categories also represent an avenue for growth and are important in moving the dial
on customers’ quality perception. A strong proposition in these categories is essential for fulfilling our ambition of
becoming a key market player in the convenience market.

In non-food, we launched ‘Exclusively at George’ in May 2023, which was dubbed the first-ever supermarket
elevated fashion collection. It put a spotlight on high-quality fabrics, with a focus on both quality and style. Following
the success of ‘Exclusively at George,’ we introduced the Studio Edit, which will be a permanent premium arm of the
George range, with a focus on wardrobe staples, premiere fabrics and finishing touches typically found in more
expensive pieces. Continuing in the elevated lifestyle space, we partnered with TV presenter and influencer Stacey
Solomon to create the homeware range, ‘At Home with Stacey Solomon Exclusively for George Home’ in
August 2023. We believe these lines showcase our ability to deliver high quality, highly desired products across a
broad range of categories to meet our customers’ every day needs.

**_Location_**

As part of our location strategy, we seek to be accessible however and whenever we are needed. We believe
that customers seeing Asda in new locations and new formats will help us broaden our customer base. In 2022, we
made significant progress in our location strategic priority area, increasing our expansion into the convenience sector.
Our core focus in our location strategy is on the successful integration of the recent Arthur Acquisition and EG UK
Acquisition, which together added 472 convenience sites and petrol filling stations and 124 standalone foodservice
sites to our portfolio.

In September 2023, we began the conversion of the Co-op sites from Co-op branding to our Asda Express
banner, implementing Asda pricing across fuel and grocery upon conversion. We completed the conversion of the
remaining convenience sites acquired from the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition to Asda Express in
March 2024. We believe we will be able to bring Asda’s great value to even more customers across the United
Kingdom by reaching new communities and shoppers with this smaller store format. In the converted Co-op sites, our
Asda Express prices were an average of 6.1% cheaper than their corresponding prices under Co-op ownership. We
also have further organic Asda Express openings planned to bolster our location strategy. Going forward, our focus
will be on the continued integration of the Co-op sites and EG UK Business into the Asda Group and delivering
synergies.

Beyond our expansion into the convenience market, we plan to continue to drive growth and market share
gains in the online channel through the expansion of our online grocery channel’s capacity to meet increased consumer
demand. We continue to seek to optimise our online grocery operating model and further develop our already
profitable economic model through the ongoing assessment of our online product range and promotions, further
monetisation of our e-commerce assets, as well as other initiatives. In addition to growing our core online grocery
business, we are targeting further growth by expanding the reach of our online platform and expanding our delivery
services. We expect to provide customers with greater and more convenient access to our product range by accelerating
our last-mile delivery capabilities via partnerships.

**_Experience_**

The goal of our experience strategy is to make shopping with us easy and enjoyable. We are focused on
operational excellence, testing scalable operational innovation for end-to-end service improvement. We are currently
looking at changes to further improve availability in store, improve stock flow and drive effective labour management.
For example, we are trialling artificial intelligence (“AI”) cameras to identify gaps in product availability and optimise
stock management in store. We believe this is an example of how AI could significantly help improve the customer
experience and optimise our colleagues’ time to focus on delivering high quality service.

We are also striving towards a best-in-class shopping experience that gives customers the range they desire
in an environment that’s easy to navigate. Our current store design had not been updated for many years, so our
near-term strategy includes modernising our stores to facilitate a better customer journey.

In order to ensure our colleagues are equipped to offer a best-in-class customer experience, we are also
investing in colleague hours in-store via a combination of additional temporary colleagues in stores and opportunities
for existing colleagues to work over-time if they wish to. Increasing the numbers of hours being worked in store means
that more colleagues are on hand to serve customers across the busy and peak periods (such as Christmas). Alongside
value and choice, we believe that service is a key quality signifier for customers and impacts where they choose to
shop. To help further this strategy, we also hired David Hills as our new Chief Customer Officer in September 2023,
who brings a wealth of retail and grocery-sector experience to our business and will play a pivotal role in providing
our shoppers a hassle-free and pleasurable experience when shopping at Asda.

**_Commitment to ESG targets and building a sustainable business for the long term_**

Part of our strategy is to ensure our Environmental, Social and Governance (“ESG”) commitments are fully
integrated into our wider business transformation plans. We believe the sales opportunity driven by eco-active
shoppers, or shoppers who are highly concerned about the environment and are actively taking actions to reduce their
waste, is expected to reach approximately £2 billion across the market by the year 2027. We believe ESG is a key

172


-----

decision enabler for customers in deciding where to shop and that setting the right ESG plan is beneficial for our
customers, colleagues and investors.

Our ESG strategy is focused on four pillars: healthy and sustainable choices (providing our customers with
a product mix that is healthier and with a lower environmental impact), energy and climate change mitigation
(reducing our greenhouse gas emissions), nature positive (sourcing and farming which respects and restores) and waste
(reducing food, product and packaging waste). In August 2023, we published our third ESG report (based on 2022
data), which provided an annual update on the progress we had made towards supporting these pillars and meeting
our environmental targets and in October 2023, we received our first external assessment of our ESG strategy, with
an entity score of 54 points and an overall rating of 3 (on a scale of 1 to 5, where 1 is the strongest) by the financial
services ratings’ agency Sustainable Fitch. Sustainable Fitch positively assessed our human and labour rights policies,
gender balanced workforce and well-defined management systems, as well as our actions to increase the share of
non-high fat, salt and sugar own-brand products and improve food nutrition labelling. Obtaining this rating is part of
our ongoing commitment to transparently reporting on our efforts to achieve our ESG targets. For example, we have
continued to reduce our operational carbon footprint, with emissions down 8% from 2021 to 2022 and 40% from 2015
to 2022, and we believe we are well on the way to achieving our commitment to reduce emissions 50% by 2025 and
reaching net zero emissions by 2040. We have committed to setting a near-term science-based carbon reduction target,
including a specific Forests, Land and Agriculture (“FLAG”) target. These targets have been submitted to the
Science-Based Targets Initiative (“SBTi”) for validation. The proposed targets were submitted before the Arthur
Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition so reflect our footprint prior to these acquisitions.

In terms of waste reduction, over 90% of our own brand packaging was recyclable in 2022, and we donated
over 2,000 tonnes of surplus food through our charity partnerships, both reducing waste and supporting those in need
during challenging times. We increased the proportion of our own-label packaging that can be recycled at the kerbside
to 88% (with a further 4.7% recyclable in store) and introduced the Refill Price Guarantee on our in-store refill zones,
guaranteeing that unpackaged products are cheaper than their packaged equivalents. We reused or repurposed 86% of
our operational waste and sent zero operational waste to landfill in 2022.

We believe we have made significant progress towards our ESG goals but that there is still much to do, and
we will continue working to build a sustainable business for the long term.

**Our Businesses**

We are an omni-channel retailer centred around a brick-and-mortar store network, which is geographically
diversified across the United Kingdom, and our websites (primarily through groceries.asda.com and George.com).
Our retail business comprises a food offer (which in turn comprises produce, ambient products and fresh food products
(including our foodservice offerings)), a non-food offer (which in turn comprises clothing, homeware and general
merchandise offers) and fuel. We also offer our customers other services, including, among other things, a mobile
phone service, various financial products, parcel drop and collection and in-store pharmacies and opticians.

**_Our Retail Business_**

Our retail business comprises a food segment, which consists of our grocery and foodservice business, and a
non-food segment, which includes our well-known George Clothing and George Home brands, as well as a general
merchandise and health and wellness offer.

We operate our retail business through both brick-and-mortar retail sites and through online sales made,
primarily, via groceries.asda.com and George.com.

Our physical retail business operates under five distinct formats: supercentres and superstores, supermarkets,
Asda Living, convenience sites and stand-alone foodservice sites. For more information on our store formats, see “—
_Our Store Formats.”_

We aim to develop Asda as a platform by forming partnerships that enable us to provide a broader set of
relevant branded products and services while also building on our existing capabilities such as logistics and the
customer-facing ‘toyou’ proposition. We believe adding partners to our platform will result in the creation of attractive
store destinations, in which more customer missions can be accomplished under one roof. See “—Business Strategy.”

_Food_

In 2023, our food segment accounted for 86.2% (£18.4 billion) of our total sales of £21.4 billion (excluding
fuel). Within our food segment, in 2023, ambient food items and non-edible items accounted for 53.3% (£9.8 billion),
and fresh/produce accounted for 46.7% (£8.6 billion), of our food sales.

_Ambient_

Our ambient product category includes core grocery items (such as rice, pasta, baking supplies, canned goods,
condiments and cereals), impulse grocery items (such as snacks, confectionary treats, biscuits and soft drinks), beer,
wine, spirits, baby and toiletry items, non-edible grocery items (such as paper products, pet care supplies, cleaning
supplies and laundry-related items), newspapers, magazines and other kiosk items, pharmacy (including health
products and ambient medicines) and optical products. We believe that certain of our own-brand ambient products,
such as our Little Angels nappies and our Shades toilet rolls, are among the most popular products of their kind on the
market.

We continue to expand the range of our plant-based and vegan food products within our overall ambient food
selection. New items offered included vegan and plant-based proteins, cooking sauces, condiments, snacks and sweets
marketed under our Plant Based by Asda and Asda OMV! offers that we released at the beginning of 2023.

_Fresh_

Our fresh product category includes core chilled products (such as cheese, cooked meats, pies, salads and
dips, eggs and dairy products), fresh proteins (such as fresh beef, fresh pork, fresh poultry, bacon, sausage and
pre-packed fish), bakery (such as cakes, breads and morning goods bought and produced in store), in-store café (such
as beverages, main meals, snacks and drinks), foodservice (such as sandwiches, snacks, confectionary treats, salads
and drinks), serve-over and self-serve counters (such as rotisserie, pizza, Panku, Sushi Daily, Kulaba Kitchen, Asda
takeaway and various local partners), frozen (such as frozen meat, chips, vegetables, desserts, ice cream and frozen
meal solutions) fresh ready meals, soups and pizzas.

_Foodservice_

Following the EG UK Acquisition, we expanded our foodservice offerings. Our foodservice partners include
Greggs, Subway, Burger King and Sbarro, as well as our own proprietary brand, Leon. In addition to these
Group-operated branded offerings, the sites acquired from the EG UK Acquisition will also continue to benefit from
additional KFC and Starbucks branded offerings operated by third parties. Outside of our convenience and foodservice
sites, we also work with a number of strategic partners that operate retail locations within our grocery stores, such as
McDonalds and Sushi Daily. See “—Our Tenants and Strategic Partners.”

_Produce_

Our produce product category includes fruit, vegetables, salads, nuts, plants and flowers.

_Non-Food_

In 2023, our non-food segment accounted for 13.8% (£3.0 billion) of our total sales of £21.4 billion
(excluding fuel), with clothing and general merchandise accounting for approximately 6.8% and 7.0% of our total
sales (excluding fuel and other revenue from Asda Mobile sales, financial services sales and, until the EG UK
Acquisition, Asda On The Move), respectively.

_Clothing_

Our clothing product category includes the George Clothing line which offers a wide variety of clothing and
apparel, including for baby, children, men, women, jewellery, footwear, socks and hosiery.

_General merchandise_

Our general merchandise product category includes George Home (kitchenwares, housewares, electrical
appliances, furniture, lighting, bath, kids items and furnishings and bedding), seasonal and occasions products and
toys (cards, celebration products, stationary, toys, hobby items and festive and Halloween products), outdoor and
essential items (sporting goods, automotive, hardware, paint, access products and home and garden products) and
entertainment (electronics, books and telecoms products).

_Fuel_

Our fuel category includes the fuel sold at our PFS locations. We have a total of 794 PFS locations (of which
two have been closed) across our portfolio, 490 of which are attached to our convenience sites and 304 of which are
attached to Asda grocery stores. We offer our fuel products and services to our customers pursuant to agreements with
a number of partners, including prominent fuel brands such as Esso at 224 PFS sites, Shell at 87 PFS sites, Texaco at
37 PFS sites and BP at 29 PFS sites.
