**_Our Other Services_**

_Asda Pharmacy and Asda Opticians_

We operate complementary pharmacy and optical businesses that offer enhanced customer experiences and
diversify our cash flows.

As of December 31, 2023, we have 247 Asda Pharmacies offering NHS, locally commissioned and private
services to our patients. These services include dispensing NHS and private prescriptions, electronic prescriptions and
collection services as well as our Asda Pharmacy flu vaccine service for NHS and private patients. Examples of NHS
services we offer include our New Medicine Service in England, Pharmacy First in Scotland and our Common Ailment
scheme in Wales, each of which are commissioned by the home nations.

Asda Opticians offers our customers access to optical services and products in 157 stores and has a dedicated
online site selling contact lenses. In our stores, we complete eye examinations, contact lens examinations, provide
additional NHS services and dispense optical appliances (spectacles and contact lenses). Our in-store spectacle pricing
model does not charge extra to patients for prescription needs, including varifocals. We offer a wide contact lens
portfolio of various brands, designs and modalities. We also offer safety spectacles, sunglasses, eye care products,
accessories and contact lens solutions.

_Asda Money_

We offer certain financial and insurance products on a commission-only basis. All products are provided
through third-party partnerships. The products we offer include home insurance, car insurance, travel insurance, pet
insurance, money transfer, breakdown cover, third-party gift cards, personal loans, credit cards and travel money. See
also “Regulation—Regulation Relating to our Money and Insurance Offers.”

_Asda Gift Cards_

We offer Asda branded gift cards for sale in our stores and on our dedicated websites, which can be used to
buy goods in-store, on George.com or to purchase online groceries. Our gift card offer includes Asda’s Christmas
Savings Card, an Asda-branded card that pays a bonus to customers in November based on how much they have saved
on their card up to that date. We also participate in pre-paid card schemes through our business-to-business gift card
programme, through which a commission is paid to businesses to encourage end-users to shop at Asda. Businesses
who purchase Asda gift cards can also receive a discount on bulk purchases.

_Asda Mobile_

Asda Mobile operates as a Mobile Network Virtual Operator, offering pay-as-you-go mobile services to
customers. Asda Mobile was launched on the EE network. In 2020, we entered into an exclusive five-year agreement
with Vodafone to begin operating Asda Mobile. Our mobile network transitioned to Vodafone during the first half of
2021, and Asda Mobile on the EE network ceased in September 2021. As of December 31, 2023, we have
approximately 220,000 customers on the Vodafone network.

We sell our SIM cards in our stores at dedicated bays alongside mobile handsets. We also operate a dedicated
website where customers can order a SIM card. See also “Regulation—Regulations Relating to Our Mobile Offer.”

_Other Service Offers_

We also offer our customers other services, including our ‘toyou’ service, which allows customers to collect
and return orders from partner retailers at Asda locations, Asda Tyres (which sells tyres and connects customers to
local tyre fitting services via a dedicated online shop), and Asda Media Partnerships (an advertising service helping
brands to reach and influence Asda’s customers through digital, social, in-store and out-of-store advertising
opportunities).

**_Our Online Platform_**

We offer online grocery shopping through our online Asda groceries platform, including delivery services
for our customers’ online orders, as well as our Click & Collect service. We also offer our popular George Clothing
and homeware range online through George.com. For the year ended December 31, 2023, £3.6 billion of our sales
were through our online platform (of which £3.2 billion were online grocery sales and £0.4 billion were George.com
sales).

_Asda groceries_

Asda groceries is our online groceries business. We sell our groceries through groceries.asda.com and our
mobile application. Customers place an order either for delivery or for collection from one of approximately 460 Click
& Collect sites. Delivery orders are fulfilled either from our home shopping centres, which are dedicated fulfilment
centres for online grocery orders, or from Asda stores, depending on the customer’s location. This in-store online
model proved effective in responding to rapid increases in demand during the COVID-19-related lockdowns in the
United Kingdom and we believe this demonstrates our ability to scale our online offering quickly to meet customer
demand.

Our online delivery covers a comprehensive portion of the United Kingdom and delivery to customers is
primarily made by Asda colleagues using our van fleet. For deliveries, customers book a delivery slot and can choose
to either pay per delivery or to sign up for a monthly or annual delivery pass, allowing customers up to one delivery
per day on orders over £40 for a fixed price.

The COVID-19 pandemic increased the use of and engagement with our online platforms. In the first half of
2021, there were approximately 8.6 million weekly visits to groceries.asda.com, with order growth from
approximately 488,000 weekly orders pre-COVID-19 (based on the average orders for the seven days ended
February 28, 2020) to an average of more than 773,000 weekly orders in 2021 (based on the average weekly orders
for the first 26 weeks of 2021) and a peak of more than 850,000 orders during the third lockdown (based on the 7 days
to January 15, 2021). Although online engagement has fallen from the peaks experienced during the COVID-19
pandemic, we have continued to grow our online business, with an average of approximately 774,000 weekly orders
in 2022 and 2023 (based on the average weekly orders in 2022 and 2023).

_George.com_

We sell George Clothing and George Home products online through George.com. Customers place an order
either for delivery or collection from one of approximately 460 Click & Collect sites. Delivery of orders is provided
by third-party couriers, with orders prepared at our three fulfilment centres. George.com also delivers to customers
around the world. Following the Separation, Walmart has agreed to permit us to continue to use the George brand
internationally. For more information about where we will be able to use the George brand following the Separation,
see “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Transitional Agreements with Walmart—Trade Mark
_Agreement.”_

In 2019, we launched the George Rewards loyalty scheme, through which customers earn points as they shop
online and can use the points to unlock discounts.

A key component of our strategy is to provide great quality and value to our customers and we are focused
on initiatives supporting our customers who are faced with cost-of-living pressures. In May 2022, we launched a new
grocery opening price point range, Just Essentials by Asda. This range replaced the existing budget offering, Asda
Smart Price, expanding the range from approximately 160 to 272 products with new branding and products
reformulated for taste and quality. The total range is designed to enable customers to keep the household running on
a budget. The range is a key part of our strategy to make desirable products affordable, giving customers the
opportunity to reappraise our quality and value offering.

Throughout 2022, our Asda Rewards programme was introduced as an indirect cost-saving scheme for
customers to earn cash back on their shopping and we also ran our “Dropped and Locked” price campaign, which was
aimed at supporting UK households tackling inflation. The “Dropped and Locked” campaign locked in the prices of
over 100 grocery items, including fresh fruit and vegetables, fresh meat, store cupboard favourites like rice and
noodles, as well as soft drinks, desserts, frozen products and non-HFSS (as defined below) products. As a result, prices
on these products dropped by an average of 12% and locked until the end of 2022 to give customers certainty around
their shopping in light of these cost-of-living pressures. In 2023, we continued our commitment to our customers
through various price drop and freezing initiatives and in 2024, we introduced “Fab 5,” which offers our customers
five of our “fabulous” quality fruit and vegetables (on a weekly basis) at a low price of under £1, both in store and
online.

**_Own-branded food products_**

We have particular strength with our own-brand food products, including, among others, Just Essentials by
Asda (our opening price point brand), Asda (our mid-tier brand), Asda Farm Stores (our line of high-quality fresh and
affordable food drawing on Asda’s long-standing farming heritage and working closely with our approved farms,
growers and suppliers), Asda Extra Special (our premium product offer) and Asda Free From (our food offer for
specific dietary requirements, such as gluten-free diets). In 2023, we also launched two new vegan ranges, Plant Based
by Asda and Asda OMV! to meet increase customer demand for plant-based eating. The OMV! range offers indulgent
meat-free meals and delicious snacks, whilst the Plant Based range provides healthy meat alternatives.

In the 52 weeks ended January 26, 2024, our own-brand products accounted for 55.8% of our food volumes,

Our approach to range development and innovation enables us to identify and meet changing customer needs
and resulted in the creation of many award-winning products; we launched approximately 950 new lines in 2021,

are focused on building more inclusive product ranges, as demonstrated by the launch of Plant Based by Asda and

In our own-brand products, we are committed to sustainability: we have set goals of using an average

**Our Tenants and Strategic Partners**

We work with a number of tenants and strategic partners that operate retail locations within our grocery

**Our Colleagues**

As of December 31, 2023, we employed approximately 150,000 individuals. Our retail colleagues make up
the largest proportion of this, with approximately 85% of our workforce serving customers in store, 9% in the
distribution network, and 4% in home offices and 2% in other operations. Typically, our total number of colleagues
increases during peak retail periods, such as Easter and Christmas, due to seasonal hires.

We are committed to providing colleagues the training, education and incentives they need to strengthen their
skills and become part of our community.

Our colleagues are subject to standard employment terms, depending on their role, and are provided with
colleague handbooks (where relevant) and policies. We have trade union agreements in Asda’s retail and distribution
businesses as well as in Asda Express. In our retail business, we have a collective bargaining agreement for hourly-paid
colleagues in Northern Ireland and a partnership agreement with the GMB Union (“GMB”) for hourly-paid colleagues
who are GMB members in England, Scotland and Wales. In our distribution business, we have a collective bargaining
agreement with the GMB for hourly-paid colleagues and a collective bargaining agreement with Unite the Union
(“Unite”) and the United Road Transport Union for colleagues in our Lutterworth chilled distribution centre. For Asda
Express, the Union of Shop, Distributive and Allied Workers (“Usdaw”) have collective bargaining agreements for
hourly and salaried colleagues in sites acquired in connection with the Arthur Acquisition. We recently entered into a
collective bargaining agreement with Usdaw for hourly-paid colleagues in Leon, in sites acquired in connection with
the EG UK Acquisition and that will be in any new Asda Express site. The GMB partnership agreement covers eight
legacy Asda Express sites.

We are committed to offering competitive compensation in line with market practices and supporting our
colleagues during this high inflationary environment. For example, in April 2023, we voluntarily increased our rate
for hourly-paid store colleagues to £11.00 an hour and further increased this in July 2023 to £11.11 an hour. For stores
inside the M25 and around Greater London, our rate for hourly-paid store colleagues increased to £12.28. For
information related to certain ongoing legal proceedings relating to wages, please see “—Legal Proceedings—Equal
_Value Litigation.” We also offer variable compensation to colleagues, including those working in retail and_
distribution, to encourage performance based on the fulfilment of business targets.

**Our Suppliers and Logistics**

We operate a “hub and spoke” logistics network, with two hubs and two deconsolidation centres serving 23
depots across the United Kingdom. Our logistics model is designed to support our extensive store and online
businesses. This approach starts with suppliers that provide goods to our hubs and depots as well as directly to our
stores for certain products. Our hubs and depots supply our stores via our fleet. In addition to in-store purchasing,
Asda and Asda Logistics Services (“ALS”) also offer customers home-delivery and Click & Collect services.

    - _Hubs. Our two hubs are split by category: our Lutterworth hub handles general merchandise and ambient_
goods, while our Doncaster hub, which is operated by a third party, handles general merchandise and
ambient products.

    - Suppliers. We work closely with over 5,900 active supplier accounts as of December 31, 2023. The top
20 of our goods for resale (“GFR”) suppliers (excluding IPL and fuel) reflected approximately 29.5%

182


-----

of cost of goods sold to GFR suppliers (excluding VAT, for the year ended December 31, 2023), while
the top 20 goods not for resale (“GNFR”) suppliers (excluding IPL and fuel) reflected approximately
51.8% of costs of goods sold to GNFR suppliers. These suppliers deliver goods either to a hub (such as
for ambient and non-edible products and non-food products), direct to depots (such as for fresh food,
produce and fast-moving ambient) or direct to stores (such as for bread). New suppliers undergo a
number of checks and procedures managed via the shared service centre team. If a supplier is identified
as a third-party intermediary, which is typically only relevant to goods not for resale suppliers presenting
a bribery and corruption risk, further procedures are required as part of the on-boarding and ongoing
management processes for that supplier, focused on anti-corruption. During the on-boarding of goods
not for resale suppliers, we undertake a compliance risk review covering topics including, among others,
modern slavery, information security and privacy. If compliance risks are identified, then we agree on
and implement appropriate mitigation measures. Relationships with goods for resale suppliers are
managed by the relevant buying team within the commercial team. Our buyers are responsible for
negotiating key terms, including pricing, promotional activity, supplier income arrangements, and
payment terms. For goods not for resale suppliers, the applicable business owners manage the contract
terms and arrangements. We leverage supplier relationships to deliver supply chain continuity.

    - Ordering process. The purchase order process varies according to the category of goods.

        - _GFR: Automatic orders are generated with suppliers based on stock levels / stock availability,_
historical demand trends and forecast trends. This is applicable for the majority of food orders.
The supply team has manual override capabilities for automatic orders, albeit limited and rarely
required. Non-food products typically operate on a longer lead time. The orders are based on
forecast sales numbers provided to the supply team by the buying team and the commercial
finance team.

        - _GFNR: Purchase orders are raised by the procurement team or the applicable colleague and_
reviewed by the budget holder (the individual who is responsible for the budget to which the
associated cost relates) within that colleague’s team.

    - _Logistics facilities. Logistics facilities receive, process, warehouse and distribute goods for sale at our_
stores. IPL, Forza and Kober are treated as suppliers and largely deliver to depots. In addition, we operate
home shopping centres, which are fulfilment centres for online grocery orders.

    - Fleet. Our drivers deliver goods to stores and customers using fleet vehicles (1,367 leased tractors and
2,629 leased trailers), home shopping vans (3,401 leased vans) or occasional spot hire or use of thirdparty hauliers (figures as of December 31, 2023).

    - Stores. aside from in-store purchasing, we also offer our customers home delivery and Click & Collect
service.

**IPL**

We believe we have a competitive advantage in food sourcing via IPL and its two subsidiary companies,
Forza and Kober, which enables a vertically integrated approach to procurement. IPL is an important asset that
provides valuable sourcing differentiation. In 2023, £1,724 million was purchased through IPL, reducing our overall
purchasing costs and delivering strong value to our customers.

Our 2023 product mix sourced from IPL was 55.7% produce, 28.3% protein, 6.6% house plants and flowers,
6.1% beverages and 3.3% grocery. IPL employed over 3,700 colleagues as of December 31, 2023 across its group of
companies, and only serves us. IPL receives products directly from producers and employs centralised sourcing,
transportation and packing. This disintermediation of export agents, import agencies, suppliers and packers is the
foundation of IPL’s cost price advantage: IPL sources fruit and vegetables, cooked meats, wine, nuts and dried fruit,
plants and flowers and has a national footprint of nine processing facilities across the United Kingdom, supported by
two overseas technical/logistical operations. IPL’s overseas offices provide us with the benefit of being close to our
foreign grower partners, which we believe gives us greater insight and control over our supply chain, conferring on

us a competitive advantage versus other retailers who do not benefit from comparable vertically integrated
procurement.

**Our Quality Control System, Health and Safety and Environmental Policies**

**_Quality Control_**

We are committed to providing customers with safe and high-quality products, including both our own-brand
products and name brand products. We have a due diligence framework in place which covers, among other things,
our supplier audit framework, our governance policies, product testing and our specification management system. Our
supplier audit framework measures compliance, supplier performance against food safety hazard analysis and critical
control point principles. In addition, we have a quality management system that measures how our products perform
in terms of quality.

To control the quality of the products we sell, we execute a number of quality control initiatives. We conduct
regular quality controls on the acceptance of fresh food at our depots. In addition, we analyse own-brand product

184


-----

samples in our in-house sensory kitchens and through a third-party, Cambridge Market Research, to ensure that our
products meet our customers’ expectations.

All new own-brand suppliers must be Global Food Safety Initiative accredited and must pass a new supplier
audit before proceeding. In addition, all own-brand suppliers will have an annual unannounced Asda Star Audit that
measures their adherence to Asda policy.

We conduct food safety audits twice a year at our superstores and home shopping centres, and once a year at
our smaller supermarkets and depots, to ensure that each site meets our required standards for food safety and hygiene.
We conduct essential training and department-specific training for store colleagues to ensure that they are trained in
all relevant aspects of food safety related to their department, including allergen management.

When deciding whether to work with an own-brand supplier, we monitor the quality of its products based on
a control of samples delivered by the supplier during the selection phase. Following selection, we regularly evaluate
the quality of the products the supplier offers, including through randomly selected samples. Our general supplier
terms and conditions include a section dedicated to quality, safety, labelling and traceability. By signing these terms
and conditions, our suppliers confirm that they are fully aware of, and comply with, our safety and quality standards.
Furthermore, suppliers must adhere to our technical manufacturing guide and associated policies for food as well as
work with our own-brand technical teams to ensure compliance with this guide and these policies.

**_Health, Safety and Environmental Policies and Ethics_**

We are committed to maintaining high standards of health and safety practices for our colleagues, customers,
visitors, contractors and anyone affected by our business activities. We therefore consider good health, safety and
environmental management as an essential part of our business performance and culture. We formally monitor health
and safety incident rates. Our health and safety policies and procedures include:

    - managing risk and promoting a corporate culture that emphasises the benefits of health and safety;

    - appropriate training and education of all colleagues to support legal compliance and best practices; and

    - proactively conducting regular risk assessments and root cause analyses to provide and maintain safe
and healthy working environments to significantly reduce occupational injuries or illnesses.

We carry out a range of monitoring activities to provide assurance of the effectiveness of our policies and
procedures. These activities are completed by both internal teams and external experts. We have a wide variety of
health and safety and ethics policies that address topics such as Food Safety, Food Contamination, Warehouse Safety,
Product Safety, Fire Safety, Privacy, Environment and Environmental Services, Anti-Money Laundering and Licences
and Permits, among others.

We also have a number of policies that relate specifically to waste management issues, such as Food and
Drink Waste, Confidential Waste, Optical Waste and Pharmacy Waste.

**_Our Environmental, Social and Governance Goals_**

As a major retailer, we believe that we have the ability, and the responsibility, to make a significant impact
on the topics that matter to our stakeholders, such as energy and climate change, food waste, plastic and packaging,
healthy and sustainable choices and the support of local communities (together, our “ESG Priority Areas”), and our
customers want us to play our part in creating solutions that work for everyone. By taking action, we intend to meet
these expectations, but also to strengthen our business for the future so that we can continue to deliver the same value
to our customers.

In 2022, we reassessed our environmental, social and governance (“ESG”) programme to ensure it remains
a critical pillar of our growth strategy. Our overarching ESG approach remains focused on providing access and
affordability for customers as the business undergoes a period of transformation and takes account of the external
environment in which we operate.

185


-----

In October 2023, we received our first external assessment of our ESG strategy with an overall rating of 3
(on a scale of 1 to 5, where 1 is the strongest) by the financial services ratings’ agency Sustainable Fitch as part of our
ongoing commitment to transparently report on our efforts to achieve our ESG targets. We also received an entity
score of 54 (on a scale of 0 to 100).

_Our ESG Priority Areas_

_Energy and Climate Change Mitigation_

_Carbon Emissions_

Our carbon footprint is nearly equally split between the transportation of goods and refrigerants and natural
gas (Scope 1 emissions) and the electricity we use across our estate (Scope 2 emissions). Our Scope 1 and Scope 2
emissions come from fleet, buildings and purchased energy, and we have undertaken numerous activities to reduce
these, including through continuing to rollout gas-powered HGVs, electrifying the Asda Online delivery fleet and
moving to lower-carbon refrigerants. For Scope 3 emissions, we continue to engage with our suppliers to reduce
product-related emissions and work particularly closely with our largest suppliers on setting climate commitments for
the products they sell us. To play our part in tackling climate change, we have been working to decarbonise our Scope
1 and Scope 2 emissions since 2007 and in 2015, set our commitment to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 50% by
2025. We have since reduced our greenhouse gas footprint for the United Kingdom by 41% to 564,247 tonnes CO2
equivalent (“tCO2e”) in 2023 (without giving effect to the Arthur Acquisition) compared to our baseline of 957,918
tCO2e in 2015. This reduction has been driven in part by a reduction in electricity and gas use, the continued transition
of our heavy goods vehicles fleet to low or no carbon fuels and implementing lower carbon refrigeration and energy
efficiency measures across our stores.

In addition, in 2021 we stated our ambition to be a net-zero business, establishing a clear roadmap to
achieving net-zero Scope 1 and Scope 2 greenhouse gas emissions within our own operations by 2040. We have
committed to setting a near-term science-based carbon reduction target, including a specific Forests, Land and
Agriculture target. These targets have been submitted to the Science-Based Targets Initiative (“SBTi”) for validation.
The proposed targets were submitted before the Arthur Acquisition and the EG UK Acquisition so reflect our footprint
prior to these acquisitions. In 2024, we will look to incorporate these acquisitions into our baseline and targets.

In 2022, our total carbon footprint was 28,295,682 tCO2e (without giving effect to the Arthur Acquisition)
including 51% from product emissions (including the farming of ingredients, processing products, through to
packaging), 2% in connection with supply chain logistics, 2% from our sites and fleet, 4% from goods not for resale
as well as our operational activity, 25% from customers using the fuel we sell them and the remaining 16% from
customers using products (including cooking, washing clothes, disposing of products and packaging).

_Nature_

Food production systems require a diverse range of plants, animals, bacteria and fungi, both for the direct
supply of food and to sustain the underlying ecosystem processes that make agriculture possible – from water supply
to soil fertility enhancement, pollination and natural pest control. We are mindful of the impact we have through our
value chain on the natural capitals of air, water, soil and biodiversity, and are committed to working in partnership to
better respect and restore nature.

In recent years, we have encouraged farmers to keep soil covered and improve biodiversity and soil structure
through the use of our bespoke seed mixture. These seeds create a wildlife habitat during the late spring and summer
and the wildlife corridors can also be used as buffer strips to watercourses.

We are committed to more sustainably sourcing key commodities and tracking performance against our most
material impacts, including soy and palm, within our annual ESG Report. We support the principles of Integrated
Farm Management (“IFM”) and, in early 2023, we committed to obtaining the global LEAF Marque Environmental
Assurance System across all our fresh produce by the end of 2025.

186


-----

_Water Resources_

Water resources are under stress around the world, and we believe improving water use and building
resilience in global supply chains is vital in order to sustainably feed a growing population with healthy and affordable
products.

In 2022, 22% of our fruit and vegetables were imported from Southern Spain. As part of a cross-industry
group working with the British Waste & Resources Action Programme (“WRAP”), we have made a three-year
commitment for funding to the ‘Water Stewardship in South Spain’ project, which is taking action to try to reduce
water-related risks in the fruit and vegetable production areas of Andalusia, Murcia and Valencia.

In addition, we work with many garment manufacturers who have taken a series of water saving measures to
reduce water consumption such as using harvested/reused water for flushing toilets and excess steam pipe water being
returned to the boiler for reuse.

_Waste_

_Food Waste_

We are committed to being a zero-waste business, which means that any waste we do generate is either
reused, recycled or redistributed. We continue to work towards our 2025 waste reduction targets across food (20%
reduction in waste), packaging (100% recyclable own brand packaging, 30% recycled content) and operational waste
(90% diversion from energy and maintain zero to landfill).

As part of our efforts to reduce food surplus, we created a new team dedicated to reducing food waste within
our supply chain in 2019. This team scrutinises our food waste performance by individual product line, enabling us to
create initiatives and to work with our suppliers to reduce food waste. As a result, we removed best before dates on
almost 250 fresh fruit and vegetable products to help customers reduce food waste in the home and save money in
2022 and, in early 2023, we went further by changing the use by dates on over half of our own brand yoghurts to a
best before date, aiming to reduce the volume of edible yoghurt thrown away each year (by all retailers). In 2022, we
processed 32,923 tonnes of food surplus (redistribution/animal feed) and food waste (anaerobic digestion/energy from
waste) from our stores and depots.

Whilst our priority is to reduce the absolute volume of our food surplus being processed as waste, we are also
committed to ensuring that we handle that surplus in the most value-adding way possible by directing as much as
possible for human or animal consumption. To tackle operational food waste, we increased the number of charities
we work with redistributing surplus food from our distribution sites and through our partnerships in 2022, our stores,
depots and home offices donated 2,182 tonnes of food, the equivalent of more than 5.2 million meals.

In addition to our Food Waster prevention efforts, we began working with our clothing factories and George
Home suppliers to help us build a robust strategy and policy around waste, which we plan to report through our future
ESG reports and our website.

_Plastic and Packaging_

Although packaging plays a vital role in protecting goods and keeping food fresh for as long as possible,
consumers increasingly want to see fewer single-use plastics, especially when it comes to fresh produce. Where
packaging is vital, we are working to make it more sustainable. Removing packaging completely or shrinking it down
to its lightest possible weight has allowed us to remove significant amounts of plastic from Asda Brand products and
eliminate some types of single-use plastic products from our stores and offices completely. Where packaging cannot
be reduced, we are working to make it more reusable. We introduced reusable or re-tillable solutions for packaging
that allowed a shift towards fresh meat and produce being transited in reusable crates and introduced customer refills
at our Middleton “sustainability store,” which is a concept designed to encourage customers to reuse and refill their
products, allowing customers to bring and fill their own containers with products such as on core products such as
cereals, tea, coffee and pet food. We have partnered with Unilever and WRAP to conduct research to make the refill
experience easier and more enjoyable for our customers.

187


-----

Where packaging cannot be reused, we are working to make it more recyclable.

_Healthy, Sustainable Choices_

At Asda, we are making nutritious food affordable and appealing, with health-focused communications,
support for public health campaigns and innovation in our own-brand products. We recognise the importance of
front-of-pack traffic lights to enable customers to manage their calorie intake and their intakes of nutrients of concern
such as fat, saturated fat, sugar and salt. In October 2022, location restrictions on the sale of high fat, salt and sugar
foods (“HFSS”) came into force in England across 13 categories, a measure which forms a key part of the UK
Government’s strategy to tackle obesity by making unhealthy food less prominent in stores and online. Despite the
operational challenges affecting the way foods in Asda are merchandised and the significant investment required, we
used the HFSS legislation to accelerate our ability to collect HFSS data across brands for all products, which is
essential to be able to report on healthy basket spend.

We also recognise the importance of highlighting healthy choices to our customers with a focus on positive
nutrients and health benefits, which is the motivation behind our 2020 launch of the Asda Live Better icon, which
highlights the healthiest choices in our own-brand ranges. In the fourth quarter of 2023, approximately 876 products,
including a wide range from the Just Essentials by Asda, bore the icon and we aim to have 1,200 products in the range
by the end of 2024.

_Supporting Local Communities_

_Fundraising and Support_

We aim to build stronger communities and to connect others to make a collective impact on our customers.
Through our network of Community Champions and fundraising initiatives, we take action to make a positive change
to poverty, tackle breast cancer, support children and families in crisis and build more resilient communities.

The Asda Foundation is an independent charity with more than 30 years’ of history helping people in local
communities. Its mission is to transform communities and improve lives throughout the United Kingdom,
complementing Asda’s ambition to be at the heart of local communities. The Asda Foundation supports grassroots
organisations as well as local communities in emergencies, reacting quickly to help people in the immediate hours
following a disaster. The Asda Foundation provides grants to small, local activities, funding a wide range of projects
from school uniforms and Christmas lunches to refurbishing a community centre kitchen.

Following Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Asda and the Asda Foundation pledged £1.0 million to support
displaced Ukrainian families in Europe and the United Kingdom and helped Ukrainian refugees by welcoming
applications for roles in our stores, warehouses and within IPL, with a guaranteed job interview and specialist support
for those recruited.

The increasing cost of living is a growing issue in the United Kingdom and in 2022, Asda Foundation
introduced a new Cost of Living grant to support local groups with increased running costs. In 2022 Asda Foundation
invested £4,315,444 in local communities, supporting 7,119 groups with grants and colleague hardship payments.

Over 14 million people in the United Kingdom live below the poverty line, and just under a third of those
affected are children. At the same time, 4.4 million tonnes of edible food are wasted in the United Kingdom each year
and as a food retailer, it is important to us to make a positive impact. Through its transformational three-year, Fight
Hunger, Create Change programme, Asda partnered with FareShare and The Trussell Trust to create long-term
positive change in the United Kingdom. Asda has since continued to support both FareShare and the Trussell Trust
through donations of food, cause-related marketing initiatives, customer fundraising and top up donations.

_Diversity & Inclusion_

Our mission is to be the UK’s most trusted retailer, which means building a business that is diverse and
inclusive, creating a safe and supportive environment for our colleagues, customers and suppliers. We focus on
providing the best possible learning opportunities for our colleagues, listening to their needs and promoting their
health and wellbeing and as further support, we launched a course called “Inclusion Matters” in 2022 to help

188


-----

colleagues build an inclusive work environment. We encourage everyone to be allies through positive and conscious
efforts and introduced an “Asda Allies” campaign to raise awareness on how our colleagues can help
under-represented colleagues and its importance. Asda Allies is a key lens for all our internal campaigns and underpins
that one does not have to be directly affected by discrimination or unfair treatment to challenge non-inclusive
behaviour, advocate the need for change, and seek to understand the additional barriers that some people or
communities face.

We have set a target to increase the proportion of female store managers to 30% by 2025 and have established
programmes to deliver this, such as our Retail Female Representation Working Group, which is tasked with looking
at the barriers to increasing female store leadership and our Female Intentional Allyship programme that launched in
2022. In 2023, 290 of our colleagues participated in the Female Intentional Allyship programme.

Over the years, we introduced 75 apprenticeship programmes, including degrees in data science, supply chain
leadership and business management and were recognised in 2022 as one of the United Kingdom’s top 100
apprenticeship employers. In 2023, Asda was a finalist in the Macro Employer of the Year category of the National
Apprenticeship Awards.

_Supply Chain and Responsible Sourcing_

Ethics and compliance are at the heart of ensuring our business meets the expectations of our stakeholders in
terms of conduct and behaviours. These behaviours and expectations extend to everyone who works with us, from our
employees to our suppliers and contractors, requiring them to share our values and help promote a culture where
people do the right thing as a matter of course. We have integrated supply chain policies into our processes and ways
of working to obtain supply chain transparency and continue to work to ensure our supply chains are resilient and lead
to positive change by sourcing responsibly, promoting human rights and eschewing modern slavery. Our Ethics and
Compliance programme is designed to manage compliance risks with key areas relevant to the retail sectors including
anti-corruption, anti-trust, consumer protection, environmental, anti-money laundering and financial services, food
safety, health and safety, optical and pharmacy, labour and employment, licences and permits, privacy, product safety,
responsible sourcing and trade sanctions. Since our separation from Walmart we have been transitioning to establish
an Asda-specific approach to responsible sourcing and in 2022, we published our Human Rights Policy and completed
a responsible sourcing risk assessment based on supplier compliance information to identify salient risks and themes
including gender, modern slavery, vulnerable workers, worker representation and working hours as key topics to
address and further integrate throughout our business.

**Our Technology and Information Systems**

Our information systems are critical to our business operations. They provide management, analytical and
performance evaluation tools that assist management at all levels to undertake business processes. Our technical
infrastructure and computer applications are also used for the day-to-day management of our business, including
purchasing, sourcing, distribution, online sales, data exploitation, invoicing, cash collection, reporting, consolidation
and electronic data interchange. Our business depends on the ability of our colleagues to process transactions on secure
information systems and our capacity to store, retrieve, process and manage information. Our information systems are
highly integrated, covering most of our fundamental business service areas. The majority of our core systems are
currently provided and managed by Walmart, and we are migrating off of these systems onto alternative solutions
through Project Future. As of March 31, 2024, we have invested approximately £600 million in Project Future,
comprising of both operating expenses and capital expenditure. We believe Project Future presents significant
opportunities in terms of our efficiency, data capabilities, customer experience and competitive edge. We are in the
third year of the four-year programme. We are progressing through the build and implement of Project Future, moving
to in-depth testing and roll-out. We have successfully converted seven depots as of March 31, 2024 as part of our new
Warehouse Management system “Manhattan” (with two more in progress) and have implemented our new store till
systems across many stores. Our core back-office SAP system is also live, onto which we have recently transitioned
our finance operations, and we are undertaking detailed testing to prepare for transitioning our commercial function
to SAP in the second quarter of 2024. We have recently implemented our new core human resources and payroll
systems across our entire network. In the second half of 2024, our inventory management and fulfilment systems will
be rolled out across our commercial, supply chain and retail estate. We are targeting complete separation from Walmart
by the end of 2024. We believe that our information systems are robust, adequate to support our activities and operate
at standards that are comparable to other operators in our industry. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our

**Our Publicity, Marketing and Customer Service**

Marketing is an integral part of the promotion of our brand, stores and products. We carry out a number of
branding and advertising initiatives through our stores, websites and mobile applications, as well as through print,
social and broadcast advertising campaigns. We work these through owned, earned and paid channels. The key focus
of our messaging to our customers is an emphasis on value, the innovative, high-quality and well-priced products we
offer and brand sentiment, services and ways to shop as well as a focus on corporate social responsibility. We also
have an online and paper magazine, Asda MAG/Good Living, through which we promote our products and brand
values, as well as encourage customer engagement with our brands and offers. We receive publicity for our innovations
in product range and quality across own-brands, which helped us to win over 700 product awards, 378 food awards,
332 beer, wine and spirit awards and five retailer awards in 2023.

Customer service is key to winning and retaining customers. We make customer service available in our
stores, online and by telephone. We offer our George customers a loyalty programme, George Rewards, and in 2022,
we launched our new loyalty programme, Asda Rewards. The scheme is app-based and enables customers to earn
cash back on their shopping, building Asda Pounds in their cash pots to spend in store. The scheme also provides the
opportunity to leverage data insights which enable to Group to better target investment in the customer proposition.
Asda Rewards had 4.9 million active customers as of December 31, 2023 over the prior 30-day period (or 5.7 million
active customers as of December 31, 2023 over the prior 13-week period) and continues to drive incremental sales. It
is central to our strategic objective around proposition and creating more reasons to shop with us than anyone else.

**Regulation**

We are subject to a wide variety of laws, regulations and industry standards administered by local, national
and other government entities. The following provides a brief description of the main laws and regulations that govern
our activities. References and discussions to directives, laws, regulations and other administrative and regulatory
documents are entirely qualified by the full text of such directives, laws, regulations and other administrative and
regulatory documents themselves.

We are in regular contact and dialogue with relevant regulators and have subject matter experts across the
business who monitor and manage compliance with the regulatory frameworks within which we operate.

**_Controlled Land Order_**

We are subject to the Groceries Market Investigation (Controlled Land) Order 2010 (the “Controlled Land
**Order”) which is UK legislation designed to limit the ability of large grocery retailers to prevent land being used by**
their competitors for grocery retailing in the future. The Controlled Land Order is administered by the CMA (as
defined below).

**_Groceries Supply Code of Practice and Groceries Code Adjudicator_**

We are subject to the Groceries Supply Code of Practice (the “GSCOP”), which is UK legislation designed
to regulate the relationship between designated retailers and their grocery suppliers. GSCOP provides detail on how
retailers should manage their relevant supplier relationships fairly.

The Groceries Code Adjudicator is the independent regulator of GSCOP.

**_Food Safety, Hygiene, Labelling and Nutrition and Consumer Protection_**

We have food safety specialists in our compliance and technical and quality teams, to ensure food supply,
handling and storage procedures are monitored closely to ensure product safety, quality standards and compliance
with all applicable food safety and hygiene laws and regulations. In doing so this ensures all aspects of food safety
risk are managed appropriately across supply, operations and foodservice. Scheduled internal and external audits are
conducted by qualified, third-party food safety experts to ensure procedural compliance and adherence with our
policies. This verification programme identifies and evaluates the hazards that are significant for food safety and
hygiene, taking account of the Food Safety Act 1990, the Food Information Regulations 2014 (as amended) and Food
Safety and Hygiene Regulations in place across England, Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales. In addition, the Food
Information (Amendment) (England) Regulations 2022 and the Food Information (Scotland) Amendment Regulations
2021, also known as “Natasha’s Law,” took effect in October 2021 and requires businesses to list all the ingredients
on individual packaging of products that are considered pre-packed for direct sale.

**_Regulation Relating to our Health and Wellness Offers (Asda Pharmacy and Asda Optical)_**

With respect to our Optical offer, we are regulated by the General Optical Council (“GOC”). Asda Stores
Limited is a registered Body Corporate with the GOC, which allows us to provide Optical services subject to the GOC
Business Standards and the Opticians Act of 1989. Our professionals are registered as individual registrants with the
GOC and are subject to GOC Standards for Individuals and the Opticians Act of 1989.

We hold NHS mandatory contracts for all of our Asda Opticians locations and are subject to the terms of

subject to the NHS standard contracts and local service level agreements. Enhanced services are defined as primary

With respect to our pharmacies, we are regulated by the General Pharmaceutical Council (“GPHC”) in
England and Wales and Scotland, and the Pharmaceutical Society of Northern Ireland (“PharmaSNI”). Each of our
individual pharmacies is registered with the GPHC or the PharmaSNI, as applicable. This allows us to carry out
pharmaceutical activity from our registered premises subject to the Standards for Registered Pharmacies. Our
pharmacists are registered with the GPHC as individual registrants and are subject to the GPHC Professional Standards
or the PharmaSNI Professional Standards, as applicable.

**_Regulations Relating to Electricity Purchasing_**

Up until March 2021, we purchased our electricity on a wholesale basis via a dedicated subsidiary, which
sold electricity back to the rest of the Asda Group companies. These electricity purchases were regulated by the Office
of Gas and Electricity Markets (“OFGEM”), which is the government regulator for gas and electricity markets in
Great Britain.

Since March 2021, we have purchased our electricity on a retail basis facilitated through a third-party agent
and therefore the regulations relating to wholesale purchases do not apply to the retail purchases made thereafter.

Following the switch from purchasing wholesale electricity (via the Power4All subsidiary) in March 2021,
we withdrew from all the various utility regulatory bodies including the BSC, via Elexon. All industry parties were
written to by OFGEM as part of the process to ensure we had no outstanding obligations. Once these confirmations
were received, the licence was revoked in July 23. As a result, we are no longer a wholesale contracting party and we
have no on-going responsibilities to report, or any liabilities with any industry party including HMRC, BEIS or
National Grid in relation to Power4All.

**_Data Privacy Regulations_**

Through our in-store and online business, as well as certain of our other services (such as our money and
pharmacy offers), we have access to and may process personal data relating to our customers and colleagues or any
other individual in connection with the provision of our services (the “Relevant Data”). As such, we are subject to
applicable laws and binding regulations on data protection and data privacy, including the UK GDPR (such laws and
binding regulations together with the UK GDPR, “Applicable Privacy Laws”). We will continue to review and
develop existing processes to ensure that we comply with Applicable Privacy Laws in relation to our processing of
any Relevant Data.

**_Competition and Markets Authority_**

From time to time, we may enter into acquisitions or transactions that are subject to regulatory approval from
the Competition and Markets Authority (the “CMA”) and may lead to investigations if the deal raises competition
concerns. The CMA is the principal competition regulator in the United Kingdom and is a non-ministerial government
department. It is responsible to strengthening business competition and preventing and reducing anti-competitive
activities.

_Green Claims Code_

In 2021, the CMA introduced the Green Claims Code, which is designed for businesses with consumer-facing
products and services to ensure that their environmental claims align with UK consumer law. The Green Claims Code
applies to advertising and any product or service, by any commercial entity, aimed at or supplied to a UK consumer,
including by a non-UK business, a distributor or an online platform.

**_Miscellaneous Regulatory Matters_**

In addition to the foregoing regulations, in the ordinary course of our business, our operations and properties
are subject to international, national, regional and local laws and regulations of general applicability, such as labour
laws, laws on advertising, regulations governing our relations with our suppliers and distributors, anti-bribery, food
and product safety, environmental, health and safety matters (including regulations specific to the fuel market, such
as for petroleum storage certificates, the management and disposal of hazardous materials, air emissions and water
discharge and the clean-up of contaminated sites), among others.

We operate a vehicle fleet that is subject to an Operator’s Licence issued by the relevant local Traffic

**_Equal Value Litigation_**

Asda Stores Limited is a defendant in approximately 52,923 equal value claims (the “Equal Value Claims”)
that began in 2008 and are proceeding before an Employment Tribunal in Manchester (the “Employment Tribunal”)
in the United Kingdom on behalf of current and former Asda store colleagues, and further claims may be asserted in
the future. There are also 8,147 claims filed in the High Court which are stayed pending the outcome of the Equal
Value Claims. The claimants allege that the work performed by colleagues in Asda’s retail stores is of equal value in
terms of, among other things, the demands of their jobs compared to that of colleagues working in Asda’s warehouse
and distribution facilities, that the difference in pay between these job positions disparately impacts women because
more women work in retail stores while more men work in warehouses and distribution facilities, and that the pay
difference is not objectively justified. The claimants are requesting differential back pay based on higher wage rates
in the warehouse and distribution facilities and higher wage rates on a prospective basis.

In October 2016, following a preliminary hearing, the Employment Tribunal ruled that claimants could
compare their positions in Asda’s retail stores with those of colleagues in Asda’s warehouse and distribution facilities.
On March 26, 2021, the Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal’s decision, that the work of hourly-paid workers
in distribution centres and the work of hourly-paid workers in stores can be compared.

The litigation is currently in the equal value stage when the Employment Tribunal Claimants are proceeding
in the next phase of their claims. That phase will determine whether the work performed by the claimants is of equal
value to the work performed by colleagues in Asda’s warehouse and distribution facilities. The equal value hearing is
scheduled to take place from September 9, 2024 to December 13, 2024 at the Manchester Employment Tribunal. At
present, we cannot predict the number of such claims that may be filed and cannot reasonably estimate any loss or
range of loss that may arise from these proceedings. Accordingly, we can provide no assurance as to the scope and
outcomes of these matters and any losses that may arise from these proceedings could have a material adverse effect
on our business, financial position, results of operations or cash flows. We believe we have substantial factual and
legal defences to these claims and intend to defend the claims vigorously.

Under a separate indemnity undertaking, Walmart has agreed to indemnify the LBO Purchaser in respect of
a portion of costs and losses incurred by the Asda Group from Equal Value Claims filed with employment tribunals,
up to an agreed cap. If the Asda Group is ultimately unsuccessful in defending any of the Equal Value Claims, we do
not believe that such an outcome would materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and/or results of
operations nor our ability to meet our debt service obligations, including on the Senior Secured Notes, or other
financial obligations as they become due.

As of December 31, 2023, the Group had material off balance sheet arrangements or funding arrangements
that would be classified as a contingent liability under UK IFRS with respect to the ongoing Equal Value Claims.
Despite the above-mentioned Supreme Court ruling, the Group has not recognised a provision on the basis that any
loss or range of loss that may arise from these proceedings cannot be reasonably estimated and any potential liability
is only a possible obligation, as it has yet to be confirmed whether the entity has a present obligation that could lead
to an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits. See “Business—Legal Proceedings—Equal Value
_Litigation” and “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Legal and Regulatory Matters—From time to time we and/or our_
_management are subject to claims that can result in litigation, arbitration, tax or regulatory proceedings which could_
_distract management from our business activities and result in significant liability.”_

**_Environmental Claims Matter_**

On July 29, 2022, the CMA publicly announced that they would be investigating environmental claims made
in relation to certain products within our George clothing range, and ranges of two other clothing retailers with
operations in the United Kingdom. Initial findings relevant to Asda were presented to us on a confidential basis in
May 2023. In presenting its findings, the CMA required all information to be specific and visible to customers at the
time of their purchasing decision. We opted to negotiate a set of voluntary undertakings (with no admission of liability)
with respect to the way environmental claims are made going forward, rather than face court-based enforcement
(which could include costs, negative publicity and exposure to significant fines for breach of consumer protection
laws (up to 10% global annual turnover under incoming legislation)). These undertakings were concluded and
announced in March 2024, simultaneously with the other two investigated retailers.

**Management Incentive Plan**

In 2022, management shares in the immediate parent company of the Group, Bellis Midco 4 Limited, were
issued to eligible members of senior management employed by the Group as part of a Management Incentive Plan
(“MIP”), in exchange for proceeds determined by an independent calculation of fair value at the issue date. Under the
MIP, an intermediate holding company of the Group, Bellis Midco 2 Limited, has entered into an agreement with the
holders of MIP management shares (“MIP scheme members”) whereby MIP scheme members are granted put
options which, when exercised, enable them to sell their management shares to Bellis Midco 2 Limited or another
non-Group entity for a value which is based on an independent valuation determined at the exercise date.

MIP scheme members are required to be employed by the Group at the grant date of the MIP shares. If a
member of the scheme ceases to be employed by the Group during the vesting period, Bellis Midco 2 Limited, a parent
of Bellis Finco PLC, has the option to repurchase, or nominate another entity of the Group to repurchase, the shares
during the 12-month period after the member’s leave date. As such, directors of the Group have determined that the
MIP scheme falls within the scope of IFRS 2. The difference between the IFRS 2 fair value and the fair value paid by
MIP scheme members at the grant date is expensed over the vesting period (i.e., the period from date on which the
MIP shares are granted to the estimated exercise date) as an expense in the consolidated Income Statement. As neither
MIP shares nor put options over MIP shares are issued by entities within the Group, and as there is no recharge
agreement in place which requires any entity within the Group to settle liabilities in respect of MIP shares, changes in
the fair value of MIP shares are accounted for on an equity-settled basis.

**Committees**

We have a range of committees with board-delegated authority that meet regularly to manage day-to-day
operations and decision-making on behalf of the Board. The areas of responsibility of each group are described below.
Committees are chaired and attended by members of the Board and Executive Committee as appropriate, and other
relevant members of senior management. These committees operate under clearly documented terms of reference and
the remit of each is regularly reviewed, and the terms of reference are updated as and when required.

**Executive Committee**

On a day-to-day basis, Asda is run by an executive committee (the “Executive Committee”), a group of
senior leaders who provide strategic direction and operational management across Asda’s business.

**Audit Committee**

The Audit Committee sits at the level of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited. The Audit Committee’s objectives are to
provide oversight and effective governance over the appropriateness and integrity of the financial reporting of the
Group, the internal financial controls and risk management systems, compliance with laws and regulations, and the
effectiveness of the internal audit function and external auditor. The Audit Committee meets at least four times a year
aligned with the external reporting and audit cycle and is chaired by non-executive director Dame Alison Carnwath.

**Nominations and Remuneration Committee**

The Nomination and Remuneration Committee sits at the level of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited. The Nominations
and Remuneration Committee meets twice a year and is chaired by non-executive director and chairman Lord Stuart
Rose. Its remit includes evaluating the balance, experience, knowledge and skills of the Board, succession planning,
monitoring independence of non-executive directors, monitoring trends and compliance with corporate governance
best practice, and recommending remuneration strategy and policies for the Group.

A separate nominations and remuneration committee for Asda Group Limited and its subsidiaries is chaired
and attended by members of the Executive Committee. It is responsible for setting remuneration policies for the
business more broadly, including decisions around bonus and hourly pay.

**Disclosure Committee**

The Disclosure Committee sits at the level of Asda Group Limited and has authority delegated from Bellis
TopCo 2 and its subsidiaries. The Disclosure Committee is responsible for managing the disclosure of material
non-public information (MNPI) to Asda’s bond investors and lenders. It meets quarterly aligned with the quarterly
investor reporting cycle and on an ad hoc basis as required when potentially material events arise. It is chaired by the
Chief Financial Officer and attended by the General Counsel, Disclosure Officer, and senior directors in investor
relations and communications.

**Liquidity and Financial Risk Management (“LARM”) Committee**

The LARM Committee sits at the level of Asda Group Limited and has authority delegated from Bellis TopCo
2 and its subsidiaries. The LARM Committee meets on a monthly basis and is chaired by Mr. Gleeson as our chief
financial officer. Its role is to review and make recommendations to the Board with respect to cash, liquidity, financial
risk management, and any other area relating to risks arising out of financial transactions, including investment
decisions, interest rate and foreign currency exposure.

199


-----

**Compliance, Ethics, Risk and Audit (“CERA”) Committee**

The CERA Committee sits at the level of Asda Group Limited and has authority delegated from Bellis TopCo
2 and its subsidiaries. The CERA Committee meets monthly and is chaired by Asda’s general counsel and attended
by Mr. Gleeson as the chief financial officer and a non-executive director. Its role is to oversee review and monitoring
of Asda’s systems of internal controls and risk management, the internal audit process, and compliance with laws,
regulations and ethical codes of practice.

**Asda Real Estate and Investment Committee (“AREIC”)**

AREIC sits at the level of Asda Group Limited and has authority delegated from Bellis TopCo 2 and its
subsidiaries. AREIC meets monthly and is chaired by the chief financial officer, Mr. Gleeson. It is responsible for
reviewing and providing recommendation to the Board on capital investment and real estate matters, including
overseeing the annual capital planning process, reviewing and providing recommendation of approval on material
projects, and identifying risks and opportunities within the plan.

**Bellis TopCo Limited Shareholders’ Agreement**

On February 12, 2021, Able Holdings Limited (a company owned by Zuber Vali Issa CBE and Mohsin Issa
CBE), Optima Group S.à r.l., Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco entered into a shareholders’ agreement (the
“Shareholders’ Agreement”), which governed various rights of the shareholders of Bellis TopCo Limited and
Property Newco in relation to their direct shareholding in Bellis TopCo Limited and Property Newco and indirect
shareholding in the Group.

On December 31, 2021, Able Holdings Limited, Optima Group S.à r.l., Bellis TopCo Limited and Property
Newco entered into a Deed of Amendment relating to the Shareholders’ Agreement (as amended, the “Amended and
**Restated Shareholders’ Agreement”), to reflect the fact that Property Newco had become a wholly-owned**
subsidiary of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited. The Amended and Restated Shareholders’ Agreement, to which Property
Newco is not a party, governs the various rights of the shareholders of Bellis TopCo Limited in relation to their direct
shareholding in Bellis TopCo Limited and indirect shareholding in the Group.

Pursuant to the Amended and Restated Shareholders’ Agreement, Able Holdings Limited (the “Individual
**Investors Shareholder”), on the one hand, and Optima Group S.à r.l. (the “TDR Shareholder”), on the other hand,**
is entitled to appoint or remove directors in certain circumstances. The Individual Investors Shareholder and the TDR
Shareholder is each entitled to appoint and remove (i) two members of the board of directors of Bellis TopCo Limited
so long as such shareholder, together with its affiliates, hold 35% or more of the share capital of Bellis TopCo Limited,
or (ii) one member of the board of directors of Bellis TopCo Limited so long as such shareholders, together with its
affiliates, hold between 15% and 35% of the share capital of Bellis TopCo Limited. The maximum number of directors
for the board of Bellis TopCo Limited will be five and, subject to certain actions which required the consent of the
Individual Investors Shareholder and the TDR Shareholder, as summarised below, all decisions of the board of
directors may be made by a majority of the votes cast.

The Amended and Restated Shareholders’ Agreement provides that certain actions in relation to the Group
may not be taken without the consent of both the Individual Investors Shareholder (or any of the directors appointed
by it) and the TDR Shareholder (or any of the directors appointed by it). These include amendments to the
organisational documents of any member of the Group, variations to the rights attaching to the shares in any member
of the Group, the declaration or payment of any dividend or distribution by any Group company (other than to Bellis
TopCo Limited or another Group company which is wholly-owned by Bellis TopCo Limited), a material change in
the nature or scope of the Group’s business and the winding-up or dissolution of Bellis TopCo Limited, any of its
subsidiaries or any other Group company.

The Shareholders’ Agreement contains certain restrictions on the transfer by the Individual Investors
Shareholder or the TDR Shareholder of its shares in Bellis TopCo Limited or any other member of the Group,
including (other than transfers to certain permitted transferees, including affiliates) an obligation to first offer any
shares to the other shareholder before offering them for sale to a third party.

At any time on or after the third anniversary of the LBO Acquisition Completion Date and prior to the fifth
anniversary of LBO Acquisition Completion Date, either the Individual Investors Shareholder or the TDR Shareholder
may propose an exit event involving the Bellis Group and the Group, including the sale of shares in Bellis TopCo
Limited; the sale by Bellis TopCo Limited or any other member of the Group of all or substantially all of the Group’s
business, assets and undertaking; any public offering in respect of any shares in Bellis TopCo Limited or any other

**Walmart Senior Shares and Special Participation Share**

On the LBO Acquisition Completion Date, Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, Bellis TopCo Limited and Global
Pinnacle Corporation (among others) entered into a shareholders’ agreement (the “Topco 2 Shareholders’
**Agreement”), which governs various rights of the shareholders of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited in relation to their direct**
shareholding in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited and indirect shareholding in the Group. On June 16, 2021, Global Pinnacle
Corporation transferred its shares in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited to Bellis Holding LLC (“BHL”) and BHL adhered to the
TopCo 2 Shareholders’ Agreement. The terms of the Topco 2 Shareholders’ Agreement provide for BHL to hold two
classes of shares: (i) the Senior Shares; and (ii) the Special Participation Share. Unless otherwise agreed between the
shareholders of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited (or where such transfer is made to a permitted transferee in accordance with
the terms of the TopCo 2 Shareholders’ Agreement or with the consent of the shareholders), neither the Special
Participation Share nor any of the Senior Shares may be transferred to any person unless there is a simultaneous
transfer of all of the Senior Shares and the Special Participation Share to the same transferee.

Pursuant to the TopCo 2 Shareholders’ Agreement, BHL, as holder of the Senior Shares, is entitled to appoint
or remove one director to or from the board of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited (the “Senior Shareholder Director”). The holder
of the Senior Shares will have no voting rights as shareholders of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, other than in relation to certain
matters that would materially adversely affect the rights of the holder of the Senior Shares.

The holders of the Senior Shares have the right to receive an annual fixed cumulative senior dividend. Such
dividend is payable on the principal amount of the Senior Shares plus accrued but unpaid dividends. Bellis TopCo 2
Limited may elect to pay such dividend in cash or for such dividend to accrue unpaid.

The Senior Shares will be mandatorily redeemed by Bellis TopCo 2 Limited upon the occurrence of certain
events, including upon an exit event involving Bellis TopCo 2 Limited. Such exit events include: the sale of the
ordinary shares in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited; the sale by Bellis TopCo 2 Limited or any other member of the Group of
all or substantially all of the Group’s business, assets and undertaking; any public offering in respect of all or
substantially all of the ordinary shares in Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, of all or substantially all shares in any other Group
company representing all or substantially all of the Group’s business, assets and undertaking or of all or substantially
all of the shares of any company which is a direct or indirect holder of all or substantially all ordinary shares in Bellis
TopCo 2 Limited; or a change of control of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited. The Senior Shares will further be mandatorily
redeemed by Bellis TopCo 2 Limited on the seventh anniversary of the issuance of the Senior Shares, being February
16, 2028. The expected repayment amount that would be required to be made in cash to Walmart by Bellis TopCo 2
on February 16, 2028, including any accrued and unpaid interest, is approximately £900 million. Bellis TopCo 2
Limited may voluntarily redeem the Senior Shares at any time subject to paying a make-whole amount.

Pursuant to the Topco 2 Shareholders’ Agreement, BHL, in its capacity as holder of the Special Participation
Share, has no right to appoint or remove directors to the board of Bellis TopCo 2 Limited, but will have the right to
appoint a board observer if no Senior Shareholder Director has been appointed. The holder of the Special Participation
Share, in its capacity as holder of the Special Participation Share, has no voting rights as a shareholder of Bellis TopCo
2 Limited, other than in relation to matters that would materially adversely affect the rights of the holder of the Special
Participation Share.
