**CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS**

The Group enters into transactions with certain related parties or the Group’s affiliates from time to time and
in the ordinary course of the Group’s business.

**Transactions** **Related to the EG UK Acquisition**

On May 30, 2023, EG Group (contracting by EG Finco Limited) (“EG”) announced its binding agreement
to sell a substantial majority of its fuel, foodservice and grocery and merchandise business in the United Kingdom to
Asda, by way of a corporate sale and subject to various adjustments and agreement upon a precise transaction
perimeter. Following discussions between Asda and EG on the perimeter of the EG UK Acquisition and discussions
with relevant brand partners, EG and Asda agreed that EG’s franchise businesses carried on under the Starbucks brand
and the KFC brand in the United Kingdom and Ireland (the “Starbucks Business” and the “KFC Business,”
respectively), together with their employees, would not transfer to Asda as part of the EG UK Acquisition. As a result
of these discussions, the EG UK Acquisition was completed on October 31, 2023 for total cash consideration of £2.1
billion.

On the EG UK Completion Date, EG Group (using EG Corporate Services Limited) entered into a transitional
services agreement with Euro Garages (Jersey) Limited (together with its subsidiaries, the “Acquired EG UK Target
**Group”), pursuant to which EG agreed to continue to provide access to or cover the costs of all centralised shared**
services (such as IT, HR, accounting, payroll, compliance and tax functions), that were, in the 12 months prior to
completion of the EG UK Acquisition, provided to the Acquired EG UK Target Group by EG, for a transitional period
(the “EG TSA”). The initial term of the EG TSA is for a period of up to two years from the EG UK Completion Date,
subject to certain rights for the Acquired EG UK Target Group to terminate, or transition away from, services early
or to extend the initial term for an aggregate period of up to a further 12 months (in 3 months increments). During the
term of the EG TSA, EG will also provide certain of the IT services that will continue to be provided to the Acquired
EG UK Target Group to Asda, for the benefit of certain other convenience retail sites that Asda and its affiliates own
from time to time, including those branded as “Asda Express.” The services provided by EG to the Acquired EG UK
Target Group will be deemed to be subject to a service credit for the first two years of the EG TSA, as a result of
which the Acquired EG UK Target Group will not be required to make any payment to EG for the services (subject
to certain limited exceptions) and thereafter will be provided for a fee based on the actual cost to EG of providing the
services, plus an agreed margin that will be applied to any non-third party costs. The services provided to Asda in
respect of convenience retail sites that are not part of the Acquired EG UK Target Group will be provided for a fee
payable to EG based on the actual cost to EG of providing the services, plus an agreed margin that will be applied to
non-third party costs. EG’s liability for provision of the services will be subject to limitations customary for an
agreement of this nature, including an annual financial cap on EG’s liability of £12.2 million for most liabilities. In
connection with such transitional arrangements, and as further consideration for the EG UK Acquisition, EG also
agreed to cover certain other centralised costs, including redundancy costs, and integration costs during the transitional
period. The EG Seller has provided certain guarantees in favour of entities transferred to Asda as part of the EG UK
Acquisition, or to the Purchaser, in respect of the obligations of EG under: (i) the EG TSA; and (ii) certain business
sale agreements entered into by certain transferred entities and members of EG in connection with reorganisations
effected prior to completion of the EG UK Acquisition.

On the EG UK Completion Date, the EG Seller and Euro Garages (Jersey) Limited also entered into a
transitional brand licence agreement which took effect immediately following the EG UK Completion Date (the “EG
Brand Licence Agreement”). Pursuant to the EG Brand Licence Agreement, EG granted the Acquired EG UK Target
Group a non-exclusive right to use certain of EG’s brands, including the ‘EG’ and ‘Euro Garages’ brands, for a period
of three years, royalty free, to allow the Acquired EG UK Target Group to rebrand its sites and businesses (subject to
earlier termination rights). Euro Garages (Jersey) Limited will have a right to extend the term of the brand licence for
a further two years, in increments of 12 months at a time, if it has not completed this debranding process by the end
of the expiry of the initial three-year term, subject to the parties agreeing a royalty fee for the use of such brands during
such extension.

On May 30, 2023, the EG Seller, the America Purchaser and Asda Stores Limited entered into a side letter
in connection with the electric vehicle charger business, which is part of EG’s retained UK&I business (the “EVPoint
**Side Letter”). Under the EVPoint Side Letter, the EG Seller, the America Purchaser and Asda have documented their**
intention that EV Point Services Limited (a subsidiary of EG) or an affiliate will be appointed as sole provider, operator

205


-----

and installer of electric vehicle charging points at Asda sites (including the sites held by the Acquired EG UK Target
Group) and have agreed to use reasonable endeavours to agree the terms and conditions of such appointment including
the terms of a framework agreement under which that appointment will be documented following completion of the
EG UK Acquisition. The EVPoint Side Letter will (in addition to certain earlier termination rights and events)
terminate if the framework agreement has not been entered into by the date falling 24 months from completion of the
EG UK Acquisition. Commercial discussions remain ongoing.

The EG Seller and the America Purchaser are in discussions regarding the terms on which EG will, in respect
of its retained UK&I business, occupy sites that are owned by the Group, or the Group will occupy sites that are owned
by EG, including sites where the operations of EG’s retained UK&I business and the Acquired EG UK Target Group
are co-located. This will include rights of occupation in respect of sites on which electric vehicle charging points,
including ‘evpoint’-branded chargers, have, prior to completion of the EG UK Acquisition, been installed by EG and
certain lease arrangements relating to the Starbucks Business and the KFC Business.

**Transitional Agreements with Walmart**

On February 16, 2021, in connection with the LBO Acquisition, Walmart (and its affiliates) and the LBO
Seller entered into several transitional agreements with Asda Group, Asda Stores Limited and the LBO Purchaser.
Those agreements included, amongst others, a trade mark agreement (the “TMA”) and a transitional services
agreement (the “TSA”) entered into between Asda Stores Limited and Walmart. The LBO Seller, the LBO Purchaser
and Walmart (among others) further entered into a transitional pensions deed (the “TPD”). The TMA, the TSA and
the TPD are referred to collectively in this Offering Memorandum as the “Transitional Agreements.”

**_Trade Mark Agreement_**

Under the terms of the TMA, Walmart, as licensor, granted Asda Stores Limited a licence to continue to use
certain of Walmart’s trade marks, domain names and brand-related intellectual property. The scope of the TMA
includes licences of the George, Scan & Go, Smart Price and Rollback trade marks, certain domain names, including
George.com, as well as certain other Walmart-owned trade mark rights used by a member of the Asda Group between
October 2019 and the LBO Acquisition Completion Date (the “Licensed IP”). The TMA permits Asda Stores Limited
to sub-license the use of the Licensed IP to specified permitted sub-licensees, including members of the Asda Group,
existing franchisees to which Asda Stores Limited has granted a licence of the Licensed IP under franchise agreements
in place as at the date of the LBO Acquisition Agreement and certain specified companies that are also owned by the
shareholders or funds managed by TDR Capital LLP, provided Walmart is given written notice and the sub-licence
fulfils certain conditions, including that it is on terms that are no less onerous than the TMA. Additionally, Walmart
cannot unreasonably withhold, delay or condition consent for Asda Stores Limited to sub-license the Licensed IP to
certain other entities including those that are controlled by the shareholders of Asda Stores Limited’s ultimate holding
company, provided that the sub-licence fulfils certain conditions, including that it is on terms no less onerous that the
TMA.

Manufacturing or packaging of goods bearing the Licensed IP may take place worldwide. The scope of the
licence for sale, marketing and distribution purposes is the United Kingdom only (on an exclusive basis) and, for the
George brand only, also specified countries in Europe as set out in the TMA (on a non-exclusive basis). These licences
are perpetual and irrevocable, subject to the termination rights summarised below. The TMA includes a non-exclusive
licence to use the George brand in substantially the same way as the brand was used immediately prior to the date of
the LBO Acquisition Agreement in certain territories outside the United Kingdom and the specified European
countries in which Asda Stores Limited has been selling George-branded goods under a specified third-party
e-commerce fulfilment contract immediately prior to the date of the LBO Acquisition Agreement (the “George RoW
**Licence”). All use of the Licensed IP (other than use of the George mark in the United Kingdom) is to be in the same**
manner and style of usage as used between October 2019 and the LBO Acquisition Completion Date, except in respect
of the George RoW Licence and licence of the Walmart spark logo, which must be used in the same way as such
branding was used immediately prior to the date of the LBO Acquisition Agreement and the LBO Acquisition
Completion Date respectively.

In addition, the TMA includes an exclusive, royalty-free licence from Asda Stores Limited to Walmart of the
Extra Special brand (that is owned by Asda) to enable Walmart to continue selling, marketing and distributing products
sold by Walmart under such brand on a perpetual and irrevocable basis in specified countries in Central America and

206


-----

in Mexico. The licence to Walmart of the Asda Stores Limited brand referred to above is subject to similar
sub-licensing and termination provisions as the licence to Asda Stores Limited of Licensed IP.

Asda Stores Limited is not required to pay any royalties in respect of the above licence of the George brand
(other than George RoW Licence), the licences of the Scan & Go, Rollback and Smart Price brands or the transitional
licence of the Walmart spark logo and “Save Money Live Better” (other than a nominal £1 royalty fee). The George
RoW Licence is royalty-free for up to 12 months and thereafter subject to an annual royalty of 2% of the Net Sales
Revenue in the relevant territory. In respect of all other Licensed IP, Asda Stores Limited is required to pay an annual
royalty equal to 3.5% of the net sales revenue received by Asda Stores Limited and any sub-licensees in connection
with the use of such Licensed IP.

The TMA includes restrictions and quality control covenants from Asda Stores Limited including ensuring
that the products sold by Asda Stores Limited under the Licensed IP maintain certain standards, complying with brand
guidelines in relation to visual style and formatting and limiting Asda Stores Limited’s use of the Licensed IP and its
ability to register the Licensed IP. These covenants include not committing or knowingly omitting acts which would
bring the Licensed IP into disrepute or damage, or weaken or be detrimental to the Licensed IP in any material respect.
Asda Stores Limited is also prevented from maintaining an online or e-commerce presence of any of the businesses
(excluding the George business in the United Kingdom) in respect of which the Licensed IP is permitted to be used
except in substantially the same manner and to substantially the same extent as the presence those businesses had in
the period between October 2019 and the LBO Acquisition Completion Date (or in respect of the George RoW
Licence, immediately prior to the date of the LBO Acquisition Agreement). Asda Stores Limited is also expected to
indemnify the Walmart Group against any losses resulting from use of the Licensed IP in material breach of the TMA
and losses related to actual or alleged defect in products or services using the Licensed IP (other than the Scan & Go
or Rollback branding), recalls of defective products and actual or alleged mislabelling or food safety issues related to
the Licensed IP (other than the Scan & Go or Rollback brands). There is no cap on Asda Stores Limited’s liability
under these indemnities or limit on the heads of loss recoverable. The TMA includes warranties on the corporate
existence and capacity of the parties to enter into the TMA but no other warranties or representations (and any implied
warranties, terms or conditions implied by statute or common law are excluded to the fullest extent permitted by law).

The term of the TMA is perpetual (other than: (i) the George RoW Licence, which Walmart may terminate
on a per country or per goods/services basis where Walmart itself intends to use or authorise the use of the relevant
Licensed IP in that country (or if required by law), and (ii) in respect of the transitional licences described above).
Either party is able to terminate the licences granted to Asda Stores Limited under the TMA on a per-licence basis
following the insolvency of its counterparty or a material breach or repeated non-material breaches of the terms of the
TMA (in respect of the relevant licence and/or the relevant Licensed IP) (subject to a notice requirement and a 30-day
cure period, to the extent applicable). Walmart also has the right to terminate the licences granted to Asda Stores
Limited under the TMA on a per-licence basis if Asda Stores Limited challenges the validity of the relevant Licensed
IP or following certain change of control events, or with respect to specific trade marks or specific categories or
sub-categories of goods or services on 30 days’ notice if the relevant Licensed IP is not put to material use for a period
of two years. Asda Stores Limited, but not Walmart, is permitted to terminate the licences granted to Asda Stores
Limited under the TMA at any time without cause subject to a three-month notice period. The licence to Walmart of
Asda-owned brands is separately terminable, under similar terms.

**_Transitional Services Agreement_**

Under the TSA, Walmart provides certain information technology services to Asda Stores Limited on a
transitional basis with effect from the LBO Acquisition Completion Date. The services comprise all information
technology and telecommunications services (and related operational system processes) that Walmart Group
Companies provided to the Asda Group in the 12 months prior to the LBO Acquisition Completion Date, and each
such service is to be supplied by Walmart until the earlier of (i) migration of the relevant service as part of the
separation of Asda Stores Limited from Walmart; and (ii) termination of the TSA in accordance with its terms by one
of the parties (as summarised below). The services are arranged into six categories (referred to as “service towers,”
which relate to stores, supply chain, merchandising, back office, e-commerce and infrastructure/security) for charging
and migration purposes.

Asda Stores Limited has the right to terminate any service tower, or the TSA in its entirety, on three months’
notice. In addition, either party has the right to terminate the TSA following the insolvency of its counterparty or a

207


-----

material breach of the terms of the TSA (subject to a notice requirement and a 30-day cure period, to the extent
applicable).

In addition, Asda Stores Limited has the right to request a “Change Freeze” which it did in respect of five of
the six service towers from May 1, 2021, and in respect of the sixth tower (e-commerce) from 2023. This means that
Asda ceases to benefit from changes and a change request service that it would otherwise receive on Walmart’s group
operating model (this is not defined but really is benchmarked by the service Asda has received to date). From the
freeze, Walmart has absolute discretion to reject any “Change Requests” made by Asda in relation to a “frozen” service
tower unless that change relates to a “Mandatory Change” (i.e., a change in relevant Regulations or a change required
for compliance or security reasons) or a usage change.

The TSA includes customary warranties concerning the corporate existence and capacity of the parties and
an undertaking to provide information and participate in discussions in connection with the delivery of the services.
Walmart agrees to provide each service to a standard and in a manner that is consistent with Walmart’s provision of
the equivalent service in the 12 months prior to the LBO Acquisition Completion Date. Walmart is not required to
provide the services to, or to meet, any more onerous standard or service level.

Walmart is required to use reasonable endeavours to obtain and maintain third-party consents that are
required for the provision of the services. Where a third-party consent is not obtained or maintained, Walmart is not
required to provide the relevant service (and the TSA will terminate in respect of the relevant service without liability
on the part of Walmart) and the parties will work together to agree a workaround (including replacement, in-sourcing
or early migration) in order to enable Asda Stores Limited to continue to receive the benefit of the affected service.
All reasonable one-off or ongoing costs of obtaining and maintaining third-party consents or implementing
workarounds are to be borne by Asda Stores Limited, subject to Walmart consulting with Asda Stores Limited before
incurring these costs.

Asda Stores Limited and Walmart have a separation plan in place and the separation costs (excluding internal
costs of the Walmart Group) are borne by Asda Stores Limited.

The charges for the TSA services for the first year following the LBO Acquisition Completion Date were
initially capped at £142 million (excluding any VAT), and the cap on service charges subsequently rises by 1% per
year thereafter. The charges payable for services in subsequent years are equal to the charges for such services for the
previous contract year (subject to any reduction as summarised below) subject to an inflationary increase of 2% per
year. The charges per service tower are split on a fixed cost and variable cost basis. The variable proportion of the
charges reduce to the extent that Asda Stores Limited is able to achieve certain agreed milestones in its separation
plan and ramp down usage of the relevant service tower. The initial terms of the TSA stated that for any service to be
provided beyond a long stop date of three years from the LBO Acquisition Completion Date, being February 2024,
the charges for any remaining services will ratchet up by 10% every six months (the “TSA Ratchet”). However, we
have received a deferral of the TSA Ratchet until February 16, 2025. If we have not substantially completed Project
Future by February 16, 2025, Walmart may be entitled to back-charge us any TSA Ratchet payments that would have
been due under the original terms of the TSA after February 2024. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our
_Acquisitions—Delays in our ability to separate from Walmart could result in significant cost and any issues with the_
_separation process, particularly system cutovers, could significantly disrupt business operations and impact our_
_ability to meet our strategic objectives.”_

The liability of the parties under the TSA is limited, where service-specific, to the amount of fees paid or
payable in respect of the relevant service tower during the relevant contract year. In the case of liabilities that are not
related to a specific service tower, the liability of the parties under the TSA is limited to the total amount of fees paid
or payable during the relevant contract year. Each party’s aggregate liability for each contract year is limited to the
amount of fees paid or payable during the relevant contract year. These limitations are subject to limited exceptions,
including in the case of fraud. Neither party is liable for any indirect or consequential losses or loss of profit or loss
of revenue and, to the extent Walmart’s breach is caused by a third-party default, Walmart’s maximum liability to
Asda Stores Limited is limited to the amount that Walmart can recover from the third party (or an equitable proportion
thereof to reflect the loss suffered by the Asda Group as compared to the Walmart Group). Walmart is not liable to
Asda Stores Limited to the extent the relevant liability is caused by a failure on the part of the Asda Group to perform
its obligations under the TSA.

**_Transitional Pensions Deed_**

Under the TPD, the LBO Seller indemnifies the LBO Purchaser in respect of any losses incurred by Asda in
respect of the Asda Group Pension Scheme, subject to certain exclusions including that the indemnity will not apply
if the losses arise from a voluntary act by Bellis TopCo Limited (or any other affiliate of Bellis TopCo Limited),
including failure by Asda to comply with its obligations under the documentation governing the Asda Group Pension
Scheme Buy-In. Walmart is party to the TPD and guarantees the obligations of the LBO Seller in respect of this
indemnity. The LBO Purchaser and Bellis TopCo Limited indemnify Asda and Walmart in respect of any losses
incurred by either of them in respect of the Asda Group Pension Scheme if the losses arise from, broadly, a voluntary
act by Bellis TopCo Limited (or any other affiliate of Bellis TopCo Limited), including failure by Asda to comply
with its obligations under the documentation governing the Asda Group Pension Scheme Buy-In. Liability under both
indemnity arrangements terminates on the later of: (i) three years after completion of the buyout of the Asda Group
Pension Scheme; (ii) the date of completion of the winding-up of the Asda Group Pension Scheme; or (iii) (in respect
of losses relate to tax only) five years after the LBO Acquisition Completion Date. As part of the arrangements in
respect of the buy-in of the Asda Group Pension Scheme Asda Stores Limited agreed to make a loan facility available
to the trustees of the Asda Group Pension Scheme. Under the TPD, in the event that a funding obligation arises under
the loan facility which Asda is unable to satisfy, Walmart Inc agrees to use reasonable endeavours to provide
short-term funding to Asda to allow Asda to meet the funding obligation. A buy-out of the Asda Group Pension
Scheme was executed on July 9, 2021 which extinguished the Group’s responsibility to fund the Asda Group Pension
Scheme as sponsoring employer. See “Management’s Discussion & Analysis—Asda Group Pension Scheme Buy-In.”

of 3.25% Senior Secured Notes due 2026 (the “Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes”). The Existing Senior Secured
Notes are governed by the indenture dated as of February 24, 2021, governing the Existing 3.25% Senior Secured
Notes, as amended from time to time (the “Existing 3.25% Senior Secured Notes Indenture”). The Existing 3.25%
Senior Secured Notes mature on February 16, 2026.

of 4.500% Senior Secured Notes due 2026 (the “Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes,” and together with the
Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes, the “Existing Senior Secured Notes”). The Existing Senior Secured Notes are

3.25% Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the “Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures”). The Existing 4.50%

interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but not including, the applicable redemption date; provided that, inter alia,
at least 50% of the principal amount of the original principal amount of the Existing 4.50% Senior Secured Notes

**Senior Facilities Agreement**

Capitalised terms used in this section “—Senior Facilities Agreement” but not defined herein have the
meanings given to them in the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Additional Term Facility Notice and/or the Additional
Revolving Facilities Notice (each as defined below).

**_Overview and Structure_**

In connection with the financing of the LBO Acquisition, on February 5, 2021 the Senior Secured Notes
Issuer entered into a senior facilities agreement with, among others, Barclays Bank PLC, Bank of America Europe
Designated Activity Company, Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch, HSBC Bank plc, Lloyds Bank plc, Morgan
Stanley Bank International Limited, Coöperatieve Rabobank U.A. trading as Rabobank London, Bank of China
Limited, London Branch, Commerzbank Aktiengesellschaft, London Branch, Intesa Sanpaolo S.p.A., London Branch,
National Westminster Bank Plc and SMBC Bank International PLC as mandated lead arrangers, the Agent and the
Security Agent (and as amended and restated on February 12, 2021 and December 22, 2021) (the “Senior Facilities
**Agreement”).**

The Senior Facilities Agreement originally provided for (i) a senior term loan facility in a principal amount
of up to £195,000,000 (“Original Facility A”), (ii) a euro denominated senior term loan facility in a principal amount
of €845,000,000 (“Original Facility B”), (iii) a revolving credit facility in an original principal amount of
£500,000,000 (the “Original Revolving Facility”) and (iv) a revolving credit facility in a principal amount of
£190,000,000 (the “Original Revolving Facility 2”) which was voluntarily cancelled by the Senior Secured Notes
Issuer in full on September 16, 2021.

In connection with the EG UK Acquisition, the Senior Secured Notes Issuer entered into (i) an additional
term facility notice under the Senior Facilities Agreement with, among others, Apollo Management International LLP
as Arranger, the Original Additional Facility Lenders named therein, the Agent and the Security Agent on October 20,
2023 (the “Additional Term Facility Notice”); and (ii) an additional revolving facility notice under the Senior
Facilities Agreement with, among others, the Original Additional Revolving Facility Lenders named therein, the
Agent and the Security Agent on October 29, 2023 (the “Additional Revolving Facilities Notice”).

The Additional Term Facility Notice provided for a senior term loan in a principal amount of £683,903,176
(the “Private Placement Facility”). The Additional Revolving Facilities Notice provided for (i) an additional
revolving facility 1 in principal amount of £117,272,727 (the “Additional Revolving Facility 1”); and (ii) an
additional revolving facility 2 in principal amount of £50,000,000 (the “Additional Revolving Facility 2”, and
together with Additional Revolving Facility 1, the “Additional Revolving Facilities”), which form part of the
Original Revolving Facility.

On or around the Issue Date, the Senior Facilities Agreement is expected to be further amended and restated
via an amendment and restatement agreement, to amend certain terms thereof to reflect certain terms of the Senior
Secured Notes and to establish the Senior Facilities as at the Issue Date.

Facility B (EUR) will be utilised on or around the Issue Date and the proceeds of such utilisation will be
applied (directly or indirectly) in or towards financing outstanding amounts under the Original Facility B and any
other senior secured indebtedness of the Group. New Facility A will also be established on or around the Issue Date
by way of redesignating part of the commitments and outstanding amounts under the Original Facility A as
commitments and loans thereunder, thereby effecting a maturity extension of the commitments of consenting lenders.
New Revolving Facility will also be established on or around the Issue Date and to the extent that any amounts are
drawn under the Original Revolving Facility as at the Issue Date will be utilised (directly or indirectly) in or towards
refinancing the outstanding amounts under the Original Revolving Facility; the commitments under the Original
Revolving Facility will be cancelled and replaced with the commitments under the New Revolving Facility thereby
effecting a maturity extension of the commitments of consenting lenders.

In addition to the Senior Facilities, the Senior Facilities Agreement includes (subject to the limitation on
indebtedness covenant and permissions thereunder) the ability to establish an additional facility (“Additional
**Facility”) at any time provided certain conditions under the Senior Facilities Agreement are met, including, without**
limitation: (i) Indebtedness incurred thereunder constitute Permitted Indebtedness on the Applicable Test Date; (ii) no
Material Event of Default (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) is continuing as at the Additional Facility
Commencement Date or Applicable Test Date (as applicable) for such Additional Facility; (iii) the Additional Facility
complies with any applicable margin, maturity and amortisation restrictions set out in the Senior Facilities Agreement
and (iv) the Additional Facility shall rank pari passu with or junior to the Senior Facilities.

**_Borrowers, Currencies and Utilisations_**

Original Facility A and Original Facility B were utilised by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer on the LBO
Acquisition Completion Date.

The Private Placement Facility was utilised by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer on the EG UK Acquisition
Completion Date.

The New Facility A and Facility B (EUR) will be utilised by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer on or around
the Issue Date, to (among other things) repay in part Original Facility A and in full Original Facility B.

The New Revolving Facility may be utilised by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, Asda Stores Limited (as an
Additional Borrower (under and as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement)) and each other of the Senior Secured
Notes Issuer’s restricted subsidiaries which accede to the Senior Facilities Agreement as additional borrowers of such
facilities, in sterling, euro or U.S. dollars and certain other currencies readily available in the amount required and
freely convertible into sterling in the Relevant Interbank Market (subject to obtaining consent of the relevant lenders
under the relevant Revolving Credit Facility), by the drawing of cash advances, the issue of Letters of Credit and by
way of Ancillary Facilities or Fronted Ancillary Facilities (each as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement).

**_Purpose_**

All amounts borrowed under Original Facility A and Original Facility B were applied (directly or indirectly)
in or towards: (i) satisfaction of the consideration payable for the LBO Acquisition (including any interest payments,
completion account-related adjustments and purchase price adjustments (however structured)) and any other amounts
payable under the Acquisition Documents (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) in connection with the LBO
Acquisition; (ii) refinancing or otherwise discharging any existing indebtedness of the Asda Group (including
backstopping or providing cash-cover in respect of any letters of credit, guarantees, performance bonds or ancillary,
revolving, working capital or local facilities or other arrangements) and paying any related breakage costs, redemption
premium, make-whole costs and other fees, costs and expenses payable in connection with such refinancing, discharge
and/or the LBO Acquisition; (iii) financing or refinancing the payment of any transaction costs or paying any other
related fees, costs and expenses; and/or (iv) making any payments contemplated by the Tax Structure Memorandum,
the Funds Flow Statement (each as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) or any other documents relating to the
Transactions (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement).

All amounts borrowed under the Additional Term Facility were applied (directly or indirectly) in or towards:
(i) satisfaction of the consideration payable for the EG UK Acquisition (including any interest payments, completion
account related adjustments and purchase price adjustments (however structured)) and any other amounts payable
under the America acquisition agreement for the EG UK Acquisition; (ii) financing or refinancing the payment of any
acquisition costs as well as any other related fees, costs and expenses in connection with the EG UK Acquisition;
and/or (iii) making any payments contemplated by the tax structure memorandum or the funds flow statement, in each
case in connection with the EG UK Acquisition. All amounts borrowed under the New Facility A are expected to be
applied (directly or indirectly) in or towards (i) financing or otherwise discharging part of the outstanding amounts
under the Original Facility A and (ii) financing or refinancing the payment of any transaction costs or paying any other
related fees, costs and expenses.

All amounts established under the Facility B (EUR) will be applied (directly or indirectly) in or towards (i)
financing or otherwise discharging part or all of the outstanding amounts under the Original Facility B, (ii) financing
or otherwise discharging certain other Senior Secured Indebtedness of the Group, and (iii) financing or refinancing
the payment of any transaction costs or paying any other related fees, costs and expenses.

The New Revolving Facility may be used for financing or refinancing: (A) the prepayment of all or any part
of any amounts then outstanding under the applicable existing senior facilities (including the payment of any accrued
interest and/or the payment of any fees, costs and expenses incurred in connection therewith and in connection with
the new Senior Facilities) in order to effect an extension to the maturity date of such facilities, together with the
refinancing of any other senior secured indebtedness of the Group (including the payment of any accrued interest
and/or the payment of any fees, costs and expenses incurred in connection therewith); (B) the general corporate
purposes and/or working capital requirements of the Group (including, without limitation, the financing or refinancing

214

of capital expenditure, any permitted acquisitions, investments, joint-ventures, restructuring costs, operational
restructurings and reorganisation requirements of the Group); (C) the financial indebtedness of the Group or any
acquired target group; and (D) certain fees, costs and expenses.

**_Availability_**

Original Facility A and Original Facility B were available to be (and have been) utilised from (and including)
the original date of the Senior Facilities Agreement (being February 5, 2021) to and including the last day of the
Certain Funds Period (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement, being February 16, 2021).

The Additional Term Facility was available to be (and has been) utilised from (and including) the Additional
Facility Commencement Date (as defined in the Additional Term Facility Notice, being October 20, 2021) to and
including the last day of the Agreed Certain Funds Period (as defined in the Additional Term Facility Notice, being
October 31, 2021).

New Facility A and Facility B (EUR) shall be available to be utilised on or about the Issue Date.

The Original Revolving Facility (as increased by the Additional Revolving Facilities) was and remains
available to be utilised from (and including) the Closing Date (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement, also
referred herein as the “Alaska Closing Date”) to and including the date falling one month prior to the Termination
Date applicable to the Original Revolving Facility (being the date falling 54 months after the Alaska Closing Date),
but is expected to be replaced on or about the Issue Date with the New Revolving Facility.

The New Revolving Facility is expected to be available to be utilised from (and including) the Issue Date to
and including the date falling one month prior to the Termination Date applicable to the New Revolving Facility.

**_Conditions Precedent_**

Utilisations of the Senior Facilities were (and in the case of the New Revolving Facility will be) subject to
customary conditions precedent.

**_Interest and Fees_**

Loans under the Senior Facilities initially bear interest at rates per annum equal to (i) EURIBOR in respect
of loans denominated in euro, (ii) LIBOR in respect of Term Rate Loans denominated in other currencies and
(iii) Compounded Reference Rate for Compounded Rate Loans, in each case plus an applicable margin, which in each
case will be subject to a decreasing margin ratchet based on the ratio of Consolidated Senior Secured Net Debt to
Consolidated EBITDA (each as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) (the “Senior Secured Net Leverage
**Ratio”). Furthermore, the applicable margin shall be subject to further adjustment upwards or downwards depending**
on whether the Group’s ESG Agency Rating (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) (the “ESG Agency
**Rating”) is more or less favourable, respectively, than the initial ESG Agency Rating obtained by the Group following**
the Alaska Closing Date.

If EURIBOR is less than zero, EURIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under the
relevant Senior Facility. If LIBOR is less than zero, LIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of loans made under
the relevant Senior Facility. Floor for Compounded Reference Rates shall be determined pursuant to the Compounded
Rate Terms of the Senior Facilities Agreement.

A commitment fee is payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of each revolving credit
facility from, (i) in respect of the Original Revolving Facility, the Alaska Closing Date, (ii) in respect of the Additional
Revolving Facility 1, the Additional Revolving Facility 1 Commencement Date (as defined in the Additional
Revolving Facilities Notice), (iii) in respect of the Additional Revolving Facility 2, the Additional Revolving
Facility 2 Commencement Date (as defined in the Additional Revolving Facilities Notice), and (iv) in respect of the
New Revolving Facility, the Issue Date, in each case to the end of the availability period applicable to the relevant
Revolving Credit Facility, at a rate of 30% of the applicable margin for the relevant Revolving Credit Facility.
Commitment fees will be payable quarterly in arrears, on the last day of the availability period applicable to the

215

relevant Revolving Credit Facility and if the relevant Revolving Credit Facility is cancelled in full, on the date on
which the relevant commitments under that Revolving Credit Facility are cancelled.

Default interest will be calculated as an additional 1% on the defaulted amount.

The New Revolving Facility shall include a springing maturity feature such that its maturity will be adjusted
to:

(a) 91 days inside the maturity of the Existing Senior Notes, if, as at the date that is 4 months prior to the
current maturity date of the Existing Senior Notes, such Existing Senior Notes have not been repaid or refinanced or
extended, in each case, to a date which is no earlier than the date which is 91 days from the initial maturity date for
the New Revolving Facility but excluding for these purposes Existing Senior Notes up to an aggregate principal
amount equal to £350,000,000 (or its equivalent in other currencies); and/or

(b) 91 days inside the maturity of the Existing Senior Secured Notes and the Original Facility B, if, as at the
date that is 4 months prior to the current maturity date of such earlier maturing Indebtedness, such Indebtedness has
not been repaid or refinanced or extended, in each case, to a date which is no earlier than the date which is 91 days
from the initial maturity date for the New Revolving Facility but excluding for these purposes any such Indebtedness
up to an aggregate principal amount equal to £500,000,000 (or its equivalent in other currencies) and in addition, an
amount of such Existing Senior Secured Notes equal to the amount of cash proceeds from the incurrence of new
Indebtedness on or about the Issue Date that have been deposited into bank accounts with a view to being used for the
future redemption or repayment of such Existing Senior Secured Notes.

**_Prepayments_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement will permit voluntary prepayments to be made (subject to _de minimis_
amounts), and will require mandatory prepayment in full or in part in certain circumstances, including:

    - from certain net cash proceeds received by the Group from certain asset disposals, to the extent not
otherwise applied for a permitted purpose and required to be applied in prepayment of the Senior
Facilities and subject to a de minimis amount (an “Asset Sale Prepayment”); and

    - unless otherwise agreed by the majority lenders under the Senior Facilities Agreement, for each financial
year (commencing with the first full financial year commencing after the Alaska Closing Date), a
percentage of excess cash flow in the event that excess cash flow exceeds the aggregate of a minimum
threshold amount and the deductible amount, which percentage decreases as the Senior Secured Net
Leverage Ratio decreases (an “Excess Cash Flow Prepayment”).

In addition, upon the occurrence of a Change of Control (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement), at
the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s option (in its sole discretion) unless otherwise agreed by the majority lenders under
the Senior Facilities Agreement, either: (i) all outstanding undrawn commitments of each lender under the Senior
Facilities Agreement shall be immediately cancelled and outstanding utilisations, together with accrued interest, shall
become immediately due and payable; or (ii) each lender under the Senior Facilities Agreement shall be entitled to
cancel its commitments and require prepayment of its share of outstanding utilisations within a prescribed time period.
A Change of Control shall include:

    - any person or group (other than one or more of the Permitted Holders, as defined in the Senior Facilities
Agreement) becoming the beneficial owner of more than 50% of the voting power of the Senior Secured
Notes Issuer, subject to certain conditions; and

    - the sale, lease, transfer, conveyance or other disposition of all or substantially all of the assets of the
Group, subject to certain exceptions.

At the election of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, amounts required to be prepaid pursuant to an Excess
Cash Flow Prepayment or Asset Sale Prepayment may instead be applied in prepayment of (i) other Senior Secured
Indebtedness (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) pro rata across such facilities, or (ii) provided that such
application would comply with applicable limitations on restricted payments (see “—Covenants”), any other Permitted
Indebtedness (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement).

The provision and the terms of the security and guarantees set forth above will in all cases be subject to
certain limitations and are at all times and in all cases subject to the requirements of applicable law and the other

**_Representations and Warranties_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain representations and warranties (subject to certain agreed
qualifications and with certain representations being repeated), including: (i) status, (ii) binding obligations,
(iii) non-conflict with other obligations, (iv) power and authority, (v) validity and admissibility in evidence,

anti-corruption law / sanctions.

Certain representations and warranties were made on the date of the Senior Facilities Agreement and the
Alaska Closing Date and at certain other times, and certain representations and warranties will be repeated on the date
of each utilisation request, the date of each utilisation, on the first day of each interest period.

**_Covenants_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain incurrence covenants, information undertakings and related
definitions (with, in each case, certain adjustments), including (i) a requirement to deliver copies of the Senior Secured
Notes Issuer’s audited annual consolidated financial statements to the Agent (as defined in the Senior Facilities
Agreement) within 120 days after the end of each of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s fiscal years; (ii) a requirement
to deliver the Senior Secured Notes Issuer’s consolidated financial statements within 60 days of the end of each of its
first three fiscal quarters in each fiscal year; (iii) limitations on indebtedness; (iv) limitations on restricted payments;
(v) limitations on liens (which includes restrictions on designating indebtedness secured on the Collateral as Super
Senior Liabilities (as defined in the section entitled “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor
_Agreement”)); (vi) limitations on restrictions on distributions from restricted subsidiaries; (vii) limitations on sales of_
assets and subsidiary stock; (viii) limitations on affiliate transactions; (ix) merger and consolidation; (x) impairment
of security interest, and (xi) limitations on sale and leaseback transactions, ground rent transactions and qualified
securitization financings involving real property, which are (or will be with effect from the Issue Date and the
amendment and restatement of the Senior Facilities Agreement) in each case substantially the same as the
corresponding covenants under the Senior Secured Notes.

In addition, the Senior Facilities Agreement also requires the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and certain of its
restricted subsidiaries to observe certain other customary positive and negative covenants, subject to certain exceptions
and grace periods, including covenants relating to: (i) authorisations and consents; (ii) compliance with laws; (iii) pari
_passu_ ranking; (iv) payment of taxes; (v) centre of main interests; (vi) provision of guarantees and security; (vii)
further assurance; (viii) compliance with anti-corruption laws and sanctions; (ix) ratings; and (x) investigations when
a Material Event of Default (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) is continuing. The Senior Facilities
Agreement also contains certain provisions facilitating an IPO debt pushdown (see “—Intercreditor Agreement—
_Required Consents—Provisions Following an IPO”)._

Solely for the benefit of the lenders participating in the Additional Term Facility, the Additional Term Facility
Notice contains certain additional covenants and/or restrictions on the Group.

Solely for the benefit of the lenders participating in a Financial Covenant Facility (as defined in the Senior
Facilities Agreement), the Senior Facilities Agreement requires that, in the event that the aggregate amount of all cash
loans drawn under all Financial Covenant Facilities (excluding any ancillary facilities and any utilisations of the
Financial Covenant Facilities by way of letters of credit (or bank guarantees)), any amounts utilised to fund any
original issue discount or flex related payments, fees or expenses or made on the Alaska Closing Date(and any rollover
loans in respect of such utilisations), less any cash and cash equivalents of the Group, exceeds 40% of the aggregate
of (i) the total commitments under the Revolving Credit Facility as at the original date of the Senior Facilities
Agreement (as reduced to reflect the cancellation in full and termination of the Original Revolving Facility 2
Commitments thereafter) and (ii) the aggregate commitments under any additional revolving facility established after
the original date of the Senior Facilities Agreement (including the Additional Revolving Facilities), on the relevant
testing date (the “Revolving Test Condition”), the Consolidated Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio does not exceed
4.90:1 (the “Financial Covenant”). The Consolidated Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio is based on the definitions
and adjustments in the Senior Facilities Agreement, which may differ from similar definitions in the Indenture and
the equivalent definitions described in this Offering Memorandum.

The Senior Facilities Agreement contains an equity cure provision enabling the shareholders of the Senior
Secured Notes Issuer to make shareholder injections by way of subordinated shareholder debt and/or equity to the
Senior Secured Notes Issuer to (i) increase Consolidated EBITDA as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement (an
“EBITDA Cure”), (ii) decrease Consolidated Senior Secured Net Debt as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement
(a “Net Debt Cure”), or (iii) repay or prepay or net off against any outstanding loans or (at the election of the Senior
Secured Notes Issuer) any cash drawings outstanding under any ancillary facility, in each case so that the Revolving
Test Condition is no longer met. The EBITDA Cure right may not be exercised on more than five occasions during
the term of the Senior Facilities. No more than two cure rights (which are either EBITDA Cures or Net Debt Cures)
may be exercised in three consecutive financial quarters.

It is intended that certain agreed covenants and other provisions of the Senior Facilities Agreement will fall
away on the satisfaction of certain release conditions, being (i) a listing has occurred which does not constitute a
Change of Control and the Consolidated Net Leverage Ratio (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) for the
relevant period is equal to or less than 2.70:1, (ii) the long-term corporate credit rating of the Senior Secured Notes
Issuer (or, as the case may be, any holding company of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer) is equal to or better than
Baa3 according to Moody’s or BBB- according to S&P and no Default or Event of Default has occurred and is
continuing, or (iii) Facility B (EUR) has achieved and maintained Investment Grade Status (as defined in the Senior
Facilities Agreement) and no Default or Event of Default has occurred and is continuing.

**_Events of Default_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement provides (or will provide with effect from the Issue Date and the amendment
and restatement of the Senior Facilities Agreement) for substantially the same events of default as under the Senior
Secured Notes. In addition, the Senior Facilities Agreement provides for additional events of default, subject to
customary materiality qualifications and grace periods, including (i) (for the benefit of the lenders participating in a
Financial Covenant Facility only) breach of the financial covenant; (ii) inaccuracy of a representation or statement
when made; (iii) invalidity and unlawfulness of the Finance documents (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement);
and (iv) material failure to comply with the Intercreditor Agreement.

**_Governing Law_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement and any non-contractual obligations arising out of or in connection with it,
are governed by, construed in accordance with and will be enforced in accordance with English law, although the
information undertakings, restrictive covenants, events of default and related definitions scheduled to the Senior
Facilities Agreement will be interpreted in accordance with New York law (without prejudice to the fact that the
Senior Facilities Agreement is governed by English law).

**Intercreditor Agreement**

**_General_**

To establish the relative rights of certain of our creditors under our financing arrangements, the Senior Notes
Issuer and the Senior Secured Notes Issuer entered into an intercreditor agreement on February 12, 2021 (the
“Intercreditor Agreement”) with, among others, the Security Agent and the agents, arrangers and lenders under the
Senior Facilities Agreement. Deutsche Trustee Company Limited, in its capacity as trustee under the Senior Notes
Indenture, acceded to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Topco Notes Trustee (as defined in the Intercreditor
Agreement) on February 24, 2021. Asda Stores Limited and Asda Group Limited acceded to the Intercreditor
Agreement on the LBO Acquisition Completion Date and McLagan Investments Limited and The Burwood House
Group Limited acceded to the Intercreditor Agreement on May 17, 2021. The Senior Secured Notes Trustee is
expected to accede to the Intercreditor Agreement as a Senior Secured Notes Trustee (as defined in the Intercreditor
Agreement) on or about the Issue Date of the Senior Secured Notes. On or about the Issue Date of the Senior Secured
Notes, the Senior Secured Notes will be designated “Senior Secured Notes” under and pursuant to the Intercreditor
Agreement.

By accepting a Senior Secured Note, holders of the Senior Secured Notes will be deemed to have agreed to,
and accepted the terms and conditions of, the Intercreditor Agreement.

The Intercreditor Agreement is governed by English law and sets out various matters governing the
relationship of the creditors to our group including the relative ranking of certain debt of the Senior Notes Issuer, the
Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Guarantors and any other person that becomes party to the Intercreditor Agreement
as a Debtor or Third-Party Security Provider, when payments can be made in respect of debt of the Debtors or
Third-Party Security Providers, when enforcement action can be taken in respect of that debt, the terms pursuant to
which certain of that debt will be subordinated upon the occurrence of certain insolvency events and turnover
provisions and provisions related to the enforcement of shared security.

The following description is a summary of certain provisions to be contained in the Intercreditor Agreement.
It does not restate the Intercreditor Agreement in its entirety and we urge you to read that document because it, and
not the discussion that follows, defines certain rights of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes and of the Senior
Secured Notes Trustee. Capitalised terms used in this section “—Intercreditor Agreement” but not defined herein have
the meanings given to them in the Intercreditor Agreement.

For the purposes of this description:

References to the “Senior Secured Notes” shall include the Existing Senior Secured Notes, the Senior
Secured Notes or any additional notes issued from time to time under the Existing Senior Secured Notes Indentures
and the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, and any other notes, securities or other debt instruments issued or to be issued
by, or in relation to which a New Debt Financing (as defined below) has been made available to or by, a member of
the Group which are designated by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer as Senior Secured Notes under the Intercreditor
Agreement, and references to the “Topco Notes” shall include the Existing Senior Notes, any additional notes issued
from time to time under the Existing Senior Notes Indenture, and any other notes, securities or other debt instruments
issued or to be issued by, or in relation to which a New Debt Financing has been made available to or by, a Topco
Borrower (as defined below) which are designated by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer as Topco Notes.

The Intercreditor Agreement uses the term the “Company” to refer to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer,
“Topco” to refer to the Senior Notes Issuer and “Senior Secured Notes Liabilities” to refer to the Senior Secured
Notes and certain other indebtedness of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer.

other member of the Group which is designated as a Topco Borrower under the Intercreditor Agreement (a “Topco

Facilities Agreement or any future senior secured facilities agreements (a “Permitted Senior
**Secured Facilities Agreement”) (the “Senior Lender Liabilities”), (ii) the lenders, issuing banks,**

The Intercreditor Agreement provides, subject to certain conditions, for the implementation of existing,

give rise to an obligation (including any payment obligation but not including any obligation to extend any Transaction
Security rateably for the benefit of such Permitted Acquired Indebtedness) under or in relation thereto.

**_Permitted Payments_**

_Permitted Payments in Respect of the Senior and Super Senior Debt_

The Debtors and Third-Party Security Providers may make payment in respect of the Senior Lender
Liabilities, Senior Secured Notes Liabilities, Super Senior Liabilities and Cash Management Facility Liabilities
(together with the Hedging Liabilities, the “Senior Secured Creditor Liabilities,” the creditors in respect thereof
being the “Senior Secured Creditors”) at any time, provided that following certain acceleration events under the
Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, any Permitted Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, any Senior Secured Notes
Indenture or Permitted Super Senior Secured Facilities Agreement or following certain insolvency events in relation
to a member of the Group, payments may only be made by Debtors or Third-Party Security Providers and received by
creditors in accordance with the provisions described below under “Application of Proceeds”; provided that after the
Designation Date there shall be no obligation to turnover any such payments received, other than those related to an
enforcement of Transaction Security or a Distressed Disposal (as defined below) of assets subject to the Transaction
Security.

Any failure to make a payment in accordance with the Senior Secured Finance Documents following an
acceleration event or insolvency event as required by the Intercreditor Agreement shall not prevent the occurrence of
an event of default under such applicable Senior Secured Finance Documents.

_Permitted Payments in Respect of Second Lien Liabilities_

Prior to the date which is the later of the Super Senior Discharge Date and the Senior Secured Discharge
Date, the Debtors, the Third-Party Security Providers and other members of the Group may only make specified
payments (including any other direct or indirect step, matter, action or dealing in relation to any Second Lien Liabilities
otherwise prohibited under the Intercreditor Agreement) under the Second Lien Liabilities to the Second Lien
Creditors (such payments, collectively, “Permitted Second Lien Payments”):

(i) if:

(1) no Second Lien Payment Stop Notice (as defined below) is outstanding;

(2) no payment default (subject to a de minimis threshold in the case of amounts other than
principal, interest or certain fees) has occurred and is continuing under any Permitted
Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, Permitted Super Senior Secured Facilities
Agreement, Cash Management Facility document or Senior Secured Notes document (a
“Senior Secured Payment Default”); and

(3) the payment is (1) of any amount of principal or capitalised interest in respect of the Second
Lien Liabilities which is not prohibited by any prior ranking financing agreements (in
respect of the Senior Secured Liabilities), or, to the extent prohibited, any required consents
to permit such payment have been obtained, (2) of any other amounts which is not an
amount of principal or capitalised interest including all scheduled interest payments
(including, if applicable, special interest or liquidated damages), the accrual of cash interest

otherwise payable during a period when a Second Lien Payment Stop Notice (as defined
below) is outstanding and default interest on the Second Lien Liabilities accrued and
payable in accordance with the terms of the relevant Second Lien Finance Document (as

any expenses incurred in respect of (or reasonably incidental to) the Second Lien Finance
Documents (including in relation to any reporting or listing requirements under the Second Lien
Finance Documents), (F) of any other amount not exceeding €4,000,000 (equivalent) in aggregate
in any 12-month period, (G) of any amount of the Second Lien Liabilities which would have been

of the accrual of cash interest payable in respect of the Second Lien Liabilities during such period
or any such amount described at (i)(C) above, provided that no such payment may be made if certain

as an event of default under the Senior Secured Liabilities or Second Lien Liabilities is continuing,
of all or part of the Second Lien Liabilities being released or otherwise discharged solely in

holding company of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer that arise as a result of any such Debt for Equity
Swap are subordinated to the Senior Secured Liabilities pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement and
the Senior Secured Creditors are granted Transaction Security in respect of any of those liabilities

non-cash interest made by way of capitalising interest or issuing a non-cash-pay instrument which
is subordinated to the Senior Secured Liabilities on the same terms as the Second Lien Liabilities,
(J) if the payment is funded directly or indirectly with the proceeds of Second Lien Liabilities or
Topco Liabilities incurred respectively under or pursuant to any Second Lien Finance Document
and/or Topco Finance Document, (K) if the payment is of a principal amount of the Second Lien
Liabilities and made in accordance with a provision in a Second Lien Finance Document relating to

Payment Default has occurred and is continuing and the payment is a payment of principal, interest
or any other amounts made on or after the final maturity of the relevant Second Lien Liabilities

(provided that such maturity date is no earlier than that contained in the original form of the relevant
Second Lien Finance Document as of the first date of borrowing or issuance (as the case may be) of
the applicable Second Lien Liabilities); or

(iii) if the requisite Senior Secured Creditors and Super Senior Creditors give prior consent to that

On or after the later of the Super Senior Discharge Date and the Senior Secured Discharge Date, the Debtors
and the Third-Party Security Providers may make payments in respect of the Second Lien Liabilities in accordance

_Second Lien Liabilities Payment Block Provisions_

A Second Lien Payment Stop Notice (as defined below) is outstanding from the date on which, following the
occurrence of certain material events of default, the Security Agent (acting on the instructions of the requisite Super
Senior Creditors or Senior Secured Creditors gave the instructions for the relevant stop notice to be delivered) (a
“Second Lien Payment Stop Notice”) to the Second Lien Creditor Representative(s) advising that the relevant event
of default is continuing and suspending payments of the Second Lien Liabilities, until the first to occur of:

(i) the date falling 120 days after delivery of that Second Lien Payment Stop Notice;

(ii) the date on which a default occurs for failure to pay principal at the original scheduled maturity of
the relevant Second Lien Liabilities;

(iii) if a Second Lien Standstill Period (as defined below) commences after delivery of that Second Lien
Payment Stop Notice, the date on which such standstill period expires;

(iv) the date on which the relevant material event of default has been remedied or waived;

(v) the date on which the Security Agent (acting on the instructions of whichever of the Super Senior
Creditors or Senior Secured Creditors gave the instructions for the relevant stop notice to be
delivered) delivers a notice to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer and the Second Lien Creditor
Representative cancelling the payment stop notice;

(vi) the later of the Super Senior Discharge Date and the Senior Secured Discharge Date; and

(vii) the date on which the Second Lien Creditors take any enforcement action that they are permitted
under the Intercreditor Agreement (see “Enforcement Regime—Permitted Second Lien
_Enforcement” below)._

No Second Lien Payment Stop Notice may be delivered by the Security Agent in reliance on a particular
relevant event of default more than 45 days after the occurrence of the relevant event of default. No more than one
Second Lien Payment Stop Notice may be served (i) with respect to the same event or set of circumstances or (ii) in
any period of 360 days.

Any failure to make a payment due in respect of the Second Lien Liabilities as a result of the issue of a
Second Lien Payment Stop Notice or the occurrence of a Senior Secured Payment Default shall not prevent (i) the
occurrence of an event of default as a consequence of that failure to make a payment in relation to the relevant Second
Lien Liabilities or (ii) the issue of an enforcement notice in respect of an event of default under the finance documents
documenting any Second Lien Liabilities (a “Second Lien Enforcement Notice”) on behalf of the Second Lien
Creditors.

_Payment Obligations and Capitalisation of Interest Continue_

Nothing in the Second Lien or Topco payment block provisions will release any Debtor or Third-Party
Security Provider from the liability to make any payment (including of default interest, which shall continue to accrue)
under the applicable Debt Documents even if its obligation to make such payment is restricted at any time. The accrual

229


-----

and Capitalisation of interest (if any) in accordance with the applicable Debt Documents shall continue
notwithstanding the issue of a payment stop notice.

_Cure of Payment Stop_

If:

(i) at any time following the issue of a Second Lien Payment Stop Notice or the occurrence of a Senior
Secured Payment Default that Second Lien Payment Stop Notice ceases to be outstanding and/or
(as the case may be) the Senior Secured Payment Default ceases to be continuing; and

(ii) the relevant Debtor then promptly pays to the Second Lien Creditors an amount equal to any
payments which had accrued under the Second Lien Finance Documents and which would have
been Permitted Second Lien Payments but for that Second Lien Payment Stop Notice or Senior
Secured Payment Default (as the case may be),

then any event of default which may have occurred under a Second Lien Finance Document and any Second
Lien Enforcement Notice which may have been issued as a result of that suspension of payments shall be deemed
automatically waived without any further action being required by the Second Lien Creditors.

_Permitted Payments in Respect of Topco Liabilities_

Prior to the first date on which all of the Senior Liabilities, the Super Senior Liabilities, the Senior Secured
Notes Liabilities and the Second Lien Liabilities (together, the “Secured Liabilities”) have been discharged (the
“Priority Discharge Date”), the Debtors, the members of the Group, the Topco Borrowers and the Third-Party
Security Providers may only make specified payments in respect of the Topco Liabilities, in accordance with the
finance documents governing such Topco Liabilities, subject to compliance with certain conditions in the Intercreditor
Agreement.

The principal conditions are that the relevant payment (if it is a payment of principal or capitalised interest)
is not prohibited by any prior ranking financing agreement, including any Permitted Super Senior Secured Facilities
Agreement, Permitted Senior Secured Facilities Agreement, any Senior Secured Notes Indenture, any Second Lien
Facility Agreement and any Second Lien Notes Indenture (or if it is so prohibited, that all necessary consents have
been obtained to permit it), no payment stop notice has been issued to the agent or trustee for the relevant Topco
Liabilities and Senior Secured Payment Default or payment default (subject to a de minimis threshold in the case of
amounts other than principal, interest or certain fees) is continuing under the Second Lien Facility Agreement.

Certain specified payments in respect of Topco Liabilities are also permitted at all times, notwithstanding
that a payment stop notice is outstanding or such a payment default is continuing. These payments and basket amounts
are substantially similar to those referenced for Second Lien Liabilities in (ii) of “Permitted Payments in Respect of
_Second Lien Liabilities” above._

**_Turnover_**

Subject to certain exceptions, the Intercreditor Agreement provides that if, at any time prior to the latest to
occur of the Super Senior Discharge Date, the Senior Secured Discharge Date, the first date on which all of the Second
Lien Liabilities have been fully discharged (the “Second Lien Discharge Date”) and the first date on which all of the
Topco Liabilities have been fully discharged (the “Topco Discharge Date”) (the “Final Discharge Date”) any
creditor (other than a Senior Secured Creditor on or after the Designation Date) receives or recovers from any Debtor,
member of the Group or Third-Party Security Provider:

(i) any payment or distribution of, or on account of or in relation to, any of the liabilities owed to the
creditors under the Debt Documents other than any payment or distribution which is either (x) not
prohibited under the Intercreditor Agreement or (y) made in accordance with the provisions set out
below under “Application of Proceeds”;

(ii) any amount by way of set-off which does not give effect to a payment permitted under the
Intercreditor Agreement;
