**_SLB Purchase Agreement_**

_Post-Closing Obligations_

Following the consummation of the sale-leaseback transaction, McLagan Investments Limited must use
reasonable endeavours to resolve certain diligence items at certain of the SLB Properties. The resolution of those
diligence items included cladding issues at the Poole property, keeping Realty informed in respect of ongoing
negotiations to sell a parcel of land at or near the Doncaster property to a third party, transfer of certain shares in an
estate management company relating to the management of the Kings Hill property and dealings with a pre-emption
agreement that encumbers part of the Poole property.

**_Material SLB Master Lease Terms_**

_Term_

The initial term of the SLB Master Leases is for a term of years commencing on August 2, 2023 and expiring
on and including August 9, 2048 for the initial 22 properties (with the (inclusive) term dates for the three latercompleted properties being – Kings Hill: November 7, 2023 to November 14, 2048; Poole: September 5, 2023 to
September 12, 2048; and Swindon (Haydon): August 21, 2023 to August 29, 2048). In addition, each Master Lease
contains two (2) renewal options (or in relation to the SLB Master Leases of the Scottish assets an option to extend)
for a term of ten (10) years each which can be exercised during the term of each of the SLB Master Leases (and
subsequent first renewal or extension lease) but not less than six (6) months’ prior to expiry of the term of each of the
SLB Master Leases (and subsequent first renewal or extension lease).

_Rent_

The SLB Master Leases each reserve a different rent payable by the Tenant in equal instalments on February
28, May 31, August 31 and November 30 in each year. The rent is subject to an annual review which is upwards-only,
linked to the percentage change in Consumer Price Index for the period from the immediately preceding rent review
date to the current rent review date subject to a cap of 4% and a collar of 1%. Interest is payable at 3% per annum
above the Barclays base rate on any sums (including but not limited to rent) not paid by the Tenant on the date they
are due. The Tenant is also required to pay all outgoings (including but not limited to business rates, taxes and utilities)
and landlord fees.

_Landlord and Tenant Act 1954_

In addition to the contractual options to extend the SLB Master Leases, the SLB Master benefit from a Tenant
statutory right of renewal pursuant to the provisions of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 (not applicable for the
Master Leases of the Scottish assets). The Tenant has a right to renew the SLB Master Leases in England & Wales at
the end of the term, subject to some limited grounds of opposition available to the landlord pursuant to the Landlord
and Tenant Act 1954.

_Guarantor_

There is no guarantor party to the SLB Master Leases in respect of the Tenant’s obligations.

_Use_

The Tenant may only use the SLB Properties as (1) retail stores within Class E of the Town and Country
Planning (Use Classes) Order 1987 (and certain specified ancillary uses to such use); (2) any use to which the SLB
Properties were used as at the date of the relevant Master Lease; and (3) any other use approved by the landlord (such
approval not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed where the proposed use would not have a material adverse effect
on the value of the landlord’s interest). The Tenant may also permit undertenants to use a part of the premises for any
lawful use within Class E or various uses within Class F, provided that such uses within Class F are limited to a
maximum aggregate area of 5% of the gross internal area of the buildings on the premises.

258


-----

_Maintenance, Alterations and Expansion_

Pursuant to the SLB Master Leases, the Tenant is obligated to repair, replace and maintain each SLB
Property. The Tenant may make de minimis alterations (which include both non-structural and specific minor
structural alterations such as creation of new entrances and exterior canopies and internal division walls required for
subletting) subject to various conditions, including but not limited to (i) obtaining any planning permissions; (ii) giving
the insurers of the relevant SLB Property notice of the work; (iii) procuring that the works are carried out by reputable
contractors in a good and workmanlike manner; (iv) making good any defects arising out of the works; and (v) giving
the landlord records in line with CDM regulations and drawings of alterations).

The Tenant may make minor alterations (which include structural alterations which do not increase the gross
external area of buildings on the premises by more than 40%) subject to the above conditions, as well as subject to
supplying the landlord full written details of the proposed alterations and confirmation that such alterations are not
part of a wider scheme of works and that all requisite consents have been or will be obtained.

The Tenant may make major alterations (being any alterations or any structural additions to the properties
that are not minor alterations or de minimis alterations) subject to the conditions which apply to minor alterations as
well as subject to receiving landlord consent, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld. The Tenant must also
procure warranties in favour of the landlord (to the extent the Tenant has the ability to call for such warranties) for
major alterations or minor alterations where new buildings / extensions are erected.

There are various restrictions on all alterations to the premises, including, but not limited to, not making any
alterations which would (i) prejudice the structural integrity of the premises; (ii) lower the energy performance rating
of the premises; or (iii) have a material detrimental effect on the value of the landlord’s interest.

_Yield Up_

The Tenant is required to return the SLB Properties at the expiry of the term having removed all fixtures and
signage installed by the Tenant, as well as any alterations made during the term, except that the Tenant shall not
be required to remove buildings or permanent structures if their continued presence beyond the end of the Term
would not have a material detrimental effect on the estimated rental value of the landlord’s reversionary interest
in the relevant SLB Property or the Tenant (in its discretion) elects instead to pay a sum equivalent to the
detrimental effect on the estimated rental value of the landlord’s reversionary interest. Any alterations which have
not been completed at the end of the term must be reinstated to the landlord’s reasonable satisfaction. The Tenant
must also return the SLB Properties free from any underleases, concessions and third-party rights of occupation
created by the Tenant other than those where the landlord consented expressly to such occupier remaining after
the expiry of the term.

_Tenant’s right of First Offer_

In the event that the landlord, whether or not for money or money’s worth, wishes to sell or exchanges their
reversionary interest in any of the SLB Properties (whether in part or in whole) or grant a lease or agreement for lease
in respect of any of the SLB Properties (whether in part or in whole) at a premium or with the intention or effect of
realising capital value from any of the SLB Properties to a third party, the landlord must first offer to sell the relevant
SLB Property which is the subject matter of the proposed disposal to the Tenant, being Asda Stores Limited or any
group company (the right of first offer is personal to the original tenant and its group companies). The right of first
offer is conditioned upon there being no event of default that would give rise to a right for the landlord to forfeit the
Master Lease then occurring under the subject Master Lease.

_Assignment_

The SLB Master Leases contain assignment and subletting rights in favour the Tenant. The Tenant may
assign (in whole only) or sublet (in whole or in part) the Master Lease of the relevant SLB Property subject to landlord
consent, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed.

The landlord may impose certain conditions in respect of giving consent to an assignment. The landlord may
impose that (i) the proposed assignee enters into a deed of covenant with the landlord to comply with the terms of the

Master Lease; (ii) there are no arrears of rents due to the landlord that are not the subject of a legitimate dispute about

_Subletting_

The Tenant may underlet the whole or any part of the relevant SLB Property provided that it obtains the prior
written consent of the landlord, which will not be unreasonably withheld or delayed.

The undertenant is to enter into a direct deed of covenant in favour of the landlord both (i) to comply with
the undertenant’s covenants in the underlease whilst it remains an undertenant; and (ii) to procure that any proposed
assignee of the underlease enters into a direct deed of covenant with the landlord on an assignment of the underlease.

Any underlease is to be granted (i) without reserving a fine or premium; (ii) at the open market rent reasonably
obtainable at the time of the grant of the underlease for the premises underlet; (iii) where the term exceeds five years,
containing provisions for the review of rent consistent with open market practice at the relevant time; and (iv)
including covenants which are not inconsistent with or impair the performance and observance of the covenants of the
Tenant in the Master Lease provided that the Tenant is able to allow the undertenant a rent free or concessionary rent
period or provide an inducement or other incentive payment to take the underlease so far as is consistent with normal
market practice.

Any underlease must not benefit from the statutory right of renewal contained in the Landlord and Tenant
Act 1954 and must be for a term which expires before the expiry of the Master Lease (not applicable for the Master
Leases of the Scottish assets).

No underlease of part of the relevant SLB Property shall permit creation of further underleases of part of the
relevant SLB Property that is underlet but may allow (i) further underleases of whole subject to obtaining the prior
consent of the landlord where it would be required to such underletting under the Master Lease (such consent not to
be unreasonably withheld or delayed) and such further underlease shall not permit any further underletting of whole
or part of the relevant SLB Property and (ii) granting of licences or other rights to share occupation of part of areas of
the carpark or units of the store as set out under ‘Concessions’ below which do not create any relationship of landlord
and tenant.

The Tenant may without the landlord’s consent grant licences or other rights to share occupation in relation

_Maximum Area subject to Subletting and Concessions_

The Tenant may only grant concessions of areas of the carpark or units of the store as set out under
‘Concessions’ above and/or Permitted Underleases (i) in relation to premises outside the footprint of the main store

_Charging_

The Tenant may charge its interest in respect of the whole of the Master Lease to reputable lending institutions
to secure debt but cannot charge its interest in respect of only part of the Master Lease.

_Events of Default_

The SLB Master Leases contain a customary event of default (forfeiture) provision, which include: (i) failure
of the Tenant to pay the rent or any other sums due under the SLB Master Leases within 15 working days after the

or any guarantor, including liquidation, the appointment of an administrator or receiver, entry into a scheme of an
arrangement with creditors or is subject to a winding up order under Part IV of the Insolvency Act 1986 unless for the
purposes of a solvent amalgamation or reconstruction of the company; (iv) disclaimer of the SLB Master Leases by
the Crown or by a liquidator or trustee in bankruptcy of the Tenant; (v) the Tenant or any guarantor is struck off the

_Insurance_

If the Tenant elects not to insure the relevant SLB Property, the landlord is obliged to insure the relevant SLB

_Termination due to damage by Insured or Uninsured Risks_

The landlord (subject to having complied with its obligations to reinstate) or Tenant may immediately
determine the relevant Master Lease if at the expiry of the three (3) year rent suspension period following destruction
or damage by an insured risk (which includes standard insured risk events including fire, lightning, explosion,

of uninsured damage, subject to the Tenant not electing to reinstate or rebuild the SLB Property, the landlord may
elect to reinstate or rebuild the SLB Property. If the uninsured damage occurs in the last five (5) years of the term of
the SLB Master Leases and neither the landlord or Tenant have elected to rebuild or reinstate the SLB Property, the

_Other Material Provisions_

There are extensive obligations on the Tenant in relation to compliance with environmental laws, providing

The Tenant provides an indemnity to the landlord against all loss arising from (i) the breach of any Tenant

**_SLB Properties – site-specific provisions_**

Transaction documentation for certain of the SLB Properties differs from those master transaction document
templates which are described in the section above. This sub-section briefly sets out any such material differences on
a site-by-site basis.

  - **Blackpool: the Master Lease for the store in Blackpool contains bespoke insurance and alterations provisions**
due to certain third-party restrictive covenants registered on the title of the Blackpool store. Accordingly,
insurance is in place covering the risk of breach or enforcement of these third-party restrictive covenants. As
a consequence, if alterations or implementing or applying for planning permission would fall foul of the
exclusions within the title insurance policy, the Tenant is required to either (i) seek consent from the insurer
and confirmation from the insurer that the title insurance cover will continue notwithstanding the alteration
or implementation of planning permission, or (ii) obtain a new title insurance policy covering the same third
party restrictive covenant risks and which would not be voided by the aforementioned alterations or
application for or implementation of any planning permission. The Tenant was also required to enter into a
deed of covenant at the date of the lease to comply with various obligations contained in a 2015 transfer.
The Tenant cannot assign the Blackpool Master Lease unless the assignee enters into a deed of covenant on
the same terms.

  - **Bolton: the Master Lease for the store in Bolton contains bespoke insurance and alterations provisions due**
to the fact that several car parking spaces may encroach on land which is not owned by the landlord (which
the tenant acknowledges under the terms of the Master Lease and confirms that it will not be entitled to claim
in respect of derogation from grant in relation to such gap). Accordingly, insurance is in place covering the
risk of the owner of the relevant land claiming ownership or bringing a claim for damages. As a consequence,
if alterations or implementing or applying for planning permission would fall foul of the exclusions within
the title insurance policy, the Tenant is required to either (i) seek consent from the insurer and confirmation
from the insurer that the title insurance cover will continue notwithstanding the alteration or implementation
of planning permission, or (ii) obtain a new title insurance policy covering the same risk and which would
not be voided by the aforementioned alterations or application for or implementation of any planning
permission.

  - **Frome: McLagan Investments Limited has retained a large nature reserve at the Frome property. The Master**
Lease for the Frome property allows Asda Stores Limited or any group company (being any company or
companies which is and/or are for the time being a member of the same group of companies as the Tenant
within the meaning of Section 42(1) of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954) to use parking at the Frome
property for visitors to the neighbouring nature reserve retained by McLagan Investments Limited.

  - **Glasshoughton: the Master Lease for the store in Glasshoughton contains bespoke insurance and alterations**
provisions due to the fact that part of the land is unregistered. Accordingly, the landlord only leases the
unregistered land with such right, title and interest as the landlord has in the premises as at the date of the
Master Lease (rather than with full title guarantee), and title insurance is in place to cover the risk of a third
party claiming ownership of the unregistered land. As a consequence, if alterations or implementing or
applying for planning permission would fall foul of the exclusions within the title insurance policy, the
Tenant is required to either (i) seek consent from the insurer and confirmation from the insurer that the title
insurance cover will continue notwithstanding the alteration or implementation of planning permission, or
(ii) obtain a new title insurance policy covering the same risk and which would not be voided by the
aforementioned alterations or application for or implementation of any planning permission.

  - **Kings Hill: the Master Lease for the store in Kings Hill contains bespoke service charge provisions due to**

landlord. The Tenant is required to pay any such service charge to the landlord within twenty (20) working
days of written demand. The Tenant was also required to enter into a deed of covenant at the date of the
lease to comply with various obligations contained in various transfers dated 2004 and 2013 and to create
various new restrictive covenants over the premises. The Tenant also entered into a separate deed of covenant
to pay estate charges and comply with various additional covenants. The Tenant cannot assign the Kings
Hill Master Lease unless the assignee enters into deeds of covenant on the same terms.

**Ground Rent Transactions – Ground Rent Facility**

**_Overview and Structure_**

Asda Propco Limited (“Propco”) was incorporated to acquire 55 properties owned by Mclagan Investments
Limited. The list of properties is as follows:

Accrington, Ashington, Barnsley, Beeston (Leeds), Boldon, Bradford West, Breck Road, Bromborough,

Darlaston, Eastbourne, Fareham, Fleetwood, Gateshead, Golborne, Gosforth, Grimsby, Harrogate, Hartlepool,
Hereford, Huddersfield, Hull (Hessle Road), Keighley, Lancaster, Leeds Middleton, Newark, Oadby, Oldbury,
Pentym, Pilsworth, Radcliffe, Rotherham, Runcorn, Shaw Oldham, Sittingbourne, Skelmersdale, South Wooton

the “Initial CGR Properties” and together with any other properties which are acquired by Propco, the “CGR
**Properties”).**

Asda Holdco 2 Limited (“Holdco 2”) was incorporated as a holding company for Propco, and Asda Holdco
Limited (“Holdco”) was incorporated as a holding company for Holdco 2. Holdco 2’s only assets are the shares in
Propco and its interest in intercompany loans it has made to Propco. Holdco’s only assets are the shares in Holdco 2
and its interest in intercompany loans it has made to Holdco 2.

Prior to the transfer of the Initial CGR Properties to Propco, Mclagan Investments Limited entered into 99
year CGR Ground Leases (the “CGR Ground Leases” and each a “CGR Ground Lease”) in respect of the Initial
CGR Properties with Asda Stores Limited (the “Tenant”). The Initial CGR Properties were transferred from Mclagan
Investments Limited to Propco subject to and with the benefit of the CGR Ground Leases. The consideration payable
by Propco to Mclagan Investments Limited for the acquisition of the Initial CGR Properties amounted to £646,660,032
and was funded in part by third party financing of £400,000,000 from the CGR Financing Lender (the “CGR
**Financing”) with the remainder funded by subordinated debt. Propco provided all assets security for the CGR**
Financing, including but not limited to mortgages over its interests in the Initial CGR Properties, over its interest in
the CGR Ground Leases, over its insurance policies and over its bank accounts. Holdco 2 provided security over its
shares in Propco and in its intercompany debt owed to it by Propco. Propco and Holdco 2 also entered into an
agreement subordinating that intercompany debt to the indebtedness under the CGR Financing.

Propco’s only source of income is amounts received by it from the Tenant under the CGR Ground Leases.

The CGR Financing Lender’s source of funds to make the Facilities (as defined below) available was the
proceeds of notes issued to certain third-party investors on or about the date of entry into the CGR Financing (the
“CGR Notes”). Certain features of the CGR Financing reflect the responsibility of Propco for maintaining a rating in
respect of the CGR Notes and for paying costs in respect of the CGR Notes structure. Two classes of Notes were
issued: £275,000,000 of Class A CGR Notes due 2068 (the “Class A CGR Notes”) and £125,000,000 of Class B
CGR Notes due 2073.

**_The Economic Terms of the CGR Financing_**

_Facilities and Term_

The CGR Financing was utilised in full on December 20, 2023. It comprises a facility A term loan, in the
amount of £275,000,000 (“CGR **Facility A”) and a facility B term loan, in the amount of £125,000,000 (“CGR**
**Facility B,” and each of CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B a “Ground Rent** **Facility”) pursuant to the ground rent**
facility agreement (the “Ground Rent Transaction Facility Agreement”).

    - The maturity date for CGR Facility A is December 12, 2068.

    - The maturity date for CGR Facility B is December 12, 2073.

_Principal indexation and amortisation_

CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B each amortise monthly.

The outstanding principal balance of CGR Facility A and CGR Facility B (and each repayment instalment)
are subject to annual indexation in December of each year. The rate of indexation is calculated as current ‘all items’
CPI divided by the ‘all items’ CPI as at the previous annual review date. It is subject to a floor of 1x and a ceiling of

265


-----

1.04x, meaning that on each annual indexation date the principal amount and reinstalments will either stay the same
or be multiplied by a maximum 1.04 times.

Rental payments under the CGR Ground Leases are subject to indexation at the same time annually and in
accordance with the same formula such that increases in amounts due under the CGR Financing in respect of interest
and amortisation are matched by increases in rent under the CGR Ground Leases.

_Interest_

Interest is payable monthly and comprises margin and the benchmark rate. For CGR Facility A the margin is
2.8% and the benchmark rate is 0.990%. For CGR Facility B the margin is 2.944% and the benchmark rate is 1.021%.

Default interest accrues on overdue amounts at a rate that is 3% per annum higher than the rate that would
otherwise have applied.

_Fees and Make whole_

Periodic fees are paid to the agency, security agent and cash manager under the terms of the CGR Financing.

A make whole fee is payable on prepayment or cancellation of commitments. The amount of the fee is the
sum of the present value of the aggregate scheduled principal and interest payments that would have accrued and
become due and payable in respect of the amount prepaid or cancelled from the date of prepayment or cancellation up
to the relevant maturity date, discounted to the date of prepayment or cancellation at a rate equal to the reinvestment
yield for the relevant Ground Rent Facility plus 0.5%.

The ‘reinvestment yield’ is the yield to maturity implied by (a) the ask-side yields reported, as of 10.00 A.M.
(London time) on the second Business Day preceding the Settlement Date on the display designated “Page PXUK”
on Bloomberg Financial Markets (or such other display as may replace “Page PXUK” on Bloomberg Financial
Markets) for actively traded index linked gilt-edged securities having a maturity of the Discount Period; or (b) if such
yields are not reported as of such time or the yields reported are not ascertainable, the average of the ask-side yields
as determined by the index linked gilt-edged market makers (as registered with the Bank of England). Such implied
yield will be determined, if necessary, by: (i) converting quotations to bond-equivalent yields in accordance with
accepted financial practice; and (ii) interpolating linearly between the ask-side yields for the (1) actively traded
index-linked gilt-edged security with the maturity closest to and greater than the Discount Period and (2) actively
traded index-linked gilt-edged security with the maturity closest to and less than the Discount Period. In this paragraph
the “Discount Period” is the period between the applicable prepayment/cancellation date and the applicable maturity
date.

For the purposes of the make-whole, no indexation is assumed after the date of the prepayment or cancelation
(as applicable).

The make-whole does not apply in the case of prepayment due to illegality, or note level illegality, a tax event
or a securitisation regulatory event. The make-whole also does not apply on the periodic amortisation payments.

The make-whole does apply to other mandatory prepayments, including from lease prepayment proceeds,
insurance prepayment proceeds, compensation prepayment proceeds in respect of compulsory purchase and recovery
prepayment proceeds from claims against report providers. If such amounts are received, Propco has the option to
substitute the affected CGR Property out of the CGR Financing. If the substitution occurs within six months of receipt
of the relevant payment, then the amount will not be swept in prepayment and therefore no make-whole will apply. In
addition, certain compensation proceeds, insurance proceeds and report recovery proceeds are excluded from the
mandatory prepayment requirement.

_Costs and indemnities_

Market standard cost and indemnity provisions are included under the terms of the CGR Financing, including
requirements to pay costs and increased costs relating to the CGR Financing and the CGR Notes structure. This
includes ongoing operating costs, amendment costs and enforcement and preservation costs.

266


-----

Propco is required to pay reasonably incurred costs of the finance parties in connection with substitutions
and with release of security following redemption of the CGR Notes.

Propco is required to pay the costs of valuations required under the terms of the CGR Financing, as well as
the costs of any valuation required in connection with a substitution or the release of collateral on maturity of the CGR
Notes.

_Cashflows and Reserves_

The CGR Financing requires Propco to retain bank accounts with a bank with a requisite rating. The bank
accounts are subject to security and (other than a Propco-controlled general account) are controlled by a cash manager
on behalf of the finance parties.

Net rental income and other amounts received by Propco must be paid into the bank accounts and there are
detailed provisions in the Ground Rent Transaction Facility Agreement as to the application of cash flows, including
payment of operating costs, interest, amortisation. The transaction has been modelled such that all outgoings of Propco
are intended to be funded by receipts under and in respect of the CGR Ground Leases.

_Payments waterfall_

Net rental income and certain other receipts must be paid into Propco’s rent account. A monthly cashflow
payments waterfall is run by a cash manager. This provides for payment of (1) capital receipts to be applied in
mandatory prepayment; (2) finance party and account bank costs, fees and expenses; (3) taxes and general corporate
maintenance costs of Propco, Holdco 2 or the CGR Financing Lender (subject in the case of such corporate
maintenance costs, to a cap of £250,000 per annum annually adjusted by CPI); (4) standby servicer and step-in servicer
costs, fees and expenses; (5) costs, fees and expenses due to the finance parties; (6) interest due under the CGR
Financing; (7) principal due under the CGR Financing; (8) payment of increased costs in respect of the lenders under
the CGR Financing, and increased costs in respect of the holders of the CGR Notes; (9) topping up the debt service
reserve (see below); (10) any budgeted amount required to pay ongoing operating/structural costs not already paid
above, and any costs and expenses related to a CGR Property substitution or release of collateral; (11) other amounts
due to the finance parties under the CGR Financing; and (12) any excess to Propco’s general account unless a cash
trap event is continuing in which case such surplus is transferred to the cash trap account.

It is a cash trap event if at any time the historic debt service coverage ratio is less than 1.05x on a
twelve-month lookback basis. If a cash trap event is continuing on two consecutive interest payment dates, the cash
manager is required to apply the monies in the cash trap account in prepayment of the Ground Rent Facility (together
with the make-whole (see section 4 above)). If a cash trap event is not continuing on two consecutive interest payment
dates, the cash manager shall release the monies to the Propco-controlled general account.

_Debt Service Reserve_

A 12-month reserve in respect of items (2) through (6) listed and the amount projected to be payable pursuant
to item (7) over the next 12 interest payment dates under “—Payments waterfall” must be maintained by Propco in
the debt service account at all times, or alternatively a letter of credit may be provided in an equivalent amount. The
debt service reserve is held on trust for the original lender under the CGR Financing and will not form part of Propco’s
estate in an insolvency. Any excess so reserved on any monthly interest payment date is released to Propco’s general
account (and such excess does not form part of the trust property).

_Expenses Reserve_

Propco must prepare an annual budget detailing the ongoing costs of Propco, Holdco 2, the CGR Financing
Lender and certain other costs associated with CGR Financing together with the costs associated with any scheduled
substitutions of the CGR Properties. Propco must at all times maintain a 12-month reserve in respect of any such costs
(the “Expenses Reserve Amount”).

267


-----

_Cures_

Provided the Tenant under the CGR Ground Leases is in compliance with all obligations to pay rent, Propco
is permitted to use the proceeds of subordinated debt or equity injections or free cash in the general account to make
up for any shortfalls in amounts available to make the payments under the debt service waterfall (see “Cashflows and
_Reserves—Payments waterfall”). This may be done within the period between the rental payment date under the CGR_
Ground Leases and the date falling four business days before the next monthly interest payment date. Otherwise
Propco is restricted from receiving amounts by way of subordinated debt or equity injection.

**_Representations and Undertakings under the CGR Financing_**

The CGR Financing is documented under a suite of finance documents based on Loan Market Association
and other market precedents for limited recourse real estate financing transactions. The documentation includes
provisions of a type typically included in real estate finance transactions in the European market, including but not
limited to cost and indemnity provisions in favour of the finance parties. The CGR Financing loan agreement also
includes representations and undertakings of a type seen in European real estate financing transactions. As such, there
are broad restrictions on (amongst other things) Propco incurring further indebtedness, making acquisitions and
making disposals.

Outside the substitution and release regimes (see “—Substitution mechanics under the CGR Financing” and
“—Release of CGR Properties on redemption of CGR Notes”), Propco is restricted from disposing of the CGR
Properties and acquiring properties.

Propco is subject to restrictions on taking non-ordinary course actions under the CGR Ground Leases
(including changing, amending, terminating, forfeiting of the CGR Ground Leases).

Propco and Holdco 2 are required to maintain the appointment of an independent director to their respective
boards through the term of the CGR Financing.

As is common in financings of this nature, certain undertakings and covenants of the CGR Financing require
Propco to procure that the transaction obligors take or refrain from taking certain actions. Propco does not have any
contractual, corporate or other legal ability to control the actions of the other transaction obligors and so their actions
or inactions could cause a breach without Propco having any recourse or ability to prevent it. By way of mitigation,
all of the transaction obligors are also controlled by the wider Asda group. The transaction obligors under the CGR
Financing are (as well as Propco), Asda Holdco 2 Limited, Asda Group Limited and (for so long as it is an affiliate of
Propco) Bellis Acquisition Company 3 Limited. Asda Group Limited and Bellis Acquisition Company 3 Limited are
not considered as transaction obligors in all instances, but there are nonetheless situations where Propco has
procurement obligations in their regard.

**_Trigger Event_**

On June 30 in each calendar year beginning on June 30, 2029, certain trigger events may require Propco to
deposit cash (from subordinated debt, equity injection or free cash in the general account) as additional collateral for
the CGR Financing or substitute applicable Affected Portfolio Stores (as defined below). The trigger events are: (i)
fixed charge cover ratio of less than 2.5x; (ii) the CGR Notes are rated BBB+ or lower; (iii) portfolio gearing is greater
than 30%; (iv) any stores has an average historical sales density that is in the lowers 10% of average historical sales
densities of all superstores (being any store operated by Asda Group Limited or any of its subsidiaries) which has a
net sales area of 15,000 square feet or more (“Superstores”) (“Affected Portfolio Stores”); (v) loan to value (vacant
possession) is greater than 65%; and (vi) no more than seven Affected Portfolio Stores have been substituted out.

The amount of cash required to be deposited depends on the percentage of stores operated on CGR Properties
(“Portfolio Stores”) that are Affected Portfolio Stores. It ranges from (if the Affected Portfolio Stores represent less
than 15% of such rent for all Portfolio Stores) 12 months’ of rent for all Affected Portfolio Stores for the year to June
30 (“Allocated Rent”) to double the Allocated Rent (if Affected Portfolio Stores represent 50% or more of portfolio
Allocated Rent).

268


-----

If Propco opts to substitute, it has 80 business days to do so. Otherwise, Propco has 90 business days to
deposit the cash or deliver an acceptable letter of credit.

Such cash call collateral will be released to Propco’s general account if (i) any Portfolio Store is no longer in
the lowest 15% of all average historical sales densities of all Superstores and (ii) there are no other Affected Portfolio
Stores, (or if a letter of credit has been delivered, it will be returned). The cash collateral will also be released (or the
letter of credit returned) if: (a) the relevant CGR Property is substituted out; or (b) vacant possession loan to value is
less than 65%.

**_Events of Default under the CGR Financing_**

The CGR Financing is subject to market standard events of default, subject in some cases to grace periods,
materiality qualifiers and other negotiated qualifiers in favour of Propco, certain of which are described in more detail
below. There are events of default in respect of amongst other things certain breaches of the finance documents,
misrepresentation and insolvency. The events of default triggered by compulsory purchase or major damage are
subject to the ability to substitute the effective CGR Property and therefore avoid an event of default occurring.

Certain events of default can be triggered by circumstances relating to transaction obligors under the CGR
Financing (see “—Representations and Undertakings under the CGR Financing”). It is an event of default under the
CGR Financing if ASDA Group Limited or any of its subsidiaries fails to comply with its obligations under the CGR
Financing tax deed of covenant or breaches any representation and/or warranty set out therein. Market standard events
of default are also included for (1) non-compliance of any transaction obligor with any provisions of the Finance
Documents; (2) misrepresentation by a transaction obligor; (3) cross default of any financial indebtedness of a
transaction obligor; (4) insolvency (but not of Bellis Acquisition Company 3 Limited); (5) insolvency proceedings
(but not of Bellis Acquisition Company 3 Limited), (6) creditor’s process (but not of Bellis Acquisition Company 3
Limited); (7) cessation of business (but not of Asda Group Limited or Bellis Acquisition Company 3 Limited); (8)
unlawfulness and invalidity; and (9) repudiation and rescission of agreements.

Events of default are included for the insolvency of the Tenant under the CGR Ground Leases, and for
persistent non-payment under or material breach of the CGR Ground Leases. In the case of the latter, such an event
of default will not arise unless a notice of intended forfeiture under s.146 Law of Property Act 1925 (or an irritancy
warning notice in respect of CGR Properties in Scotland) has been served on the Tenant and the Tenant has not
complied with such notice, and Propco has not substituted the affected CGR Property.

It is an event of default if a judgment of a court, arbitral body or agency which is reasonably likely to have a
material adverse effect is issued against Propco, Holdco 2 or the Tenant under the CGR Ground Leases.

It is an event of default if at any time Propco does not maintain the Expenses Reserve Amount. This event of
default is subject to a five business day grace period if there is a shortage of funds available in the rent account to top
up the reserve, but all amounts under the CGR Ground Leases have been paid in full.

It is an event of default if the CGR Notes are no longer rated and such failure causes the CGR Financing
Lender to cease to be a “note-issuing company” within the meaning of Regulation 5 Taxation of Securitisation
Company Regulation 2006 (SI 2006/3296). It is also an event of default if any of the CGR Notes are not rated, subject
to a carve-out where Propco is in compliance with its obligations under the CGR Financing that relate to maintaining
the rating, and a replacement rating is obtained within 90 days. No event of default arises in the event of a deterioration
in the rating of the CGR Notes.

**_Substitution mechanics under the CGR Financing_**

Propco can elect to substitute a CGR Property rather than applying capital proceeds relating to that CGR
Property in prepayment of the loans, which attracts a make whole payment.

Propco can request to substitute a CGR Property for another property at any time, subject to the satisfaction
of certain conditions including the provision of certain documentary conditions precedent. Any costs associated with
the substitution process itself and any increase in the budget resulting from the substitution must be funded in advance
into the bank accounts structure from subordinated debt or an equity injection.

269


-----

Propco can request to remove a CGR Property from the transaction perimeter for cash (in an amount equal
to the portion of the loans that corresponds to the proportion the vacant possession value of the outgoing CGR Property
bears to the overall vacant possession value of all CGR Properties, plus a make-whole amount that would apply on
the application of such amount in prepayment of the CGR Financing), subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions.
Following such removal, Propco has the ability to bring a new property into the structure within six months (subject
to satisfaction of certain documentary conditions precedent), in which case the cash is released to Propco. If no new
property is substituted in with six months, the cash is swept in prepayment of the loans and payment of the associated
make-whole.

**_Release of CGR Properties on redemption of CGR Notes_**

At any time following redemption of the Class A CGR Notes, or within six months of a mandatory
prepayment of the CGR Financing due to a redemption of the CGR Notes for taxation, illegality, change of control or
recharacterisation of the CGR Financing as a securitisation for the purposes of relevant EU Securitisation Regulation
Rules and UK Securitisation Regulation Rules, Propco may request the release of certain CGR Properties from the
CGR Financing Transaction. Any costs associated with the release process itself and any increase in the budget
resulting from the release must be funded in advance into the bank accounts structure from subordinated debt or an
equity injection. The release of the relevant CGR Properties is subject to the satisfaction of certain conditions,
including the provision of certain documentary conditions precedent.

**_Tax deed of covenant_**

The CGR Financing Lender, Propco and Asda Group Limited have entered into a tax deed of covenant for
the purposes of managing certain group level tax compliance obligations. The tax deed of covenant provides for a
framework to manage, among other things, the surrender of group relief in and out of Propco, the corporate interest
restriction position for Propco as a member of the wider Asda group, the application of transfer pricing between Propco

270


-----

and other members of the wider Asda Group and the accounting consolidation of the CGR Financing Lender. The
purpose of such provisions is to ensure that the tax profile of Propco is in line with the financial model assumptions.

In addition to the management of certain group level tax compliance obligations, the tax deed of covenant
contains a tax indemnity given by Asda Group Limited to Propco to cover the imposition of unexpected tax liabilities
arising in connection with the Asda group. For example, the tax deed of covenant contains an indemnity covering the
imposition of any secondary liability taxes or the imposition of any de-grouping charge. The purpose of such tax
indemnities is to ensure that there are no unexpected liabilities which would impact the tax profile of Propco and cause
deviations from the financial model.

**_Regulatory indemnity_**

Asda Group Limited has provided an indemnity in favour of the CGR Financing Lender for any increased
costs it incurs itself, and for any liability for increased costs incurred by noteholders in each case in the event the
transaction is recharacterised as a securitisation under UK Securitisation Regulation Rules or EU Securitisation
Regulation Rules. In addition, Asda Group Limited undertakes to take such actions as are within its control to comply
with UK Securitisation Regulation Rules and EU Securitisation Regulation Rules, and to procure that Propco and any
relevant affiliate does likewise.

**_Certain definitions_**

“EU Securitisation Regulation Rules” means Regulation (EU) 2017/2402 of the European Parliament and
of the Council of 12 December 2017 laying down a general framework for securitisation and creating a specific
framework for simple, transparent and standardised securitisation, and (i) all regulatory technical standards and
implementing technical standards made pursuant thereto or otherwise applicable in relation thereto; (ii) all official
guidance published, or otherwise applicable, in relation thereto; and (iii) all related national implementing measures,
all, except as otherwise expressly stated, as amended, varied, substituted, replaced or superseded from time to time.

“UK Securitisation Regulation Rules” means Regulation (EU) 2017/2402 as it forms part of the domestic
law of the United Kingdom by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018, as amended by the Securitisation
(Amendment) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019 and (i) all technical standards made pursuant thereto or otherwise
applicable in relation thereto, and (ii) all official binding guidance published, or otherwise applicable, in relation
thereto, all, except as otherwise expressly stated, as further amended, varied or substituted from time to time.

**_CGR Ground Lease Terms_**

The CGR Ground Leases were originally entered into between McLagan Investments Limited and Asda
Stores Limited, however, the reversionary interest in each CGR Ground Lease was transferred to Asda Propco Limited
shortly after the CGR Ground Leases were entered into.

_Scotland_

A kilted form of the CGR Ground Leases for the stores in Scotland follows the same format as the CGR
Ground Leases with references to equivalent legislation (where relevant) applicable to property in Scotland.

_Term_

The initial term of the CGR Ground Leases is for a term of years commencing on December 12, 2023 to and
including December 11, 2122.

_Rent_

The CGR Ground Leases each reserve a different rent payable by the Tenant, payable in equal instalments
on the first day of each calendar month. The rent is subject to an annual review on December 1 in each year of the
term of the CGR Ground Leases which is, linked to the percentage change in the Consumer Price Index for the period
from the immediately preceding rent review date to the current rent review date subject to a cap of 4% and a collar of
0%. Interest is payable at 3% per annum above the Barclays base rate on any sums (including but not limited to rent)
not paid by the tenant on the date they are due. The Tenant is also required to pay all outgoings (including but not

271


-----

limited to business rates, taxes, gas and electricity) and landlord fees. For the period of December 12, 2023 to
November 30, 2024, the aggregate rent payable under the CGR Ground Leases is £23,173,323 (and will increase
slightly following the substitution of certain CGR Properties, which is anticipated to take place on or about April 30,
2024).

_Landlord and Tenant Act 1954_

The CGR Ground Leases in England & Wales benefit from a Tenant statutory right of renewal pursuant to
the provisions of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 (not applicable to the CGR Ground Leases of the Scottish assets).
The Tenant has a right to renew the CGR Ground Leases in England & Wales at the end of the term, subject to some
limited grounds of opposition available to the landlord pursuant to the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954.

_Guarantor_

There is no guarantor party to the CGR Ground Leases in respect of the Tenant’s obligations.

_Use_

The Tenant may only use the CGR Ground Leases as (1) retail stores within Class E of the Town and Country
Planning (Use Classes) Order 1987 and as ancillary to such use; and (2) any other use (other than specifically excluded
uses, including but not limited to manufacturing of tobacco products or weapons, any illegal or immoral purposes, or
residential use) where the Tenant has demonstrated to the reasonable satisfaction of the landlord that such use would
not materially adversely affect the landlord’s interest. The Tenant may also permit undertenants to use a part of the
premises for any use within Class E or Class F which is commonly found in supermarkets from time to time (other
than the same specifically excluded uses as above).

_Maintenance, Alterations and Expansion_

The Tenant, at its sole expense, is to keep and maintain the relevant CGR Property demised under the CGR
Ground Leases in good and substantial repair and condition. The Tenant must commission regular fire safety risk
assessments no less than every four (4) years and implement any recommendations from such reports. The Tenant
must, following service of any notice by the landlord (in respect of the Tenant’s maintenance, alterations and repair
obligations under the CGR Ground Leases) or public authority, commence any repairs to the relevant CGR Property
required by that notice within a reasonable period. If the Tenant does not comply with such notice (save for in respect
of minor repairs) and continues to fail to comply twenty (20) working days after service of a further notice by the
landlord then the landlord (upon giving the Tenant 14 days’ notice) may enter the relevant CGR Property to carry out
the repairs. The costs incurred by the landlord in carrying out such repairs are to be borne by the Tenant. The Tenant
must indemnify the landlord in respect of injury or death to any person or damage to property arising from the state
of repair and condition of the premises arising from any act, default or negligence of the Tenant in breach of the lease.

The Tenant may carry out all alterations, including major alterations (those being demolition of structures or
any structural additions to or creation of any new buildings the net effect of which either (i) increases the gross external
area and/or the gross internal area of the buildings by more than 50%; (ii) decreases the gross external area and/or the
gross internal area of the buildings by more than 50% or (iii) would involve the demolition of more than 50% of the
gross external area and/or the gross internal area of the buildings) if the Tenant (i) provides the landlord with at least
20 working days’ notice of the proposed alterations; (ii) obtains any required planning authority; (iii) carries out the
works in a good and workmanlike manner and in compliance with permissions and applicable statute; (iv) keeps and
provides access to the landlord to CDM regulation records and drawings of alterations; and (v) in the case of major
alterations, prior to commencement, demonstrates to the reasonable satisfaction of the landlord that such major
alterations would not materially adversely affect the landlord’s interest in the relevant CGR Property and thereafter
permits the landlord to inspect progress of the works. The Tenant may not carry out any alterations which will
adversely affecting any asset rating, EPC rating or environmental performance of the relevant CGR Property or
materially adversely affect the Landlord’s interest in the relevant CGR Property.

-----

_Yield Up_

The Tenant is required to return the CGR Properties at the expiry of the term (1) with all additions and
improvements to the premises and all fixtures and fittings in the premises, other than the Tenant’s fixtures and fittings
which the Tenant shall be entitled to remove; and (2) free of any third party occupation or third party occupational
rights. The Tenant is not required to demolish or remove any buildings or alterations carried out in accordance with
the terms of the relevant CGR Ground Lease, nor remove any plant, machinery, lifts, flooring, etc.

_Assignment_

The CGR Ground Leases do not permit the Tenant to assign the CGR Ground Leases.

_Subletting_

The CGR Ground Leases contain broad subletting rights in favour of the Tenant. The Tenant may underlet
the whole or part of the CGR Properties (other than to an individual, company or entity that (i) manufacture tobacco
products; (ii) derives 25% or more of its revenue from the wholesale distribution of tobacco products and/or (iii)
derives 25% or more of its revenue from the retail sale of tobacco products) ((i) to (iii) inclusive being “Excluded
**Occupiers”) without landlord consent provided that: (a) any underletting is not granted for a premium; (b) any**
underletting must expire before expiry of the CGR Ground Leases; (c) any underletting is consistent with normal
market practice, including as to incentives, inducements, tenant covenants and rent review; (d) any underletting must
include covenants which are not inconsistent with or impair due performance and observance of the tenant covenants
in the CGR Ground Leases; (e) any underletting includes provisions as to forfeiture for non-payment of rent, breach
of covenant and insolvency; (f) any underletting of part must not permit the undertenant to create further underleases
of part but may allow further underleases of whole (subject to obtaining the landlord’s consent, not to be unreasonably
withheld or delayed), so long as such underlease is not to an Excluded Occupier and otherwise complies with the
underletting requirements in the CGR Ground Leases; (g) any underletting of the whole of the relevant CGR Property
or store must (i) be for a term which does not exceed 25 years; (ii) not benefit from the statutory right of renewal
pursuant to the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 (not applicable for CGR Properties in Scotland) and (iii) be for a rent
which is the market rent reasonably obtainable at the time of the grant of the underlease and contains provisions for
the review of rent consistent with market practice at the time of the grant of the underlease; (h) if any underletting is
to a tenant group company or affiliate of the tenant then the underletting must (i) not benefit from the statutory right
of renewal pursuant to the Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 (not applicable for CGR Properties in Scotland); (ii) contain
a break right in favour of the landlord of the underlease, exercisable if a CGR Ground Lease is terminated or otherwise
comes to an end and at the time the break right arises the tenant of the underlease is a group company or affiliate of
the Tenant of the CGR Ground Lease; (i) any underletting must not have a material adverse effect on the value of the
landlord’s interest in the relevant CGR Property; (j) any underletting must contain the same rights reserved to the
landlord in the relevant CGR Ground Lease; (k) the Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease must take reasonable steps
to remedy any underlessee’s breach of terms of the CGR Ground Lease if such breach has the potential to materially
adversely affect the landlord’s interest in the premises; (l) the Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease shall take
reasonable steps to enforce the performance and observance of the covenants by the undertenant contained in any
underlease; (m) the Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease shall ensure that the rent payable under any underlease shall
not be reduced or paid more than one quarter in advance and (n) the Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease shall ensure
that the rent under any underlease is reviewed in accordance with the terms of the underlease.

In respect of any underlease of the whole of the relevant premises or store, the Tenant under the CGR Ground
Lease must not vary or waive the terms without the CGR Ground Lease landlord’s consent (such consent not to be
unreasonably withheld or delayed) or where such variation results in the terms of the underlease being inconsistent
with the assignment and subletting provisions contained in the CGR Ground Lease or breaching the conditions for
underleases.

If a tenant under any underlease of the relevant CGR Property becomes a group company of the tenant, or if
a Tenant under an underlease of whole or any part of the relevant store becomes an affiliate of the Tenant under the
CGR Ground Lease, within 12 months, the relevant underlease must be varied to contain a landlord break right
permitting the landlord under the underlease to terminate the underlease if (i) the CGR Ground Lease is terminated or
otherwise comes to an end in any way and (ii) at the time that the break right arises the tenant of such underlease is a
group company or affiliate of the Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease.

-----

If a tenant under an underlease of part of the relevant CGR Property that is not located within the relevant
stores becomes an affiliate of the Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease, on and from such date the Tenant under the
CGR Ground Lease must use reasonable endeavours to ensure that the relevant underlease is varied to include a

_Sharing Occupation_

The Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease may permit a group company (so long as such group company is
not an Excluded Occupier) to share occupation provided that no relationship of landlord and tenant is created and such
occupation ceases as soon as the companies cease to be group companies or, if earlier, the date on which the CGR
Ground Lease expires or otherwise comes to an end.

The Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease may share occupation of part of the relevant premises with a
concessionaire, franchisee or licensee (so long as such concessionaire, franchisee or licensee is not an Excluded
Occupier) provided no relationship of landlord and tenant is created.

_Charging_

The Tenant under the CGR Ground Lease may not charge part of the relevant CGR Property. The Tenant
under the CGR Ground Lease may charge the whole of the relevant CGR Property provided that prior to such charging
the chargee has been supplied with full copies of any documents made supplemental or collateral to the CGR Ground
Lease and the Tenant shall use reasonable endeavours to procure that an acknowledgement of that is documented in
the charging document.

_Events of Default_

The CGR Ground Leases contain customary event of default and forfeiture provisions. The landlord may reenter and forfeit the CGR Ground Lease if (i) the whole or any part of the rent or any other sums due under the CGR
Ground Lease remain unpaid more than 60 days after the due date for payment or (ii) the Tenant materially fails to
perform or observe any of the Tenant’s material covenants in the CGR Ground Lease and fails to remedy the breach
within a reasonable period of time (the landlord giving the Tenant written notice of the aforesaid breach together with
details of anything necessary to be in done in order to remedy the aforesaid breach) or (iii) if (A) the Tenant is a
company or a limited partnership: (i) a meeting of the Tenant’s creditors or any of them is summoned under Part I of
the Insolvency Act 1986 and/or (ii) the Tenant enters into a compromise, scheme or arrangement or restructuring
under Part 26 or Part 26A of the Companies Act 2006 or (B) if the Tenant is a partnership, it is subject to an event
similar to any listed in (A) (together with (A), a “Credit Event”) and as a consequence of any such Credit Event there
is a reduction in the rent paid or payable by the Tenant under a CGR Ground Lease (including any changes to the rent
after any rent review as contemplated by the CGR Ground Lease)– this event of default was added by way of a deed
of variation (which is not registered at HM Land Registry) dated December 20, 2023 to all of the CGR Ground Leases.

Where the Tenant has charged its interest in the CGR Ground Lease to a mortgagee and the landlord has
notice of such charge, before commencing any forfeiture proceedings in relation to the CGR Ground Lease or
exercising any right of re-entry the landlord shall give notice of the breach and details of anything necessary to be
done in order to remedy the aforesaid breach to the mortgagee and if the mortgagee confirms in writing to the landlord
within fourteen (14) days of the date of the notice that it wishes to remedy the breach, allow the mortgagee (i) in
respect of non-payment of rent or other sums due under the CGR Ground Lease, thirty (30) days; and (ii) in respect
of a breach of any condition or Tenant covenant in the CGR Ground Lease, sixty (60) days or such longer period as
be reasonable in view of the nature of the breach, to complete the remedial actions following the service of such notice.

_Insurance_

The Tenant shall insure and keep insured the relevant premises against damage or destruction by insured
risks (such risks include fire, lightning, explosion, earthquake, landslip, heave, subsidence, riot, damage caused by
terrorism, civil commotion, aircraft, aerial devices, storm, flood, water, bursting and overflowing of water tanks,
apparatus or pipes, theft, impact by vehicles, malicious damage and third party liability and any other risks reasonably

274


-----

required by the landlord or the Tenant) and such insurance shall cover the relevant premises (excluding Tenant’s
fixtures and fittings) for full reinstatement cost, as well as cover third party liability and public liability at the relevant
premises and shall comply with the obligations of the landlord (in its capacity as borrower) under the Facility
Agreement. If the Tenant does not maintain insurance pursuant to the terms of the CGR Ground Lease, the landlord
may effect the insurance (at the Tenant’s expense).

_Damage by Insured or Uninsured Risks_

The Tenant is obliged to reinstate the relevant CGR Property if the relevant CGR Property is damaged or
destroyed by an insured or uninsured risk and the Tenant must make up any shortfall of costs out of its own resources
where no or insufficient insurance monies are available. The Tenant shall procure deeds of collateral warranty from
any contractors or sub-contractors involved in completing the reinstatement works, such deeds of collateral warranty
being for the benefit of the landlord and any funder. If it is not possible for the Tenant to reinstate the relevant CGR
Property due to reasons beyond the reasonable control of the Tenant, then the Tenant shall only be obliged to keep the
relevant CGR Property in a safe condition and in compliance with any statutory requirements and shall direct the
insurer to pay to the landlord the proportion of insurance proceeds which would have been applied towards
reinstatement. At all times while the CGR Financing is subsisting, any insurance proceeds received by the Tenant or
landlord which relate to reinstatement shall be dealt with as required under the Ground Rent Transaction Facility
Agreement.

_Other Material Provisions_

There are extensive obligations on the Tenant in relation to compliance with environmental laws, providing
data to the landlord in relation to environmental performance, and taking any required remedial action at the end of
the term to return the relevant CGR Property in a standard required under environmental law. The landlord is not liable
for any existing contamination at the CGR Properties.

The Tenant provides an indemnity to the landlord against all loss arising from (i) the breach of any Tenant
covenant or obligation in the relevant CGR Ground Lease or any other agreement affecting the relevant CGR Property
(entered into by the Tenant or to which the Tenant consents); and (ii) any breach by the landlord of the superior lease
that is caused by an act or default by the Tenant.

There are no rent cessation provisions in the event of (among other causes) any damage or destruction to the
CGR Properties, any interference with the use of the CGR Properties, any default by the landlord under the CGR
Ground Leases, or any other cause whatsoever. The Tenant shall not terminate the CGR Ground Leases and waives
any right to reduce any rent or other sums payable under the CGR Ground Leases.

The Tenant acknowledges that the landlord may charge the CGR Ground Leases and that no amendment or
waiver of any provision in the CGR Ground Leases shall have effect without the mortgagee’s prior written consent.

**_CGR Properties – Site-specific provisions_**

The Shaw CGR Ground Lease includes an additional obligation on the Tenant to investigate the relevant
property to determine the extent of any Japanese knotweed present at the premises and to take action at its own cost
as necessary to treat or remove such Japanese knotweed.

(i) Clayton; (ii) Keighley; (iii) Lancaster; (iv) Pilsworth; (v) Radcliffe and (vi) St Leonards-on-Sea: these
CGR Ground Leases contain various carve outs in the provisions relating to underletting or renewal of an existing
occupational lease (which is defined by reference to the Ground Rent Transaction Facility Agreement).

(i) Chorley; (ii) Gateshead; (iii) Huddersfield; (iv) Newark and (v) Shaw: the reversionary interests in these
CGR Properties are leasehold properties therefore the CGR Ground Leases for these CGR Properties include an
obligation on the Tenant to observe and comply with the tenant obligations under the terms of the relevant headlease
and obtain superior landlord consents where necessary under the terms of the relevant headlease insofar as they relate
to the relevant store.

as the CGR Ground Leases for the stores in England & Wales, with the following changes:

o Statutory references have been amended to applicable Scottish law. In particular, references to the
Landlord and Tenant Act 1954 have been removed as the act is not applicable in Scotland, meaning
that the tenant has no statutory right to renew.
o The mortgagee protection rights in relation to forfeiture of the lease are slightly different to reflect
applicable Scottish law.
o All references to superior leases are removed throughout the CGR Ground Leases in Scotland,
because there are no superior leases.
o The alteration provisions are amended to remove the landlord’s step in rights and to expressly
confirm that the Tenant’s obligations apply regardless of the cause of damage or destruction, even
if the cause is a latent or inherent defect again, to reflect applicable Scottish law.
o The underletting provisions are amended to remove the requirement for a landlord break right in the
event of any underleases of the whole of the premises or of the whole of the store to group or
affiliate companies.

Notes may be transferred or exchanged, in whole or in part, in minimum denominations of £100,000 in principal
amount and integral multiples of £1,000 in excess thereof. In connection with any such transfer or exchange, the
Senior Secured Notes Indenture will require the transferring or exchanging holder to, among other things, furnish
appropriate endorsements and transfer documents, to furnish information regarding the account of the transferee at
Euroclear or Clearstream, where appropriate, to furnish certain certificates and opinions, and to pay any Taxes in
connection with such transfer or exchange. Any such transfer or exchange will be made without charge to the holder,
other than any Taxes payable in connection with such transfer.

Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Registrar and the Transfer Agent are not required to register the transfer
or exchange of any Definitive Registered Notes:

(1) for a period of 15 days prior to any date fixed for the redemption of Senior Secured Notes;

(2) for a period of 15 days immediately prior to the date fixed for selection of Senior Secured Notes to
be redeemed in part;

(3) for a period of 15 days prior to the record date with respect to any interest payment date (which will
be 15 days prior to the relevant interest date for Senior Secured Notes held in definitive registered
form); or

(4) which the holder has tendered (and not withdrawn) for repurchase in connection with a Change of
Control Offer or an Asset Disposition Offer.

The Senior Secured Notes Issuer, the Trustee, the Paying Agent, the Transfer Agent and the Registrar will
be entitled to treat the Holders of Senior Secured Notes as the owners thereof for all purposes.

**Security**

**_General_**

On the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Secured Notes will be secured by
first-priority security interests over (a) the issued share capital of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer (the “Issuer Share
**Collateral”), (b) any material intercompany receivables owing to the Senior Notes Issuer by the Senior Secured Notes**
Issuer, (c) the material intra-group receivables owing to the Senior Secured Notes Issuer by other member of the
Group, (d) the material bank accounts located in England and Wales of the Senior Secured Notes Issuer, and (e) a
floating charge over all or substantially all of the assets (other than customarily excluded assets) of the Senior Secured
Notes Issuer, as and when created (collectively, the “Closing Date Collateral”). Within 30 days of the Issue Date,
subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Senior Secured Notes will be further secured by first-priority interests
(i) over each Guarantor’s (a) material bank accounts, (b) the issued share capital of such Guarantors, (c) material
intercompany receivables owned to such Guarantors by other member of the Group, (d) a floating charge over all or
substantially all of the assets (other than customarily excluded assets) of each of the Guarantors and (ii) over (a) the
shares held in Euro Garages (Jersey) Limited by Project America Bidco Limited and (b) any material receivables owed
to it by Euro Garages (Jersey) Limited or its Subsidiaries from time to time, in each case, with respect to (ii) on a third
party limited recourse basis (the “Post-Closing Non-Real Estate Collateral”).

The Senior Secured Notes will be further secured within 180 days of the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed
Security Principles, by security interests granted on a first-priority basis over each Guarantor’s Material Real Property
(the “Post-Closing Real Estate Collateral”, and, together with the Post-Closing Non-Real Estate Collateral, the
“Post-Closing Collateral” and, together with the Closing Date Collateral, the “Collateral”).

The Senior Secured Notes Issuer shall take such necessary actions and shall cause its Restricted Subsidiaries
to take such necessary actions so that, to the extent legally possible and subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the
Post-Closing Non-Real Estate Collateral shall be confirmed no later than the date that is 30 days after the Issue Date
and the Post-Closing Real Estate Collateral no later than the date that is 180 days after the Issue Date.

Subject to certain conditions, including compliance with the covenants described under “—Certain
_Covenants—Impairment of Security Interest” and “—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Liens,” the Senior Secured_
Notes Issuer and its Restricted Subsidiaries will be permitted to grant security over the Collateral in connection with

Secured Notes issued by the Senior Secured Notes Issuer as permitted under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture and
the Intercreditor Agreement. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our Capital Structure, Our Financing and Our
_Indebtedness.”_

Any other security interests that may in the future be granted to secure obligations under the Senior Secured
Notes, any Notes Guarantees and the Senior Secured Notes Indenture would also constitute “Collateral.” All Collateral
will be subject to the operation of the Agreed Security Principles and any Permitted Collateral Liens.

As described above, all of the Collateral also secures the liabilities under the Senior Credit Facilities,

**_Priority_**

The relative priority with regard to the security interests in the Collateral that are created by the Security
Documents (the “Security Interests”) as between (a) the lenders under the Senior Facilities Agreement, (b) the
Trustee, the Security Agent and the Holders of the Senior Secured Notes under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture,
(c) the counterparties under certain Hedging Obligations, (d) the trustee, the security agent and the holders of the
Existing Alaska Notes under the Existing Alaska Indenture, (e) the trustee, the security agent and the holders of the
Existing Connecticut Notes under the Existing Connecticut Indenture and (f) the trustee, the security agent and the
holders of the Existing Senior Notes under the Existing Senior Notes Indenture, respectively, is established by the
terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Existing Senior Secured Notes
Indentures, the Security Documents and the Additional Intercreditor Agreements (if any). Such documents provide,
among other things, that under certain circumstances, including a repayment in full of the amounts outstanding under
term facilities under the Senior Facilities Agreement, the Revolving Credit Facility, the New Revolving Facility,
certain Hedging Obligations and certain other Indebtedness permitted to be secured on a super priority basis may be
re-designated as “super senior” obligations under the Intercreditor Agreement, and following such re-designation,
Holders will only receive proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral after the obligations under such other
Indebtedness have been paid in full. See “Description of Certain Financing Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement”
and “—Certain Definitions—Permitted Collateral Liens.” In addition, pursuant to the Intercreditor Agreement or
Additional Intercreditor Agreements (if any) entered into after the Issue Date, the Collateral may be pledged to secure
other Indebtedness. See “—Release of Liens,” “—Certain Covenants—Impairment of Security Interest” and “—
_Certain Definitions—Permitted Collateral Liens.”_

In addition, the Shared Security also secures the Existing Senior Notes on a second-priority basis.

Collateral for the Senior Secured Notes may be granted by means of supplemental debentures to, and
confirmation agreements of, existing Security Documents or by means of further layers of Security Documents. As
such, in certain circumstances, the Collateral may be second-ranking and only be deemed and treated as security
interests ranking pari passu with the security interests securing the Senior Credit Facilities and the Existing Senior
Secured Notes pursuant to the application of the provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement. If the Intercreditor
Agreement or the relevant provisions thereof were avoided or held to be unenforceable for any reason, holders of the
Senior Secured Notes would not benefit from such first-priority treatment and be subordinated, with respect to such
security interests, to senior security interests over the same Collateral securing the Senior Credit Facilities and the
Existing Senior Secured Notes. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes, the Notes Guarantees
_and the Collateral—The rights of holders of the Senior Secured Notes in some of the Collateral may be adversely_
_affected by such security interests being second-ranking.”_

**Agreed Security Principles**

The Agreed Security Principles apply to the granting of Notes Guarantees and security in favour of
obligations under the Senior Secured Notes and are substantially similar to the agreed security principles appended to
the Senior Facilities Agreement. The Agreed Security Principles include restrictions on the granting of Notes
Guarantees and security where, among other things, such grant would be restricted by general statutory or other legal
limitations or requirements, financial assistance rules, corporate benefit rules, fraudulent preference rules, “thin
capitalisation” rules, capital maintenance rules, retention of title claims and similar matters, where the time and cost
of granting the guarantee or security would be disproportionate to the benefit accruing to the Holders or where security
would be granted over the Capital Stock, property or other assets, or liabilities of a member of the Regulated Group.

In this “Agreed Security Principles” section only, any reference to “Acquired Person **or** **Asset,” “Agent,”**
“Debtor,” “Finance Document,” “Secured Debt Document,” or “Secured Parties” is a reference to that term as
defined in the Intercreditor Agreement as in effect on the Issue Date. See “Description of Certain Financing
_Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement.”_

**_General Principles_**

The guarantees and security required to be provided under the Secured Debt Documents will be given in
accordance with the security principles set out in these Agreed Security Principles. The description that follows
identifies the Agreed Security Principles and addresses the manner in which the Agreed Security Principles will impact
on and determine the extent and terms of the guarantees, including the Notes Guarantees, and security proposed to be
provided under or pursuant to any Secured Debt Document, including the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Senior
Secured Notes and the Security Documents.

(a) The Agreed Security Principles embody the recognition by all parties that there may be certain legal
and practical difficulties in obtaining effective or commercially reasonable Notes Guarantees and/or
security from all relevant members of the Group in each jurisdiction in which it has been agreed that
Notes Guarantees and security will be granted by those members. In particular:

(i) general legal and statutory limitations, regulatory restrictions, financial assistance,
anti-trust and other competition authority restrictions, corporate benefit, fraudulent
preference, equitable subordination, “transfer pricing,” “thin capitalisation,” “earnings
stripping,” “controlled foreign corporation” and other tax restrictions, “exchange control
restrictions,” “capital maintenance” rules and “liquidity impairment” rules, tax restrictions,
retention of title claims, employee consultation or approval requirements and similar
principles may limit the ability of a member of the Group to provide a Notes Guarantee or
security or may require that the Notes Guarantee or security be limited as to amount or
otherwise and, if so, the Notes Guarantee or security will be limited accordingly, provided
that to the extent requested by the Security Agent before signing any applicable security or
accession document, the relevant member of the Group shall use reasonable endeavours
(but without incurring material cost and without adverse impact on relationships with third
parties) to overcome any such obstacle or otherwise such Notes Guarantee or Security
Document shall be subject to such limit;

in respect of the security, the extent of its perfection and/or registration) is the applicable
time and cost (including adverse effects on taxes, interest deductibility, stamp duty,
registration taxes, notarial costs and all applicable legal fees) which will not be
disproportionate to the benefit accruing to the Secured Parties of obtaining such Notes
Guarantee or security;

(iii) members of the Group will not be required to give Notes Guarantees or enter into Security
Documents if they are not wholly owned by another member of the Group or if it is not
within the legal capacity of the relevant members of the Group or if it would conflict with
the fiduciary or statutory duties of their directors or contravene any applicable legal,

member of the Group, provided that, to the extent requested by the Security Agent before
signing any applicable Security Document or accession document, the relevant member of
the Group shall use reasonable endeavours (but without incurring material cost and without
adverse impact on relationships with third parties) to overcome any such obstacle or
otherwise such Notes Guarantee or Security Document shall be subject to such limit;

(iv) Notes Guarantees and security will be limited so that the aggregate of notarial costs and all
registration and like taxes and duties relating to the provision of security will not exceed
an amount to be agreed between the grantor of the security and the Security Agent;

(v) where a class of assets to be secured includes material and immaterial assets, if the cost of
granting security over the immaterial assets is disproportionate to the benefit of such
security, security will be granted over the material assets only;

(vi) it is expressly acknowledged that it may be either impossible or impractical to create
